column10: daryl dixon
A Hideo Kojima Game
IT CHANGED ME. 10/10 MASTERPIECE

[h1]Probably one of the hardest games to successfully market[/h1]
If I didn’t have complete and utter faith in Hideo Kojima, Norman Reedus, and Mads Mikkelsen, I don’t think I would ever have played this game, but give it a chance! One of the best original stories I have ever played if not the best.

[h2]Story[/h2]
I almost want to cry trying to comment on the story Ha ha hah… this is so difficult to sensibly put into words…The world is set after what could be referred to as an extinction event, death now transcends all understanding with people needing to be burnt to prevent further casualties lest they be swallowed by the death stranding which are entities similar in shape to humans now tied to the world through what resembles an umbilical cord pervading the earth, and wherever they are unique weather phenomena called time fall also persists causing rapid time acceleration or aging wherever the rain touches.

The world unequipped to deal with this event found its infrastructure rapidly destroyed and the nations people withdrawn into themselves, cut off from all others. You follow the story of Sam Porter Bridges a man with psychological conditions that he finds best enables him to live by transporting packages when no one else would risk venturing into the now harsh world, and living alone. Despite this his history ties him to a greater fate and destiny than he would like to acknowledge. As Sam comes to grips with this destiny, the player helps to shape the world into one connected through technology now possible due to the new connection with time and death.

Ultimately this story, despite how drastically differently the people of the world perceive it, revolves around death and understanding one self. Help Sam keep on keeping on towards a brighter future for himself and others, and eventually help him keep the bonds with others he so cherishes, by battling the terrain, people lost in their ways, death itself, through blood, sweat…. And ♥♥♥♥.

That is how I would try and summarise the task in playing through the story. I will say this, it really is an interesting story if you give it a chance, and invest yourself in it.

[h2]Level design[/h2]
I almost feel level design is not the right word to use, as it is more like world design. Death stranding almost exclusively occurs outside in an open world environment. The reason for this being Sam’s job and life occurs outside. This being the case the designers developed a variety of terrain for the players to traverse as opposed to simpler level design such as buildings or more structures in a flatter open world with less intricacies focused on the outside than in.

Sam therefore has the challenge of having to move across a world that is entirely uneven and natural, as opposed to manoeuvring the typically unnaturally flat designed worlds like GTAV. As such the physics and mechanics of the world centre mostly around how you traverse in the world to overcome the terrain to get to your destination, and how Sam does this is up to the player and the tools they have on them, or at their disposal. The game has been likened to walking simulator as quite rightly, you are having to manage aspects of life closer to walking in the real world then most other objectives in games you would come across. This however should not be considered a negative, and no less challenging than other platforming games as the management of the items Sam has to bring with him to his destination require pristine treatment as the recipient needs those items. Risk jumping across a crevasse with a 15 metre drop? Well that would probably kill you if you don’t land it first off, and what about the 50 kg’s worth of packages on your back? Maybe take the long way, or use a ladder, or use a rope to get down and out, or jump it using a specially made exoskeleton to enforce your physical capabilities, or maybe try using a bike in rugged or slippery terrain? All comes with risks and rewards and is cleverly thought out. As you get on later in the game you have access to more infrastructure better enabling travel by vehicle, foot, or other means.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
The level of gameplay variety is a bit hard to cover entirely, but assuming you understand the level design, and how it implies careful management of Sam’s body and physical capabilities we can move on past those interactions with the world itself and onto more normal aspects of gameplay with enemies and tools outside the traversal section.

[h3]Enemies[/h3]
So death stranding has two or three main types of enemies, simply put, humans and death stranding entities. Human enemies typically relate to mules and they are motivated by greed of taking things from you, the game means this literally… maybe if you have nothing on you, they do not bother you. Aside from this there are terrorists… which kind want to kill you, so yeah it is all in the name with human characters. A variety of methods exists for both sides with how to deal with your human counter parts, keeping in mind a lethal take down has extreme repercussions by which I mean the death stranding kind of eventually causes an eruption equal to a nuclear crater. So non lethal is typically the way to go. With this being the case the player can choose to knock out, incapacitate, electrocute, or otherwise disable human players to progress through territories under enemy control. Doing so on a wide scale has benefits of allowing npc porters to traverse more safely as well as automated systems to traverse more safely.

The player has access to a variety of tools to effect the engagement, ranging from movement support on the terrain for greater manoeuvrability with your package load… no innuendos please, as well as the weapons themselves, with non-lethal grenades, rope close quarters combat, firearms a variety, bola gun for non lethal, and use of your BB… a baby biological tool that senses death stranding and operates your terrain detector and flashlight… yeah no good way to say that. Stealth is always an option, but your enemies have detection tools and traps too. Keeping in mind what you use incorporates into what you must carry means you must always maintain a well kept inventory to make sure you are not overloading yourself or crippling your ability to reach your end goal.

Touching now on the death stranding, the unique aspect of this game is how you go about defeating death in a way. How you achieve this is ultimately a spoiler in the story, but suffice to say it is all down to Sam. You are able to make some serious weapons that allow you to deal serious damage to these monsters, however it costs resources to make these like everything sometimes you are better off trying to avoid a fight and running.

[h2]Graphics and sound[/h2]
Graphics in the game are important but only so much in allowing you to experience the world in all it offers with its various visual effects made through particle physics, cloth physics, water physics, etc . It is quite obviously a natural beauty game presenting some of the best environments for pictures the gaming world has to offer yet, rivalling Red Dead Redemption and surpassing it in some aspects.

In regards to the sound, it has some very unique and well made folly sounds, with a lot of effort being made to increase the immersion of the player in the world. Keeping in mind that the game has few sections in which music is played, but when it does are often well chosen moments and make for a very touching or emotional scene.

I suppose voice acting and animations deserve a mention, which I will quickly sum up as superb, and is like watching a movie at times. Motion capture is really well implemented.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
A 10/10 game for me and all round experience. Delving into and exploring all the mechanics makes the game, and even just exploring it causally for the sake of exploring is a pleasant experience. At times it does not feel like a game.
NICE GAME
Kojima let loose.

Yes, it's a walking sim. In an ocean of games spanning every genre, from top-notch to outright terrible, this stands as the king of walking sims. The combat can feel a little awkward at times, and the story a bit convoluted, but the game's ability to immerse you in the experience of traversing a post-apocalyptic world all alone is truly magical.

Some argue that it gets better later on, but I disagree. It remains a walking sim through and through. The equipment and weapons acquired later hold little significance to the gameplay. The essence of the game lies in the choice of transport and the story. If you find yourself not enjoying it a few chapters in, chances are you won't enjoy the later parts either.

Personally, I can't seem to get enough of it, even after attaining all the achievements. Keep on keeping on!

To be honest, this is one of the only games that you'll need to break through Chapter 4 in order to see it flourish. I know how it sounds, but if you haven't pumped more than 10hrs past a certain point, you'll miss the real purpose of Death Stranding. In this project you'll find forward pushing technical marvel at a much slower pace that is littered with excellent potential regarding overarching gameplay loop, fidelity and immersion. The uncomfortable isolation is permeated across this game and is quickly rewarded with how much you're sharing this loneliness with other players. Kojima has delivered an experience unlike any other, I promise - just push through.

With all of its Hideo quirks, this game is offering a simple message through wildly imaginative expression that can be lost on some - it makes sense as you progress.

10/10 definitely recommend to decompress from the fast pace mindless shooters we have today.

In a time i was in some desperate need of company this game blessed my soul and accompanied me through some of the most lonely times of my life.I played it twice again and what can i say.Clearly the main issue is Kojima's extreme focus on tiny minute details and they are just not interesting.I adore stories in games and i'm an avid reader but man,first 10 hours of this game is a mess.it just tries to tell you so much about this world before you even get hooked into it and it alienates.

 Though again,if you get past the early game and discover the beauty of just simply walking,delivering packages and exploring yourself and your life and your world whilst doing it this game becomes so much more.there's something stoic about just listening to the ambient sounds of the game,music and slow paced walking.it's a bore for some of it's time allright but in the end it's one of the most beautiful and calming experiences i've had in my life like i used to walk in the old forests at the mountains in my hometown.

 Also even if the game was bad.It still made me discover one of the best music i've ever listened and still do.Low Roar is the main artist that's used in the game and i still listen to it while working to this day.after so much time since playing Death Stranding for the first time..
The games is a bag of mixed emotions. When the music starts playing after a hard journey, the game feel so alive!

If you want to experience your well known offering from Kojima, then this is it. The production quality here is way above top notch and the story couldn't leave you with even more questions, answer some, but also surprise you along the way. Overall, I really enjoyed the game with only two complaints, which I feel a lot of people would agree on. The first complaint is how tedious some of the deliveries are. Yes, I know... the game is all about being a postman, but some were created just to make you eat up time, especially when you want to see the next piece of the story. The second complaint I have and something I really really hope they fix in the sequel is the vehicle traversal. Travelling on either vehicle was more tedious than useful from time to time and it was very frustrating at times. Beyond that, play this game. You'll be happy you did. Just make sure to have some patience along the way.
It deserves more credit than being called just a "walking simulator." The story was beautiful and made me cry a few times. I loved it and can't wait for the next one :)

I have a lot of questions after all that... 
Good game though.

I'm giving a negative review because the negative outweighs the positives in this game, FOR ME.
I do enjoy games that are story rich, like Persona games for example, however, even though I like story rich games, the gameplay has to be the most fun part, because, well, it's a game, not a movie, and to me Death Stranding has everything: story, original world, soundtrack, cinematic cutscenes, everything except... Fun gameplay. 
For about... 15 hours it was engaging because it was new, reaching your destiny while a music starts playing is so captivating, but after you put some hours into it, even after I got my hands on guns and fought my first boss, the gameplay just revealed to be very repetitive, with the delivering being very tiresome, and the world bland, monotonous, to the point that exploring it doesn't bring any excitement.
Another gripe that I have with this game, is that the NPCs love to interrupt gameplay every minute to say things that are either useless or something that's been already explained, for example, an npc explains something you can do in the map screen, then comes Die Hardman and says the exact same thing! Or when there's a text box explaining something, and an NPC calls you to say the exact same thing that was already in the text, this annoyed me too much. My impression is that this game would be an experience where I'd be able to feel how it's like being lonely, and then reconnecting with people, but with the NPCs calling me all the time, I ended up wanting to do the opposite of reconnecting...
To summarize: it wasn't for me because the gameplay it's to repetitive, in a world that's bland and the NPCs annoyed me. I come out of this game wishing it was a movie, or series, and not a game.

I wish I could delete my memory of this game and play it again, it brought myself & my girlfriend to tears at points. From prior reviews when it released I expected a walking simulator with little else to offer & I can safely say it’s one of my top games of all time.
If you’re on the fence, just buy it

Death Stranding is a game. It's not a [i]great[/i] game, but it's not a terrible game either. As a whole, I'd say it falls a step or two below average, even though parts of it shine bright at times.

Slight spoilers below.

The story starts off decently strong with an interesting premise and a few interesting questions to lead you on. However, as the game goes on, these questions are only rarely answered, as you are asked to focus on your main objective - reconnect America. Towards the middle you are served even more questions, and only few answers, and finally, as you reach the climax, with an overabundance of questions, many of these are answered at the same time, sometimes in roundabout ways. This leads to a sort of ridiculous amount of cutscenes and phone calls to tell you all these things, one after another, while letting you play a quick 10-15 minutes of "go to place" gameplay in between. I was left with an impression of messy, badly-paced storytelling that hurried to tie up loose knots before I could notice just how many there are.

Meanwhile, as a sucker for logistics, the gameplay and delivery loop itself was fun, but needed some tempering on the upgrades to really engage. Preparing for a trip and heading out to do it is great, but you quickly unlock a very fast trike, which lets you zoom around for deliveries, with really only BT's being a greater threat to hinder your progress. There's not often anywhere on the map that you'd want to go, that you can't go on a trike, and if you're online, other players taking the same path will even have cleared out smaller obstacles for you, as the combined walking creates desire paths. Personally, choosing to not use some of the tools given proved more satisfying, but also seems like a bit of a misstep on the game's part, for making it a bit too easy, perhaps.

Overall, by the time I was halfway through, I was about ready to focus only on the story missions and be done with it. At three quarters through, I was trying to speedrun my way from cutscene to cutscene. The game ended like 3 times, but just kept going regardless, only prolonging what I thought was the end of the journey.
If you're on the fence because this game was divisive when it came out, just buy it

If you're looking for something outside the box; a game that's addicting but doesn't fall into the same tired genre of the FPS, this is a good choice.  The graphics are hi-res, the world is interesting, and the story line is off the charts bizarre but not ridiculous.  You need to play it for at least 5 hours to really get into it, but once you've made that investment in time, it really starts to grow on you.  I would definitely recommend that you watch a few preview and "tips and tricks" videos for this one, though.  It will help make sense of the off-the-charts story line.

Some really amazing cutscenes and a decently engaging plot bookending some exceedingly dull gameplay.  I was hoping for more stealth action, but ready to settle for the sort of survival/crafting game this looks like its going to be.  I was disappointed on both accounts because its just hiking around with a really big backpack and trying not to fall over.  Most of the game mechanics seem to be centered around making walking around with a backpack less tedious with occasional dips into being a real horror-walking simulator when ghosts (or something, I don't know) attack you.

I hope they make a good movie out of this because that could be really cool, but yeah, the game sucks.

+
The execution and staging are very well done and polished.
The character designs, the cutscenes, the stories, the music.
The delivery-related gameplay is original and has a slow pace.
The freedom.
You unlock new items/abilities throughout your entire playtime.

-
Navigating through the menus can feel repetitive and a bit tedious and managing your cargo (in the menus) is a pain.
The boss fights (I didn't find them good, and I feel they add nothing).
The online elements (for me, they add nothing, and even worse, they detract from the value of the gameplay, the ambiance, and the realism of the world).
You have to set the difficulty to the maximum to truly experience challenges in making deliveries and even then, it's not that difficult.

≠
I disagree with those who claim it improves after a few hours. Frankly, if you didn't enjoy the beginning, I fail to see how you'd suddenly like it later on as the core gameplay is the same (but if you do, I'm happy for you).

I gave it a chance because it was a game outside the box; few games currently dare to try different things. What I can say is that it was simply worth it, very much so.

The game evokes a feeling of loneliness, yet at the same time, of unity. Alone yet simultaneously helping and being helped by others. The storyline is absurd, unpredictable, it captivates the player from start to finish, and features great performances by renowned actors such as Mads Mikkelsen, Norman Reedus, Lea Seydoux, among others. It also boasts a spectacular soundtrack, truly remarkable. And when it comes to gameplay, as mundane as the premise may sound, it's very fun and addictive, with excellent mechanics. Don't draw conclusions from videos, play it.

The technical aspect is a spectacle with incredible graphics; the Decima Engine truly justifies its potential here. Additionally, it's well-optimized; you can buy it without fear as long as your PC meets the requirements.

I highly recommend it for those seeking something different from the norm, those who have the patience to understand the proposal and feel immersed in the game's universe. It's not for everyone; some won't like it (sorry for those people), but it's worth giving it a chance. I simply loved it; it's an experience I'll carry with me for life.

Positive points of the Director's Cut version include the addition of content, but in my opinion, the best part is the support for haptic feedback on the DualSense controller in the PC version. For those who have a DualSense, I highly recommend the upgrade.

(My review of the original edition of DS)

 [h1] I'll Be Waiting For You On The Beach [/h1] 

I can see you scrolling around, watching and reading reviews to see if you are going to buy Death Stranding. You know you want to play it because it's a Kojima game but then again you have seen more than enough reviews saying that it's boring and soulless and the only thing there's to do in this game is walking. Now, after 47hrs I'm here to tell you that nothing can help you and prepare you for this game. If you are having doubts buy it on sale, if you are looking for fast action and quick satisfaction, don't bother.

Death Stranding is a new type of game, a new genre, it's everything that people praise it or accuse it to be. Is it a masterpiece? Sure. Is it boring? At times yes. Do you just walk? Most of the time, yes. Is it full with plot-holes? Absolutely! Annoying? YES! Repetitive? Yup. Is it soulless? Absolutely not! There were times when playing this game, that I felt that I was a better person, a better human. This game made me focus on what's important and if you play and take the story's message at heart you are going to be rewarded. It is my firm belief that Death Stranding is good for the soul.

My personal experience with the game goes like this. I bought it on February 2021 and played it straight for 18hrs and then I dropped it. Life you see. I wanted to return but then I kept thinking that the only thing that I was doing is walking and delivering packages and I was just kinda bored. Of course I was thinking of the AMAZING soundtrack and the PHENOMENAL performances or the trippy story, but I was bored of the main gameplay. I remembered feeling great while playing at first but something was holding me back from resuming my playthrough. Seven months later I was on Spotify listening, when the main theme started playing in my brain having reignited the desire to listen to the soundtrack. Then I installed the game again, resumed playing and after 29hrs I completed it.

After completion, do I understand Death Stranding? I feel that I'm in a good direction but in all fairness I don't think that the game is designed to be understood, but to be felt. Death Stranding is a cure to loneliness, a beckon to the outcasts. Death Stranding for me transcends genre, medium and reviews. It's a work of art plain and simple. That doesn't mean it's beyond criticism, nothing and no one is, but it's not as simple as watching Dunkey's eight minute review or Whitelight's 7hrs review on YouTube and deciding. You just have to take a leap of faith with this game and be thirsty for something new.

Lastly, Hideo Kojima directed the s*** out of this movie. He managed to capture great performances by all of his actors. Every scene with Mads Mikkelsen is eerie, gut-wrenching and heart-warming all in one and this is for sure Norman Reedus' best performance ever. Every scene is well-crafted and created to perfection. The visuals are beyond of this world so much so that you have to see it to believe it!

As with everything new, Death Stranding needs time to find its place in the world. Only time will tell but I'm happy that I finished it because it turned out to be one of the most unique gaming experiences of my life. If nothing else, just play it for BB, for me one of the best companions in gaming.

PS. You see what I did? I wrote "movie" instead of "game". That's a mistake but I decided to keep it because that's what I mean by "transcending mediums".

PPS. I'll be waiting for you on the Beach.

There are already a thousand essays in the reviews that list everything about this game, so I will just keep it short and sweet.

Kojima, as well as the cast of his wonderfully talented actors have poured their souls into this game. It is one of the most beautiful experiences that I have ever witnessed and I am truly happy that I decided to bite the bullet and try it out.

Without trying to spoil anything, I can say that this game is definitely something very personal to Kojima and has been written with more love and passion than any of his other works.

I just have no complaints honestly, the gameplay is solid, it eases you in with a great difficulty curve and always introduces new and exciting obstacles. The mechanics are very consistent and really nice to utilize. 
The vehicles may need a bit more work, but honestly I just liked walking instead.

As for the story, it is everything, its beautiful, touching, emotional, sometimes silly, a few times quite cheesy, then its over complicated, after which its painfully simple, but it is always good.

If you like solitary experiences, environmental art, and a good atmosphere, then please do yourself a favor and try it, but do it with the online functionality. This is one of the only games that just relies on its online functionality in a way that elevates the experience and makes it that much more enjoyable.

Death Stranding is unlike any game out there. It's a thought provoking scifi world that brings fresh ideas and themes to the table, with a gameplay loop that's extremely satisfying and relaxing. This is one of those games where the more you put into it, the more satisfaction you'll receive.

The story gripped me from start to finish. It's hard to comprehend how any individual could come up with this game's setting and scenarios it puts you through, how the world and it's story unravels around you. While there are some moments that I felt the writing could've been improved that's about the extent of my complaints with the game.

The further you get into Death Stranding the more tools are at your disposal. The start of the game can be very clunky and tedious, but it's done so on purpose so that you appreciate and enjoy how far you've come when you reach the later stages of the game. You are constantly rewarded, constantly given feedback about everything you do. Giving you that satisfaction and being shown and told how well of a job you're doing, by both the characters and real players.

The online functionality of this game really took me by surprise regarding my enjoyment of it. I became utterly addicted to creating the roads for the players I shared the same world with, reveling in the amount of Likes players gave me. Something about the melancholic world and tone that harmoniously compliments the online infrastructure of DS. For me at least, it helped me appreciate others, strangers. It helped me feel kindness towards strangers. Similar to the message system of Dark Souls, players can leave messages saying a number of things. Most of what I see are motivational messages left by others to keep pushing forward, it's a unique feeling.

Music and the use of your soundtrack is one of my favorite elements of gaming. If implemented correctly, the right music at the right time can heighten your sense of emotion. Death Stranding understands that completely. Key parts of the story or environment when triggered will start to play a song, mostly from the band Low Roar. Their music fits the world and message of the game so perfectly it almost seems they were created side by side. The original soundtrack is composed beautifully, as expected from masterclass composer Ludvig Forssell who also created MGSV's score.

There are many moments in Death Stranding that filled me with awe and a sense of serenity I never thought existed in gaming. Death Stranding is one of my favorite games ever created, and in my opinion one of the best scifi worlds filled with such rich lore ever created. It left me in tears, and in love with the story that KojiPro has told. Most importantly, it has helped me appreciate and show kindness towards complete strangers in a world where it's far too easy to forget that you're not the only one living in it.

The definitive edition adds a lot of content to an already lengthy game. There's a racetrack that's surprisingly fun, many new tools and structures that fit well with everything else. Some stealth challenges that I really enjoy and a lot of really small additions. It's definitely worth the 10 dollar upgrade.
Love it. Not a fan of the ending, but the gameplay is something I always come back for.

The plot is good, but would have been more enjoyable as a movie.

Kojima Productions have proven they can make original, compelling, & fun games. The Director's Cut doesn't add a huge amount of stuff, but it also doesn't screw anything up either, which is about as much as you can hope for from a release like this.

If you're considering giving it a try, I suggest you do so. As the servers die off (as powerful a metaphor as every other aspect of this game) something of the experience will be lost forever, so get on it.

death stranding is one of my favorite games of all time. so this review will be more of a "should you buy this one or the base version if you're new to this".

in my opinion the additions and gameplay tweaks were done very seamlessly that none of the new missions, gear, weapons, tactics, etc; felt tacked on. this version is harder than the base version, but only because theirs more factors to deal with when making a delivery than before (BT territories especially got more threats). the biggest addition that i think makes this a must for new death stranding players is the gun range. being able to test out and get used to how the weapons work in a no risk environment really lets you learn what will and wont work. 

I highly recommend new players to get  this version. its an improved main course with a nice dessert.

story: 10/10 - Hideo Kojima and his team strike again with a moving narrative and characters with immaculate depth.

game-play: 7/10 - Most of it is just walking, with some added mechanics to make it more interesting. The combat is bare-bones, but this game isn't combat focused to begin with, so you won't be encountering it all too much.

game-feel: 10/10 - Despite the aforementioned "just walking," every step you take feels weighted, and with purpose. Everything about the movement feels really lifelike and natural.

convenience: 6/10 - This game isn't easy to pick up and put down in quick succession. A lot of deliveries (this game's "quests") range from 15 minutes to maybe even an hour. If you've got a busy life, this game might not be for you.

From the eyes of someone who plays games casually, I'd give this an 8.5/10. It's a solid title if you're looking to add something new to your collection.

Returning vet porter, 300h+ of DS standard version on Epic Game, all achievements. I'm buying this on Steam again just to support Mr. Kojima and his spectacular vision toward creating an unique gaming experience. DS is a great a game with a exceptionally slow start and I understand not everyone can accept the pacing of such design. But if you are curious, I strongly recommend you to give this game a try before DS2 release.

Some tips to help you go through the Eastern Region (potentially spoiler):

1. Timefall is harsh to cargo crate, especially on high difficulty, but it only damage the crate, not the content inside. The low cargo crate hp will make the content inside taking more damage if the cargo receives impact. But as long as you don't fall on the ground, your cargo will be safe and you can still get perfect delivery rating. So you don't have to bring two bottles of repairing spray every time.
2.If you sneak through (or fight your way through) the first Mule camp and keep hugging the mountain as high as possible, you can avoid the second BT zone completely.
3.Musician is located South of middle Bridges station, on the cliff, next to a waterfall. It's hard to reach at first, but I highly recommend get to that shelter and at least do one or two order to reach one star. Musician will thank you by gifting you a harmonica, which is a way more effective way to calm down BB than shaking.
4.About Wind Farm BT zone: well there aren't much space to work around to avoid this one, it's a very scripted BT encounter. But there're three ways as I know of to get through it:
-fully sneaky, hug the edge of map or just hold you breath and cut through the middle;
-not so much about sneak as long as you can get away from being caught, bring a few "special" grenades, if you trigger a BT, and the ground turns tar-like, you can drop the grenades right on your feet, which will temporarily keep those tar-people away;
-The Big Ball Move, intentionally get caught and dragged by BT to trigger the BT-boss fight, during those kind of fight, all the map assets (trees, rocks, player buildings) will be temporarily hidden underneath the ground, instead it will generate a tar lake arena with some buildings for your foothold, so all you have to do, is to jump around the buildings and keep heading toward the wind farm, generally these early BT-bosses are not aggressive and you can walk away easily. If one does decide to chase you, just welcome it with your grenades. Once you are far enough, the BT-boss will despawn and timefall will stop for a short time.

I will update this comment after I complete the steam DC version and full achievement this game again.

It sounded interesting from reading reviews, but this game is simply boring, infuriating and gruesome.
I wanted to get a refund from Steam even though I only paid 20 bucks for it.  
Many reviewers here on Steam try to tell you 'don't listen to the people who say this game is boring or stupid... &tc."  Wrong.  Do listen to them. Or waste your money.  Your choice.
I'll post spoilers here, even though the game is spoiled enough without it.  
The protagonist is a super ugly guy who has to lug junk all over the place for no reason while dodging invisible disgusting creatures.  And the game makes it super difficult to do even that.

You as the player get to micro-manage how Ugly Guy walks.  That's literally it.  That's the whole game.

The user interface is a nightmare, and good luck figuring that out.
The game seems completely based on ultra-long, protracted cut scene close ups of the ugly guy's face, so if you're into that I guess you can have fun.
YOU CANNOT SAVE YOUR GAME. It relies on 'autosave only' and as such you're screwed if you have to quit.
Some of the voice acting is ok. Some other is not.  But either way it's overshadowed by listening to ugly guy pant and puff, and then shoots random crappy music at you to further piss you off.  
Of course, the opening BS takes more than 2 hours to suffer through, so I can't get a refund any more.  I can, however, uninstall this senseless game.
And that's what I'm doing right now.
If you want awesome and beautiful exploration, get Horizon Zero Dawn. 
If you want to spend a lot of time waiting for a game to finally get good, only to make you angry that you wasted your time with it, get this game.  Good luck.

Now straight to the point. No more silly formats, too lazy for that and it does nothing in return. This game is amazing, I'll try to be as objective as humanly possible, but sometimes it's really hard. The thing with this particular game is [b]it takes you down with brute force spearheaded by its unmatched originality and gameplay decisions[/b]. Even if you're prepared for something unorthodox having heard all those stories about the genius of one certain man and things he's capable of. Many gaming maniacs and game addicts have spewed a lot of good bullsh1t about this project and you're sitting there wondering what the hell is to expect there!? 

Well just like an actual storm this game has a slow start as it takes speed gradually with seemingly the never ending cutscenes that occupy most of the playtime during first two chapters. I'll be honest, I had doubts about it since I really came to play the game and not watch all those brilliant video cuts, nicely done chaps, but where's my game? Not that it bothered me terribly, as [b]it's difficult to get bored over the sheer quality of the said cutscenes[/b], couldn't possibly be fed up with such brilliance since the graphics raise the bar very high. To my eyes the game's got the best graphics I've personally seen, ever. 

[b]Just the way in which the plot unfolds is simply superb; each of the character somehow involved with the storyline has its own 'arc' in the chapter dedicated to that character[/b]. With new things being uncovered along the way you sometimes couldn't foresee beforehand, it is beautiful. Gameplay may seem to be having no longevity written on it as it would be getting stale pretty quickly or so you'd think, carrying stuff from place to place but, it's the way you do it, and what for! As you progress in the story gameplay updates along with new objectives and main missions. 

Cute 'n' friendly part time interactions with other players deliver freshness other types of such games lose fast, you never see anyone else but you know that they're always there. A special kind of excitement to be liked and appreciated by the local in-game community drives you to be aspiring in activities you'd unlikely do otherwise. [b]I am only about halfway through the storyline and I already think there's no game currently out for sale that can surpass this master piece[/b]. Out of the line thinking to the approach and to present the game, both risky and so open, unheard of among the other allegedly blockbuster titles, put this one well above others. Nothing more to say.

[i]I tried to highlight some of the takeaways from this review for you but I'd be thankful if you read that all anyway[/i]

I mean, by no means this is a game for everyone, I very much understand that perspective, but how amazing of an experience that is. From the story, to the landscapes, to the characters, to the music, it is truly amazing to work that gets further enhanced by its own rhetoric on connections. It is not without its hiccups, with my biggest complaint being the vehicle physics that absolutely sucks (you basically get stuck on every rock there is), but the breathtaking taking visuals more than makeup for it. I came and stayed for the story, but I know there is so much more to explore for those who are interested! Go for it and enjoy it!

AFTER 5-20 HOURS IN: The story unfolds slowly, there's a lot of walking and running (which is - belive me or not - quite fun and relaxing), but after completing 'story missions,' more equipment and structures are added to the player's disposal (grenades, motorbike, meds, assembler, - for building structures -  guns and even fast travel). After logging in to online mode, structures and signs built by other players will be added to the game, which will make our gameplay a bit easier and more fun. I'm definitely curious about what will happen next in this story, and yeah - the story is great.

30 HOURS IN: I completed around 50% of the story and I am amazed by it so far. The multiplayer aspect of the game is very original, non intrusive and satisfying. Plus you can switch it off completly or just partially.

This game is devisive to say the least: either you adore it or you hate it apparently. 
I'm in the first category. Death Stranding enters my top 5 easily! What a game! I stayed shocked for two weeks after finishing the story and finally managed to cry only after that period, it was like a sort of mourning. It touched my heart and "soul" (sic)  like few games have. 

The gameplay is not centered around combat and i loooved that, it's still there, there's still adversity (a lot actually) but it's better avoided and killing is really not advised. Instead the game lets you contemplate and meditate on its heavy themes (exctinction threat, death, life, birth, loneliness, work, connection, love and hate, all very human and "deep" subjects) while keeping you busy with a gameplay loop that is innovative, fun, tense or relaxing depending on the moment. 

Like always with Hideo Kojima, the game is a declaration of love to games, cinema and music. Kojima and his team uses that passion for cinema and music and its inventivity and knowledge to create a piece of art. The graphics and environments are superb, the cinematics contains the best motion capture and acting I've seen in a game. But it doesn't take itself too seriously neither and there is quite a bit of humour in there and a lot of very fun gameplay. It really is a mix that few games manage to do and Death Stranding delivers in every area.

It's heavy with symbolism, if you love and "get" symbolism, you'll love the story, if you like questionning and reflecting on big life subjects, you'll love the story, if you like a mix of heaviness and lightness, strong emotional up and downs, you'll love the story. If you think that reflecting and meditating on life is a waste of time, if you don't like the idea of a gameplay loop that doesn't involve combat as it's center mechanic then pass, you won't like what's in there. Me, i get it, i even need it, i'm a contemplative emotional and overthinking person and need that level of engagement. This game captured the zeitgeist like few artworks manage to. 

Technically the director's cut is quasi-flawless, everything ties together superbly. The soundtrack is fantastic and i discovered Low Roar and Woodkid thanks to it. 

A fantastic experience, thank you Hideo Kojima and all the people that worked on this game, thank you so much, it was .... special, very much so. Now I can let it go for a while and hopefully my heart can feel a bit lighter as I do so until i come back to it or to death stranding 2.

Death Stranding is an absolute masterpiece that defies convention and offers an unparalleled gaming experience. From its stunning graphics to its captivating storyline, every aspect of this game is a testament to the creativity and vision of Hideo Kojima.

The protagonist, Sam Bridges, portrayed by Norman Reedus, navigates a post-apocalyptic America burdened with the weight of humanity's hopes and fears. His journey is not just a physical one but a deeply emotional and philosophical exploration of connection and isolation.

The graphics are breathtaking, immersing players in a hauntingly beautiful world ravaged by catastrophe. Every detail, from the rugged landscapes to the intricate character designs, is a testament to the developers' commitment to excellence.

The supporting cast, including Mads Mikkelsen and Guillermo del Toro, delivers outstanding performances, further enriching the narrative and drawing players deeper into the game's universe.

One of the most innovative aspects of Death Stranding is its multiplayer component, which seamlessly integrates the efforts of players around the world. Through shared structures and resources, players collaborate to overcome challenges and achieve their goals, fostering a sense of community and camaraderie.

In conclusion, Death Stranding is a groundbreaking achievement that pushes the boundaries of storytelling and gameplay. It's a must-play for any gamer seeking a deeply immersive and thought-provoking experience.

[i]I have around 60h in this game, but in the previous "non director's cut" and I had this review up in the game page. Since the older version page is deactivated, I have copied my review over here[/i]

I'd like to start the review debunking the argument that [i]"the game might not be for everyone"[/i], since this was used so many times during the launch period. It sounded so arrogant, as if people needed over 1000 IQ to appreciate [i]"such a complex game"[/i] - or a [i]Kojima[/i] game. The game is as much to everyone as any popular shooter, MOBA, RPGs, etc. You might like it or not, but that's not because you [i]"lack sophistication"[/i] or anything like that. Also, since I mentioned Kojima, I must say that this is my first Kojima game. I have never ever played any other game so I don't share the love and appreciation that fans have for him. I won't also enter in any story spoiler during this review.

After that lengthy disclaimer, I can proceed to say that [b]this game is very good in so many ways[/b]. I'll start with the game [b]story[/b], which is very focused on details. The game is somewhat story heavy during the start and nearing it's end, but I think during the [i]"mid-game"[/i], it insert conversations and cinematics in small doses that are good enough to keep you interested instead of boring you. The fact that the characters are all actors and the lip sync is very good makes you appreciate a lot of details during cutscenes. The story, as you might have read in other reviews, tries to be full of twists, but if you are paying attention, most twists won't come to you as a big surprise. There is a good amount of foreshadowing for some revelations that you get during the game. Getting a better understanding to some aspects of the game requires you to read mails and interviews, which are mostly text walls and you receive them all the time. I can understand people stopping reading those after some time, since many of those contain no useful information at all. Since most of the time you are wandering by yourself, I feel like the game lost the opportunity to give you more audio lore [i]that could be audible during gameplay[/i]. The fact that every conversation or audio is done while the game is paused is something I don't really like. A delivery briefing could be done while I'm organizing my cargo and getting my Trike ready. I can understand the love some fans have for Kojima's writting, he certainly tries to be unique, even if the main starting plot is basically [i]"we have to save America"[/i]. Like I said, I won't discuss spoilers here. The story is good, but I was expecting much more from the end. The end is long, very long, and it didn't need to be that long, that's for sure. It is not bad, I liked it, but I just expected much more.

Now, about the [b]gameplay[/b], it is very good and unique. You are what the game call a [i]Porter[/i]. You make deliveries, as you may have heard before. But you have to remember that you make those in a very particular post-apocalyptic world, where you have to take into account several challenges along the way, those being mostly: rough terrain, rivers, chasms, hills, timefall rain, MULEs, BTs and many others. You'll also have to keep in mind your cargo, weight, balance, stamina, etc, etc. The game gives you so many tools to handle all that, and you get a lot of new and upgraded tools along the game, which is so, sooo nice. You can close gaps between deliveries in so many different ways. Use a ladder for a small bridge, use vehicles, create structures - your call. Also, I remember Kojima mentioning that this is a [i]"strand type of game"[/i], which lead me to think: [i]what the heck is that supposed to mean?[/i] Well, once you are playing for an hour or so, you will connect regions to the UCA network. These regions are [i]online enable[/i] in a manner of speaking, which means that part of the world can be shared with other players. Some other player structures and tools will appear on your world, and vice-versa. Let's say you escalated a big hill with lots of slippery slopes? Well, you might just put an anchored rope on the top to make your life easier on the return trip, and also if you need to go this way again, you can use that rope. This rope can also be shown for other players that are connected, and it shows on their world with your name. They can even [i]like[/i] the help and you will receive that notification. You might even find other players lost cargo and return it, and they will receive it! The game is all about connecting with other people (you will hear this a lot) and that is a small way to demonstrate the [i]strand type of game[/i]. It feels so nice knowing you helped another random player. It feels so good when you seems to be running out of a tool during a hard trip, only to find some stranger builded a bridge or something like that, saving your skin. This is still a single player game, but that aspect makes it so interesting. [b]I do hope more games try this approach[/b]. It is simply amazing. My only complaint here is that you cannot choose to see or connect to a Steam friend. You have to be lucky to find something from them randomly, if ever.

This is just me trying to scratch the surface of this game. I don't want to spoil gameplay mechanics or tools, not even the story, but I do think it's a good game to be played at some point. The game is pretty straight forward in the beginning. I think it is safe to say that if you are playing it for about 2 hours (refund window) and you are not interested yet, maybe just skip it and refund. The game does not show it's true potential in the first hours, it only gets better, but the core gameplay and story is already in motion at this point.

Death Stranding : By Triple F 

From the visionary mind of Hideo Kojima comes an opus that defies genre boundaries and narrative norms - "Death Stranding". This isn't just a game; it's a profound exploration of human connections, a mesmerizing blend of game-play and storytelling that leaves an indelible mark on the very essence of gaming itself.

In "Death Stranding", Kojima has masterfully crafted a post-apocalyptic world that is as haunting as it is beautiful. The desolate landscapes, the eerie echoes of a broken society, and the hauntingly emotive score fuse together to create an atmosphere that is nothing short of breathtaking. You'll find yourself mesmerized by the sheer attention to detail - from the minutiae of footprints forming in the rain to the sweeping vistas that beg you to pause and soak in the awe.

But it's not just the visual and auditory spectacle that elevates "Death Stranding" to greatness; it's the game-play itself that resonates profoundly. This is a game about connection, and it's not just a thematic choice; it's a game-play mechanic. As Sam Porter Bridges, portrayed brilliantly by Norman Reedus, you are tasked with the delicate duty of reuniting a broken world through the act of delivering packages. The seemingly mundane act of traversal becomes an absorbing and spiritual experience.

Traversing the rugged terrain demands an intimate engagement with your surroundings. Every step counts, every decision to place a ladder or forge a path has weight, and every encounter with the ethereal entities known as BTs (Beached Things) demands strategic finesse. "Death Stranding" seamlessly blends open-world exploration, resource management, and adrenaline-pumping stealth mechanics into an experience that is as meditative as it is heart-pounding.

What truly sets "Death Stranding" apart is its narrative depth and emotional resonance. Kojima weaves a tale of isolation, human longing, and the enduring power of human connection. The cast, featuring celebrated actors like Mads Mikkelsen, Léa Seydoux, and Guillermo del Toro, brings their characters to life with a poignant authenticity that draws you into their struggles and triumphs. The narrative is a puzzle, where each piece holds significance, and the revelation of its intricacies is as satisfying as solving the most enigmatic riddles.

"Death Stranding" is not without its quirks, but these idiosyncrasies only serve to enhance its charm. The game's deliberate pacing might not be for everyone, and its thematic depth might require a contemplative mindset. Yet, for those willing to immerse themselves fully, "Death Stranding" delivers an experience that leaves an imprint on your soul, urging you to contemplate life, connection, and the indomitable spirit of humanity.

All in all, in an industry often saturated with sequels and formulaic releases, "Death Stranding" emerges as an avant-garde masterpiece that challenges norms and sets new benchmarks for artistic expression within gaming. Hideo Kojima's magnum opus is a testament to the potential of video games as a medium for storytelling and introspection. It defies classification and demands to be experienced by anyone seeking a truly transformative journey through the uncharted territories of gaming innovation.

A Masterpiece of Connectivity and Exploration: Death Stranding Review

In the vast expanse of the gaming world, where innovation meets artistry, there exists a title that transcends traditional boundaries to deliver an experience unlike any other. Death Stranding, the brainchild of visionary game designer Hideo Kojima, is a masterpiece that weaves together stunning landscapes, profound storytelling, and gameplay mechanics that redefine the very essence of connection in gaming.

From the moment you step into the shoes of Sam Porter Bridges, portrayed with unparalleled depth by Norman Reedus, you are thrust into a world that is as hauntingly beautiful as it is desolate. The landscapes of Death Stranding are nothing short of breathtaking, with sprawling vistas that stretch as far as the eye can see. From snow-capped mountains to lush forests and treacherous ravines, each environment is meticulously crafted with an attention to detail that is simply awe-inspiring.

But Death Stranding is not just a game about traversing stunning landscapes; it is also a game about forging connections in a world torn apart by isolation. As Sam, you embark on a journey to reconnect the fractured cities of America, delivering essential supplies and rekindling hope in the hearts of those you encounter along the way. The gameplay mechanics, while initially daunting, quickly become second nature as you navigate the rugged terrain with the aid of your trusty BB and an array of ingenious gadgets.

One cannot discuss Death Stranding without acknowledging its roots in the Metal Gear Solid series, particularly Metal Gear Solid V. The influence of Kojima's previous work is evident throughout, from the meticulously designed stealth mechanics to the intricate storytelling that keeps you guessing until the very end. Fans of Metal Gear Solid will find plenty to love in Death Stranding, while newcomers will be drawn in by its unique blend of gameplay and narrative.

At its core, Death Stranding is a game about connection – both on a personal level and as a reflection of our interconnected world. It is a game that challenges players to think beyond themselves and consider the impact of their actions on others. It is a game that celebrates the beauty of human connection in all its forms, from the bonds we share with loved ones to the strangers we meet along the way.

In conclusion, Death Stranding is a triumph of storytelling, gameplay, and visual design that stands as a testament to the power of video games as an art form. With its stunning landscapes, deep narrative, and nods to the legacy of Metal Gear Solid, it is a must-play experience for gamers of all stripes. Simply put, Death Stranding is a journey unlike any other – one that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

Death Stranding Director's Cut is a masterpiece that offers a unique and unforgettable gaming experience. The game's atmospheric world, gripping story, and innovative game-play mechanics make it stand out. Traversing the desolate yet beautiful landscapes, encountering diverse characters, and delivering packages across rugged terrain require careful planning and adaptability. The Director's Cut offers new features such as additional weapons, missions, and a revamped delivery system, making it even more satisfying and re-playable. Whether you're a fan of Kojima's work or crave something truly unique, this game is a must-play.

I've experienced countless virtual worlds and narratives, but Death Stranding stands out as a remarkable journey that left an indelible mark on my heart and soul. From its captivating storyline to its immersive gameplay mechanics, every aspect of this game resonated deeply with me on an emotional level.

First and foremost, the storytelling in Death Stranding is nothing short of exceptional. The developers have crafted a rich and poignant narrative that explores themes of life, death, friendship, and self-discovery. As I embarked on the protagonist's journey, I found myself emotionally invested in every twist and turn of the plot, experiencing moments of joy, sorrow, and everything in between.

What truly sets the game apart is its ability to evoke genuine emotions within the player. Through masterful storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, the game creates an atmosphere that tugs at the heartstrings and leaves a lasting impression. I found myself laughing, crying, and reflecting on my own life as I accompanied the characters through their trials and tribulations.

Beyond its narrative depth, Death Stranding also excels in its gameplay mechanics. The controls are intuitive, the level design is ingenious, and the challenges rewarding. Every aspect of the gameplay is designed to complement the emotional journey, enhancing the overall experience and drawing the player further into the world of the game.

In addition to its emotional impact, the game also boasts stunning visuals and atmospheric sound design that further immerse the player in its world. From lush landscapes to hauntingly beautiful vistas, every scene is a work of art that begs to be explored and savored.

Death Stranding is not just a game—it's a transformative experience that left me profoundly moved and deeply touched. It's a testament to the power of storytelling in gaming and a reminder of the emotional depth that video games can achieve. For anyone seeking a truly unforgettable gaming experience, I wholeheartedly recommend this experience as a must-play masterpiece that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

Oyunun orijinal sürümünü 2 kez bitirdim ancak satıştan kaldırıldığı için o sürüme inceleme yazamıyorum. Oynanış süreme takılmayın diye veriyorum bu bilgiyi. 

Oyun tasarımcılarının yaşadığı sıkıntılardan biri de insanların gündelik hayatta yaptıkları basit eylemlerin bir oyuna nasıl dönüştürüleceğine karar vermek ve bu durumda Death Stranding çok iyi bir örnek bana soracak olursanız. Tıpkı son dönemlerde çıkan Jusant'ın tırmanma eylemini bir oyuna dönüştürmesi, Deus Ex'lerin insan ikna kabiliyetlerini basit bir diyalog seçiminden ziyade bir mini oyuna dönüştürmesi veya Griftlands'in konuşmayı bir kart oyununa dönüştürmesi gibi Death Stranding de yürümeyi bir oyun haline getiriyor. 

Eğlenirsin, eğlenmezsin bu başka konu ancak aslında Death Stranding'de yürümekten ziyade oyun oynuyoruz. Yürümeden önce envanter yönetimi yapıp yanımızda taşımamız gerekenlere karar veriyor, yürürken karşımıza çıkan engellere karşı önlem alıyor ve tüm yolculuğumuz boyunca karakterin dengesini korumak için çabalıyoruz. Düşündüğünüz zaman tüm bunlar yürüme eylemini gerçekleştirdiğimiz diğer hiçbir oyunda yapmadığımız, dikkat etmediğimiz şeyler. Çünkü onlarda yürümek sadece yürümekken Death Stranding'de yürümek aslında bir oyun haline getirilmiş.

Bu yüzden Death Stranding'in yürüme simülasyonu olduğuna katılmıyorum ve bu yorumun bu oyuna haksızlık olduğunu düşünüyorum. Zaten oyun da yürümekten ibaret değil, gizlilik, savaş, araç kullanımı gibi oyunun pek çok farklı yönü var. Düşündüğünüz zaman özellikle lineer ilerlediğimiz yapımlara kıyasla Death Stranding daha az oynanış elementi falan barındırmıyor aslında, bir oyunun her saniyesinde aksiyon barındırmıyor oluşu onu kötü bir örnek yapmıyor bence. 

Kısacası Death Stranding benim epey severek oynadığım, ilginç bir şekilde dünyasında olmaktan keyif aldığım (yalnızlığımdan olabilir bu, kendimi o dünyaya ait hissettim açıkçası), fullemekten en çok keyif aldığım yapımlardan biri oldu. Çok marjinal bir oyun evet ve görünen o ki Kojima bu yolda gitmeye devam edecek, o yüzden herkese hitap edecek bir yapım değil ancak gerçekten "yürüyorsun işte sadece" diyerek basite indirgeyip bu güzide yapımı bir kenara atmayın, bir şans verin bence.

Death Stranding is a Fantastic pick up and deliver game. I slept on this game back when it released on the PS4. I bought it for Norman Reedus and the story but didn't stay due to the gameplay. This time around the gameplay did intrigue me and I wanted to give this game another shot. Really glad I did, the journey was awesome if you really stick with the game it builds as you progress but there is a Zelda element to this game where you can rush to the end game if you wanted to but you will miss out on so many tools and equipment that would have really benefited you along the way. Getting a 5 star connections with the various Distribution centers is key to unlocking better gear for Sam. The people who love it, love this game and the people who hate it haven't really given this game a proper run through. This game plays at a slightly slower pace, yes you can get guns and vehicles, you can kill people in this game and it's all well and fun but that is not where the joy lies in the game. The joy is getting a 5 star connection with the distribution centers, getting a new piece of story, new gear, new tools, getting that S rating on deliveries, destroying BT's, key moments where other porter's constructions come in clutch when you really need it and much more. 

As I stated already I'm glad I gave this game a second chance, I didn't like it because I thought it was a walking simulator but because I rushed my run of this game I missed out on unlocking vehicles really early which was my own mistake and how stupid i felt this time around seeing that all the places I struggled in my prior playthrough I was able to breeze by because I took the time to actually play the game and unlock all the gear I missed my first time around. This game is a solid 9/10 for me, a really unique game and with a rich mysterious story. You are missing out by not playing this game, put the FPS down for a bit and relax and take a drive through the world of death stranding for a bit, and to those who already played this game and are reading this review... just keep on keeping on.

(REVIEW IN PROGRESS)

This game... oh man, this game...

[h2] GAMEPLAY [/h2]

First, let's get something more simple out of the way - the gameplay. On a grand level, the closest sort of feeling that it evokes is if you enjoy things like European Truck Simulator or playing something like Elite Dangerous or No Man's Sky and if you enjoy vibing out just delivering stuff to different locations. That's the sort of core loop, and there are elements of stealth sometimes involved and a bit of combat here and there. So if you're expecting constant high octane action, that's not what you're gonna get here. Come in with expectations of post-apocalyptic delivery vibing, and that's what you're gonna get.

At first it's very difficult because you're essentially doing it all on foot in difficult terrain. Eventually, you will unlock plenty of sci-fi toys and vehicles that will help ease this process. Another fun thing is this game has a sort of Souls-esque system where things that you and other players place in the world can show up in other worlds. So eventually you're all sort of helping each other to make the world more traversable and generally more hospitable, it's a warm sort of social aspect to a game that is inherently somewhat lonely.

[h2] STORY [/h2]

Have you ever had a friend or family member almost... [i]challenge[/i] you on your cuisine? In the first hour or so of this game, it feels like Kojima lays out a heinous charcuterie board in front of you, filled with the stinkiest of cheeses and fermented hors d'oeuvres. He smiles at you expectantly, and you will either recoil and say "what is this garbage?" or you will start to dig in and say "hey I'm actually super into this freaky stuff." I'll be honest, I really wasn't sure how to feel at first. It felt like the game was saying "yes this is insane, and no, we [i]will not[/i] be explaining."

However, if you can stomach that first hour or so, it actually does do a pretty decent job of explaining itself, especially if you're the sort of person that enjoys reading the logs and interacting with side characters. Does it make sense? Not according to our reality, no. But if you feel like buying into the weird dream logic of this world, it actually has a really fascinating cohesion.

I'm sure I have much more to play of this game, but I'll say I haven't felt this intrigued and entranced by a game, its story, and its world in a long time. It's a sort of creative project that makes you wonder, how can this possibly exist? How did people hear this pitched and actually agree to be involved? On top of all of that, how was it made with so many famous people and with such a huge budget? In a way, just the fact that a game this shamelessly strange and creative exists at all is an incredible achievement. This game may be divisive, but so far I am heavily invested and looking forward to the rest of my time with it.

[h1]THE TEAM [/h1]

that made this followed Kojima's vision, I am referring to apart from the acting team, the music Ludvig Forssell, Yoji Shinkawa, the writers, producers including Kojima himself, didn't fail to grasp our attention.

The world he created was too similar to ours, Sam Porter too recognisable a person with flaws, strengths and weaknesses where we could identify with, perhaps most of all was his still or quiet nature, that allowed us to be drawn into the after effect of the ''extinction event'' that the earth suffered from by this time, the ''DEATH STRANDING''.

[h3]DIFFERENT TYPES OF TERRAIN[/h3]

Of all the strange occurrences in the world after the great 'extinction event', or apocalypse if you understand it as that, the rain in the world is TOXIC, making ageing at a fast rate human skin if it touches it. Or extreme RUST on metals. The 'tar-belt', the unusual effects on the environment to be seen, in the game you traverse all sorts of landscapes (FOREST/SNOW/MOUNTAINOUS/HOT DRY/VOLCANIC)

[h3]NORMAN REEDUS-THE PERFECT CHOICE[/h3]

Norman Reedus allowing us to OBSERVE the world, after it has been altered by the effect of the death stranding, WITH him. 

Here we see the affirmation of the choice of Norman Reedus, his quiet nature, leading us to fully enjoy a totally ''NEW EXPERIENCE''. It's  almost common-place to notice this game throughout as a stealth – game, though I would argue, even though stealthy like actions were sometimes employed, it isn't entirely so..

Yes, if you're happening on a 'terrorist base', or a terrorist, or a 'mule-base', or a mule or a few maybe patrolling in a vehicle and YOU USE stealthy actions, the game is too a THRILLER, of HORROR proportions.

[h3]BT's[/h3]

I'm of course referring to the BT's, or ''beached things'', [b]which our faithful BB, helps us to navigate[/b] like [i]minefields[/i] of these spooks, MASTERFULLY ✔ leaving us with  a heightened sense of extreme eeriness &, HORROR, in these encounters with appropriate screeching music & our choices are usually limited for success, following an encounter with these 'beings', most of the time we end it by comforting BB/Lou,[strike] 'DON'T YOU ALL BREATH A SIGH OF RELIEF NOW'[/strike], either as you do so.

At this point, I shall HIGHLIGHT that there are types of BT's, from massive giants to literal babies, to animals, beasts & fish like BT's, where IF left to defeat Sam, cause a massive 'VOID-OUT', a crater like 'scar' on the earth testament of your lack of skills to defeat the BT's. So throughout the game, your map of your game-has THESE craters, where you failed to succeed.

[h3]LEVEL UP[/h3]

There is room for improvement, if effort is put in, you may be a Kingpin deliverer, and you shall notice your skills improvement in the game menu. 
Your tools do level up, over time, you acquire, level's 1-3 usually, the best having the best duration, & more functionalities than the previous.
The story is vast & it becomes 'CURIOSITY' level to play 10'S OF HOURS, having personally played around 380 hours at review time.

[h3]FINAL THOUGHTS[/h3]

[i]Is there fast travel [/i] (there is YES, a form of fast travel, though it wasn't my favorite form of travel, so you sit there thinking ''YOU PREFERED TO STANDARD TRAVEL than [u] FAST TRAVEL'', my answer for you YES,[/u] you'll see, it's an amazing game).

There are various methods of travelling, biking, cars, training grounds, cart like trolleys.

Played in 3rd person view as the first iteration of the game, sure there's a crossover with CYBERPUNK 2077, keep an eye out for it.

All in all, a personal game. The game is played in episodes, some shorter than the others.

The review is to encourage you to play the Director's cut, with the new content,
the game is great. 

There is no [b]NG+[/b], though the game remains slightly beyond description, it requires you to experience it to know it,

I shall leave comment space available for discussion, if something you wish to know without too much spoilers

[b]RECOMMENDED[/b]

Death Stranding ist ein Meisterwerk und gleichzeitig der größte Geduldtitel aller Zeiten.

Es ist wirklich schwer „Death Stranding“ jemandem zu empfehlen. Denn das Game ist nicht für jeden geeignet.
Man sollte wissen, was einen erwartet während der 30–40 Stunden.

DS ist sozusagen ein 90 %-Paket-Lieferungssimulator. Man bekommt halt die Aufgabe, den Osten von Amerika mit dem Westen zu verbinden durch Knotenpunkte auf dem Weg dorthin. Bei dieser Hauptaufgabe liefert man halt Vorräte und andere Pakete an diese Stationen. Das ist „Death Stranding“.
Man nimmt seine Pakete und versucht einen Weg zu finden durch das postapokalyptische Amerika. Mit der Zeit bekommt man natürlich bessere Ausrüstung, Waffen und Fahrzeuge, um diese Aufgabe zu bewältigen. Dennoch ist es eine schwierige Aufgabe, denn die Gelände, die Sam überwinden muss, werden von Stunde zu Stunde schwieriger. Deswegen ist eine gute Planung und Vorbereitung das Wichtigste.

Wenn man sich dieser Aufgabe für 30–40 Stunden widmet, bekommt man als Belohnung eine fantastische und epische Handlung. Die Story hat mich von der ersten bis zur letzten Minute gefesselt. Es gibt wahnsinnig gute Charaktere und die Handlung wird immer komplexer und verrückter. Ebenso fühlt sich die Geschichte sehr emotional an. Es gibt zwischendurch immer Szenen, die einen das Herz brechen.

Davon lebt „Death Stranding“ … Seine einzigartige Story mit vielen Wendungen und toller Charaktertiefe. Das Paket zu liefern ist halt die Hürde, um diese Story erleben zu können.

Lohnt es sich 30-40 Stunden? Auf jeden Fall !!!
Auch wenn ich des Öfteren genervt war, konnte ich dennoch nicht aufhören zu spielen. Man hat immer den Gedanken „Noch ein Paket, dann bekomme ich mehr Story“. Das hat mich persönlich am Ball gehalten.
Zugleich gibt es aber auch Momente, die einen total die Zeit vergessen lassen. Durch die Schönheit des Geländes und der wundervollen Musikuntermalung. Hatte des Öfteren 6–7 Stunden auf dem Counter, ohne es gemerkt zu haben.

Pro
+ Geniale Grafik
+ Soundtrack !!!!!
+ Epische Story
+ Tolle Charaktere
+ Neue Art von Spieldesign
+ Onlinecommunity (Man hat das Gefühl, ein Teil von etwas Großem zu sein)

Contra
– sehr träge zum Teil
– Walking Simulator, der sich über 30–60 Stunden zieht
– Story zwar genial, aber auch schwer zu folgen

Fazit: 9 von 10
Wer seine Geduld testen will und eine atemberaubende Story erleben will, sollte DS 100 % eine Chance geben. Dennoch seid ihr gewarnt: Entweder könnt ihr was mit dem Spiel anfangen, oder ihr wirft es nach einigen Stunden in die Ecke!

Versucht durchzuhalten. Es lohnt sich.

So, I was a bit skeptical at first when I heard about Death Stranding. I mean, the whole concept seemed kinda out there, you know? But hey, I figured, why not give it a shot – and boy, am I glad I did!

This game totally sucked me in from the get-go. The story, the world-building, the characters – all of it had me hooked. I found myself totally immersed in this post-apocalyptic world, having a blast exploring and making connections.

And let's talk gameplay – it's unlike anything I've experienced before. Balancing cargo, navigating obstacles, solving puzzles – it's strangely addicting! Plus, can we talk about how gorgeous the graphics are? And that soundtrack? Absolutely killer.

Long story short, Death Stranding blew me away. It's a total gem of a game, and I'd recommend it to anyone looking for something fresh and exciting to play.

This game is without a doubt, the best game I have ever played. I have ~80 hours in the regular release version to make a total of about 190 hours. -Great story, very confusing throughout but in the end it all makes sense , the cast of characters is great and it was nice learning about each one and finally playing a game where i was interested in the plot and pushing forward to get more story instead of just trying to finish the game. That being said there were moments while playing i was thinking to myself "please stfu already and let me get on with it" 

-Incredible graphics and landscapes. Every 5 to 10 minutes i was using photo mode, theres non stop beautiful views through the entire game. And it supported my ultrawide curved monitor and thats always a major plus for me

-Gameplay is so much fun, being a delivery guy moving across beautiful and difficult terrain using ladders and ropes left behind by other porters and setting up my own to help out was a very cool experience. I built a few roads and it was a good feeling knowing i made some of the trips easier for not only myself but other porters, and dreading a difficult trip ahead crouch walking in the snow to see someone built a zipline up ahead was such a relief and im slamming the like button to thank whoever that person is . The only thing i disliked was that the time fall seemed to be in the same spots no matter what, i really wish it was more random and some trips could be made the entire way without time fall happening but other trips on the same route it would occur. I would love to be able to hop on the bike and enjoy a long trip across the map without always having to get off my bike at the same point because i knew a few more steps and the rain would start at the exact spots every single time. I also kind of hoped the end game was ridding the world of the time falls and being able to just deliver packages in nice weather taking in the views free from having to crouch walk and deal with BT's because it does get old after a while, they arent difficult to deal with especially once you unlock the cutter cuffs so it became less of a fun moment where you are in fear and more of a "dude i gotta crouch walk and inch my way forward for the next 10 minutes"

Despite my few complaints Overall i loved the game and would love a death stranding part 2

While the story is an absolute incoherent fever dream, Death Stranding really is a unique experience that you have to play to understand. The game properly opens up in episode 3, and it's well worth playing until you get there.

Like many others you'd be forgiven for thinking this is 'just a walking simulator', but the game opens up to being so much more than that. It involves strategy, stealth, combat, resource management, and building infrastructure. The game goes from walking simulator, to shooter, to horror, to Euro Truck Simulator, to Assassin's Creed and back again. Death Stranding manages to juggle all these different genres just enough to remain interesting from start to finish.

You're constantly introduced to new equipment and mechanics until well into the endgame, keeping the gameplay fresh and interesting. The unique way 'multiplayer' is implemented also means that even though you're traversing the world alone, you always feel like you're playing in a world with other players.

Truly a unique experience. Keep on keeping on.

This will not be for everyone, I enjoyed it after about 20 hours. The first part of the game is about as much fun as walking barefoot through a field of glass and salt. It's story is great if you are a fan of Kojima, who I support for many reasons, least of which was how he got shafted by Konami. Once you start unlocking more equipment and really start rebuilding with the help of strangers you'll never see, the game is honestly fun. Its a downright spiritual experience if you can make it past the opening.

It's a game about walking that's been made as interesting as it can be. If you like walking/hiking games, you're going to probably love it, but if you don't like those, you'll probably hate it. Little in between. The depth of gameplay is astounding. The soundtrack is fantastic and mood of the game is unique. 

Immersion is frankly the #1 thing for me for games and this one rarely broke it for me. Probably why I played it for so long. 

The story and some of the style of the game has its Kojima-isms, which may feel strange if you've never played any of his games. The product placements are honestly funny in how blatant they are. 

The only shortcomings I can think of are how glitchy things can get with the inertia system near the late game when some areas get steep. The ending of the game is also long, as is tradition with Kojima's games.

In a world where the majority of big budget game releases are boring and safe, I really appreciate that this tried to do something unique. Unfortunately, there's no better way to explain besides saying "this is boring".  This is a game I have attempted to chip away at for years at this point (I even upgraded to the directors cut version). Every time I try to return to this game, I'm reminded of the frustrating and tedious gameplay which is entirely unrewarding and feels like a waste of time. I have a strong tolerance for boring gameplay, however even this was far too great of a burden for me to bear. I have to give credit, the premise, storytelling, and aesthetics are all top tier stuff and the creators of this game should be proud, however the gameplay could have been a lot more engaging and stimulating than what we ended up with.
