A Masterpiece of Connectivity and Exploration

Death Stranding is a mesmerizing journey that defies traditional gaming conventions, offering an unparalleled experience that blends stunning visuals, an emotionally charged narrative, and innovative gameplay mechanics. Hideo Kojima's vision shines through, delivering a game that challenges the norms of the industry and leaves a lasting impression.

First and foremost, Death Stranding boasts breathtaking graphics that showcase the beauty of its post-apocalyptic world. The landscapes are meticulously crafted, from the sprawling mountains to the desolate plains, creating an atmosphere that is both haunting and awe-inspiring. The attention to detail is nothing short of remarkable, making each step of your journey a visual feast.

The narrative is a complex tapestry of human connection and isolation, expertly woven together by Kojima's storytelling prowess. Norman Reedus delivers a stellar performance as Sam Bridges, a courier navigating a fractured America. The supporting cast, including Mads Mikkelsen and Lea Seydoux, adds depth to the narrative, creating a captivating and emotionally charged experience. The themes of connectivity and the impact of our actions resonate throughout, making Death Stranding more than just a game – it's a philosophical exploration of the human condition.

The gameplay is where Death Stranding truly shines, introducing a unique and innovative system centered around the concept of rebuilding connections. As a courier, your mission is to bridge the gap between isolated communities, delivering crucial supplies and re-establishing a sense of unity. The use of traversal tools, such as the trusty ladder and the versatile BB (Bridge Baby), adds a layer of strategy to exploration, turning seemingly mundane tasks into thrilling adventures.

The online multiplayer component enhances the sense of shared experience. Structures and items left behind by other players in their own journeys can be crucial resources for your own expedition. This collaborative approach to gameplay creates a sense of community in an otherwise desolate world, reinforcing the game's central theme of connection.

In conclusion, Death Stranding is a groundbreaking achievement in the world of gaming. It challenges players to think beyond traditional genres, offering a deeply emotional narrative, stunning visuals, and innovative gameplay mechanics. Hideo Kojima has once again proven his ability to push the boundaries of storytelling in video games, and Death Stranding stands as a testament to his creative genius. If you're looking for a gaming experience that transcends the ordinary, Death Stranding is a must-play.

A fascinating experience tarnished in public eye by people too stupid to listen to what the game tells them and then complains the game doesn't explain anything. You can not like the gameplay, that's fine, but most criticisms of the game and gameplay I don't find valid and were largely done for memes, laughs, or attempts to say they always knew Kojima was a hack.
Popular complaints are;
The gameplay isn't fun. But neither is truck sim nor farming sim, and both are incredibly popular.
The story is nonsense. It's explained very clearly. And it's interesting.
You can just walk outside and go for a hike. I don't live in Iceland, and that's ignoring the entire story aspect. I also expect these people to not play COD, Battlefield, nor ARMA in favor of signing up for the military.
Kojima should stop making games and just do movies. His games only work as games, and his gameplay systems are constantly exceptional. There's dozens of other studios that make far more linear experiences that get praised as the height of games. R* and Red Dead 2 is an excellent example. You can't do anything how you want in that game, you have to do it exactly how R* wants you to, and they also have an over-reliance on cut scenes. Kojima also does a much better job of integrating the player, not just the player character, into the world and story. Seeing someone walk up a mountain in a movie isn't the same as being the one to do it. This point annoys me most as it's most likely attributed to the fact that he has cutscenes, like every other game now.

-Spoilers-
I've played a ton of games throughout my life, and have many favorites, but yet, this game managed to become one of my top 10 favorite games. This is actually the 3rd time I've beaten it, (and as of December 2023, I just finally 100%-ed the game). I first got it back when it came out in 2019 for the PS4 and played it until completion on there, then I bought it again on my PC last year, and then I bought the Directors cut as an upgrade to the base game and completed it again. There's just something about it that makes it so apart from other games. The only way to rightfully put it would be: it's very Kojima like. The characters are really cool and all have their own unique backstory: you've got a man that has a literal heart-shaped heart and dies every (I think it was 8 or 10 minutes?) on purpose so that he can try to find his dead family on the beach; there's two twin sisters that become literally combined together because one of them dies and so the soul enters the other sister; you've got one of the coolest villains I've seen in a long time (voiced by the one and only Troy Baker of all people) who basically has magic powers and can summon the enemies of the game; and there's even more characters that all are unique in their own ways but if I kept going on then this would take an hour to write.

Now, a lot of people misjudge this game because back when it came out, everyone just called it a "Walking simulator" or "Fedex: the game" (which, the first example is ironically not true because for most of the game you're driving a motercycle/trike) which is sad because it deterred a lot of players away from the game because that's all that they were led on to believe. The story of this game is actually *insane*. Not just in a good way, but in a "this is the weirdest game story I've ever seen" sort of way. It has some of the biggest plot twists that you don't expect at all (WHICH ONE OF IS LEGITIMATELY TOLD TO YOU NEAR THE BEGINNING OF THE GAME BUT AT THE TIME YOU HAVE NO IDEA WHAT IT MEANS); it has likable and unique characters as I said before; and it's generally just a good story. However there is an issue that most people bring up, and I even agree with, and that is: the story is confusing as all hell and it's hard to figure out what is going on for the most part, especially at the beginning where you are just thrown into the game and they start speaking all of these words you've never heard before and don't understand what they mean quite yet. I had to google my fair share of things to understand the complete story, but once you do get it, it's really good in my opinion.

The game play itself (at least the delivery parts of the game) I feel is a little lackluster. I do like the details of things like figuring out where to pack the cargo on yourself so that you can combat things like wind and weight distribution; and the worry of making it out of Timefall with all of your cargo intact; there's even enemies to look out for like the BT creatures/being that you have to sneak around or otherwise they'll grab onto you, throw all your cargo to the ground and drag you to a giant BT thing that you have to run from; there's also Mules which are people that have basically gone crazy for loot, so they try to knock you out and steal your cargo, they definitely become a lot harder the farther you progress in the game (especially in the Directors cut version); and then there's one other enemy which really you don't even see unless you go to very specific areas in the game or you're forced to meet with them at the very end of the game, and those are the Jellyfish BTs. I had somehow managed to avoid them all game and never saw them until the very end where you go through like a ruined city and they are all just floating up in the sky, it honestly terrified me because for the entire game previous of this, there was only 2 threats, now suddenly there's giant black masses floating up in the sky. But once I realized that these things were practically harmless, the fear factor of it vanished. That is one of the bigger things I wish this game had, more threats, and deadlier threats, because even on the hardest difficulty (which I beat) it's not *too* hard. Really the only thing that had me ripping out my hair was the war zone segments of the game with Cliff. Even if the threats weren't even enemies, just give me something else to worry about and manage. TLDR: Game needs more threats, needs to be harder, and more things to manage as you deliver.

The graphics of the game is gorgeous and most of my time in the game was probably spent in photo mode just wandering around taking photos of Sam and the environment, some of the photos even look like they were taken in real life. I had no issues with lag or graphic issues even with it set on maximum. And it all looks really pretty and detailed. So it's all good in that department.

I wish more people would give this game a chance. When I first played this game I didn't know *anything* about it, actually I don't even remember why I bought it at the time, but I'm so glad I did. The game is just so different from others. the story is weird, unique, kind of confusing, but still really good and has good plot twists throughout it. The characters are all different and have their own backstory and personalities and are honestly pretty likable, even the villain of the story. The game play when it comes to delivering becomes a little samey over time, I do like how there's different ways you have to handle certain cargo though, like some can't be touched by water, some can't be shook up to much by a bumpy ride, some has to be stored a certain position, but even then, it just feels a little tedious after awhile. The combat part of the game isn't bad though, but still, I wish you had more stuff to do. Graphics and animation is phenomenal, looks realistic sometimes. All in all, it's a great, strange game that most people didn't give a chance because they thought it was something else. I bet if I told you that you get transported to war world 1 and 2 in the game you wouldn't believe me but it really happens. There's a lot more to it than just a simple walking simulator. It will likely remain one of my favorite games for a long long time, if not for ever. Give the game a shot, it has a lot more to offer than you think (especially with all of the stuff the Directors cut added. You can even race with race cars around a track). 10/10.

This game is an experience. I kept putting it off because i knew how much time I would be spending if I actually did dedicate myself. It took me a little less than month of playing sporadically to get about 85% of the achievements and finish the game. 

Overall Kojima really knows how to make games intriguing and fun. 

I really never expected a package delivery game would make me so addicted to the characters and world inside of it. There are certain part of the game that dragged on a bit and you sorta have to take your time and try not to burn out during that part, but if you persevere you are rewarded with a game that is addicting and has some of the best story telling in gaming history (imo).

Death Stranding probably wasn't what most people expected, and calling it a delivery simulator is not an exaggeration. However, I believe for anyone who had the patience to feel the story and immerse themselves in this beautiful world, this game is a masterpiece. Even if you do not like the gameplay of Death Stranding, I think we need more developers like Kojima who dare to try new things and such attempts should not be discouraged.

Death Stranding is a weird game. It's hard to even call it a game for that matter. A substantially portion of my playthrough was simply holding down the 'W' key alongside the occasional balancing act when stepping on uneven terrain or some course correction here and there. But I'm so glad I stuck with the game through the credits, until the very end.

Hideo Kojima and his team have crafted what can easily be considered one of the best and most intriguing video game campaigns of all time. I mean it when I say to go in as blind as possible. This game is filled with masterful metaphor and extremely complex symbolism that can easily have infinite interpretations. The story itself is far from straightforward, however, rest assured knowing that nearly every question worth answering is answered to some meaningful capacity. Each character is finely crafted to serve a purpose, and while the actions of the player may seem inconsequential at times, every action builds to make the world feel more real.

Let's talk gameplay, as that is easily the most divisive aspect of this game. I am a fan. While it is objectively boring and tedious (almost to a point where I almost assume it was defined to be aggravating) it really puts you in Sam's shoes. Your struggles are his, and his are your's. The multiplayer aspect integrates seamlessly into general gameplay and helps you realize just how much impact you have not only in your individual instance, but in the world of other players. Combat sequences are tight and responsive, with everything from grenades to a wide arsenal of guns feeling incredible to use. This is in stark contrast to the rest of the controls which are serviceable at best and miserable at the absolute worst. Some menus are clunky, and several mechanics are hard to initially grasp, but it all makes sense in due time.

The game is an incredibly slow burn, however, towards the end (after about Chapter 7) it picks up significantly. However, chapter duration ranges wildly. For example, Chapter 8 took me around 8 hours to complete (although I wouldn't be surprised if it takes some much more) while the very next chapter took me just eleven minutes (excluding cutscenes).

Lastly, let's talk this PC port. 505 Games have done an excellent job of porting the Director's Cut to PC platforms, with incredibly solid performance, in depths options (minus an FOV slider), and some nice quality of life options such as Ultrawide resolution support.

I truly can't recommend this game enough. While not for everyone, sticking with this game despite it's flaws is absolutely worth it. I cannot wait to see what Kojima and his team are cooking up next.
this game is fun... for about 5 hours

[b]As a video game, I have a very hard time recommending Death Stranding.[/b] The deliveries are repetitive and grueling. Enemy encounters are stressful, but not difficult. Some of the dialogue sucks. The entire first map is just a tutorial. The endgame sequence literally drags on for hours. 
For the most part, I did not enjoy [i]playing[/i] Death Stranding.

[b]And yet, this is my favorite game of all time.[/b]

As a gaming [i]experience[/i], it is a masterpiece. The depth of the story and characters blows every other game out of the water. The grueling package deliveries made me feel like I actually mattered to the post apocalyptic world. I didn't just control a character, I [i]became[/i] Sam Porter Bridges, the Great Deliverer. All of the people I met along the way had their own lives and stories, and Sam's interactions with them absolutely nailed the theme of connections. In a counter-intuitive way, the rough edges of Kojima's style make it a magical experience. As for the Director's Cut edition of the game, the asynchronous online multiplayer only added to the realism. Even though I knew I wasn't actually playing with other people, I was genuinely collaborating with my fellow porters by constructing roads and sharing equipment on our slow crawl to the West. From a technical perspective, the Decima Engine also makes the game look fantastic, and the physics control well. Unless you're going out of your way to break the game, the movement feels incredible.

To claim that Death Stranding is a "Walking simulator" may be correct, but at the same time, it's so much more than that.
This game is truly a work of art.
Not just a walking simulator- excellent and engaging gameplay, stunning visuals and overall ambience.

Death stranding is a post apocalyptic delivery simulator where you play as Sam Porter Bridge. Sam ends up being given a task bigger than he has before reconnecting the United states and its population. By delivering life saving goods and connecting a network while the whole time fighting humans and the unknown beings plaguing the world 

GAME PLAY

A good way to describe the experience playing this game would would be like American Truck Simulator mixed will the metal gear solid games funny enough but with way more direct engagement 

II you don't think the gameplay looks cool or fun then dont play this game or just read my review then judge for yourself 


DELIVERY

The Delivery game play is either.explore while you make the post possible routes.and using equipment to create clever shortcuts. Which ends up making for an extremely relaxing methodical game. To the opposite race of time and skill something similar to time trials. This goes into how the game perfectly throws curve balls in the gameplay that will make you have to reconsider how you approach deliveries. From “special Cargo” with different requirements to keep them safe to area challenges where the environment delivers location itself will be the change up. There are so many missions to do but not all are required but all will earn you something from your hard work.


COMBAT 

 The combat is very metal gear solid but not in the normal way guns are hug part of DS the whole without spoilers you can't normally kill enemies like in MGS butt das a big butt you can just destroy and beat the shit out of people without actually killing them and non lethal gun combat is a huge mechanic. 


STORY : The games story is hard to put into short word but ill try. its  a story about the sins of war, and connections life and death humans and communication and. the story is is very special  and eccentric exploring supernatural elements. The story is not something that should be spoiled at all but from this review you should be able to get a good idea of what your getting.


CARRYING AND EQUIPMENT

 This is the secret sauce of the game. the way you can tackle each delivery is almost always up to you how you want to go about dealing with it. You can only carry so much stuff on you by default just the way you are. The more you meet people and grow relationships you will get new equipment to assist you with delivery services in many way such as being able to carry more. With carrying more comes the trouble of balance and stability. You will need to scan your environment through your map to make sure you have the right delivery equipment to handle the job and the terrain.

Overall 130 hours is what I've spent playing this game. I even spent two hours writing this review. I think death stranding is a game you shouldn't sleep on.

Death Stranding is a 3rd person adventure/walking simulator/survival horror coming from the creative mind of Hideo Kojima and his new team. You deliver packages in this game while trying to avoid the dangers of the road which includes the terrain itself, the weather, bandits and also ghosts.

The story is more or less straight-forward. You're playing as Sam Porter Bridges, a courrier who's given the task of connecting settlements to the Chiral Network, which is basically the equivalent of our own internet but with some twists. The gimmick is that in this world, the concept of death itself has been thrown out the window and ghosts roam the lands between these settlements. I won't say more about the story as a big part of the journey is to uncover the mysteries of this world and why things are the way they are.

On the graphic side, this is peak level of details for our current generation. Beautiful landscape, nice colors and some of the best face details I've seen in years. The only game who comes close to this amount of detail overload is Red Dead Redemption 2. Amazing cutscenes, fluid animations, this game has it all.

As for the sound and music, it's excellent. Carefully handpicked songs played at precise moment helps elevates the emotional scope of these moments when you've almost reached your destination. Excellent voice acting by everyone. Neat sound effects for menus like the MGS series. What I dislike is how some songs are cut short because sometimes you deliver stuff very fast, so you only hear a brief segment of these songs. Second is the absence of the Music Player when you're out in the field. That's a big L right there. Besides these 2 little nitpicks, it's all good.

On paper, Death Stranding might sound like the most basic and dull game ever made. This was my mentality when I first heard about this game. It isn't as exciting as blowing up 100 zombies per second, yet it is a very zen and relaxing experience. In this day and age where online games and microtransactions rule, only a madman would attempt to make a game like this and I guess Kojima was up to the task for the sake of originality and creativity.

The art of balancing Sam's cargo weight while navigating slippery sloppes is realistic and at the same time, so goofy and funny. You haven't truly experienced this game unless you took a real bad tumble while being absolutely overweighted. But you see cargo lying on the ground and you STILL insist on picking it up.

This is why this game isn't for everyone, especially if you're impatient. The open world/sandbox vibe allows you to do whatever you want, carry what you want and go where you want. This game will teach you to make careful decision and how to take each steps carefully.

Note that I omit lot of details in this review because I'd bust Steam's character limit with some tl:dr paragraphs.

I highly recommed this game to anyone but beware, you need to walk in here with a different mindset than most mainstream games.

A masterpiece that will probably become a cult classic in the years to come. Bravo Kojima, you absolute lunatic.

10/10

Kojima's most self-indulgent work (and that's not always a good thing), but also the best story he's ever told.

The basic gameplay loop (traverse terrain and deliver packages while avoiding and/or fighting enemies) is enjoyable and extremely well-crafted. The physics of Sam moving across rocks, up and down hills, through streams; it's all the best I've ever seen in a video game. Sam's inertia feels real, and it's beautifully tied into the vibration on the controller (again, the best I've ever seen in a video game). You'll feel rocks on the ground, packages picked up, etc. The sound design is also incredible, with the sound of rain, wind, and rocks just crystal clear and realistic. This is game development at its absolute most meticulous, with attention to even the tiniest details. It's an incredible accomplishment.

That said, this definitely isn't for everyone. It's more of an interactive movie + work of avant-garde art, than what most people consider a "video game." More than anything, I'd say it's about atmosphere. The moody music from Low Roar certainly helps with that, and pairs nicely with the beautifully rendered landscapes.

A few frustrations: Getting grabbed by BTs and forced into boss fights can get annoying, and some of the unavoidable story-based boss fights are extremely obnoxious at times. Sam/Norman Reedus will eventually get access to an arsenal of weapons, but combat is not Death Stranding's strong suit. Unlike the Metal Gear series, combat gameplay feels clunky and awkward throughout (although maybe that's by design; Sam is a porter, not a soldier like Big Boss).

Another frustration is the multiple false endings. Slightly spoiler-ish, but when you're fighting what you assume is the final boss, you're actually only kinda halfway through the game, and there are a number of other boss fights to come. Multiple times, you're told "This is your final delivery" or "final mission," only for someone to tell you the exact same thing 20 minutes later.

The high point is the story (even though it drags on at times) and the absolutely incredible acting. Yes, the sci-fi/fantasy is a little silly, and eventually explained to you in seemingly endless lore-dump monologues (as is typical for Kojima), but it's refreshing to see something so boldly imagined and new. The sci-fi is completely original, unlike anything out there, and often breathtaking in sheer spectacle, which is nice in a time when everything feels so derivative.

I can honestly say that this is the best acting I've ever seen in a video game. The entire cast is stellar, but Mads Mikkelsen, Tommie Earl Jenkins, Troy Baker, and Emily O'Brien are especially outstanding. I'm not a sucker for drama, but the acting here is just riveting. Nobody phones it in just because it's a video game. It was honestly surprising for me to see. It's all helped by the incredibly good script. The dialogue is excellent and believable; there are no eyeroll-inducing lines, despite how silly the sci-fi stuff can get. The emotion is raw, real, and extremely heartfelt. I was not expecting that when I got this game.

TLDR:
Not for everyone. Part game, part interactive movie, part avant-garde art. The best story Hideo Kojima has ever told, and absolutely incredible acting. Enjoyable gameplay loop, but frustrating combat (when it happens). Overall, unlike any other game out there.

If you come in looking for something specific, you probably won't find it. But you might. There is a magic here, but it might not materialize for everyone.

Death Stranding Music Analysis

Death Stranding takes place in a beautiful open world, set against the backdrop of a post-apocalyptic landscape. The game's setting is further enhanced by its remarkable soundtrack, which features soft, ethereal vocal performances, innovative instrumentation, and recurring motifs that complement the visually stunning environment. The use of ethereal, ambient sounds and melodies can evoke a sense of isolation or otherworldliness, aligning with the game's post-apocalyptic setting.

The use of music inside and outside of the cutscenes is strategic. A commonly known thing about Death Stranding is that there is a lot of walking. Much of the game has no music playing in the background. Instead, music is played at critical points in your gameplay: traveling through an area for the first time or getting close to the finish line in a very long mission are some examples. The tracks that play during gameplay are dynamic: usually open with very subtle sounds to ease you into the music, such as muted percussion noises or soft vocals, then slowly transforms into a fully textured and immersive composition. Unlike many other games, these songs do not loop, and are instead meant to blend with the cinematic experience you are having as a player. I wish I could experience this game for the first time again, because these moments exemplify Kojima’s mastery of game design and his potential as a film director. 

In the moments of intense action where Sam has to beat up terrorists, the music reflects the urgency and intensity of hand-to-hand combat. When spotted, a loud airhorn-like sound plays from the terrorist that spotted you, then the combat music starts. The shift in tone and pace during combat contrasts with the game's more ambient and ethereal tracks, providing a dynamic, immersive audio experience.

"Anything You Need" by Low Roar from the album “0” (2014) sticks out to me the most, mainly because of the hypnotic, unchanging melody. It captures and carries your attention for the full three minutes. Mixed with Ryan Karazija’s somber vocals, this track feels like it belongs in the game more than any other. Like Death Stranding, “Anything You Need” stands out in its medium and is avant-garde in all respects.

quick start guide for new players.(spoiler free)

Rush through the starting area. There is a main area you will spend most of your time in
Second area the first thing to do is steal a truck from the mules and use it as much as you can until you get your own. 

You can 5 star facilities to get certain items unlocked, some are useful some are not.

Useful facilities to 5 star.

William Lake -Lake Knot City
Reverse trike - transport(if you dont want to use the mules truck, same cargo space except faster)

Thomas Sutherland - Distribution Center South of Lake Knot City
Long Range Truck Lv 3,

The Collector
Backpack Cover Lv 2


Junk dealer
Speed skeleton lvl 3

 Philip North - Distribution Center North of Mountain Knot City
Extra Battery Lv 3

It's worth making roads so don't be scared of using your mats, you can always farm them from MULES.there are some roads that are worth making and others not.

MATS for the roads are lowered as soon as you get them into the chiral network.
So make them after you connecting to maximize usefulness.

Roads I recommend making.

Lake knot>distribution south>south knot
	You will be going through here a lot in the early game.

Late game you can make.

Distribution south>mountain knot>distribution center north

After this your all set to complete the game.

I recommend doing so first. Since you get a free roam mode after to do any extra side stuff after.

Good luck, have fun, I hope this helps!

[h2]Welcome to the Facebook simulator ladies and gentlemen. If you like this review make sure to send me some [b]L I K E S[/b] hue[/h2]

As with most Japanese games I played, this one is overcrowded with sh*t. You get 100 new words and concepts crammed to your throat first couple of hours. Whatever, I'll get used to it, and I did. Stuff is pretty interesting after all, right? THEN I try to organise stuff.

UI clunky as f*ck, you will get used to it but.. You gotta click 50 things to set up your inventory / deliver stuff / organise sh*t. Simplest of interactions feel like picking up that 200 kg of cargo you're carrying in game, in real life. PlayStation moment at its best. THEN I move on to doing missions.

If you cut the unnecessary dialogue, I'd believe %30 of the game would be gone. For example - the c*nt named [spoiler]Die Hardman[/spoiler]who's probably sittin at his office and jerkin' off all day with his[spoiler]stupid mask and lame voice[/spoiler], while I'm[spoiler]moving literal TONS of gear and supplies between the settlements.[/spoiler] Make a drinking game - everytime he says "Sam", you take a shot. Oh boy, gonna go blind in 20 minutes, lemme tell ya that. You KNOW once he starts yappin', sh*t's gonna take at least 10 minutes. This mf talk so much and so empty, I'm sure half my playtime were his dialogues. Instead of saying 1 loud and clear sentence, homeboi goes on and on and on and on..[spoiler]Who needs rain that makes your skin grow older if it touches you[/spoiler], when you can just talk to[spoiler]Die f*cking Hardman[/spoiler]? Yeesh, even his name is cringe lol. I've seen stuff like this many times in animes I watched as well, so I'm guessing this... "mansplaining" is a Japanese and/or Kojima thing.

Speaking of over extended dialogues - bruh - who's writing entire pharagraphs to the protag Sam, sprinkled with 20 cringe ass emojis every sentence? Even my mom stopped doing that and she's 73 ffs. I don't mind trying to set up a decent lore for a post apocalypse game, but sh*t, don't write entire ass essays to me via e-mail lol, I got sh*t to transport. Since you made it this far, wanna hear my 2 cents on this fellas? They're trying to establish lore and identity with wall of text headass e-mails bc your handlers for each town / settlement have like 5 spoken dialogues and personality of a grain of rice I ate today. Damn man, my exes didn't text me this much during our most fatal moments - but this mf sends a 20 line message about a f*cking pizza? Gaaaaaahdam. Anyways, THEN I move on to exploring more.

They world that they built... Looks good, feels empty. Best thing you can hope for while exploring is a decent scenic view of an area, random cargo you can pick up and carry to a settlement or USB's that contains real life info on movies / bikes exc. The online stuff comes in, which is actually pretty decent. People build stuff for easier movement, warning signs for hostiles exc, and you can see and use 'em, while they do the same to your constructs. Fun to see how people overcome obstacles but... Oh brother, if only they filled the landscape up with some decent, interesting stuff.. I mean, you got the ENTIRE layout of U.S.A. and an interesting lore here, come on man, USE it dammit, instead of sending me hundreds of e-mails... Anyways, THEN I discover new toys and vehicles to play with.

Progression feels decent, but I feel like some of the stuff that unlocks later on should have been unlocked earlier. What am I gonna do with stun grenades when I'm packed with blood bags (heal items) and an AR?

For a game that focuses on transportation, vehicles are horrendous, extremely clunky and counter intuitive. My brother in Christ, GTA Vice City,[i] which came out in 2002,[/i] had better controls / handling compared to the bikes in this game. You think enemy [spoiler]Mule's and BT's[/spoiler] are your problem? No, [u]r o c k s[/u] are your ultimate nemesis. My brain bleeds when I hit that one rock and my truck breaks space/time continuum and physics go off into the garbage can. So start building them highways ASAP, dear Porters. Oh yeah, speaking of roads - where's my radio at? You put good, calm music into the game, but won't lemme play it while I travel? The f*ck man?

Game has interesting ideas and a relatively addicting core gameplay. But as I get closer to the end? I am EXTREMELY neutral about this one, with a pinch of negative. Been pushing for the end for the last... 10 hours tbh. Hence I'll mark it a thumbs down for now, but who knows, maybe once I finish the whole thing... IF I can muster up the energy to do so, that is.

EDIT

Okay after 2 weeks and adding a whoopin' 100 something hours to the game, it'd be unfair on my end to not edit the review. 

So, using one simple trick made the game immediately more fun. Instead of being super reliant on vehicle based travel, I built an entire network of ziplines that pretty much covers the entire continent. Less cancer from vehicles = more fun. This is not without its own problems though, bc you have a "Chiral Network Limit" which means how much sh*t you can build. This can be increased by getting better reputation with settlements. Unfortunately, chiral limit is filled up with not only the stuff you built, but what other players added to the network as well. This means you gotta mix your ziplines with others, bc you won't have unlimited limit. You can dismantle other player structures, but sadly it doesn't remove them from the limit, just deletes them visually. Kinda restricts the freedom, bc sometimes you won't be able to build that perfect straight zipline from A to B, since you have to mix and match with other player ziplines, but after getting enough towns to 5 stars, you're much more independent, which means you can build more freely. Once I discovered this, it was really fun to plan where to build ziplines for optimum travel times and distances. Game also picked up the pace immensely story wise after Chapter 6 / 7, so that was really good as well. 

Yet, unfortunately my other complaints still remain about the game. Let's just hope they will fix and improve their annoying stuff in 2nd game, bc this was genuinely a good story.

Once, there was an explosion…an explosion which gave birth to time and space.
 Once, there was an explosion…a bang which sent a planet spinning in that space.
 Once, there was an explosion…a bang which gave rise to life as we know it.
 Once, there was an explosion…and it was our last.

Calling Death Stranding a 'walking simulator' is the biggest understatement you could possibly make about Hideo Kojima's latest masterpiece. Of course, most of your time will be spent traversing behemoth landscapes - you will walk, run, and jog across varying biomes and terrain, as well as wade through rivers and snow-capped mountains. For the entirety of it's length, you will be hauling bigger, and more fragile cargo through bigger, and badder landscapes littered with apocalyptic threats - such as: hoarding-obsessed bandits, terrorists, supernatural entities, and time accelerating rain - all the while increasing the efficiency of your deliveries using strategic routing, available tools, and co-operation with other players.

While 'walking' may be part of the core of Death Stranding, your motivation to deliver in the first place is what elevates it above many other games I've played before. What ties the experience together, as simple as it sounds, is making connections. The more you deliver cargo, forging bonds as you go, the more tangible rewards you receive and the easier it becomes as more player structures will appear to aid you, making journeys safer and most crucially, more efficient - in this way, you are quite literally connecting people together. This contextual link between the superbly addicting gameplay loop and Kojima's enthralling, detail-rich, storytelling is what makes Death Stranding not only one of the most immersive entertaining experiences money can buy, but the result of what I can only describe as another genre-defying stroke of genius by Kojima and his team.

TLDR? Let me be clear, this is not a 'walking simulator' - even if movement is simulated to an extent that it alone could carry an entire game - it is a cinematic, post apocalyptic, multi-genre masterpiece featuring, of course, walking, all the thrills I've already described, and so much more. Don't let anything hold you back and do yourself a favour - buy this game.

DS is possibly the greatest video game that I can't recommend to people, well I do (obviously) but only to certain types of people. If you enjoy games with a slow burn story that unravels itself over the course of many hours, then this game is for you. If you appreciate games with such intricate game and level design that the tiniest rock can throw you of off your balance then this game is for you. And if you enjoy spending hours and hours walking around and planning travel routes, then this game is for you. 

[h3]Game-play & Design[/h3]
This might be DS's strongest and weakest selling point, because it is so intricately crafted it's actually pretty amazing how they managed to incorporate so many features into one game. Like I mentioned previously, the slightest rock or elevation has the potential to throw you off your balance which requires you think more cautiously on how and where you traverse, even how you set up your cargo load can affect your centre of mass. The game has really thought about its balancing elements in its game design, for example, you can build trikes and trucks to travel throughout the land. However, most areas have such uneven terrains that trying to use such vehicles becomes often becomes difficult to handle, pretty much forcing you to walk to most of your destinations. Their is a fast travel system but the catch is you can't bring any cargo with you, which again forces you to walk. To some people this might seem frustrating and/or boring to deal with, I thought like this at first but after a while I actually found it to be quite soothing to take in a lot of the landscape and scenery.

Their are a variety of structures that you can make along your journey to help provide more efficient routes of backtracking or tools to help scale large landscapes. once a structure is set up it can also be used by other players online, and vice versa (any structures they make you'll also be able to access), furthering the game's themes of connection. You can even like and music to your structures too. However, you must be aware that after a while these structures may begin to break down due to time-fall and will require maintenance, especially for structures set up in areas with heavy or frequent time-fall. their are also highway's that can be constructed that allow for travelling to be much easier but they require large quantities of materials which can take ages to accrue. Once constructed and other users use the highway's that you built, it can yield ten of thousands of likes to your bridge link profile. facial mapping is highly accurate.

In typical Kojima fashion, the design is catered around the idea of encouraging more peaceful routes to conflict (due to his personal aversion to war and violence) their are lethal and non-lethal weapons within the game, and outside of boss battles, using lethal weapons is discouraged (e.g. when you kill a mule they begin undergo necrosis which attracts BTs) thus you are encouraged to handle most situations as non-lethally as possible.

The only complaints that I have with the game design is that recycling materials can be unnecessarily tedious and the gun-play in this game isn't all that great, most of the weapons sound too quiet and feel as though they don't have any weight to them. The guns themselves are fine in what they do, just wish they'd feel more impactful. Some of the bosses are pretty cool but do get a bit little repetitive after a while. 

[h3]Story & Characters[/h3]
An event known as the Death Stranding has reformed the land of America, to become this allured landscape plagued by ghastly entities known as BTs (Beached Things). You play as Sam Porter Bridges, a lone delivery man, when you're called upon to expand the Chrial Network to connect cities all over America to form the UCA (United Cities of America).  The core theme of DS is about connection and it explores this theme exceedingly well, not just in the literal sense of connecting cities and preppers to join the Chrial Network, but also in the metaphorical sense. Each character in the story that you meet and interact with (even preppers) deal with the matter of connection in some form e.g. Sam Porter has aphenphosmphobia (the fear of being touched) as a result he doesn't connect with anyone, no friends, even family is strained, it isn't until he encounters BB (a Bridge Baby, connecting the world of the living and the dead), over the course of the story, as he encounters more people along with the struggles that they go through, and spends more time with BB, he begins to slowly become more receptive to the people who wish to connect with him. 

Their are quiet a few antagonists and morally grey characters interwoven within the story with plenty of twists and turns, BTs aren't the only thing that poses a threat to humanity. A terrorist cell group called the Homo Demens, have caused a series of void out explosions, lead by the intimidating and all powerful Higgs (named after the God particle). I could say more but then'll be encroaching spoiler territory. 

The story may seem at first glance to be convoluted, but when you actually think about the plot threads and start to connect the dots it actually makes perfect sense. It manages to introduce so many story elements that culminate to form a complex yet somehow cohesive story, it explores its themes of connection extremely well. It may be a slow burn story (then again I like those) but it has some amazing and rewarding emotional payoffs that makes it well worth trudging through hours of walking from place to place. Seeing all of these characters with such deep backstories being unfurled with such care and craft is nothing short of amazing.

The only complaints I'd have about the story would only be nitpicks, and even then it might only be how a scene is presented. Or without getting too much into spoilers there is one section where you are given the illusion of choice (where it acts like you have a choice to make but really it only ends one way). Another nitpick is that doing side or orders that aren't relevant to the story have no impact on how the story plays out (seems like a bit of missed opportunity). aside from that the story is emotionally powerful and quite thought provoking about its perspective on the human condition

The dialogue is great and impactful, for the most part. There are a hand full of lines that sound like something you'd see on r/im14andthisdeep, but when you have so much dialogue they can't all be winners. 

[h3]The World of Death Stranding[/h3]
The maps in DS are massive, as this is a game where you primarily deliver packages to people this means lots and lots of travelling. Travelling over obstacles, travelling through BT infested areas, travelling through cargo mule territories, etc. with all sorts of different, well laid out terrains and environments, with many ways to approach them.

When I first played DS, I only played about 5-7 hours of the game and stopped, initially I thought it was boring, pretentious and not worth my time. This was back in 2019, my life had changed considerably since then. One day I bought DS on sale and I'd decided actually give it a fair chance. Doing so has allowed me discover that I was wrong to dismiss such a game on ill thought-out bad impressions, and it might be one of the most personal gaming experiences I've ever had. 

[b]Ratings[/b]

+ Fantastic story
+ Great cinematic cutscenes
+ Characters with lots of depth 
+ Great soundtrack
+ Intricately detailed game design
+ Nice graphics & accurate facial mapping
+ relaxing (to me at least :P)
+/- Lots of backtracking
+/- Not too many order type varieties
+/- Bosses are cool but a little repetitive 
- Gun-play is a little lacklustre

Started playing this game a little over a week ago on the retail version that was gifted to me on release. At about 15 hours, I purchased the DC upgrade. One of the biggest regrets, after nearly 100 hours in this game, was that I had never played it sooner.

The game does start slow but I assure you that once you've made it past the onboarding phase, things open up and catapult this game into allstardom.

This game is one of the best multi-layered tales of our time. The lore is deep and enriched by the data you collect through the game. The end of the game is satisfying and leaves you wanting more - not out of a lack of fulfilment, but because you want more Sam and BB against the world. There are highs, lows, tension, horror, drama and incredible action moments which kick the adrenaline into high-gear and have a great payoff once completed.

The acting is top-notch - all the talents that Kojima is working alongside brought their A-game and every main performance served the story. I have a lot of love for some of these characters who have shared a variety of moments with Sam on my journey.

The environments are gorgeous and varied and these contrast so well with the tense moments. We are offered awe-striking moments of beautiful scenery accompanied by one of the most well-curated and designed soundtracks of our time.

The game is paced with you. If you want to slog and complete all the side objectives to make your latter-game experience a bit easier, go ahead. If you don't want to spend a mountain of hours to get through the campaign, you can do that as well - although you'll have a bit of a tougher time with some routes or unlocks not on your side.

I'm taking the time to write this for the few of you who are wondering what to expect... and it's hard to explain this game to somebody out of the blue - but you won't have an experience quite like this one. You are, essentially, controlling your own action movie. Like Infamous, The Last of Us or Uncharted - it really takes you through a journey... you just need to get through those first 3 Acts to make the game really open up and unlock flexibility.

But by the end, you'll have experienced something that I believe anybody who loves story-driven games absolutely should.
Its one of those games where love it, hate it, or think its OK.

DS is slowly becoming my all time favorite game. It is hard to truly recommend because you will either love it, or hate it (I'm 8 hours in and according to achievements, 50% of players never made it that "far").

Some people may find the game boring, but it's all about your approach to the game - not every game has to be a frenetic action 24/7.

Pros:

+ Art design is absolutely insane and really fresh. Every little detail seems incredibly original. 

+ Gameplay is incredibly meditative and tranquil. I could spend hours just walking and admiring the vistas. Also it is definitely not just walking simulator. 

There are various enemies and threats, stealth, weapons, vehicles, tools and much more.

+ Visually the game is stunning and timeless.

+ UI is very thought out and controls are flawless, everything works just perfect.

+ Story is very convoluted until it's slowly not, feels very rewarding to uncover.

Cons:

- The amount of new stuff the game throws at you can be a little overwhelming at times.

- Vehicle physics and controls are sometimes a little janky, (but still enjoyable).

- Loading is sometimes a little longer than I'm used to from other games (over a minute on nvme ssd).

Fun

Fantastic game, I put more hours into it than I expected. 55 or so before game completion. 

Fluid movement, decent story, good music, good combat if you take the time to learn it, and beautiful graphics.

My main complaints for the game is twofold: One, there are many optional mechanics that aren't given to you early enough. For example, you don't unlock the ability to customize your clothes until end-game.

And also, once you get over the initial fear of falling, you realize traversing the map is just too easy. Things like ladders, grappling hooks, etc; are completely optional, and are generally much slower than simply climbing up or down the side of a mountain. There are countless footholds, and you can just hold both triggers, and hold x, and you'll climb up nearly anything with very little risk of falling. Any deep river can casually be driven through with any truck. And 99% of rivers can be jumped over the moment you have robotic legs. 

The moment I realized this, it took away a very considerable amount of the enjoyment the game had to offer.

But it all comes together at the end, and it delivers a surprisingly damn good story.

It was always inevitable, considering game designer Hideo Kojima’s cinephile tendencies, that Death Stranding would get a director’s cut. What’s surprising about this revised PlayStation 5 version of the game is that it doesn’t involve hours of extra cinematic sequences that were cut from the original. Thank goodness. Instead, it’s a thoughtful, thorough and visually arresting enhancement of the game, with interesting and sometimes amusing new features.

It still remains the mystical, artful and gloriously pretentious delivery sim it always was: you play apocalyptic postman, Sam, attempting to revive an America torn apart by a supernatural explosion that annihilated the barrier between life and the afterlife. Working for a sort of idealistic version of DHL, he must deliver packages to cities across the country, hooking the residents up to a quasi-spiritual version of the internet as he goes. But haunting him at every step are the BTs – horrible semi-invisible monsters that represent the trapped souls of the dead. The only way Sam can see these things coming is via the foetus he carries everywhere with him in a glass incubator, which requires constant care and pacification. Amid all the dialogue about hope, belief and mortality, Death Stranding is really a game about how difficult it is to get out and about when you have a baby.
alleys, over moss-covered rocks and through babbling streams, it’s like being in your own Andrei Tarkovsky movie – the silence, the tension, the geologically precise scenery bathed in deadening blue-grey light. Add in the excellent support for which places the natural sounds far outside the whirs and clicks of Sam’s technology, and this is now a world that envelops you in its peculiar sadness.

Enhancing this greater sense of immersion is the Dual Sense controller support. The adaptive triggers put up much more of a fight when Sam is overloaded with cargo, giving you a physical sense of his struggle to stay upright. At the same time, the pad’s haptic feedback provides a tremor every time you take a heavy step, accentuating your physical contact with the earth. This effect is greatly exaggerated when under duress: say, when you’re trying to regain your composure after jogging down a hill with way too many metal boxes on your back.

There are few games where I can say without a doubt, have had an effect on me to the level of this game. I initially downloaded the original game years back as a joke because it looked like just a delivery simulator in a sci-fi post-apocalyptic world. It didn't take me more than 5 minutes to realize I fallen through a hole into another dimension of horror, wonder, and mystery.

The core gameplay of this game is getting needed packages from A to B, dealing with finding a safe path that won't have you ending up dropping the crates and damaging them. As you connect more places together you will see other players warning signs, infrastructure, paths, vehicles, and buildings. Though, you won't have to deal with players directly. This allows for a community without a community in a way. Sometimes someone has put a bridge in just a right spot and everyone likes it. Sometimes you find a way through and other follow your footsteps. Everyone is in it together trying to get their packages delivered and the asynchronous cooperation is done masterfully well.

The story is absolutely amazing and every turn only adds one more piece to the puzzle. I won't go into it here but what a journey. I tell everyone do not miss out on experiencing this game.

Very addictive and compelling gameplay, and if you do certain missions youll even get Jonny silver hands hand and bike, John Freemans halflife truck and a few other fun things. so many differnt ways to play the game too.

I recommend this 9/10 is now in my top 10 list of all time!

[h1][b]preface[/b][/h1]
[h3]For those just interested in basic game details, please skip to the review proper as this section makes reference to my experiences with the game more broadly, and therefore [strike][i]may[/i][/strike] contain[b]s[/b] too much information for someone who has not played.[/h3]

I played Death Stranding for the first time shortly after it came out, got about 40 hours into the game casually before life happened and I had to sell my PS4, but it left an impression from trailers enough for me to buy it in the first place, and the gameplay was fun enough to want it again.

The Steam release found me finishing the game with a fondness for its systems and as tight a grasp on the story as the sea of cutscenes I had just waded through could give me, but I felt slightly cheated by the really interesting cinematics leading up to release. [spoiler]I hadn't played a Kojima game before.[/spoiler] Still, this left me enjoying the game enough that I started another playthrough before the Director's Cut was announced, which I then put on hold just after what I would consider to be the tutorial area so I could pick up at release where I had left off.

I first approached playing the director's cut like it was DLC, importing my lightly used save file before very quickly realizing things had been added even early on, so I restarted with the mission to max out every connection before moving on past an area so I could more easily make myself get every star. Had I known I would go on to finish every achievement, I may have instead opted to save myself a few dozen hours and just rush through the story to simplify cleaning up, but I find stopping to smell the roses in this game is extremely rewarding to me personally, and this more deliberate playstyle gave me a deeper perspective on the different tiers of play.

Prior to this final playthrough I racked up ~150 hours in the base game, and at time of review I have now clocked another 150. I don't think it is very likely that I will be playing again anytime soon to do anything other than to get LLL on my remaining couple hundred deliveries, though I may start taking on ranked missions as well. Here's hoping DS2 sees an early PC release.

[hr][/hr]

[h1][b]review[/b][/h1]
[h2]death stranding[/h2]
[list]
[*] [h3][i]story[/i][/h3]
[b]7/10[/b]
[/list]
You are Sam Porter Bridges, "America's Last Hope" in reconnecting after an apocalyptic event known as the Death Stranding occured. Planes no longer fly, radio waves no longer travel nearly as far, and death waits around every corner for us all. Rain is now deadly, and ghosts are capable of turning a body into an antimatter bomb if they catch you. You must navigate the landscapes and ruins of the (quaintly scaled) continental United States as you cross the country to piece it all back together.
Core themes include [b]connection[/b], [b]loss[/b], [b]trust/truth[/b], [b]identity[/b], and [b]death[/b].

I encourage anyone interested in understanding the story to read every in game interview you come across, as many of the best details are hidden here behind the somewhat nonsensical cutscenes.

[list]
[*] [h3][i]visuals[/i][/h3]
[b]8.5/10[/b]
[/list]
Overall very cohesive and pretty photorealistic style, good use of colors, and well detailed landscapes. Early portions of the game can look a bit ugly and sparse, and many areas are not populated by many objects other than rocks and the occasional sign of plant life. Pop in present during raised driving sections but not problematic or noticable in other situations. Occasional flickering/shimmering of distant objects makes it hard for me to tell if there is a visual glitch or just a feature. Very few obvious model/terrain errors. Some niche animations seem to have been left unpolished [spoiler](such as Sam's face while singing in the bath)[/spoiler], however the game is beautifully rendered otherwise.

[list]
[*] [h3][i]audio[/i][/h3]
[b]9.5/10[/b]
[/list]
Both ambient audio and music are on point, the soundtrack is one of the game's strongest features. Sounds of walking on different terrain, moving machinery, and weapons all feel good. Many moments in the game are scored based on what's happening, but silence will accompany most of your journey. Soundtrack pieces play at key moments and lend greatly to atmosphere. Voice work ranges from servicable to spectacular. Seriously, just listen to the soundtrack.

[list]
[*] [h3][i]gameplay[/i][/h3]
[b]9/10[/b]
[/list]
[h3]controller recommended[/h3] 

Take on a variety of orders to fetch and deliver thousands of packages across a wasteland. As you progress through more deliveries, more materials and upgrades like weapons for dealing enemies, and tools to ease your future traversal become available. Developing routes through challenging areas and adapting to sometimes changing conditions will see you through to completing larger and more complex deliveries.

Locomotion is the point of it all, you must maintain Sam's balance while protecting your cargo from the elements, enemy humans, and most importantly the ghosts that haunt all the edges of your paths and some spaces in between. Some light resource and energy management is required to progress, which can take a toll with all the menuing required.

At some point the game will require you to engage with gun combat, though nonlethal measures should always be fully explored as a dead body can leave you with more trouble than you started with. I recommend attempting to remain in stealth or avoid most overworld combat encounters unless you plan to clear an area out for a while. The ghosts can present a frustrating challenge for some beginners but become mostly trivial speed bumps around midway through the game. 

Death Stranding always leaves me wanting to complete one last haul over and over. Its a very satisfying core loop that rewards planning, building up infrastructure, and engaging with all its systems.

[hr][/hr]

[h2][b]on upgrading to director's cut[/b][/h2]
For those who have played the base game and feel satisfied, this is not a necessary purchase. There is nothing fundamentally transformative from the game you have experienced, though if you would like to play through again I don't recommend against an upgrade if that option is available to you. You will have access to a few new and variant items and overall improved combat experience, a couple new locations and activities, a robust photo mode, and DualSense support. Added context for several characters doesn't go amiss. Overall the combat feel is quite substantially improved, and the added training mode provides fun scenarios to try out each new weapon and help onboard new players to the challenges they will be facing in a low-risk scenario. These are nice touches on an already strong work, but may not be compelling enough to recommend an additional purchase.

[h2][b]a short case for DualSense[/b][/h2]
Playing through these last 100 or so hours on my PS5 controller has been a wonderful experience, and its all thanks to the adaptive triggers. The effect of having Sam grasping a cumbersome load translate to varying levels of added trigger resistance, and the snappy feeling of firing off shots with some weapons or binding an enemy with your strand is very satisfying and harmonizes with gameplay. I don't recommend going out and buying one just for this, but if you have one to hand its my preference.

A meditation on the loneliness of modern life and the impact social media has on it, told through the medium of post-apocalyptic parcel delivery, featuring babies in jars, inter dimensional ghost whales which can cause nuclear explosions, a chat show host, the Doritos guy and several Hollywood directors. 

None of the allegory is at all subtle, but there are depths to the metaphors. It's obviously the work of an auteur, and it's a game that *remembers* that it's a game, and never fails to remind the player - this isn't the faux-cinema of so many other prestige titles, this is very much a video game with strong story-telling, although your tolerance for Kojima-isms will inevitably impact your enjoyment of that. 
 
It's a game I can't recommend highly enough.

I cannot tell you why this game is fun. It really feels like it shouldn't be. Some of the details are absolutely ridiculous. You're a big tough guy courier and you have to carry a baby around in a jar on your chest. If you fall down (and you will) your baby -- sorry, your "B.B," -- cries and you have to comfort it. My god, that sound. No game should ever include the sound of a crying baby, ever. 

Brief aside: Listening to Mads Mikkelsen say "B.B." over and over is bizarre and hilarious.

All the same, this game is fun, immersive, interesting, complicated, and very weird. It's also very pretty, atmospheric, entertaining, and... did I already say weird? I did. it's weird. Like, Japanese anime strangeness weird. There's a whole lot of spacey-wacey timey-wimey nonsense, that you can sort of pretend to listen to and understand. But it's not super important.

At the two hour mark, I almost quit the game. A long walk got me lost in the mountains and I had to walk all the way back where I came from. But I gritted my teeth and carried on. Now I've been playing for 13 hours, and I have to admit I am in for the long haul.

Buy it. Stick with it. You'll get sucked in and wonder why the hell you got sucked in.

I love this game. It's Kojima weird. I appreciate Kojima weird. It looks great and it plays great. I can't recommend the game, though.

As I age, I have come to the understanding that I just don't have time for something like this. Some things are worth doing and I don't believe that spending 40+ hours in this game is worth my time. 

Instead of playing 40+ hours I watched a 22 minute video on Youtube by Playstation Grenade that summarizes the game.

If you're looking for chill scenery to take your time in, this game has that. If you're looking for tense moments with spooky ghosts, this game has that. If you're looking for the occasional stealth-focused combat, this game has that. If you like navigating and exploring frontiers, this game has that. If you want deep introspective sci-fi storytelling, this game has that. If you want dumb videogame-y bull****, this game has that. If you want to say, "I know that guy!" this game has that.

If you want the performances to make you feel something, this game has that.
If you want to feel triumph from figuratively and literally conquering a mountain, this game has that.
If you want to pee, this game has that.

I'd buy it full price, you should at least get it on sale. There really is nothing else like it.

I recommend this game if you like games where you go on a journey trekking across landscapes, it's actually a new type of platformer game where navigating the environment is the challenge.
[b]THIS GAME IS CHALLENGING[/b], yes it is a [i]literally a walking simulator[/i] but you can trip, slide, fall and drown and that's assuming you don't encounter enemies.
You have a full arsenal of weapons and your going to need them, it's absolutely a third person shooter.
Good story with some impresive acting but don't overdo it with side quests or else you will ruin the pacing and [b]DO NOT USE VEHICLES[/b] they make the game trivial and the music does not sync with them (not a bug).

You need to plan your route, bring ladders and climbing equipment and other supplies in order to arrive at the destination with your entire cargo.
As you play you can leave behind structures to aid your current or next journey as you make your way thru very large open spaces.
It features the most complex landscape to navigate in a game maybe not in vastness but in details.

I'm not sure I can really come up with the right words to do this game justice. I initially bought this game on PS4 when it was first released. Like most people, I had no idea what I was getting into at the time, but by the time I completed my first play through, it turned out to be one of the most positive and moving experiences I've ever gotten from a video game (no really, I was actually moved by it.)

"Walking Simulator" is a really bad description, and this must have been coined by people who didn't actually play it, or only played the first few hours (or heard it from an influencer who only played the first few hours.) Sure, there's a lot of walking - at first. It isn't long before you start unlocking vehicles, though. Also, I found the walking bits to be extremely enjoyable either way. Often times, the mission is all about the journey and less about the destination. 

The general theme of this game is making connections. It's a lonely world out there, and everyone's separated and living in bunkers. You're tasked with making deliveries and essentially hooking up their version of the internet. The world is broken, and you're bringing it together. 

A neat aspect of this game is that it has an online connection, but you never directly interact with other players. Instead, you'll come across things they've left behind. A rope, a ladder, perhaps a bridge or a shelter. You can leave things behind to help the next player along. Cross the same area a few times, and you'll leave a path for the next player to follow. The world is lonely, but these things show that you're not truly on your own out there. I find it very beautiful, actually. 

You'll learn a lot of terms that definitely won't make a lot of sense at first, but after awhile it starts to click. I found the story to be very unique and interesting, and the more I learned about what the "Death Stranding" is and the effects it has on the world, the more I was intrigued. It even has a very cool take on death itself and what it means, and for some characters, death is only temporary. 

Speaking of death, this game is very unique in the way that it discourages you from killing any living person. The game pushes you to tie them down, knock them out, or otherwise use various non-lethal means to incapacitate the human enemies. It doesn't actually stop you from killing, but it very strongly discourages you from doing so, and in the event that it does happen, you'll have to deal with the body (and a very upset baby in a jar.) In most cases, you'll probably make it through the entire game without killing a single person. If you're looking for a big shoot-'em-up game, this ain't it.

Another type of enemy you'll encounter are the non-living ghost-like entities called "beached things" or "BTs." Why are they called that? Well, beaches are a common theme in the lore of this world and are connected to death. It's explained pretty heavily during the game, but basically every person has a beach that they go to when they die, and these "beached things" have crossed into the world of the living. If you move quietly, you can often slip right by them without them noticing you, with the help of your "bridge baby" or "BB" (or as some refer to as the "funky fetus.") However, it can still be hard to get by them at times, so if you are noticed, all hell breaks loose and you'll be in for a spooky fight. 

Also, I can't help but mention how BEAUTIFUL the world is. It's supposed to take place in the U.S., but you won't actually see any real U.S. landmarks or anything. A lot of it looks like Iceland, really. Either way, I loved exploring the world. Some of my favorite parts were those long journeys where you're not actually in any enemy territory, and a nice song from bands like Low Roar is playing. It was easy to just kick back, relax, and enjoy the views. 

The story has a lot of twists and turns, and a lot of it won't make any damn sense at first. Once you start to "get it", it's very beautiful. If you're not into story-driven games, or not interested in stories that make you think, you probably won't like this game. However, if that is your jam, prepare for an emotional rollercoaster of epic proportions. 

There's also no shortage of cool stuff you can do in this game. Want to build a zipline from one mountain peak to another? Go for it! Want to build a sick jump to ride your motorcycle off of? Hell yeah! Want to make your journey more efficient and build an entire freaking highway? Get those building materials and pave away! Want to take a piss on a rock and make a mushroom grow out of it? Yeah, you can actually do that! The possibilities are endless. 

I still feel like this review has barely scratched the surface of what this game is truly all about. I can't overstate enough about how much of a positive feel-good experience this game actually is. Kojima and his team have truly created a unique, beautiful masterpiece, and it has easily become one of my favorite games of all time. I loved it so much, that I bought it again on Steam. 

Also, if you happen to own this game, you should definitely play it on your birthday. You'll see why. ;)

I used to be a fan of Hideo Kojima, used to be anyway, when he was working on metal gear solid he was a super star, he had a great franchise there, but that was before konami screwed him over. I understand he's trying to reclaim his glory days by coming out with new games and new franchises, but this one really just didn't hit the mark.

Death stranding isn't really an awful game, but it's not exactly an amazing game either.

The only positive thing I can really say about this game is that it plays really smooth, it has some of the best optimization in a game I've seen to date lately. But that alone doesn't excuse the egregious nature of it's story, It's pretentious and dumb, and the worst part about it is the kojima-ism's really come into full force here. Had the game had more engaging gameplay to entertain me apart from the bad story, I wouldn't have minded so much.

Seriously who thought naming a character Die-hard-man, or dead-man, or momma, was a good idea? I mean, I know there were some ridiculous ones in MGS but it's just full force here.

The game really becomes a slog at the end, once you hit the mountain region it just goes downhill from there. It left me wanting the game to just be over with, which is really bad, generally if a game is alright, I always have a feeling to come back for more, but for some reason with this game, I just couldn't fathom playing it anymore, but like a trainwreck I had to sit here and see it through to the end.

Honestly kojima, I hate to say this, but with MGS dead I'm afraid you may just be slowly sinking into irrelevancy.

What a breath of fresh air.  Hideo Kojima has created an original IP that has the creativity and daring to be different that channels the best games of the 90's and early 2000's.

The story is layered and intriguing, revealing information and twists and turns, and finally tie's up all upon its conclusion.  The game play equally so.  As you progress throughout your journey, new mechanics, modes of travel and equipment is unlocked at just the right pace to keep your interest.  The sharing of structures and equipment with the community aids in this process, giving you a genuine feeling of progress and a desire to build and share to be apart of the greater game.

Death Stranding comes in a time where most of the AAA space is populated with sequels and derivatives of the same tired old types of games.  The creativity of the gaming market is so much less now that what is was.  This game has the courage to be different, to be creative.  To try something new.  I respect Kojima and the creative team for their courage to make this game and highly recommend it.

After watching the haunting, bizarre and fascinating trailers for this game, that stormed the internet back in 2016-2017 (!!!), I was eager to finally play it, and lift the veil on the mistery of Sam Porter Bridges and the world of Death Stranding.

After playing the game through to completion, my experience has been a wildly mixed one, with a few (very high) highs, and many (miserably low) lows.

I guess that, if you are the famous and self-proclaimed "genius" Hideo Kojima, you can't settle for a believable story, or provide a simple yet viable game experience: you have to go all-in, no prisoners taken.

The unfortunate result of such uncompromising approach is a gargantuan pastiche, that tries to be a brilliant and clever concoction of videogame and movie, but ends up steering too far away from both the interactive and appeasing nature of videogames, and the narratively rich and concise nature of movies.

What little gameplay is provided is tedious, unimaginative and frustrating, and the cinematic sequences are repetitive, boring, overly drawn-out and without any sense of measure or direction.

Scenarios, albeit vast and believable, are painfully devoid of any meaningful landmark, and end up feeling empty and look-alike.

The main themes of the game are stated over and over and over, and what should constitute a canvas of human feelings and hopes, in the form of e-mails and dialogues, ends up being tedious, scholastic and repetitive to the point of making everything seem like it's been written by the same person.

The interface pays the heavy price of having being designed with a PS4 controller in mind: everything that pertains the cargo management screams "drag&drop with a mouse", but the player is instead forced to fight with an unintuitive sequence of "press a"/"hold a"/"press random button" that NEVER becomes natural, even after many many hours of "gameplay".

It's a pity because presentation is stellar: lightning, textures, animations, motion capture, voice dubbing, sound effects... everything is excellent, and really conveys a sense of credibility to the audio/visual elements of the experience.

Also, physics are magistrally implemented: every inch of terrain interacts with Sam and his cargo in a believable way... it's easy to completely forget that this is a videogame, and concentrate on bringing that damn cargo to it's destination, no matter how many arbitrary wrenches the game throws at the player to obstruct their progression.

All in all, it feels like there's an insanely talented team behind this game... I just hope that they will get to work on something better and more focused in the future.

Every time I revisit this game, I like it a bit more.  To me, that's the sign of a truly amazing game.

It's a bit slower paced, almost meditative at time.  You'll trudge through marshes and rivers and over mountains to deliver stuff.  Then, right when it starts to feel like you'll never make it, you see your destination in the distance.  This game captures that feeling of hiking when you're nearing the top and you see the first view out over the mountain you just hiked up.

Also, the multiplayer aspect is great.  It's worthwhile to build a lot of stuff to help yourself out, but it feels so much better when you get a message that someone else used your bridge or your road.  Someone else was struggling over the mountain and found shelter in something you built.  It makes you want to go out and build stuff up to help people out more.

Game's good. It's loosely community based, and you do see the fruits of everyone's labor by way of structures being built around you as you play and progress. Controls are slightly difficult without being overwhelming. Sound design is so amazingly crisp and hard hitting. The storyline is good with some good twists and suspenseful moments. Don't let the "mailman" gimmick fool you; there's guns, grenades, and melee weapons. It's definitely worth having in your collection.

The vibe of Death Stranding is truly unlike other game. Norman Reedus as a post apocalyptic mail man fighting ghosts and bandits while trying to reconnect people across America is something wonderfully unique. The game play loop is way more addicting than I thought and the story kept me on the hook for most of the game. I must say that the dialogue was not the best and even though the concept of what the game conveys is very interesting, the deployment of it was lack luster. Even so the game is a 9/10 which goes to prove how good the game play loop truly is.
Don't listen to other people's reviews. Give it a shot; you might just fall in love like I did.

After stalling for a good while I decided to play this one.
Being a Kojima fan I thought I was ready for what was coming, and boy, was I wrong.

30 minutes in and I am fully invested in the plot and mechanics, embrancing the full scope of the experience. That for itself is a compliment. Currently I am trying to max rank all my clients before moving on with the plot, thats how invested I am in this narrative and in the world that entails this game.

With that said I can tell you that Death Stranding is an enjoyable experience on its own. Play it with an open mind, and never forget  that you arent alone in this harsh world.
