This game is amazing.  It has problems, but for me they are not the same problems I see echoed frequently online.  Yes, it's a walking sim in the most literal sense but that is also as reductive as you can possible be.  It's a Kojima-directed post-apocalyptic paranormal sci-fi open-world mission-based hiking sim.

First, there is a solid gameplay loop here, consisting of accepting delivery missions, loading up with cargo and tools, and hiking to your destinations.  If you have played MGSV, many of the controls and mechanics will feel familiar to you, but combat and stealth are de-emphasized, while traversal and problem solving take center stage.  That's not to say there is no combat; it is less common but what's there is suprisingly deep and well integrated with the game's cargo system.  Using loose cargo as a melee or ranged weapon is not only possible, but encouraged.

Missions can become repetitive late game, especially if you choose to 100% it and I think that could have been easily fixed by having fewer missions or more variety.  This problem is exacerbated by roads and ziplines which are useful but completely trivialize most deliveries once you have put some resources into them.  While it feels good to knock out 5 contracts at once with a fully loaded truck, it has the unintended consequence of optimizing the gameplay right out of the game, leaving....I don't know.  The satisfaction of a job well done?  By contrast the early missions embrace a slower pace that makes every obstacle feel significant and every rope and ladder feel like an accomplishment.  Navigating a mountain or river with the simple tools at your disposal feels uniquely satisfying.

The open world map is beautiful with a wide variety of terrain to navigate.  My only issue with this is that the map is broken into several disconnected parts, which makes each area feel small and the game gives no incentive to revisit earlier areas once you've left them.

Sadly the director's cut is not really what I would expect from a director's cut, so if the core game is cheaper I recommend it.  You won't miss out on a single story beat or new cutscene as far as I noticed.  There are only a couple new craftable tools which I rarely used on my 100% run, if ever.

The story is often a sticking point and I've seen it described online as messy and nonsensical.  It is definitely what we have come to expect from Kojima over the years but moreso.  Kojima's stories are generally theme-heavy but Death Stranding's story ONLY makes sense through the lens of its themes.  In other words, it's ALL theme man.  Every tool, character, game mechanic, and plot point engages with the themes established early on: connection, relationships, and binding; isolation, separation, and death.  If something in the story seems not to make sense, I encourage you to ask yourself if it serves the theme, and the answer is almost certainly yes.  Is it weird? Most definitely but have you played Metal Gear Solid?!

All that to say, I love this game.  It's not perfect but it tries a lot of new things and takes some big swings.  I hope we keep seeing new and interesting things from Kojima because that's why I go for his games.  I think too many people forget that Metal Gear Solid became popular for being innovative and not just by being a good stealth/action game.

After beating this game i just want to say that this is a significantly different game compared to others i have played, it has been awhile since i was gripped by a story to the verge of tearing up towards it's end and kept me invested as i continued my westward journey across America, here are my pros and cons

Pros:
+ Gripping and Unique Story
+ Fun combat/stealth with many unique approaches that you can unlock as you progress
+ Addicting gameplay loop with a very in depth carrying system
+ Atmospheric world and breathtaking environments
+ Online elements are very rewarding and makes you feel satisfied that what you do helps others in their playthroughs 
+ Stunning and immersive soundtrack (Seriously! At least listen to it on Spotify/Youtube if you get the chance)
+ Some amazing performances in game (including one involving Tommie Earl Jenkins)
Cons:
- Frustrating off-road physics with vehicles
- certain scenes with awkward dialogue
- not enough of involvement between Sam and other characters in cutscenes

Although this may not be everything i can praise/criticize the game it was an overall 10/10 for me and i highly recommend it to those that want a different gaming experience or to those that enjoy Kojima's other works such as Silent Hill, or Metal Gear Solid.

I don't usually post negative reviews, but I just couldn't get into this game at all. I kept waiting for it to get good, but it just never clicked.  I'm not saying it is a bad game, but I just don't get it and I couldn't enjoy it. 

I found the game play loop to be extremely boring. The world was uninteresting, I didn't care about anybody, and the game kept throwing new terms and concepts (timefall, BBs, BTs, Chiral network, etc.) and none of it made sense.

This is a game I put off playing for 4 years because I didn't "get it" at launch.  The game-play loop presented to you in the first couple of hours was not something I felt I wanted to put time into to see if it got more enjoyable. After hearing nothing but good things about this game as it has aged, I finally sat myself down in '23 and and forced myself though the first 5 hours. 

Maybe it was the pandemic? Or something relating to a rather hectic work/life balance I had finally escaped after 7 years, but being able to *build* connections in a desolate world finally resonated with me. There is a real sense of accomplishment watching the world take shape around you as you make connections between extremely isolated cities and individuals. You are also continually rewarded with better skills and items that enable greater efficiency in making these connections. You truly feel like you are making a difference in the world and in turn, it is making a difference to you.

Yes, it has all the Kojima trappings, and yes he is way too far up his own ass - Hell, there is a 1 hour cut-scene about why a guy has a heart shaped heart - But you will eat it all up. Much like literature and cinema epics, a significant number of story beats happen well after the major conflict is resolved (hilariously, most of them after the end credits roll), but by then you will be so involved in the world's story and your band of Kojima freaks, that you probably wont mind the chaotic editing of this game.  

After 4 years of avoidance, I can now say that this is one of my favourite games, and might even be considered an all-time classic. Hell, it might even be something that is important.

The introduction into this game is likely alienating to a lot of players due to there being minimal player input, and lots of exposition about the world and general plot for the first 45 minutes to an hour. But, once the controls are finally given the player this game is a good time.

It is fairly unconventional in both story and game play. 

The story is not directly about fighting a form of tyranny or tracking down a villain, but reconnecting America and bringing divided communities back together. This in combination with the trauma's of the players character that are revealed over time sets up for a story that is both inspiring, and wholesome.

The game play will have you delivering packages from point A to point B, which on it's face sounds very mundane. But, in practice is an engaging experience that you can't quite find anywhere else to the best of my knowledge. The terrain is a constant obstacle and a force to be reckoned with at nearly every moment. It engages a primal part of your brain, like a cave man wandering his domain looking for the best path forward. That is until you connect your point B to your point A via the Chiral Network, a abstract version of a WAN that is operated using other worldly forces. Once the network is back online for the individual area, you can then start to see the traces of other players on their own journey's through America. This leads to a pseudo co operative experience that is somewhat similar to the Dark Souls series. Leaving warning signs, or words of encouragement via messages left on the ground. Building bridges over rivers, leaving ladders climbing up mountains, or setting up climbing ropes to scale down them. These are a few things that you can do that will not only have an effect in your world, but other players worlds as well. Thanks to these mechanics it makes this otherwise lonely world feel a lot less lonely. 

This game ushers out of you the want and desire to connect to other people, so not only are you experiencing these thoughts and concepts when consuming the story, you are also feeding off of those same emotions when delivering your packages. This is a wonderful design and I don't think I have ever seen anything like it.

Metal Gear Solid 6: the Walking Pain

A misunderstood, expertly directed masterpiece. While not without flaws, like the occasionally horrendous dialogue and taking explanations too seriously for its pseudoscience nature, it is generally an eye opening experience that attempts to challenge numerous tropes and assumptions of the industry.

If you hated on this game without ever playing it, you truly do not know what you are missing. Played it first on the PS4 at launch and now I'm replaying it on PC for the Director's Cut and it is fantastic!

After playing through the Metal Gear Solid series, I was excited for this game as Hideo Kojima's first solo outing after the split with Konami. Unique doesn't come close to the originality this game puts forth. The game has slow parts but so do all games with 50+ hour campaigns. The game really picks up once you are able to start crafting gear and items as it gives you the ability to go and explore or just make the world around you easier to traverse. The shared world system was very cool in this game. Other players can craft things like bridges, ladders, and ropes or they can leave things like vehicles and weapons behind for others to utilize. Really awesome feature and it makes the game much more enjoyable. Coming up to a cliff you didn't realize was there, but then looking over to see someone made a way to get down or put signs to guide you to a better path is just one example of how useful this can be.

The story of this game is mesmerizing. With such a unique story I couldn't help but keep playing to find out more about it. If you are at all a fan of Metal Gear Solid or stealth action games, I would highly recommend giving this game a fair chance.

[h1][b]Score: 7/10[/b][/h1]

[b]Summary[/b]
There is not a simple way to classified Death Stranding.
Without going into the lore, you have to deliver things from point A to B. Sometimes you have to retrieve the items from a dangerous place, sometimes the danger is physical, sometimes it is not.
The places that the music triggers is really awesome and gives you a good feeling that it's very rare on nowadays gaming industry.

It took me around 200hours to get all achievements while having fun doing it. I do recommend the game and also I agree that it's love or hate game, but anyway, I recommend at least playing through the second area of the game because a LOT changes after you get a ton of equipment to traverse land.


[b]Goods[/b]
[list]
	[*]After you end the game, you will automatically reload a couple of hours before the "ending events", so you can finish all your achievements (trophies) in one playthrough.
	[*]When you reload after the ending events, you get some extra options, so I recommend leaving to get all achievements after the ending events. After episode [spoiler]15[/spoiler]:D
	[*]Epic boss battles.
	[*]Option to replay Boss battles and compete with other players for a best score on them.
	[*]Dynamic Weather system, where you can check for "rainfall" prediction in a place and avoid it if you need.
	[*]Game physics are great.
[/list]


[b]Bads[/b]
[list]
	[*]Changing difficult doesn't make the game too much challenging when you get used to handling your enemies. Boss fights on the other hand will be a lot harder. So eventually, even on Very Hard, the game feels too easy.
	[*]I like the Day/Night cycle in games and I miss it on Death Stranding
[/list]


[b]Quick Questions / Quick Answers[/b]
[list]
	[*]Can you get all achievements on one playthrough? [b]Yes[/b]
	[*]Does it have guns? [b]YES[/b]
	[*]Is it open world? [b]YES[/b]
	[*]Is there wild animais in the game? [b]No[/b]
	[*]Is there a day/night cycle? [b]No[/b]
[/list]

There are tedious things, but I firmly believe most if not all of them seek to exist to juxtapose how efficient things can be with enough work and cooperation with your fellow players, making that sense of achievement that much greater. If you've been curious, I say pick it up on sale and make up your own opinion. Just be open minded coming into it and it might just be as rewarding for you as it was for me. I tried to like Death Stranding and pushed through last night for over five hours and stayed up until 3am to complete this game, but I didn't. I really wasn't impressed. 

*Spoiler warning ahead*

The story suffers from serious logorrhoea. It makes up its own glossary of words. Beaches, strands, chirlliam (or however it's spelt), Amelie, BBs, ha and ka, and blah blah ad infinitum. It relies on its mailing system to bring context to the events in the world, which visually looked like someone just copied and pasted from Notepad. Characters are thin in their motivation and reasoning, their dialogue insufferably long to explain any concept, and the world's lore feels incongruous to the player as everything is said and repeated without feeling organic. It feels like it heavily relies on its poetic license for why things are the way they are. It assumes the audience is following its longwinded multiple cutscenes and wants what the characters want: a connection. I assumed it was telling me everything I needed to know, but what it was were two confused participants who have no idea what Death Stranding is all about. I felt nothing for any of the characters. I didn't care for any of them or their well-being, including the baby in its orange Fanta jar, and I feel like I'm quite an empathetic person. After all, I've just pumped over 40 hours into this game so that I could be moved. For instance, there's a lot of drama around Die Hardman with why he wears a mask and his adoration for Bridget, but it's weak in its explanation. Yes, he loved her, but where was the seed of emotion for when she died at the beginning? I still don't believe his reasoning for why that's his motivation for wearing a mask. The man isn't even disfigured; which would have been the basic explanation had he felt self-conscious. I felt like I was inside Hideo Kojima's teenage diary, playing with their adolescent imagination and meagre reasoning as if they've just broken up with someone and pouring their emotion out onto a flurry of arbitrary plot points. I grew tired just as Sam Porter as we walked together throughout the entire foothills of this game where I felt he and I were both so exhausted by the meaninglessness of this entire world whereby I was rooting for the Extinction Entity to do us all a favour and wipe everything out. 
What was disappointing was the time it took to tell a story. Hideo Kojima's goes beyond his known charm for making his games like films as the very end cutscene was a literal 90 minute film. I kept an eye on my wristwatch throughout the laborious, mind numbing exposition movie because I kept faith that it was going to end, but it didn't. I don't think this game is a masterpiece in the slightest. I feel that critics aren't realising here that great art requires great sacrifice and discipline. What was evident was that Hideo Kojima threw everything at this including the kitchen sink, hoping it would float. It's a mess. He even goes out his way to incorporate anything into the plot so that it would (hopefully) make sense and bring substance to the story. It didn't. Such as, at the end Amelie reveals that Ame is French for "soul" and that reveals that her soul is a lie. First off, when did French themes come into this narrative when it was supposed to be set in the USA and incorporate that country's DNA, and secondly how does that reveal affect the entirety of the experience? The simple answer is that it doesn't. It's unschooled. Uncollected. It uses "ha" and "ka" to describe the body and soul when it could just have made it less confusing and say "body" and "soul". It's a blur of sci-fi things that don't know why they exist in its oily soup of ideas. To its merit, Death Stranding's only saving grace is that it is true to its meaninglessness. In the end after the credits roll you are left to wander the world in hope of finding genuine connection, though in reality you're just left alone to wander without being harangued for the explanation in it all. So there's some peace in that.

Death Stranding is a game I have played like no other. The emptiness of the world juxtaposed with the connections you make along the way is beautiful. The world is beautiful. The gameplay loop confused me at first and quite honestly, overwhelmed me. But I gave it another shot and I am so glad I did. The story really gripped me and shook me. I finished it a couple years ago and I still think about it to this day, and I'm actually going on my 2nd playthrough right now. I am really taking my time this time around (first playthrough was 65+hrs).

It's a tight story, lots of questions at the beginning, but many answers at the end make this a very satisfying game to complete (though you might still have questions at the end, since this is a very dense game).

My favorite parts of the game are the game loop, getting orders, setting up my cargo (optimization), and picking the best route in order to deliver everything safely and on time. It's not for everyone, sure, but I do encourage you to give it a try. It is a slow game, this is the kind of game where you do sit to contemplate the view and the environments, the whole atmosphere really. The soundtrack supports this so well.

The music in this game is phenomenal. It is how I discovered Low Roar. Amazing music (RIP Ryan).

I can't wait for DS2. Keep on keepin' on!

Of course it's not a perfect game, but it gets a well deserved 9/10 from me. Can't wait for the sequel!

I'm someone who plays single player games almost exclusively, and enjoy slow burning experiences. I love exploration, mysteries and deep story narratives. I also enjoy a good challenge.

Although this game supposedly checks all the boxes, I'm sad to say that I just didn't get a feel for this one. I [i]should[/i] have liked what this game had to offer [i]in theory[/i], but it just didn't come together.

I'm completely lost on what the core gameplay loop should be. As far as I can tell, it's delivering packages back and forth, between a handful of locations over and over again, at long distances. Supposedly you can acquire vehicles and build infrastructure for tons of resources, to be able to do the same, only a bit faster. It's never really explained how you do this. There is a multiplayer element as well, although the mechanics for that too are never explained either. The actions of other players affect your game world, and this is supposed to make your life easier, but it just ends up being confusing. You turn around and new roads that end nowhere criss-cross the landscape, random grapples litter cliffs, etc.

I was told that the game starts "getting good" after about 30 hours, but: 1) I don't want to keep at it for twice as long as I have just to test whether that's true; 2) I doubt the core, trudging gameplay will change enough to change my opinion.

Death Stranding: Director's Cut enhances the Strand experience without straying too far from the original. With added content and features, it transforms an already good experience into something even better. It leaves you wondering why these elements weren't included from the start.

The very first time I played this game I went in it expecting the worst after seeing reviews calling this game boring or "walk simulator". In the end I was pleasantly surprised, it is now one of my favorite games of all time. I've played it twice now and can see myself returning to it in the future as well.

I think this game suffered a lot with the Hideo Kojima hype and his Metal Gear games legacy and I people, with very little info, began to expect it to be the next metal gear, and unrealistic content from this game. 

If you don't like Hideo Kojima's storytelling you will probably dislike the game since there is a lot of it, but otherwise you should give it a chance. If you are unfamiliar of his way of telling a story, I could see finding the early game a little bit disappointing, I believe this game is made to be a slow burn purposefully since it fits the whole theme of the game.

I find the game fascinating the story is told in several different and interesting ways, no just through cutscenes, the graphics are amazing the gameplay is very creative and makes you feel your progress in a very significant way. For me the game is boring in the same way someone could find Minecraft boring since it doesn't have much action thrown in your face all the time, but the atmosphere makes it work for me.

I would recommend anyone to give this game a try, but I can also see how it is not for everybody will like it. I think you appreciate this game the most after you get to near to the end.

If Death Stranding was a Movie, it could have potentially ranked among titles such as Ghost in the Shell and Akira in terms of cultural significance. Sadly, it is not a movie but a game. A game filled to the brim with tedious mechanics and a painfully slow pacing.

After buying the game upon its initial release on PS4 and never finishing it back then, i thought i give it a second chance with the director's cut. I had high hopes that after four years the game would be finally be a polished experience, but i was vastly disappointed. Especially driving vehicles is still the worst i have ever seen in a game.

Also, a lot of times the game makes little to no sense at all, e.g. [i]"Sam, you are the only hope for 'Merica and thus all mankind, because the world would simply stop existing without Uncle Sam. But don't worry, we will help you in any way we can! What is it Sam? ...oh that vehicles parked over there would be helpful on your mission? Well you see ... we actually need those to drive our lazy arses around this facility... but here: have some ropes and ladders... well you actually need to bring us materials in exchange, we don't run a charity here, you know. But rest assured, you are our only hope and we totally got your back."[/i]

The game also makes a lot of mistakes in its storytelling by bombarding you with informations that you can't possibly understand because the words have not been propperly explained to you beforehand. Instead, all characters just throw gibberish-words at you like you are supposed to know what they are talking about.

Playing this game makes me wonder if it wouldn't have been for the better if Kojima-san would have just retired after Metal Gear Solid 4.
I recommend !

It's a very strange game obviously.  I did find it relaxing, once you learn the full mechanics of the game.  The first chapter or so is high tension simply because you don't understand the dynamics of the game.  Once you get used to them, it's far more "relaxing" a game to play.  

I had the most fun prior to the final expansion west....the map is effectively cut into 3 sections, but only the first and second are really part of the core game.  The 3rd section is simply a runaway slide to the conclusion of the game.  

I found the full story mediocre, particularly the conclusion.  They aren't kidding....the finale is like 4 hours long.  It isn't bad of course, but I feel like the way they tied it up was predictable.

Definitely recommended when on sale, but I have a feeling this game isn't going to be everyone's cup of tea.

A contemplative and strategic game, yet full of action, innovation and aventure. In order to enjoy this game you have to let yourself be inmersed in the fascinating world Mr. Kojima and company have carefully crafted. Take your time with it, dont play it while doing other things. Every step, every meter you advance in your travel through the breathtaking scenery is a micro-challenge. Put attention into details: the sounds, the colors, the ambience, the stories, and you will have one of the most wonderful experiences in gaming history.

Very sobering experience. Wait, I mean So Boring.

Like an RPG, fighting monsters and enemies, collecting loot, becoming encumbered all the time when trying to take the loot back. Oh, and you can’t actually kill enemies because that would basically nuke an area. Best way to describe it would be this is a walking simulator, where they really lean into the being encumbered all the time, having even more to carry, and walking slowly trying not to fall down.

I was also bored with the story. Also, if you didn’t know Hideo Kojima made this, don’t worry, they will remind you about 10 times.

I think I got this with a humble bundle choice membership. I am glad that I didn’t dump any real cash on this. I do not recommend, it is not worthy.

This game, in my opinion, is a masterpiece. The only reason you wouldn't like it is because you hate walking simulators, which is understandable. Some people don't, but hear me out for a moment: A story that, while confusing at times, is still a wonderful experience, and this is coming from someone who will skip every cutscene in any game. Now for the gameplay, this game is aptly named FedEx simulator by the community. I can tell you why you are just delivering packages to each place until something happens, but you're still delivering packages. Still, the best part is in providing the parcels. The fact that you have to Teeter yourself left to right to make sure that your containers don't fall off your back makes the game a little bit more engaging than just walking from point A to point B for the music or the ambiance that will constantly put a stone in your stomach when you get into a BT-filled area or the low hum of whatever song is playing while you're just walking around enjoying what you're seeing the just walking around got me lost for about enjoying a sunset or watching waves crash on the beach had me mesmerized with how beautiful this game can look. The options of so many different items that you can use at your disposal to get you from point A to B to C is a blast to enjoy. I believe I sunk about maybe 3 hours in just creating a zipline highway to get to four different locations so that I could keep getting rewards from them, and quite honestly, I didn't regret any moment that I had in there; just optimizing the paths so I can truly feel like I was going above and beyond for a customer LOL. Still, yeah, let's get down to brass tax. This game is enjoyable; combat is interesting, the environment is breathtaking, and objectives are cookie cutter, easy, 10/10, in my opinion.

10/10 Full Recommendation!!

This game makes me feel connected to others playing it while playing alone in a way that I haven't really felt since the first time I played Dark Souls and noticed the writings on the ground.  This game steps it up a notch by putting whole built structures that everyone can contribute to.  I am ridiculously addicted to seeking out entrusted cargo from other players and getting them to their destinations and fixing roads so everyone can use them.  This game gives me hope in humanity again in a weird way while giving me peace and allowing me to explore one of the most beautiful game worlds I have ever seen.  This game is helping me out of my depression and I love it for it.  Not a game, this thing is an experience and I am thankful to experience it.

This game is really hard to recommend to a normal gamer. It's definitely for the niche gamers that like a bit of grindy backtracking traversal, beautiful scenery, and cinematic story. 

Things I really like about this game:
- Guillermo del Toro and Hideo Kojima teaming up to make a very beautifully directed story. (Still want Silent Hill)
- Grindy aspects of traversal and rewards for making them in the first place.
- Stunning scenery
- The attention to detail when it comes to the game-play.. You essentially deliver packages but the game is so much more than that with equipment management, weight loading management, item utilization, traversal planning, enemy disposal, and world building (in a literal and figurative sense).
- Everything in my last point can be upgraded in some capacity such as extra weight capacity for easier management, weight dispersal with better up-gradable equipment (won't spoil that), better items, better traversal, and again better ways to travel later in the story.
Nitpicks that I have with the game:
- Can't destroy mule camps with a void out. 
- Void outs can't be traversed which is very sad cause they look like such cool terrain to navigate through.
- There is a limit to how many structures you can have in a world which I get buuuut let me build as much as I want for the best traversal! :(

All in all a very good game for the niche gamer.

I just want to say I regret going with the negative feedback and waiting for so long to experience this masterpiece . 
If someone ask me to describe game mechanics then probably i have to say  it's amazon delivery game , there is no way you can describe this game to someone . So you have to experience it on your own . 

This game is all about connecting people and rebuild the broken relationships but it's also a social experiment about connecting players and rebuild the broken game world . The opening hours is so cruel and punishing that you are almost going too quit this game , and at this exact time the multipliers kicks in and the you can realise the value of people and their presence . 

This game teaches you the weight you carry is not yours alone , everyone is walking the same difficult paths.
This game doesn't want you to suffer , this game wants you to reduce the suffering of others .
One you stop playing this game just like other game for your own enjoyment and starts to play for benefit of everyone , it became the most fulfilling experience you have ever had .

As a video game it's not for everyone, i agree ; but the potential it has is absolutely mind blowing

Side note: Kojima finally released a game before the events depicted in the game.
For those not in the know Kojima on several occasions has had to change aspects of his game because they mirrored events that were happening in the world. And not that he did it on purpose but that he had a script laid out and then parts of that script happened in the world. Prime example is MGS2 was suppose to have more damage done to NYC during the ending but then 9/11 happened and they knew any deceptions of building being destroyed in a militarily attack would not be good.
Then he released Death Stranding right before a global pandemic that killed people silently and everyone had to stay inside and relay on delivery people....I am not saying Kojima is a prophet or anything like that. Just that he obviously see's the world in a different way then most people and DS2 is on the way. lol

I have 106 hrs on the original version of DS. I love the game, the gameplay. It is one of my favourite game of all time.

But here are some problems I have with it...

anyone else felt a bit disappointing with Death Stranding story when it could have been much more amazing?

These are some points I'd like to point out when I saw them setup at the early point of the game and never went anywhere.

1. The Introduction of Chiral Network - Die Hardman said 'it will bring back 10 thousand years of human history, bring dinosaurs back to life, connect us to the past' First I heard this, I imagined when we connected more regions, we could go back to the past, pull objects from past events back to life but in the game it's just a 0 PING Internet connection and learning a bit about the first Death Stranding.

2. No Face-to-Face Conversation, only Hologram - With this mechanics, the game wants you to feel lonely, a long journey alone. I wholeheartedly recommend this game, I love it.

Death Stranding-Director's Cut:

Have I mentioned that I love the type of story-telling that Hideo Kojima has to offer? Even though this title was subject to some mixed responses upon release, I just had to try it for myself. Let us answer the most burning question of all. Do you deliver stuff from point A to point B? The answer is Yes. This is what you do but it is slightly more than that actually. It is about connecting people and finding ways around challenging landscapes. 

Coupled with the type of over the top story-telling that Kojima is known for, it is probably one of the best games I have ever played and I still return to it yearly. 

The simple gameplay loop is fun and engaging. The characters are so good. Them nasty BT's are a force to deal with. The Road can be a lie :-). The Director's cut edition id probably the one you want more than the normal edition and worth it now on a sale. 

It is not for everyone, but it certainly is for me. I highly recommend it to others

DEATH STRANDING is an incredible game, and one that deserves its nominations and awards. The gameplay is polished, unique, and highly innovative, while the story is a cinematic masterpiece from start til finish. However, you should only play this if you like an atmospheric slow burner that uses some very experimental ideas.

I [b]sincerely[/b] recommend you play this game with:
- PS4/5 controller (Xbox controllers have bad rumble and gyro support)
- Good headphones or surround sound.
- Excellent display (4K or higher, HDR, ideally with DCI-P3 or better gamut).
- Hardware to run it at maximum settings.

I also suggest playing at maximum difficulty; you'll be forced to be more careful with your routes and equipment, which helps keep the game fresh as you progress.

This is not a game for everybody, some people will find the concept of traveling through rough terrain to deliver packages to be boring. And that's fine, to each their own. But for those who enjoy the game play, there is no other experience like it on the market. I have already completed the game and I'm still playing to 100% cause I find it so fun.

My only complaint I would have is that I wish there was a demo so people to feel out the game for awhile before deciding to buy it.

Death Stranding is a rollercoaster of emotions and provides a conclusion that completely stuns us.

The end is only the beginning.

It's a Masterpiece, but IT'S NOT FOR EVERYONE

Satisfying and calming. I've heard others complain about how the whole game is cut-scenes, but I think it's a good balance. Sure, it pushes the limit here and there, but overall I'm fine with it.

The gameplay has fluid and intuitive mechanics, and somehow doesn't get tedious, even after making MANY deliveries (I think it's because the story is linked to all of the main ones).
I don't have a high-end computer (just a laptop so far), but it runs surprisingly well, and with very pleasing graphics at that.

Definitely worth the money, and after 40+ hours I haven't finished yet.

Extraordinary, but with a caveat.

If you are like me and you went into Death Stranding wanting a meditative experience with moments of artistic storytelling, Death Stranding is for you.

If you expect a "proper game," you are going to have a bad time, especially in the first few chapters of the game.

Put in an analogy: Consider taking a week to watch a TV show one episode at a time. But between each episode you go on a hike to ponder. Not necessarily ponder the show itself (but that included). Just time to think and reflect with something to keep your active mind occupied.

That's Death Stranding. And if that sounds horrible and boring, this game is not for you. But for myself and others who give it a positive review, it is a delightful respite.

EDIT: I want to express one genuinely deep criticism I have of the game. Destination NPCs have SO FEW lines of dialogue for a successful delivery. Hearing them say the exact same line of dialogue for an S-tier delivery, every time, makes it ring hollow, sarcastic. More dialogue variety for delivery would have gone a long way.
It's like having a job but for no monetary gain, this is true capitalism!

Provided you have the attention span longer than your average Tik-Tok viewer, you'll enjoy the game. The story is filled with depth, providing you with background information from interviews and emails from characters. The gameplay is engaging as you balance how you'll complete a delivery with the resources you have, which are congruent with the effort you've put in to unlock various gadgets, or spend time rebuilding roads and structures. The more connections you make, the easier, but longer the game gets, and I appreciate that kind of grind.

It's a slow burn, and you should play it as such. If you try and rush it, you'll miss out. Enjoy the storytelling, the music, the mechanics.

Very late to the Party, what can I say what hasn't been said already? I think this game deserves a place in every PC Gamers Library, especially this tidy Directors Cut. Treat yourself this game when you face a weeklong downtime, sit down and just discover this unique mixture of a game.
If ou do not like combat, like myself, rush the first landscape area of the game and only do the minimum amount of work (you can return later) -> and reach Chapter 3 - the game will open up to you and you'll have a HUGE MAP to freely explore. Nobody stops you from reaching the craziest spots early =) Nobody stops you from being kind to players and leave vehicles around. =)
It's a massive game that keeps on giving - there is nothing like this on the market to my knowledge. Grab it whenever you can, play @DLSS Quality (or comparable) and just enjoy this metalgear-infused movie/game/openworld/adventure experience. You deserve an adventure unlike most, dear reader - and Hideo Kojimas' Death Stranding in this "Director's Cut" provides exactly this. 

Oh and btw - you absolutely CAN singleplayer this without any online content, you absolutely can fight every MULE (human enemy type) and BT you meet - the game will bend to your playstyle, in a way. I liked to build highways for others and drive my bikes around so... there is flexibility here. Have a gr8 day, buying this isn't a mistake for anyone who experienced some tingling in your fingers when reading this review.

Yes, Death Stranding is a walking simulator. But it is still pretty good regardless. It's an oddly therapeutic game, at least that's how I felt. I could go on and on about the plethora of weird design decisions, flaws, or jank this game has but at its core, I think DS is still a good, unique experience. I can't really say if you will enjoy it because I think every person is going to take to this one differently. Some will love it, some will hate it. I think that the gameplay and controls are, at times, remarkably stupid, but in a weird way, part of the game is trying to work around the controls with different tools like rope, ladders, or vehicles. I definitely enjoyed the game the most when I had the least amount of options and had to be creative with the little tools i did have. Early on, the decision to carry a ladder or a rope is incredibly important, as you do not have the liberty of tacking on as much gear as possible. Do you add that extra ladder or take another order? Look at the map, do you cut through the mountain where you need more gear or take the low road and sneak past MULEs? Small decisions like these that make you plan out a route to get to one place to the next were so cool to me and I really loved working out the best way to link the country up. Once you get roads and vehicles and a bunch of upgrades to make traversal easier, the game is less enjoyable to me. It's really just way too easy to hop in a truck and make the rounds on a road in the late game. The combat is hit or miss, and it feels like it should've been more like metal gear solid 5 and less like the traversal of DS. because it feels like the combat has the same problems as traversal. The story is also so fucking insane, and a lot of the best parts of the story, like the small interactions between the very diverse cast, disappear later in the game in favor of a lot of shit that doesn't make any sense on purpose. So overall, while I still liked the game, I would only recommend this game if you're fine with having to work around the quirks of the game as a feature and not a bug.

At no point during my playthrough did I go "this is fun", yet I never wanted to put the game down.
The story, while a little confusing, is fantastic and the music complements it really well.
There came a time where the world of Death Stranding screwed me up and I found myself calling Sam words that aren't very nice but by the end of this journey I realized that I actually liked this whole experience.
I highly recommend this game to anyone that has patience, to you and I, this game is a masterpiece.

To settle and call this game a simple "walking simulator" is a complete disservice to what the game is. While the gameplay entirely revolves around being a glorified courier, the game itself takes you on a journey like no other.

The gameplay is a little challenging to get used to at first, it presents you with packages to carry from point A to B, occasionally it rains and the timefall from the rain damages your package, or you might be expected to traverse mountainous areas to your destination. You also have to deal with BTs (basically the ghosts of the dead) by sneaking around them or else fight your way through them if you have the equipment to do so.

This was my first foray into a Hideo Kojima production and the easiest way I can put it is if someone watched a few too many American movies and tried to replicate the cliches and feelings associated with watching them. The story of Death Stranding involves, in addition to being a courier, is that your player character Sam is tasked with the duty of reconnecting civilization across a post-apocalyptic United States wherever he delivers packages. There's a whole lot of "America this" and "America that" which seems so cliche, but the game eases up on that once you're past the first chapter or so.

Once the game really picks up, the story goes into the mystery surrounding the Death Stranding - the apocalyptic event that ended the world and forced people into hiding in bunkers. The story of how the Death Stranding happened and the surrounding lore is so fascinating and really gets you scratching your chin in awe (and confusion).

I would also like to give praise to the art direction, environmental design and soundtrack for all being absolute masterpieces that makes the game feel like a gorgeous moving painting.

The game isn't for everyone as the pacing varies depending on how you play. However, that said, go into the game with no expectations on what the hell is going on - it's the best way to experience it.

Hideo Kojima's Death Stranding is nothing short of a groundbreaking masterpiece that defies conventional gaming norms and invites players on a captivating, thought-provoking journey. With its thoughtfully crafted world, complex narrative, and exceptional attention to detail, Death Stranding offers an experience unlike any other in the gaming world.

One of the most striking aspects of Death Stranding is its visually stunning and meticulously realized game world. The landscapes are both breathtaking and treacherous, perfectly capturing the post-apocalyptic beauty of a fractured America. The game's Decima engine brings the environment to life with unparalleled fidelity, immersing players in its haunting, desolate beauty.

The narrative of Death Stranding is a dense, intricate tapestry that unfolds gradually, rewarding players with each revelation. At its core, the game explores themes of isolation, connection, and the human spirit's resilience. Kojima's storytelling prowess shines through, weaving a complex web of characters, organizations, and enigmatic phenomena that keeps you guessing and eager to delve deeper.

The gameplay mechanics of Death Stranding are both innovative and deeply engaging. You play as Sam Porter Bridges, a courier tasked with reconnecting isolated communities across the United Cities of America. The act of traversal, balance, and carrying cargo on your back becomes a metaphorical and literal journey that resonates with the game's themes. The sense of isolation and vulnerability is palpable, making every step you take feel significant and intense.

Death Stranding is not just a solitary experience, however. The game's asynchronous multiplayer elements, such as shared structures and messages from other players, reinforce the idea of connection and interdependence, even in a desolate world. This design choice adds a layer of depth and unpredictability to the gameplay, fostering a sense of community and cooperation.

The cast of characters in Death Stranding is a star-studded ensemble, with exceptional performances from the likes of Norman Reedus, Mads Mikkelsen, and others. These performances, combined with Kojima's masterful direction, make the characters feel genuine and relatable, adding emotional weight to the story's twists and turns.

Death Stranding is not a game for everyone, as its pacing and complex narrative may challenge some players. However, for those willing to invest the time and effort, it's a journey that rewards with deep introspection, breathtaking landscapes, and a truly unique gaming experience. It's a testament to Hideo Kojima's visionary creativity and a reminder of how video games can be a powerful medium for storytelling and art. Death Stranding is a triumph of innovation and an essential addition to any gamer's library.

I love this game, but oh man, is it not for everyone.  I loved the world building, the characters and the cooperation with other players online. It really felt like I was sharing the world with other players, and our buildings helped each other a lot.

However, the story is all over the place, and some of the dialogue is just so cringy. One of the characters, Fragile, has a catch-phrase so lame that it sounds like a child wrote it cause it "sounded cool".

If you want to take your time and dive into a game where there's still space for your own imagination without wanting to be swallowed by another sandbox, this is for you. And it's a masterpiece of its own peculiar genre. The only annoying thing I thought was the sister character and all the melodramatic speech that she provides.

I had this game installed for almost a year but couldn't muster the strength to start playing it. Despite the time that had passed since its release, I managed to avoid spoilers and enjoyed my time with it.

I was generally satisfied and even impressed, although I can't claim to have completely understood the entire plot and all of its intricacies.

For the first couple of hours, I was highly fascinated by what was happening. Then I began to realize why the game was dubbed a courier simulator. After about 10 hours, I found myself delivering cargo like a maniac, mindlessly trying to progress. The ingenious gameplay of cargo delivery was structured in a way that kept feeding you new gadgets and features until you reached the mountainous regions, where the real challenge began. Perhaps I should have taken a break there, as I was quite exhausted from the game after reaching the 50-hour mark. Nonetheless, I continued building ropes, transporting cargo, and constructing roads. Sadly, my patience eventually wore thin. Maybe if I had played it from the start, there would have been more online structures to interact with, but I can't say that I suffered much.

I knew one of the game's features was the ability to encounter other players' contributions in your session, and oh my, how many times ladders and bridges from other players saved me. The idea of connection with all players and using shared structures and ideas is brilliant. It's a bit like communism – why not?

The game is accompanied by magnificent music and sounds throughout your journey. I even added the game's soundtrack to my playlist upon completing it. The game features splendid cinematic moments and acting.

However, there were some minor drawbacks. Sections where you had to collect cargo on hostile creatures' territory could get overly tedious. They weren't particularly challenging, but having to shoot them repeatedly just to pass or complete a delivery was incredibly boring. I also encountered some control issues where the character continued to move forward even though I was pulling the gamepad trigger backward. As a result, I tumbled down a mountain quite ineptly and had to reload. Additionally, I wish I could listen to emails and diaries while walking. I believe this combination would have allowed me to enjoy the gameplay to the fullest. Nevertheless, I managed to alleviate the routine with the following...

I highly recommend playing the game if you have a second monitor. While I was balancing cargo, I watched numerous interesting videos in the background. Here's a list: Director's Interpretation of Blade Runner, History of the Orthodox Church, Full History of Making Silent Hill 2, Alan Wake, The Thing, Return to Castle Wolfenstein, BloodRayne, Quake 4, Amnesia: The Bunker, Cities: Skylines 2, Total Overdose, Assassin's Creed Mirage, Resistance: Fall of Man, Heavenly Sword, COD MW3, Call of Juarez: The Cartel, The Getaway, Postal 2, Spider-Man 2, Scarface, Death Stranding, Wheelman, The Godfather, Prey 2006, Night Watch, The Elder Scrolls Adventures: Redguard, Vivisector.

Although I was tired by the end and had to watch the credits three times, I was very satisfied with this game. It truly provides a new experience, and it's no wonder they call Hideo Kojima a genius game designer. For me, it's the first Hideo Kojima game I managed to complete without abandoning it halfway.

A Kojima classic. Not for everyone and I certainly would understand why someone would dislike this because I use to be that guy when it first released on PS4. This is a one-of-a-kind experience, not a gamer's game for sure. You are basically picking up and dropping off packages for a country with crappy WiFi, yes, that is the gameplay loop. It is admittedly not fun, AT FIRST. You got to put in that work and feel immersed, those cinematic almost movie-like cutscenes are your palette cleansers. The more deliveries you make, the more connections you have. The more connections you have, the more things you can create. The more things you create will then help not just you, but other real players out there discovering these locations you previously trekked through. Human connection is what this is all about and often you forget you are playing multiplayer games with other real humans behind the screens, so DS takes that concept and  made it about connecting strangers together with likes and sharing things, it is such a cool take on a formula that has been done time and time again.    The story alone is good, not the best, but damn good. The characters all feel some sense of disconnect with each other and it's up to this strange and lonely guy, Sam Bridges, to bring people together. It works well with the gameplay loop and benefits everyone. The boss battles are sadly the most boring and annoying thing in the game, which is a disappointment considering how awesome the characters are in the cutscenes. The fights are standard third person shooter stuff, throw your grenades, run, and sometimes you even get use actual guns against enemies later in the game. It's not hard, it's just too easy and predictable, considering Kojima and team made the legendary MGS franchise that had the best boss fights I have ever seen in any video game.  Even with that being said, DS is nearly a masterpiece. I enjoyed that loop, the music, the people I connected with in the game and my portable baby! DS made me shed a tear at the end, which is crazy since I have never felt something like that with any other game. Cannot wait for the sequel!
Best game from Kojima Studios, playing this game since the First Death Stranding and hundred hours of Experience. Can't wait for the sequel as well.

Death Stranding is a game that is refreshingly unashamed of itself. It is the brainchild of Hideo Kojima, and indeed, it will make that abundantly clear. It is a silly game, with a strange plot (though not as confusing as popular opinion suggests), quirks that some might dismiss as QoL failures, and a gameplay loop that - by all metrics - should be mind-numbingly boring.

And yet, it is not.

Death Stranding is [b]not[/b] the "walking simulator" that it is so often derisively referred to as (make no mistake, though, there is plenty of walking), but rather an experience of many inextricable parts. If this sounds pretentious, well.....it kind of is, but to great effect. 
Death Stranding is not just about the walking. It's about the planning: what all should I bring? How many orders will I bring at once? Am I headed this way anyways? Is there going to be timefall? Should I bring a vehicle? Should I bring a PCC to build some structures to make the next trip easier (and not just for myself, but for other porters)?
Each of these questions takes one, maybe two seconds to answer, and you could feasibly finish the game even on the hardest difficulty with very little planning. And yet, I still find myself smiling whenever I encounter a situation I had prepared for. Logging in and seeing that other porters got some use out of my structures feels good. Giving another porter likes for doing the same in turn feels good. Taking note of a road or bridge in progress and doing my part to contribute feels good. Picking up entrusted cargo and delivering it for its original porter feels good.
You don't [i]have[/i] to do most of this, and I suspect a large portion of Death Stranding's mechanics will not be fun to many players. If you aren't interested in slowing down and enjoying the climb, maybe look elsewhere. If you're an infrastructure nerd who loves the feeling of contributing, this is probably the game for you.

I know, I know, we can gain happiness through linking people together. Sounds good. But wtf just by delivering goods over and over and over again??? I've suffered it for 4 hours on this tedious loop and you tell me there's 40 hours more? Oh no I'm playing a video game, not a COURIER SIMULATOR...
As an undergraduate major in Software Engineering, I bought this game just for two reasons: I want to see how Real-Time Graphics develops recently, and, I've listened to the music, "Ghost - A. Walker / Au/Ra", that sounds good... Now, uh, this game is sure very well in Graphics, but... just well in Graphics... That's all... Nothing more... 
Because I may become a game developer in the future, so I always try to push myself to accept different kinds of games. Though gameplay and style varies, I always try my best to discover every game's value and accept it. But I'm so sorry, I beg your pardon I can't accept this one... Sorry...
If I can turn back time to two days ago, I'd rather use 15 dollars to buy a "Mathematical Analysis" and a cup of coffee, then reading book there, NOT buy this game.

Update: That's just my personal opinion. There's still lots of people find this game amazing, leaving very positive comments here. But just ignore my negative comment above, there's one thing, for sure, Death Stranding doesn't seem like a traditional game. If you never play some similar games before, spending tens of dollars on this game is without doubt "risky" and may let you down.

好好好，我知道这个游戏能通过把人们联系在一起获得快乐，听起来真不错。但是tmd你告诉我，把人们连接到一块需要我一趟一趟地送快递？？？我已经跑来跑去送了四个小时的快递了，单调乏味，然而你告诉我这个游戏后面的四十个小时还都是送快递？天哪我是在玩游戏啊，而不是快递员模拟器啊……
作为一个软件工程专业的本科生，我买这个游戏只是出于两个目的：我想看看实时计算机图形学现在发展的怎么样了，以及，我觉得A. Walker和Au/Ra的Ghost听起来不错……好吧，这个游戏的图形质量还真不错，但是，也仅仅是图形质量不错……仅此而已，没了……
考虑到我将来可能会成为一名开发者，我需要去主动尝试各式各样的游戏。尽管玩法和风格各异，但是我会尽力去体会每个游戏独特的价值，然后接受它……但是抱歉，原谅我，我真的接受不了这个游戏……不好意思……
如果时间能倒回到两天前，我宁愿花99块钱买一本《数学分析》和一杯咖啡，然后坐在咖啡店里看书，而不是买这个游戏……

补充：
这只是我个人的观点。仍然有相当多人认为这款游戏很惊艳，给了这款游戏相当积极的评价。但是忽略掉我上面的差评，有一件事情是可以肯定的，死亡搁浅和常见的游戏不是一个“套路”。如果你之前没玩过类似的游戏，直接花99块钱冲死亡搁浅无疑是“很冒险的”，并且有可能让你失望

I played original version normal difficulty. 150+ hours in, basically solo, took my time to build most zip-line routes and 5-stared most shelter except probably 2 and I just can't say confidently that I would recommend this game to my friends.

This is not a walking simulator. It had a grand beginning but disappointing end.

This game does not respect a player's time investment by the fact. I had experience 4 times that my hard-earned items and weapons disappeared after a cut-scene teleportationm e.g. those supercell fight. A whole truckload of weapons, custom items that earned by each delivery, just GONE. It just feel so so bad and I was only playing on normal, imagine playing on very hard difficulty where everything is effort.

The game does not respect your planning on end-game boss fight and endgame story fights are unrewarding as. Your planning is meaningless to the endgame. Structures on the whole regional map, built after tens of hours of gameplay would be completely erased from what is explained as 'heavy timefall', while a long dead NPC's rusted ladders are immortal. Your weapons and tools loaded on the truck or even those carried on your back would get dropped on the ground and blocked by a transparent wall. All the rocket launcher, level 2 grenades and HG custom guns mean jackshit because you cannot use any of them. Instead, you are locked to use weapons that are generated in the boss arena, i.e. assault rifle lvl.2 and cryptobiotes. Even worse, my scanner did not pick up any chiral crystal after the boss dead. My fight ends in no reward at all.

It is unfortunate that early game is actually pretty good. I enjoyed it even when walking takes up most of the part. Rough journey but get to feel the trip. Plan the trip and use ladder and anchor to navigate and finish the trip. It felt good. Getting preppers to the network and reading their email feels connected and learn the NPCs' story and more about the world setting.

Mid game feels like drunk driving simulator and boring hanging simulator. Drive a lot and used zip-line a lot. With shit collision physics, bike steering mechanics. camera-oriented direction control, shit collision physics again, lots of stones and rocks on ground to collide with, sudden strong wind mechanism, low traction physics and weird vehicle mechanics, driving experience is honestly not impressive at best and outright intolerable and unplayable at worst. Vehicles can go to the opposite direction you input, keep hitting a rock in front of the vehicle repeatedly, and slide all the way down hill with hand brake applied. I have completely given up on vehicles in favor of zip-lines on mountain region because vehicles are simply unusable in that region which is a shame as that region is one of the major region. Zip-line gets the job done but is tedious to setup and boring as fuck to ride on. No sense of achievement for each delivery and soon this major gameplay element becomes a chore. Not fun at all. They are done only to grind for weapons or a chance that there might be something cool, but disappointing most of the time. Multiple weapon systems are unlocked after the major Higg's fight, but there is no point for them anymore at that point.

The game feels like ended midway after Higg's fight. The story at the early game is good. It was mysterious, intriguing and immersive full of descriptive cut-scene. Higg's fight is the climax and it feels like the final boss fight. Endgame story telling after Higgs' fight has a rather significant quality drop. The supposedly climax of explaining death stranding ended up in a long, dull monologue by Amelie. This part is so so so boring that even Sam tried to kill himself. While most characters, even those side NPCs like preppers had emails and holograms for side depiction. All we have for Amelie is her monologue. She is at the same time THE most important and THE least described major character, which is very unfortunate.  Her cut-scenes simply are not enough to connect her feelings with me, the player. There is no depth in this character and I fail to feel any emotion or story development from her. The whole death stranding and human extinction story becomes a joke, a chore or whatever insignificant news and I lost interest completely mid way. 

Frequent abrupt interruption by voice-call from NPC during gameplay is also quite distracting and annoying. It is like the game should have ended, but it is too short so we force some content at the end. Everything feels so deliberate and distracted.

Artwork and the landscape is astonishing and occasionally breathtaking though. Have to give that credit.

All in all, the gameplay and story is needlessly slow and long. There is actually not much content if all the repetitive side quest are not counted. As delivery became a chore after 7 or so chapters, there is not much replay value either. So, I for sure would not recommend it for full price for both original and director's cut. 

On sale, maybe.

My review is going to be very different from other people's review of the game. Let me start off by saying i'm a HUGE fan of long games. I 100%'d The Longing, and enjoyed every second of it, so you could say i'm a bit of a connoisseur of long type games.
       
          However, when I first opened Death Stranding, i could already tell this was going to be a different experience. I immediately immersed myself in the world, the atmosphere was unlike any other. The story was enriched, and as a proud red blooded american it really made me consider issues differently.

          THE GAMEPLAY was immaculate, the fact that the more cargo you carry the slower you move, really adds some realism to the game which i quite enjoy. The car mechanics really spiced up the gameplay, it felt like i was playing a whole new game, they really know how to switch it up when almost gets too boring. The ice physics made it feel like i was really treading on snow.  Every venture across (sadly) broken american terrain always had something new to discover, and there was never a dull moment. The ending of the game had me in tears, I won't spoil anything but it was one of the most memorable gaming experiences i've had in a long time. 

           All that being said i give this game a 4/10, although it did create the strand like genre as we know it, people would later improve on the formula, such as The Video Game Donkey's "the notorious dunk", although it was a song and not a game, i still feel it improved on the genre as a whole.

           PS: I haven't played the longing, I haven't beaten death stranding, this review was co-written by someone who has never played either game, and most of the actual review is me thinking of random things to praise it for. "I rate this review 7/10 - Mr. Kojima Konami" -me

The trailer turned me off of this game for a long time.

I did not want to play a game where Norman Reedus spent his time crying and mothering an infant, as was suggested in the promotional materials.

Well, very minor spoiler (first 10 min): his tears are an inadvertent reaction to his surroundings, and he "mothers" a pod baby tool that detects ghosts. It's not too bad.

Once you get past the awful naming conventions (on the level of Ash Ketchum or John Darksouls), you'll find unique work with truly top notch art direction, vibe, and atmosphere. The story is long winded, and yes-- often boring and convoluted; but the themes are strong and the world building is some of the best I've seen. It's more like a poem than a story. You feel this thing.

Gameplay itself is easy and serviceable. It's more mechanically interesting than a routine walking simulator, but might lack the depth many would expect. I personally enjoyed balancing my weight while trekking across the terrain. The world just looks so cool.

Overall, it's trying to do something different and succeeds on its own terms. I'll remember a couple of the visual set pieces for some time to come.

Beautiful. Weird but captivating story. Some fighting, some logistics, mostly walking/running/climbing and trying to deliver as much as you can as efficiently as you can to a great soundtrack. Perfect chill.

A masterpiece of an experience, yes the delivery game.

You're playing as Sam Bridges, given the task to reunite America after the apocalypse; "The Death Stranding". On the way, you meet certain important characters that not only are crucial to the story, but also carry their own story. They make you realise this whole world you are trying to reunite is broken.
'Broken people in a broken world, Sam is broken, Everything is broken'.
But what is broken can be fixed, this is where the multiplayer system comes in, every utility you place is placed in other player's world, and vice versa. The game also manages to make a distinction between dangers, and the parts of relieve. It's not possible to explain the feeling of having climbed a mountain or crossed hostile terrain, and then having the slow walk with music in the background. The game also ends with a last walk with the best music theme there is.

-THIS GAME IS BEST EXPERIENCED BLIND-, Try to avoid any information about the game story wise, the game will give you many unthought off surprises that will be ruined once you've heard of them.
Do note that this is a story-heavy game, expect the same gameplayloop with an unraveling (weird & disturbing) story. Also be aware that the game has many cutscenes, like watching a movie.

If you're after quite an easy game with a brilliant story that asks philosophical questions? Kojima's got your back.

I will go straight to the point this game is 10/10 and I cant wait for the sequel. I wish I knew the following info before I started playing the game but I will share with those who think the game sucks.

If you were like me who completely got lost and confused with the gameplay mechanics in the beginning of the game and quit couple of times then read:

 1. This game is awesome and a lot of people (including myself before playing) think the game is only about a walking simulator. It is not and after short amount of time you get the ability of fabricating/creating vehicles and load your cargo on it. My favorite unlockable is the ZIP LINE. I do not remember last time I was walking too long after unlocking the Zip Line. Also you will see other peoples zip lines as well and you can connect yours with them and literally zip line across the whole map lol
 
2. Focus on your main objective (ORDERS FOR SAM) all the time and only pick the standard orders if the delivery location of standard orders are closer or the same place that your main objective orders needs to be delivered.

3. Ignore the LOST CARGO's around the world. At least for the beginning as those may be confusing as hell to understand. You will end up loading lots of these without understanding the purpose. But maybe you are smarter than me and figure out faster lol
 4. You DONT HAVE TO build strong relationship with anyone, there is only ONE ending. So dont worry for not doing Standard deliveries. Only reason I would recommend to do the standard deliveries is to unlock upgraded items such as shoes or weapons. But again if you do standard missions like I mentioned in my 2nd point then you will be fine :)

And the rift between is a beach?  Somehow time is broken and rains down from the sky?  The dialogue also feels forced and unnatural.  And what is in it for me, the porter?  Likes?  For real?

Long story short: I got bored of hauling other people's stuff largely by foot across vast landscapes for nothing more than social media praise.
Lot's of fun but definitely an acquired taste, if you're not very patient then don't waste your money.

Death Stranding taught me the value of patience. As Sam Porter Bridges, I embarked on a journey to reconnect isolated cities and people in a post-apocalyptic America. This was no easy task. The terrain was rugged and treacherous, scattered with obstacles and threats around every turn. Simply getting from point A to point B required immense patience and perseverance. I couldn't rush the journey or take unnecessary risks. I had to cautiously plot my route, take my time navigating rocky cliffs and river crossings, and pause frequently to catch my breath and regain my stamina. The game forced me to slow down, move methodically, and understand that progress requires patience.

This patience paid off through the connections I built with other players along the way. When I took the time to contribute resources to build roads and structures, it benefited others down the line. By liking and sharing other players' ladders and vehicles, I could lend a helping hand. And receiving likes in return motivated me to keep building communal tools and infrastructure. I realized delivering packages wasn't just about me and my destination; it was about being part of something bigger. My patience and cooperation with others quite literally paved the way forward.

Death Stranding also taught me to keep going in the face of failure. Sam frequently lost his footing on slippery terrain or got ambushed by terrorists. Whenever I botched a delivery, I wanted to give up in frustration. But I had to remember that failure is inevitable, and what matters most is learning from mistakes, picking yourself back up, and trying again. Just as Sam persevered after every setback, I grew to accept failure as part of the journey. There was too much at stake to dwell on imperfection. Persisting through failure brought me closer to accomplishing my mission.

Most importantly, Death Stranding instilled in me that every delivery—every promise made—matters. The packages I transported as Sam weren't just cargo. They represented connections to people waiting on the other end, people in need of aid, resources, and human contact. The promises I made to deliver brought hope and comfort to them. My capacity to keep those promises gave meaning to their lives. The gravity of that role taught me to value human relationships and understand that we all depend on one another's reliability. When I focused on the responsibility of my promises rather than the difficulty of the delivery, I gained purpose and motivation to press onward.

In an isolating world, Death Stranding showed me how patience, cooperation, and perseverance bind us together. Its poignant message will stay with me: the strands that connect us are fragile, but unbreakable when we walk hand-in-hand. Sam Porter Bridges' journey mirrored my own. Through his grueling trek that required patience, endurance, and a concern for others, I gained insight into what it means to be human—to profoundly need other people and be needed in return. Therein lies the strand that gives us purpose.

I got addicted to this game, a special experience that will last in my memory for a long time.

To put it simply, game's a remarkable experience and a journey that feels different than many other games. There was really something unique achieved here with this game so don't listen to the "postman/DHL simulator" comments, it's so much more than that.

Now, on the more complex note, what I really found great about the game were numerous things that really stand out like the soundtrack, feeling of interacting with players via structures and paths you've taken, going on a journey to a not-yet connected region on your own and the build up of gradually becoming known as a porter via the story development. These major things in my view give the game a one-of-a-kind atmosphere.

Overall there's a grand selection to choose from when it comes to buildable structures like zip-lines, ladders, anchors, generators, safehouses, postboxes, jump ramps etc., as well as bringing gameplay "modifier" items that enhance your customization further such as stabilizators so you don't fall over enough and make landings smoother, or extra battery, pouches, heating pads for colder regions. There was a lot of thought brought into your options which are really vast and fit well the general lenght of the game.

Speaking of playtime, I've found the game to be quite lenghty for a single-player game, filled with content from main missions, to standard orders that are repeatables but still feel often unique as you may take different paths, use different vehicles and overall using different means of transportation whether on foot, bike or a truck. In terms lf lenght, it's most fulfilling, even to the point that it may feel like it's never going to end and when it finally does, there's like a 2-hour long ending with an epilogue.

That brings me to the topic of the story. Perhaps the only aspect that wasn't, in my opinion, handled as well as it could've been. Now, the story ITSELF is amazing, from start to finish, I won't spoil anything here but suffice to say that the idea behind what's going on and how it ends is amazing. What felt odd was the story-telling, may just be me so take this with a grain of salt but at some point, the story that even though it was expanded upon, it was often repeated on and on where plenty was said but didn't really feel like anything new was mentioned, rather repeating, a lot of dialogue/monologue lines for nothing new, really. I generally never dislike more dialogue/monologue and long cutscenes but even I stopped often and wondered if it's not enough. To summarize, characters monologue too much, frequently and at a point where it adds very little to the story. But that would really be the only thing I could find that sticked out for me, apart from the odd controls of the vehicles that takes some time getting used to.

The Director's Cut offers new structures to build and activities to use in the world, at some point I've found myself thinking that there's always something to do, it's amazing but it's a shame it's a purely single-player experience, which of course, for the purpose of story, is ideal. However, given how much content there is in the game, I've often imagined how great co-op would be here.

There are also easter egg missions including Cyberpunk 2077 and Half-life that I won't spoil but they're not exactly hidden so you will come across them on your own.

To summarise, it is one of the games that will stand out for me the most, great story, characters, wide array of gameplay technicalities, feeling of connecting with other players, vast range of usable items to help you on your journey, atmospheric soundtrack, nigh endless lore, plenty of collectibles and always something to do. It's quite obvious that a lot of hard work and personality was put into this game and for all the reasons above I wholeheartedly recommend this game.
