I put about 200 hours into this on ps4 pro back at launch. Had the collector's edition BB and everything. Replaying after some years now. What can I say? Even though I've already beaten the game, I played for hours tonight without missing a beat. There is just nothing like this game it sucks you in and won't let go. Anyone who says it's just a walking sim and boring without giving it an earnest go, is simply missing out. It is far more than that.

It took a while to get into, but I'm glad I stuck with it through the first few chapters.  The story and game play loop ultimately pulled me in, and Death Stranding is now my favorite game of all time.  Highly recommended!

I've read the reviews saying it gets better if you stick with it, but if a game does not grab my interest in the first 5 hours (on any level), then it's just not going to make a difference if I stick it out and keep playing.  I've already been put off by the game.

Note: If steam allowed mixed reviews,I would post just that
With that out of the way,the game's biggest strength is that the gameplay loop is quite original among major titles,however it suffers from numerous shortcomings that spoil the experience. 
For review purposes I will be including minor spoilers regarding game mechanics and some story chapters.

As you may already know,the focus of the game is around making deliveries,however soon you discover that the real meat is the "optimisation" of deliveries - figuring out how to fulfill orders with minimal effort required. 
As such,you are provided with a wide range of tools to achieve your goals,starting from simple ladders and bridges to cargo catapults and ziplines.
 This is where the first caveat hits - half of the tools at your disposal are worthless. The only PCC buildings I've ever bothered with were bridges and ziplines,the latter of which render the bridge obsolete as well. 
Let's take the ramp as an example,it launches players and vehicles alike. You can use it to cross gaps,pretty cool,right? Well it only works one way,so you need two,at which point a bridge will do the same job,with the extra benefit of not having a chance to get you killed. Using it to get vehicles to high places? Those places are too bumpy to traverse with a vehicle anyway.

The walking isn't actually too bad,the character's animations adapt to terrain,crossing rivers is a neat minigame (although climbing feels very "stiff",as you snap to ledges while scaling rocks). Getting tired limits your range,incentivises strategically placing shelters and encourages picking shorter routes and (only early) keeping an eye on cargo weight.

You know the buildings I mentioned? "Maxing" your reputation with a recipient takes around 3-4 trips.
Setting up a building requires the following: 1. Walk through bare terrain to connect to the network 2. Walk along the same route to build everything
This effectively means that you get to use your cleverly placed buildings once or twice.

Vehicles - I cannot stress how abysmal the driving physics are here,by far the worst I have ever seen. Bikes are super-glued to the ground,trucks (or rather delivery vans) get stopped by mere pebbles on the ground,forcing you to spam spacebar in hopes of jumping over them. Regarding the aforementioned pebbles,what if you *actually* wish to stop a vehicle? Well it'll slide as if it was on ice for the next 30 meters unless you purposefully crash into something. Thankfully the devs didn't bother to code cargo damage inside vehicles,so you can crash all you want (as long as you don't drive off a cliff). 

My biggest gripe of all is the obnoxious story. The first 3 hours of the game bombard you with cutscenes,then for the rest of the game all you hear is "America Reconnect Together Beach America Chiral Network Beach Reconnect". You're hauling hundreds of kilograms of cargo for what? Some ugly lady that you feel zero connection towards,as she doesn't show any personality outside the aforementioned "America Rebuild Beach" babbling. 
Even main characters are very shallow,with their personality revolving around a single gimmick ("Has heart problems" "Has a twin sister" "Wears an edgy mask")
The game is supposed to take place in former US territory,but they could've called it an alien planet and no one would tell the difference,as the environment looks un-natural. All that story budget could've been spent on making the gameplay less repetitive,yet here we are.

I am impressed by how Death Stranding manages to blend various genres and cater to all of my preferences. I was fascinated right away and had a great time playing it all the way through. It's an impeccable choice for those who appreciate a captivating storyline, immersive simulators, and action. Without a doubt, this game has taken the crown of my all-time favorite, and I definitely suggest it to everyone for a truly exceptional and enjoyable gaming experience that lasts all the way to the finish. PS: You'll be surprised by the game's ending.

I rarely write reviews, but I felt I had to get more people to play this. I know this review says I've only played 5 hours of it, but I have many more on the original PS4 version. If you are a fan of Metal Gear, YOU HAVE TO PLAY THIS GAME. This game is not stealth-inclined like Metal Gear, nor does it have a story that follows the usual conventions, you WILL get confused through this story and you PROBABLY will have to go over certain story beats again to keep track. This is nothing new, Kojima has done this for years, writing a story with so many plot threads, big names, and self-references that the story in a way keeps an air of mystique and intrigue. The only difference is that this game preaches about life and the acceptance of death and not any existential crisis related to politics and thought control. This is still a Kojima story, so awkward humor and the occasional loose plot thread is obviously going to happen, but isn't that what we play these games for? The gameplay is nothing revolutionary, and it's technically a walking simulator just coupled with some extra layers of depth tacked on, some of which is not very deep at all. This is where theory and actual gameplay don't meet, this game somehow takes the most unenjoyable concept, a walking simulator, and somehow turns into something worth experiencing. There is no other game I can think of that plays like this game, the somber tone of the music, trudging your own path through a harsh wilderness, doing it all alone with the occasional help from good samaritans, playing a balancing act with your cargo, all of this adds up to a fun experience. This may not be Kojima at it's best, but it is 100% worth playing for people who miss the strange quirks and unconventional nature of video games that only Kojima can convey.

I knew very little about this game when I got it, other than it was recommended by a friend. Not what I was expecting from the promotional video, but in a good way - much more interesting. At it's heart it is a delivery game, taking cargo from point A to point B, optimizing routes and dealing with various obstacles and challenges along the way.
The good:
- Paranormal/high-tech shenanigans kept things interesting and fresh
- Lots of cameos and easter eggs
- Goals are fairly straightforward and manageable, with lots of possible approaches and ways to make things more challenging if you want to.
- unsurprisingly, reminiscent of metal gear games in many ways
- while you don't interact directly with other players, you can affect each other's worlds in pretty significant ways. Pretty minimal at the start, but becomes more significant as you play.
- Toolbox expands as you play, adding fun options to make life easier keeping pace with missions getting harder.
The bad:
- A little heavy on themes of 'America' and 'being Connected'
- The last 10-20% is more like a movie with some interactive bits than a game
- The paranormal / high-tech shenanigans don't really follow any rules except to drive the plot

The atmosphere in this game is enveloping but does not seem as threatening as the characters imply. Besides boss fights the enemy encounters have not been a problem on Very Hard Difficulty, (Act 3: Delivering Relief Supplies to SNC). I am thoroughly enjoying this game. I am using it to relax and explore a beautiful rendition of the continental United States post weirdmageddon. If you are looking for a relaxing gameplay loop focused on navigating desire paths through uneven terrain with EXTREMELY SIMPLIFIED PHYSICS this is the game for you. The soundtrack goes hard.

I admit, I greatly underestimated this game. Initially, I believed it would just be a mundane delivery game. Even after watching a review, nothing truly sparked my interest.
However, a video featuring Junji Ito, the renowned Japanese horror manga artist, changed my perspective. In this video, Death Stranding was mentioned as a similar experience, and for good reason. The game's world is incredibly strange, governed by unfamiliar rules.
The allure of this game lies in its enigmatic and horrifying nature. As you progress, the once-mysterious laws of this world become more familiar, yet it remains captivating to play.

Positive aspects of the game include:
- An astonishing and distinctive world, introducing strange and new forces of nature to contend with
- Engaging characters with emotionally charged and well-executed dialogues
- Superb art direction, showcasing beautiful landscapes throughout
- Unique gameplay: While it is a delivery game, it also incorporates action and armed combat (although this is not the main focus of the game), and delivering packages is surprisingly enjoyable and very addictive

My rating: 2/5 (bad)
I tried to like this game but I just can't get into it. The main gameplay loop is boring and tedious. There are also many irritants such as clunky menu screens that are visually confusing. They throw a lot of techno babble at you with made-up words that are not well explained. You do all these deliveries yet the world is empty of people and you don't go in the supposed cities, just the delivery terminals. It also takes me out of the game to see other players stuff and "like" it.

There's a story that seems decent but I just can' be bothered to continue.

Daunting and tedious inventory management system.  Like BAD!  Convoluted mess of a GUI.  Adding, removing, replacing, dropping inventory results in many steps to do one simple thing.  Game is beautiful and quite fun and a solid challenge but the inventory management which is 95% of the functionality of this game is too much for most.  Read the reviews, even the glowing reviews rag on this.  It truly takes away from the immersion of this game and had they made this a bit more structured with less steps to click for everything, this game would be dope.  I mean, even after doing a successful delivery in this game one MUST left click the mouse about 25 times to expedite the review of your delivery status.  This as opposed to a one click done.  I really really REALLY tried to like this game.
An oddly addictive play loop, amazing visuals, and gorgeous soundtrack come together to make a truly captivating game that will keep you entertained for hours.

If you have previously played a Hideo Kojima game and didn't like it then this is not for you. If you have an are wondering what I'm talking about a Kojima game means long segments of being exposition dumped or hearing a character tell your their wacky and contrived origin-story. It means naively thinking that the game is over before being hit by 2-3 more hours of playtime and cutscenes that means you finish the game at 2 AM in a delirious state, waking up the next morning wondering whether or not it was just a weird dream. BUT, and I don't know whether it is just Stockholm syndrome or not, I promise these cheesy Kojima games always seem to hit you right in the feels at the end in a way that makes all the ridiculousness worth it. They always have a really good credits song as well.

Jokes and warnings aside, this game does a lot of things that are unique and interesting if you are okay and aware of the above. This game is all about working to make connections with others. Whether that be leaving a ladder or a zip-line in the perfect spot for future players to have an easier time, or helping all these eccentric NPC's with their life problems in the grand attempt to reconnect America after an apocalyptic and isolating event. It doesn't seem very meaningful when you read it but the first time I thoughtlessly "5-starred' my connection with someone only to be given a gift of a unique and helpful item, something only that character could make, this virtual experience suddenly felt very real and very human. I don't normally go out of my way to be a completionist but these connections felt meaningful in a way that I haven't experienced often in video games. They felt like real people I wanted to go out of my way to help and their gratitude felt meaningful and genuine. I am always a fan of games that try to make you be a better person and between all of the Kojima ridiculousness this is one of them.

I also want to say that this game turns the traditional open world design on it's head in a very clever and interesting way. Most open world games just spread the content across vast open spaces that take a long time to traverse, ultimately hurting the games replayablility. In this game traveling from point A to B IS the content, the destinations are just where you go to rest and get more packages. You can take the long and easy path or you can use any of the growing amount of tools you are given to make your traversal easier, the gameplay is conquering that distance and finding the shortest and safest path to where you need to go. It gives this game the replay value that other open world games lack.

I'm not much into repetitive games, but Death Stranding really captivated me! The graphics are stunning, and the gameplay system is as well - it even becomes calming in some way... Yet what truly drew me in was the deeply engaging story and the unprecedented gaming mechanism that challenges the conventions of traditional games.

The post-apocalyptic setting of the game, with breathtaking landscapes and a sense of solitude, created a unique atmosphere that kept me fully immersed in the experience. Exploring the open world while carrying valuable cargo through rugged terrain brought a sense of challenge and achievement that kept me coming back for more.

Moreover, the connection with other players, even indirectly, through shared structures and messages left behind, added a fascinating layer to the game.

After visiting Iceland, I was inspired to give the game a try, as the game's terrain and environment reminded me of the stunning landscapes I had witnessed during my trip. Overall, Death Stranding was a truly unique experience.

Death Stranding is a game that requires lots of your time and dedication, It's an amazing game don't get me wrong, but it's a very slow one. The story begins very mysterious and vague and in my opinion starts to get good about 30 hours in, probably because I tried to 100% everything before moving onto the next story mission, but it did feel slow. However, the sophisticated gameplay and visually stunning graphics help a lot. 

The gameplay it's very rewarding and challenging depending on your difficulty levels, people say this is a walking or UPS simulator, but it's got so much more, you have to plan almost every initial delivery but also by building new structures and using an specific path you make future deliveries a lot easier. I believe what makes Death Stranding a great game it's the online functionality, helping other players by donating resources, building Zip line networks using already placed Zip lines and lots of other interaction make the whole thing more connected and welcoming.

This review is mostly about the base version (126 hours), since I only wanted to try out the director's cut new features, but I have to say that even after playing just 4 hours on the new version I definitely recommend playing that one instead of the original. While not so many changes were made, they were mostly QoL updates and a few new items, but those do make a difference!, and the cosmetics are really cool.

I definitely recommend playing this game to 100%, get all the tools, items and lore, it's wroth it and you'll understand more the beautiful yet complicated story, be sure to get it as soon as you can and try it out, you might not like it at first but give it time and you'll definitely enjoy the unique experience.

Masterpiece.

A calm, addicting, and emotional journey connecting the United Cities of America, conveyed through an emotionally distant man that you connect with more than you'd think. Easily one of the best games released in the last few years.

As someone who suffered an event in life that caused me to lose everything, was forced to try and fit in and continue at life through severe depression, and had to "Repatriate" so to speak several times when I suffered an emotional death that caused me cut everyone out of my life and avoid everything, stay offline and block everyone... This game hit deep... never smilling or touching anyone, and avoiding everything, then Covid 19 hits and I laugh like... psh... this has no effect on me. Then I eventually play this game and it hit me like a friggen truck... 

I played this on a whim, kind of as a silly joke because it was on sale and I wanted to see the "Walking Simulator" and laugh and say Kojima was going through some kind of phase and made a crazy weird game. Then I saw there was a multiplayer element and genuinely almost quit because I refused to play with other people, even felt cheated or like getting a refund... but I kept through it, made fun of it as I was playing and the laughs turned silent... this somehow bacame one of my favorite games of all time, no joke this game was amazing. This was so deep from the art to the style of gameplay to the music to pointless little details and overly annoying message about uniting people that I wound up feeling weird about getting into...

Found myself building bases and helping people, not even for likes, just... felt like I was doing something helpful... I dunno... I went through allot of emotions , even with the soundtrack and some of those songs.. "Pale Yellow" for example. "Asylum for the feeling"...

Anyhow I don't know if I can recommend this game for everyone, it may be too weird, to scifi, to horror'y actiony, emotinal, dramatic, I don't know, some people wont be into this... but dam that was one of the most incredible game experiences I've had, no lie. That was real art... For the people this game is meant for.. they are missing out on something huge if they don't play it. Allot of deep lessons and epic experiences and battles in here. lol So much more than a ... walking simulator lol

My review of Death Stranding as a whole is up top, My review of the directors cut additions can be found below.

=====================================================================================

I cant honestly review death Stranding without spoiling major story beats. So warning, spoilers below.

I am one of the four people who is obsessed with death stranding and I don't really know why. Its weird, its clever, its stupid. Breaking it apart to review each individual component (graphics, sound design, story, etc) would reveal a mehh title, but as a whole its so much more (and less) than the sum of its parts. The soundtrack and world building do a lot of the heavy lifting, but the appeals to "gamers" bring it down and it drops the ball in a lot of places. I still love the game, but I'm aware of its flaws.

I was first attracted to death stranding by its bizarre trailers, and the game does not disappoint in the bizarre. I wanted to know what drove that guy to such desperation to stab himself when being pulled into the sky by some mysterious giant... man shaped thing. Whats up with the body bag twitching and turning into tar? Why does Normal Reedus have a baby in his throat? Whattup with all the dead whales, dolphins, fish and crab seemingly having some kind of wire ran from their bellies into the ocean? And the floating people far off? What neat imagery, I cant wait to learn why! The answer to all this, unfortunately, is because it looks mysterious and cool, well not the guy stabbing himself, he had good reason to try to end himself before what happens, happens. The fish, crabs, dolphins and whales are tied to astrological signs but their not explained any further than that. Norman Reedus has a baby in his throat because he has a baby on his chest, it might have some kind of metaphorical reason, but that's really it. The world building around what and why happens to corpses is in depth, and I feel like id be doing a disservice to explain it, and at that point this "review" would become just a bunch of explanations and I have other things I need to talk about.

Such as the boss fights. The boss fights are meant to appeal to "gamers" and I think they make the game worse overall being what they are. The game is much scarier, and better when fighting back isnt an option, and the boss fights force only that option, kill it or be killed. The Boss Boss fights against Mads Mikkelsen are neat but suffer from the exact same problem, but with guns this time. The coolest thing that comes from these boss boss fights are the beaches themselves, being where your soul gets stranded if you and a bunch of other people die at once or in great agony, so Mads's beaches are themed around the great wars and Vietnam. I would have loved to see some truly tragic beaches however. What does Hiroshima and Nagasaki's beaches look like? The Japanese coast with its frequent tsunamis would make for a particularly tragic beach. 9/11? 

The very final boss fight is one of the weirdest things I've ever seen, full of surface level video game references, its Bayonetta levels of odd and is completely out of place in death stranding, its like Hideo is telling us to not take the game so seriously, but..... First you fight and kill a giant bt, then you learn about a suicidal god of death and that explains the extinction event(The Death Stranding), but doesn't explain it at all. Then you punch Higs in the face a few times on a beach, then the game returns back to normal like nothing ever happened (but with one more, very cool bt fight against a giant bt whale). If the game just faded to black and rolled credits after fighting the final giant bt and connecting the qpid it would have been a better game. The Higs fight only works to degrade the final product. Don't get me wrong, I liked Higs as a villain and his character design tells you a lot about how the death stranding happened if you pay attention, but at the same time, the final confrontation with him is a major let down.

The core game-play loop of delivering packages though haunted and hostile yet beautiful landscapes is neat, but can be boring once you've built roads and zip lines. The story itself is entertaining and odd, typical Hideo fare. The progression is fun and fair, although, if I had my way trucks would come when you unlock mountain knot city, not much much earlier as it is now. The characters are neat, but fragile needs a rework, or at least stop having her say that stupid "I'm fragile but I'm not that fragile" line. Its stupid. Guns shouldn't exist, and their inclusion gives people the wrong idea about the game. Its worth mentioning that the original Death Stranding was infested with advertisements for real world products, namely monster and Norman Reedus's Ride. These are almost gone in directors cut, monster is entirely removed and the only reference to Ride is a single Bike. I understand their placements though as the game wouldn't have been able to be made without some form of sponsorship.

Death stranding pulls a Dark Souls in some of its world building. The qpid is covered in mathematical formula, the Einstein field equations, the quantum entanglement equations, the reaction-diffusion system model, the Higgs field, the Dirac equation and the Schwarzchild Radius, but these are never called out, only being visible in the brief cut scenes when you connect the device. Higs is covered in similar tattoos, namely parts of electromagnetic tensors equations and quantum field theory equations. I don't know this for myself but that's what internet discussions have come to the conclusion of. What that might mean and why, I wont delve into as I'm not smart enough to explain my thought process behind what I think is happening, but any students of physics and philosophy should be able to follow the threads to a meaningful conclusion. Without this knowledge your left very much in the dark about what caused the Death Stranding, other than "dunno, one day people started turning into ghosts that summon other ghosts that eat people and explode". There are also endless emails and data points that explain and over explain and over over explain certain aspects of the death stranding and its effects on our psychology, its just that the questions you really want answered will remain in the dark unless you dig. Most videos of people who try to explain what the death stranding is are wrong or very surface level, never digging into what isn't said or these formula, which is a shame because they all seem so certain that they've got the correct answers, when its not that simple and are harming future interpretations.

=====================================================================================

Here be my review of the directors cut changes.

Directors cut removes a lot of the advertisements and adds a new road between mountain knot city and the weather station as well as a car. Its also prettier, but the game was already gorgeous. It also adds a secret or two, minorly re-balances the mid game and adds new build-able structures that you'll almost never use because the core structures get the job done on their own, but are still fun to play around with. The only thing I don't like about the directors cut is that it isn't available for ps4, where I've poured the vast vast majority of my time before my computer was able to run the directors cut. Directors cut is more Death Stranding, its a good improvement and in my opinion worth the price.

tldr; like watching a really weird movie and playing a game with the main character between scenes.  Clunky menus and clunky movement around some of the coolest scenery I have seen in a game.  Can recommend especially if you pick it up on sale.  Would probably play better on a Playstation, this seems like a pretty bad port.  But if you don't have a PS5 this isn't a complete waste of time and money.

The Good: Awesome scenery, awesome character models, good music, and original game concepts make for a pretty enjoyable experience.  The story is pretty good at certain points which is key when so much of this game is cutscenes.  The voice acting and motion capture are next level which makes the cutscenes incredible.  Interesting enemy types and the graphical effects for the enemies are impressive.

The Bad: Horrible clunky menu which has you pressing buttons way more than you should have to.  Default game setting takes you out of game every time you engage the BT enemies and plays an animation.  Even when you turn off the setting that pulls you out of game, it still stops your vehicle in its tracks when you are close to the BT enemies which is very annoying.  

The movement on foot and driving vehicles feels very clunky on mouse and keyboard.  Driving the reverse trike can be fun at times but there is a lot of struggling smashing into rocks.  I understand Kojima was trying to simulate a top heavy courier but there are certain points when I was losing balance barely carrying anything.  Having to hold both mouse buttons for most of the game to balance got pretty old.

By the end of the game I was ready for it to be over.  Many of the NPC dialogues ramble on way longer than is necessary or enjoyable, even the ones that have a generic greeting (which is most of them).  The story is pretty hard to follow although it is weird enough to be interesting.  Only 21 percent of the playerbase has finished the last two episodes which tells me almost 80 percent didn't like the story enough to finish the game.

I love this game so much. Thank you for this wonderful experience Hideo Kojima. This game made me laugh, cry and angry. It's hard to explain this game to anyone, because it's not like any other game you've ever played. This game might not be for everyone, but it slowly grows upon you. 

Seriously, listening to various songs which come while delivering cargo, felt very satisfying after encountering a BT. The entire story of uniting the world together can be very confusing, but towards the end, when everything is revealed, it just felt so good. The characters in this game are some of the best, and I'll never forget them.

Bit of a spoiler, but I remember watching the E3 2016 reveal for the game and the song "I'll Keep Coming" by Low Roar just took me out by surprise, loved the song instantly and when I finally started playing the game, I was waiting to unlock it right from the start. Nonetheless I thought, it was only for the trailer but I was so freaking happy when I got it after finishing the game.

One of the things I loved the most about the first Dark Souls was it's passive multiplayer features. Hearing bells being rung by other players, miracle boosting spots, vagrants.. those were just small things that made the experience cooler and for a game that is slow and heavy, it's always nice to see other players. This sadly was only for the first dark souls. Every other game in the franchise (including elden ring) doesn't have anything like it and it really makes me sad.

I used to think Dark Souls 1 was the perfect example of passive multiplayer but Death Stranding goes above and beyond in this and it's something I adore. When logged in, you can see player structures or lost cargo that you can pickup and use for your playthrough. Nier Automata had something similar but to me it wasn't performed too well. They were just bloodstains from dark souls.
Receiving help from other players and going out of your way for helping others it's amazing. It's open world is not bloated with dumb content as the content itself is how you traverse through the different routes that the game offers to you. There are a few things scattered around to make the offline experience not as bad, but for the most part; online is where it's at.

There is a specific mechanic in this game that has really blown my mind which is trailblazing. When you or other people go through the same path multiple times, the path will become dirt and softer. This allows you to go your destination quicker and safer and I don't know it's so fucking cool to know that I can help others just by walking, people pleasers heaven fr fr 

The story of this game is told in a way that respects the consumer. It is usually shown or told but not explained and it's not like the games needs to be explained, really. It is an incredibly original story with concepts that are new but easily explained due to the lack of need for details. 

The gameplay itself is fantastic and rewards skill without being too hard to get into. I love the peaceful sections but the action ones can also be interesting, specially given how killing humans can often make things worse unless you're willing to be responsible for those deaths.

It's a great game but I understand it can be a hit or miss for a lot of people.
If you don't mind games where you're not actively shooting or in danger at all times such as Stardew Valley, games where you need to stop and plan ahead without much action like the first dark souls game, then you're gonna be okay. This is not a walking simulator. It can be very stressful at times but for the most part it's quite chill.

It's relaxing fun. Just avoid MULE camps, and you're free to explore without anything trying to kill you. To be fair, it does take a little bit to get going, but it's hard to put it down once you're into it.

This is a game for the patent gamer. Some might see it as a walking postman simulator, but I see it as a "sit back with a cup of coffee, and relax."

IF you fancy this game, which everybody absolutely WON'T, you'll probably never ever run out of things to do. I finished the story in 10 hours, and after that, I've been pretty much just running around building things, delivering packages, and killed BTs.

As said - if you don't understand or fancy this game, I truly get it. But I think it's a fantastic game.
Not really much to say about this, it's a nice game for when I want something more laid back. :)

Death Stranding is a truly special game. A once-in-a-generation experience.  Sure, it's not for everyone, but I think everyone should still give this game a fair try, and learn to be open to newer experiences, even if they don't fulfil the traditional definition of what you expect from a video game. This game actively reinforces how video games in general can be art, and how the medium can be used in incredibly powerful ways and allow you to engage with it in a way that no other form of media can, and very few games succeed in giving you this feeling. I don't even say this as a Kojima fanboy (although I am), but I think more gamers will likely benefit by broadening their horizons and learning to engage with a game and its themes on the game's terms. 

I think calling it just a "walking simulator" is very reductive and dismissive, the equivalent of watching something like Oppenheimer or 12 Angry Men and being like "it's just people talking". There's a great amount of depth in both the themes and the gameplay mechanics, and the way those themes are reinforced by the gameplay itself is nothing short of legendary- I mean that's almost always the case with Kojima's games but it reaches a level that it never did before.  The world is beautiful to look at and to traverse, the gameplay feels smooth and fluid, and despite me usually disliking navigating menus and complex UIs in most games, here it's mostly such a fluid experience that it rarely takes away from my immersion. I'm not exaggerating when I say that I've played this game upwards of 12-18 hours in a single sitting multiple times, and I've thoroughly enjoyed every single second. 

It's so difficult to describe the feeling when you see a structure - a zipline, a safe house, a bridge, a truck or even just a simple ladder- planted, or left abandoned, by another player at just the right place for you to be able to push through that last stretch to the destination with a heavy load that you realized too late that you were under-prepared for.  That feeling of gratitude and connection. And when you log in on some random day and see a structure you created got thousands of likes on something you built because it happened to be useful for dozens of players. It's a little silly considering how likes are sort of meaningless and any benefit you get from them is mostly secondary since equipment and structure unlocks are a thousand times more useful, but...it works, man. It's even funnier since the game lampshades this very thing and calls out how funny it is that something as inconsequential as likes can get you a oxytocin high, and reading those logs I was like "heh, sure" thinking it's just a funny gimmick. 
But by the end of the game I absolutely understood what that meant. The theme of connection and helping others in creating a better world and building structures that might only be of passing use to you but will help countless others in the future works incredibly well. When something helps you out during a difficult delivery and you feel so grateful that you're inspired to make something in return to help the journey for future travellers even easier. It's wonderful.

The open world is also possibly the best open world I've ever experienced in a game. Not only is it mesmerizingly gorgeous, it also feels very deliberate, down to the last stone. It's extremely difficult to traverse at times, but not because of wonky movement mechanics or poor collision systems or the player urge to break those mechanics as is the case with most other games,  but it is so by design. I mean, technically, you can still 'Skyrim-horse' your way up some inclines using trucks or motorcycles but they also have their battery limits too, and sometimes that's far more inefficient than abandoning them and moving on foot at some point, so it's not exactly something you can consistently break- but regardless. It's very easy to immerse yourself in the loop of micro-managing your inventory, macro-managing your trips and losing yourself as you put one foot in front of the next. If you find yourself engaged with this gameplay loop, you'll be losing dozens of hours in the game before you even know it. The difficulty is highly dependent on your patience and your preparation. Theoretically, if you prepare well enough  and pay attention to what the game tells you, plus plan for your future deliveries, you can prepare well enough to make the game a breeze to walk past. But the game also throws enough curveballs and challlenges to not make it all mindless, and still leave room for a fair bit of improvisation during the journey. 

Every design decision feels extremely deliberate and very well-polished in this game. Sure, there are some things that are somewhat annoying- such as navigating different menus for private lockers, share lockers, for claiming cargo or for donating cargo, for recycling equipment, for claiming materials, etc. Not to mention the mini-cutscenes and dialogues you have to hear over and over at times. But still, for the most part, it feels natural and fluid and none of it takes me out of the game or bores me or makes it feel tedious even though it easily could have (or I'm sure it does for many other players). 

Moving on to slightly spoilery territory (you've been warned)- firstly, the combat.

To begin with, you're not a stealth commando. you're not an action hero. You're a porter, a deliveryman in a post-apocalyptic world. And the combat makes you feel that way. Your guns don't have perfect accuracy, your actions are not necessarily faster than your enemies, and you need to prepare well in advance before you head out to take on a horde of goons. But it still feels nice and just on the cusp of easy and difficult. If you're skilled enough, you can Rambo it up and take on 20 thugs at once, or you can cheese it out and bombard them with stun grenades from afar. That choice is entirely dependent on how confident you are on your skills, how much patience you have, how much risk you're willing to take, and most importantly- what's most fun for you. I also love how this game, like most Kojima games, offers you a choice between going non-lethal or lethal, and how (depending on how you look at it) it rewards and punishes either choice but still heavily encourages non-lethal based on the themes of the game. In my 110 hour playthrough I never killed a single person. 

The story, however. Although I understand the themes, and the overview, there are still so many details that don't necessarily make sense to me. I don't know if I can buy this universe and the characters and their motivations as easily as I could in Kojima's earlier games, and I'll definitely have to spend a long time marinating these details in my head and playing and analyzing the game over and over before I can truly grasp it or to even decide whether I like it or not, but I have to admit that I did not fall in love with it as easily as I did in every Kojima game prior. I expect that to change soon because it did grow on me by the end, but still, not to the extent I had hoped. The story is also extremely front and back heavy which will definitely turn off a lot of players, but I don't mind that and I've come to expect that in most Kojima games, hell, I think it's even a good signature style and I don't want him to change that for anything. I play his games for a certain experience and it delivers. 
Although this time, I have to admit that the ending hours, although touching, were getting a little hard for me to sit through, but I honestly blame only myself for this because I decided to end the game with a 14 hour binge. 

There's also a lot of MGS V DNA in this game, in a good way.  I have so many more thoughts but apparently character limits are a thing in Steam review. So, as a conclusion- I absolutely adore this game and I loved every second. The moment I finished it I already wanted to start it over, and I'll remember this experience for the rest of my life.

This is a unique and intriguing game that defies easy categorization. It's part open-world adventure, part walking simulator, and part sci-fi thriller, all wrapped up in a package that's both beautiful and haunting.

At its core, Death Stranding is about connection - both the connections between people and the connections between life and death. As Sam Porter Bridges, you traverse a barren and desolate landscape, delivering packages and reconnecting isolated communities in a world that has been shattered by a cataclysmic event known as the Death Stranding. The gameplay is simple but engrossing, with a heavy emphasis on exploration and survival. You'll need to manage your resources carefully, navigating treacherous terrain and dealing with the ever-present threat of supernatural beings known as "Beached Things" (BTs).

What really sets Death Stranding apart, though, is its storytelling. The game is a masterclass in atmosphere and mood, with a sense of existential dread that permeates every moment. The performances from the cast are top-notch, with Norman Reedus turning in a standout performance as Sam Porter Bridges. The game's themes of isolation, grief, and the fragility of human connection are all expertly woven into the narrative, creating an experience that is both emotional and thought-provoking.

That being said, Death Stranding isn't for everyone. The pacing can be slow at times, with long stretches of walking punctuated by brief moments of action. The game's mechanics can also feel repetitive, with many missions involving little more than delivering packages from point A to point B. Some players may find the game's story and themes pretentious or overly convoluted, and the game's steep learning curve may turn off more casual players.

Overall, Death Stranding is a game that's not afraid to take risks. It's a haunting and beautiful experience that's unlike anything else out there, with a compelling story and top-notch performances. While it's not for everyone, those who are willing to take the journey will be rewarded with an experience that's truly unique.

Hideo Kojima's Death Stranding is a polarizing masterpiece, an experience that defies conventional gaming norms and challenges players to grapple with the profound themes of human connection, isolation, and the consequences of our actions in a post-apocalyptic world.

The game introduces us to Sam Porter Bridges, convincingly portrayed by Norman Reedus. He is a courier who travels in a destroyed world and is supposed to bring together the scattered survivors. At its core, Death Stranding is about rebuilding human relationships in a broken society that reflects the fragmentation of our modern lives. It forces players to consider the weight of their own interactions and the impact on others, because every ladder, rope, and bridge built by players can help other travelers on their journey.

One of the most striking aspects of Death Stranding is the mesmerizingly desolate landscape, a hauntingly beautiful depiction of a world pushed to the edge. The game's graphics and sound design are simply breathtaking, creating an eerie atmosphere that resonates long after you put down the controller.

The gameplay, often criticized for its repetitive delivery missions, can be seen as a metaphor for the monotony and routine that sometimes plague our own lives. Kojima's decision to lean into that monotony may frustrate some players, but it's a deliberate choice that challenges us to find meaning in the seemingly mundane. Each trek through rugged terrain becomes a journey of self-discovery, contemplation, and meditation.

Perhaps the most thought-provoking aspect of Death Stranding is its examination of death and the afterlife. The concept of "stranding" explores the idea that death is not an end but a transition, and the "Stranded Things" (BTs) that haunt the world blur the lines between life and death, blurring the existential boundaries we often take for granted.

In summary, Death Stranding is an immersive, ambitious, and thought-provoking experience that challenges players to reflect on their own existence, the connections they make, and the consequences of their actions. It's not a game for everyone, and its deliberate pacing and complex narrative may deter some, but for those willing to embark on this enigmatic journey, Death Stranding offers a unique and profound reflection on the human condition in an age of digital disconnection.

This game like the original has a special place in my heart. I sometimes have a week where things go bad and I need to let off some steam and relax and this is that game that cures that. No pvp and no disaster issues just working your butt of to improve yourself and deliver to stations. The best part of it all is when you go from a basic support frame to the next frames and it just makes things easier and faster than before and more convenient and you end up getting the next upgrade and the next one. The story is somewhat confusing at first but the more you think about it and read about it, it makes sense. The depth of the story is primarily based on the main characters interaction with others but you can tell there are some things that fall in place overtime. Mads and Norman are two excellent characters in this game with excellent performances. I hope the next iteration just builds on everything excellent on this game.

Kojima does it again

It should be pretty obvious that this game's focus is an adventure game where the primary obstacle is the land between you and your destinations. This means it's deeper than just being a "walking simulator" as your journeys are hard and require attention, thinking, and some degree of stealth due to murderous ghosts or crazy lunatics. On top of this, the game world is just overall beautiful, with the only caveat being that the game world probably should've been twice as large; the "great plains" region in the game is practically non-existent sadly.

There are a few notable issues with the game, though:

You need at least 4GB of vram so the game won't stutter horribly, which means older computers might not be capable of even the lowest settings. If you only have 4GB of vram you need to set streaming memory to the lowest setting to avoid stuttering. If you have more than 4GB of vram you can set it to the highest setting.

Tutorial tips overload. Thankfully you can skip/speed through these but unfortunately there's literally about 100 of these that will keep coming up regularly until the end of the game and after reading them the first time you have to find them in the pause menu to look at them again to get rid of the "unread" indicator on already-read tutorial tips.

Cutscenes/dialog. It's a Kojima game so you have to deal with tons of repetitive dialog and cutscenes that vary from relevant to irrelevant in regards to the actual gameplay. Everything's skippable, but I've only felt like skipping 1 or 2 cutscenes in the entire game which is better than some other games (like Hardspace Shipbreaker where I wanted to skip every dialog/cutscene but they're all unskippable D:<)

Combat. It's in there mostly because someone decided invisible murderous ghosts wasn't enough, but somehow they half-assed the combat despite the game being produced/directed by the Metal Gear Solid guy. Just take the long way around human enemies, unlike those murderous ghosts the human enemies always leave a way to walk around their territory.

It's weird. Slow. But very cathartic if you're looking for something different from the norm. If you want guns & shooting etc, play MGSV Phantom Pain. Just don't expect either game to really explain jack shit. It's still Kojima.

玩到了第六章开头，前面积压的枯燥和不满的情绪终于得到了剧情的安抚。
玩之前就看到有评价说这个游戏核心玩法是送快递，我还以为只是一种比喻，没想到真的就是字面意义的送快递。
先说缺点吧，
这个游戏最大的问题是，剧情叙事和游玩割裂得太严重了。对于故事和背景的讲述，全部被封装在过场动画、交货后的投影，和数据文档里面。在你探索世界、执行任务的过程中，你得不到什么信息。说白了就是，玩家了解剧情的过程完全是被动的，而互动的部分玩家得不到什么关于剧情的信息。这使得游玩体验的吸引力大打折扣，不够引人入胜。
第二点和第一点相关，就是游戏世界里，没有太多能引发玩家思考、推理的设计，显得空无一物。像《荒野大镖客》里，地图上会有各种随机事件、兴趣点，引发你对西部世界、对时代背景、对故事情节的思考，有些甚至布置得像犯罪现场，让玩家可以去推理还原现场经过。这一点在《死亡搁浅》里是完全没有的，只是截至目前没有遇到。
第三点，纯吐槽，看交货后的神态僵硬的全息投影真的看吐了，而且还莫名其妙是个仰视视角。
第四点，摩托车越野手感过于糟糕，骑个山地磕磕绊绊听sam吭哧吭哧的真是哭笑不得
值得夸夸的地方
1. 设定还是挺有意思的，虽然在地球上，但游戏里的世界有很强的异世界的感觉
2. 游戏的重点放在连接和建造，而非破坏上，讲究和环境的互动，因地制宜
3. 优化好，界面清爽（除了地图），游玩体验流畅
4. Low roar的配乐是真的好听啊，很治愈。当游戏开始Don't be so serious响起的时候非常惊艳。
5. 主角的各种小动作、自言自语显得很真实，还会和摄像机互动，打破次元壁
6. 作为摄影爱好者，觉得游戏的拍照系统很赞，可调整的参数很齐全，如果能加入快门速度调整就更完美了

I understand now, I understand why I like this game.
This game is an experience and definitely isn't for everyone. The rating system on steam is honestly really primitive and needs to be reworked because I can only choose to either recommend the game or not. 
I can't in good faith recommend this game to just anyone however a lot of love and care went into creating this experience and I really like it. 
This game is like a movie with almost no bugs to speak of. (I can't even really remember any bugs, not even small ones.) 
What's even more impressive is the story. 
Is it convoluted? very. 
Should game stories be made like this? no, just no.
And yet I find myself coming back, wanting to make America whole again one package at a time.
The community of the game and the feeling of doing your part is what keeps me coming back wanting more not to mention the really cool technology and the interesting take on combat.
In the beginning the mules are a big threat. If you overload yourself and get spotted by mules with no way back, in short you are gonna get shanked and your stuff will be lost and likely damaged on top of that. 
However, when its later in the game you will learn how to fight back and even learn new tactics to fight back.
[spoiler]If you are having trouble with mules in an area try using the electric stun gun on the mules when they are in water. you're welcome.[spoiler]
same with with the BT's but it's slightly different. Instead of action you get stealth where you have to be very careful in the beginning. What makes it even more difficult is the timefall which causing your equipment to deteriorate and your packages to become damaged. So it's advised to be prepared and use every weapon you can to your advantage.

In short, this game has absorbed my soul and ever since covid-19 shook up the world this game has helped me become whole again.

I haven't invested much time in story driven games, so I might not have such a solid base for comparison with other games. However, I can say this game is quite something else, probably the best and most unique experience I've had in a game.

Earlier on, it might be hard to invest in. There's a lot of information to take in, things might take some time to understand. I actually went several months without playing the game after the first couple of chapters, not because I didn't like it, but because I felt like each time I logged in, I had to invest a lot. I felt the game drained me to my very core, both physically and emotionally. I'm not the only one to have felt like this, I've seen a lot of people that have been through a similar situation as well, and say this is more of an "acquired taste".

This, I believe, is due to the way the game was made: you have very long moments of bliss and chill - long walks where you take in the amazing graphics and ambience, the music that perfectly envelops it all -, but those moments are punctuated by moments of increasing tension - like timefall and encounters with BTs, MULE camps, or cutscenes.

That's the beauty of it, it's not an action packed, all highs sort of game. But the way that the lows and the highs are intertwined is ingeniously crafted, and that's what makes this experience amazing. It might feel somewhat boring, confusing or unpleasant at first (depending on who you ask), and it might take some time to get used to, but I think it's a necessary step for you to be fully invested for the rest of the game.

Once you're invested, though, it is indeed a rollercoaster as you reach the end!
Great game if you want to put yourself to sleep.

This was an experience I will never forget. Death stranding is THE trailblazing game, if you ever wanted to be the first person to hike out to the middle of nowhere or up a giant mountain this is your game. Death Stranding is about preparation, decision making, the struggle of existence, and doing what you can to make someone else's life that much better. I really do mean that you help other players, the story and unique multiplayer system tie in together in that your rebuilding america for the NPCs but also for other players in the shared world. You never see these players in person but their marks on the world are everywhere and can do anything from wish you good luck to saving you 10 minutes or from death. 

The story is its own beast but its, unique. I enjoyed it a lot but It has its flaws. If you can Id recommend you give this game a try. Its a truly weird but satisfying game.
One-of-a-kind game, highly recommended.

[h1] STORY [/h1]

Hideo Kojima is the only person who can create hundreds of logs explaining a story and still create a mystery. This is genuinely the craziest game I've played, the story is just absolutely mind fucking. Took me so long to understand but once I figured it all out I just couldn't stop thinking about the game. The great thing about the story is that you can't just pick up on it from the start and get it at the end. You really have to pay attention and piece the story together bit by bit until you come to an understanding. It's honestly so confusing but it might just be one of the greatest stories I've ever witnessed.

[h1] GAMEPLAY [/h1]

There are probably more people who hate this game than love it, but it's because the walking to point A to B type of play isn't right for everyone. On paper, the game should not be fun, but some how just walking or driving around the environment is just so amusing. Something about this game is so addicting that it's unhealthy. So far I've had 3 addictions, one on the original game and 2 on this version. Once this game gets you hooked there is no way to break free, the only way to escape is to beat the game, but then a year later you will see a thumbnail of [b] Death stranding [/b] and decide to start a new game and go through it all over again.
The movement and controls are a little clunky and annoying but they still work for combat. The combat is pretty fun but only in close range with human enemies. Now the driving will absolutely piss you off every time you hop on in a vehicle. if you try it you will know what I mean.

[h1] RATING [/h1]

I personally would give the game a very solid [b] 8.5/10 [/b] because the story is absolutely immaculate along with the map design but the gameplay itself isn't loads to look at.
Can Die-Hardman STFU?

I would recommend this game if you have the right mindset for it, or the desire to follow the story. Because, while it innovates and/or proposes new gameplay options not often found in other games, the gameplay loop is lacking; deliveries remain almost the same from beginning to end with little variation in how fun they could be, only different ways to approach them, but once you reach certain early stage of the game, they are mostly done in the same manner. Combat remains largely boring and lackluster from start to finish, including boss fights which are, surprisingly, even more boring.

However, the game shines through its narrative, atmosphere, cutscenes, music, themes, characters and world-building; it all strikes the right balance of emotions, seriousness and silliness. The psychological, societal and self-discovery themes are treated excellently in a manner that few games could achieve.

I did 0 research before trying this out as a joke but this might be one of the best games I've ever played. Never would I imagine being hooked up to a delivery game, but the charming cameos and lovely face acting, the timely music tracks setting the atmosphere in a quiet game of mostly wilderness, and the dopamine hits during combat / tasks, and the feeling of achievement when you get that parcel to the destination. A must try with a little patience.

CONS:

- Unskippable annoying short cutscenes (Recycling - I am looking at you)

PROS:

- Interesting world-building & scenario
- Overall clever and demanding game mechanics that require thinking & planning
- Very good physics system in regards to human movement ("walking simulator")
- Completely new, novel concept that probably no other game on the market has right now

NEUTRALS:

Still, the game is very playable, but this is not a game for everybody. 

If you're into new revolutionary things that do stuff differently, this is a game for you. Otherwise better skip it, or you're in for a world of pain.

I have been playing PC games for over 25 years. Whenever you hear the name Hideo Kojima on any game created or developed, you know straight away it requires an immediate audience without delay. The man requires no introduction, he is one of the greatest game developers in existence. For those who are unaware he essentially created/designed Metal Gear Solid.. flex. 

The intro itself is balls to the wall, if that doesn't pull you in and set the scene then the game will have no effect.

Death stranding is a particular case of enigmatic art. After 137 hours of gameplay both finishing the storyline and some grinding, I will safely name this one of the best games I have played in a decade without hesitation.

To be frank, DS is a dichotomy or two realities if you will. An incredibly detailed open world, post apocalyptic simulation. On the other hand, 11 hours of cut scenes, that have a plot much like you would see from M. Night Shyamalan movies. Weird, eerie and beautiful to say the least, It is a masterpiece filled with love, war, hope and futility. This literally could of been made into a tv show or movie adaptation with global success.

Where to begin, Norman Reedus (from the walking dead) is the protagonist and beautifully portrayed in both graphical design and voice acting. This extends to others such as Mads Mikkelsen (Casino Royale), Léa Seydoux (Spectre and No time to die) and Guillermo Del Toro (director of the Hobbit). An incredible and effective cast of talent that created a unique Chiral Connection!

As I stated above, at its foundations, DS is a walking/delivery simulation. For a real world example you are UPS courier if you're American and an Aus postie if you are Australian! Your job as a courier is to deliver supplies/cargo across the United States to isolated areas to reconnect people via a network. The land is post-apocalyptic, is dangerous, has rough terrain, with bandits and creatures of the undead that inhabit the land.
 
This is a game of strategy not brute force. Your delivery reputation in this game is everything.
You will be given challenges that you must overcome, like crossing rivers, mountains, snow etc. You have to carry items that are fragile, have time limits, have certain conditions that must be met.

However you will have many tools at your disposal and some that will present itself as time goes on to make things much easier. Furthermore other players will interact with your environment. Making many things more fortuitous in game. You will rebuild along the way, in the form of structures and roads, which also in turn helps other players.

The game will appear to start out slow, but it builds with time. It is suitable for players who like an essence of grinding, as opposed to fast action pace games like COD. You have to be strategic and surgical at times with a learning curve.

Overall, the game received positive reception from reviewers and critics alike. The only real downsides to the game I had was I guess clunky controls at times. But I really had no other graphic errors or the like that severely affected my experience. In fact it was quite seamless.

I was not privy to playing this game when it was released in 2019/2020 during the early days of the pandemic, but the game does portray themes such as isolation and loneliness which Im sure people would have found similarities at the time to the current world situation and even now. It is an emotional game and it will resonate with people in one way or another.

Time, effort and creativity was put in this this game, it is commendable and Honorable. It reminds me of the old days where video game creators cared about the games they created and delivered instead of delivering AAA polished crap these days to make  a quick dollar. This is why Kojima is so distinct - +100 likes 

In conclusion, its a must play but it is easily over 100 hours. Well worth it in my experience. Your either going to love it or hate it.

Enjoy the game and keep on keeping on folks.

This is one of the most interesting gaming experiences I've had. It's a masterpiece, but you need to set aside some time to fully enjoy. It's very slow and quiet, you need to be deliberate about how you play, and you need to be patient. It's a long game which took me roughly 10 hours to really open up.

Once it opens up, you're greeted by an open world that often leaves you alone with your thoughts for long periods. A lot of the game play is spent trying to find a way to get from point A to point B. Combat is infrequent, often giving the player the option of avoiding enemies altogether. The online community is something that makes this game really shine. Buildings, roads, vehicles, items and resources are shared among worlds, with lead to a fascinating cooperative experience that I found very rewarding.

The presentation is wonderful. Graphics, story, design. It is very much a Kojima game. It ranges from camp to emotionally poignant, funny and terrifying, frustrating and fulfilling. And it does these things very well. The sound design and music wrap it together quite nicely.

10/10, loved every bit of it. However, know that this is not an action game. It is often lonely and quiet. It's a game that took 50+ hours to finish. There are long cutscenes. But it's worth playing.

I have so many mixed feelings on this game. It creates an incredible atmosphere that I've never seen anywhere else through its visuals, sound design, and music choice. On the other hand, this has the most convoluted, nonsensical plot and frustrating gameplay I've ever forced myself to engage with. The phrase "Kojima sniffing his own farts" really encapsulates how I feel about the story. And I just don't understand how Kojima made MGV, which had some of the best feeling gameplay and movement I have ever interacted with, only to make an actual rock tripping simulator where Sam fights like he's under water. Again, the soundtrack and visuals created breathtaking moments, but I would never subject myself to playing this again.

"Death Stranding" is an unforgettable experience and a fresh take on gaming. The goal is to connect fragmented America, and as the game progresses, it revolves around making deliveries. It might seem tough at first, but you receive help through structures and equipment upgrades. As you travel, the beauty of nature surrounds you, but watch out for the menacing BTs (ghostly enemies) and the MULES (thieving terrorists).

The story starts by showcasing the breathtaking natural landscape that becomes the game's backdrop. You become Sam Porter Bridges (played by Norman Reedus) and get to know him deeply. The game introduces several characters, each with their own stories. The narrative hooks you by offering answers while leaving you with questions. The cast's acting immerses you, and the frequent cutscenes, while plenty, keep you engaged in the plot. The game provides a sense of purpose by letting you assist others by upgrading structures, building roads, and delivering lost items. The vehicles are a bit tricky to control, though.

The game's music is a prominent feature that should not be neglected. The carefully planned soundtrack wonderfully compliments the gameplay and mood, amplifying the emotional impact of important moments. The music swells and flows at just the perfect moments, bringing depth to the experience.

In conclusion, "Death Stranding" is an 11/10 for me. It hooked me right from the start with its freshness. Some might find delivering cargo a bit dull, but the sense of satisfaction and the joy of helping others more than makeup for it. The idea of donating and upgrading structures is truly appealing. Most importantly, I'm not one to cry during movies or games, but "Death Stranding" had me shedding tears. I'm eagerly looking forward to "Death Stranding 2."

Hopefully, more movie stars will find the gaming industry appealing enough and come and give performances like those in this game.

[b]Waiting for Godot[/b]
(tragicomedy in 2 acts)

[By Samuel Beckett]

[i]Estragon
Vladimir
Lucky
Pozzo
a boy[/i]

[b]ACT I[/b]

[i]A country road. A tree. Evening.[/i]

[i]Estragon, sitting on a low mound, is trying to take off his boot. He pulls at it with both hands, panting.
He gives up, exhausted, rests, tries again.
As before.
Enter Vladimir.[/i]

[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] [i](giving up again).[/i] Nothing to be done.
[b]VLADIMIR:[/b] [i](advancing with short, stiff strides, legs wide apart).[/i] I'm beginning to come round to that opinion. All my life I've tried to put it from me, saying Vladimir, be reasonable, you haven't yet tried everything. And I resumed the struggle. [i](He broods, musing on the struggle. Turning to Estragon.)[/i] So there you are again.
[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] Am I?
[b]VLADIMIR:[/b] I'm glad to see you back. I thought you were gone forever.
[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] Me too.
[b]VLADIMIR:[/b] Together again at last! We'll have to celebrate this. But how? (He reflects.) Get up till I embrace you.
[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] [i](irritably).[/i] Not now, not now.
[b]VLADIMIR:[/b] [i](hurt, coldly).[/i] May one inquire where His Highness spent the night?
[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] In a ditch.
[b]VLADIMIR:[/b] [i](admiringly).[/i] A ditch! Where?
[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] [i](without gesture).[/i] Over there.
[b]VLADIMIR:[/b] And they didn't beat you?
[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] Beat me? Certainly they beat me.
[b]VLADIMIR:[/b] The same lot as usual?
[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] The same? I don't know.
[b]VLADIMIR:[/b] When I think of it… all these years… but for me … where would you be… [i](Decisively.)[/i] You'd be nothing more than a little heap of bones at the present minute, no doubt about it.
[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] And what of it?
[b]VLADIMIR:[/b] [i](gloomily).[/i] It's too much for one man. [i](Pause. Cheerfully.)[/i] On the other hand what's the good of losing heart now, that's what I say. We should have thought of it a million years ago, in the nineties.
[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] Ah stop blathering and help me off with this bloody thing.
[b]VLADIMIR:[/b] Hand in hand from the top of the Eiffel Tower, among the first. We were respectable in those days. Now it's too late. They wouldn't even let us up. [i](Estragon tears at his boot.)[/i] What are you doing?
[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] Taking off my boot. Did that never happen to you?
[b]VLADIMIR:[/b] Boots must be taken off every day, I'm tired telling you that. Why don't you listen to me?
[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] [i](feebly).[/i] Help me!
[b]VLADIMIR:[/b] It hurts?
[b]ESTRAGON:[/b] [i](angrily).[/i] Hurts! He wants to know if it hurts!

I did not finish the game because it felt way too bloated. Despite enjoying the gameplay in the beginning, after a while, I felt like my time was being wasted. I particularly enjoyed the hiking simulator aspect of the game. The challenge of navigating difficult and gorgeously rendered terrains with the tools you brought along was fun initially. However, the same terrains you conquer end up becoming monotonous as you have to traverse them repeatedly.

The first time you climb a mountain is really enjoyable, but the second time becomes more of an annoyance. The story couldn't hold my interest either. I found it to be melodramatic and overly long. I read and watched a few summaries to see what I would miss, but I didn't find it appealing enough to justify playing through it.

The combat sections are frustrating, as the terrain traversal gameplay doesn't integrate well with the combat mechanics. I personally don't find this game enjoyable. While I did find the climbing mechanic reminiscent of Breath of the Wild fun, unlike that game, traversing the world in Death Stranding one isn't as rewarding or smooth as it was in The Legend of Zelda.

I believe you might appreciate this game if you enjoyed the surreal elements of the Metal Gear Solid series, don't mind lengthy cutscenes, and appreciate gameplay that rewards careful planning.

Maybe if Hideo Kohima achieves his dream of getting this game a Criterion release that could fix all the isues I have of it; Turning the cutscenes into Kino.

O lo amas ó lo odias, y yo por suerte lo ame cada segundo, excelente historia (clásico kojima), jugabilidad adictiva, gráficos impresionantes, personajes entrañables, una obra maestra no bien apreciado en su momento de salida.

Únicos puntos débiles: tal vez algunas mecánicas animadas dentro del cuarto de descanso de Sam  que se vuelven tediosas, algunas detalles con respecto a las interfaces y la manejabilidad  de algunos vehículos, pero al final de cuentas son puntos minúsculos

Bugs: el único que encontré fue un problema de cracheo en un punto especifico de juego (Timefall Farm) pero en general no era tan frecuente

una obra de arte y excelente trabajo por parte del equipo de kojima
! keep on keeping on !

traslate:

You either love it or you hate it, and luckily I love it every second, excellent story (classic kojima), addictive gameplay, impressive graphics, endearing characters, a masterpiece not well appreciated at the time of its release.

Only weak points: maybe some animated mechanics inside sam's rest room that become tedious, some details regarding the interfaces and the maneuverability of some vehicles, but in the end they are minuscule points

Bugs: the only one I found was a crashing problem at a specific point in the game (Timefall Farm) but in general it wasn't that frequent

a work of art and excellent work by the kojima team
! keep on keeping on !

Death Stranding is a game all about being a delivery boy. That's all you do the entire game: deliver packages from one customer to another, over and over again. Sounds exciting, doesn't it? Actually it's tedious and boring unless your childhood dream was to be a truck driver when you grew up. Sure you have to schedule your deliveries because of limited load carrying capabilities, and you have to avoid timefall events whenever possible, but that is very short lived compared to the time spent delivering packages. The only excitement you might experience, is when you encounter BTs, but even that is short-lived and repetitive.

The most valuable commodity in this game is likes, therefore instead of being payed money for making deliveries, you are paid with likes. As a delivery boy, you are supposed to connect to other delivery boys (and girls?) by liking the things they do, recovering any of their lost items, and building structures to make delivering packages easier for everyone involved so you can get more likes.

In Death Stranding I get to see and interact with real life famous people that the game studio is connected with that are taking part in the game. That's a nice touch but I never get to see or interact with any other players. You are all alone in Death Stranding's world, yet you are somehow supposed to feel connected or want to connect to other unknowns -- just so you can get more likes? How genuinely "connected" could that make you to them? So Death Stranding is also a story about connecting with others, just not connecting very well.

Yet I still play the game anyways. Why? Because I'm bored and because I paid for it and I want my moneys worth. And I can tell this game was made by the Japanese because the attention to (graphical and mechanical) detail is fantastic, and I get to travel and see all that detail up close. All that and I want to see where this story is going.

I didn't realize that in order to progress in the game, you have to fulfill SAMS' ORDERS, and STANDARD ORDERS are only optional. After realizing this, the game picked up a little bit for me after I changed my "strategy" of fulfilling orders, but a new problem sometimes is knowing where the next SAMS' ORDERS is going to be. But my mistake has a fortunate side effect of racking up a bunch of points that I otherwise wouldn't have ever acquired, points that make the game a little easier to play later on.

The story does get interesting at times, but unfortunately there are times when it seems to take a stroll a little bit on the sick side (but only a few times). I mean there are scenes in the game that are questionable, e.g. -- the "accidental" hints of incest with the little girl (who turns out to actually be a Japanese woman) and the implicit hints of homosexuality when you are forced into the shower with DeathMan. Numerous online posts also mention the same thing so it's not just me. Also, how mature can a game be where your "weapons" are your piss and poo that is collected every time you have to go to the bathroom?

I thought this game wouldn't be worth recommending playing, but I changed my mind. Like I said, the attention to detail (in the graphics, mechanics, and story) is enrapturing. It's also more like work than a game but to see the story progress every once in awhile somehow makes it worth the work.

WORD OF ADVICE

Save the game. A lot. There is no warning when some negative unexpected thing  will happen that you are not given time to prepare for (e.g. -- the inability to bypass BTs in some regions, even with weapons and stealth).

Be prepared for an extremely long and very boring ending in which you will not be able to save or quit the game. For example, you will be forced to sit through -- not one -- but two identical closing credit scenes.

Due to all of the above, while I would recommend this game worth playing, it would most definitely be worth playing only once. There is absolutely no replay value in playing this game twice.

This game is special to me. Playing through it and getting 100% achievements again has only cemented it as one of my absolute favorites. There's nothing quite like Death Stranding, and there are very few games which have resonated with me personally as much as it has. It truly is an incredible experience, filled with introspective, quiet moments where it's just you, BB, the terrain ahead of you, and the calming, melancholic music. I don't really know how to describe how this game makes me feel, but I love it, and if you think you might like it too, give it a try.
And remember, keep on keeping on!
Keep on keeping on

I cannot believe Kojima has done this, you are FORCED to watch the credits THREE TIMES while you are walking around on an empty beach and drip fed lore that was telegraphed 5 hours ago. Absolutely disgusting practice that should be made illegal by law.

Kojima has done it again, the story in this game is absolutely insane (in a bad way). I don't understand why this guy is still allowed to write anything at all. It starts off ok (I GUESS) but it reaches fever dream levels at an exponential rate as you are nearing the end. And oh boy is the ending 5 hours longer than it should be. Oh you thought you were done after [spoiler]defeating the OTHERWORDLY ENTITY THAT WANTS TO END THE UNIVERSE AND EVERYTHING IN IT?[/spoiler]. Nah, we're just getting started friend. Kojima is in charge and you're not getting off this train until you've watched his two feature length movies back to back starting right after you thought the game ended. And for the record, Kojima should be sent to horny jail for life (although some of those "risque" scenes were kinda funny I'll admit).

Gameplay is top notch and the only reason you should be playing a Kojima game, ever. If you agree with this statement disregard everything else I said and this review is now a thumbs up. You should definitely try this game as it does innovate in a lot of ways with fleshed out mechanics and cooperative world building that probably worked a lot better when more people were playing the game but is still impactful 2+ years after it was released (on PC). It feels  similar to MGS 5 in a lot of ways, and has a lot of gadgets of varying usefulness but always interesting in some way and easy to try out. Stacking boxes on your back made out of titanium and trying to manage terrain, horny enemies and a crying baby that WON'T SHUT UP as you're trying to cross a mountain range in the most horrendous snowstorm you've ever seen is absolutely glorious and the reason why I forgive all other transgressions in this game. Standing ovation on that front, Kojima has DONE IT AGAIN!

Since I'd played the original Death Stranding already and did a lot of walking already, and I'd spent hours building up the road networks.  Once I started Death Stranding Director's Cut, as a player in the know, I made it my mission to start plopping down ziplines everywhere I was able.  As soon as I reached a new location, I had a zipline ready, and over time my zipline network grew until I could traverse the game up and down the map just zip zip ziplining.  It felt like cheating, but it was fun.

I feel like this opened up the game so much for me, and it was a lot of fun, for me personally, climbing to ridiculous locations only to plunk a zipline there and never have to walk there again.  And always laugh everytime I zipped past that difficult location, over and over again.  I love getting the warning that BT's are near, those spooky bastards!   But my zipline has zipped past them already, and I'm off to my delivery.  :D

Death Stranding is a walking simulator that lets you get rid of the walking, and just focus on the story and otherwise fulfilling the objectives in the most efficient and brief manner you are able.  With a well maintained zipline network, anything is possible.

Death Stranding Directors Cut adds a few cosmetic and quality of life upgrades over the original Death Stranding that are really helpful, and feel hard to believe they were left out, as they fit seamlessly and add so much to the overall experience.  In any case, if you don't want to be a zipline nerd like me, you could get a bike or a truck and do it the hard way, if you want.  

All in all I think this game is awesome and really fun but maybe it might be too weird for some people.
