Depends what you like in a game I guess, for me it was OK because I soon learned that the storyline was 'challenged', there are gaping holes in the logic - clearly the work of an artist and not a scientist. Containers that degrade only after you pick them up, vehicle physics are appalling, AI can use lethal weapons with no consequence but you cannot - in fact the way the 'Mules' and 'Terrorists' level up is absurd - but then the whole story is. I particularly disliked the religious overtones that become vary apparent in the latter stages, some of the 'boss' fights are ridiculously difficult, unnecessarily so and forcing you to eat bugs - yuck and I have no idea what the intent was behind hauling a baby around the reasoning behind that escapes me entirely and it was a distraction I could have done without. What is truly annoying are the narrative parts that cannot be skipped, particularly irritating the second time around. 

So why did I continue - spent my time building stuff such as connection levels with others, roads etc etc, spent many hours doing so but this kind of gameplay may not suit those really seeking a shoot em up type gameplay - for sure Death Stranding is not that.

This is one of best games I've played in my life, and I've played thousands. Bear with me while i explain. First i'll say its personal opinion based on several existing factors that enhanced my experience with this game. Being a writer myself i could understand fine narrative points made here, the greatness and uniqueness of characters, and unprecedented game-play. This game is not for everyone for sure. Its fine tuned for people with emotional maturity, wanderlust and general taste for great storytelling. Death Stranding has it all. As being a person who has wide array of interests in cinema, music, games especially i can say from artistic point of view this game is one of few pinnacles of gaming ever made. Funny how when you see the scope of human condition, man can reach of place of disappointment in what he knows, what he has seen and experienced, yet these 150+ hours spent on this game make it quite the opposite. This game has to be made if for nothing but to prove games can be art and probably best ones in the world atm, and also that life spent in gaming and imagining, experiencing all these different lives is not wasted, all the contrary. So if you're seeking for unique lifetime experience of great narrative driven game, full of mystery, emotion, sadness and hope this is the one! Let it be an "Asylum for the feelings" for at least a little bit for you. All the best!

Thank you Mister Hideo Kojima for making this absolute epic, emotional and mindfking masterpiece !!! My new TOP 1 apocalyptical pc game. It's a title that you will remember for years.

I expected nothing when i started playing this and got completely blown away.

In 2023 this game still looks and plays super nice and pretty, i can just recommend to play it. The Devs are even working on DS2. Just info, the game was even playable on my GTX 970.

People may tell you: "THIS IS JUST A WALKING SIMULATOR"

Yes, the game starts with you WALKING in the wastelands. It's a destroyed world, what do you expect? You won't find any streets and cars in the early game. There is nothing than a beautiful, mindblowing LANDSCAPE. And you have to deliver a package to one of the last cities THROUGH this landscape. This is how the game starts. But you can't just RUSH with running forward or you will fall. The map is rocky, you have to control your feet, control your balance, control your stamina. Watch where you go. It's weird in the first minutes, yes. But when you understand the mechanic it's getting fun, fun, fun. 

And it's not just walking and running. The really good story will kick in very fast and THRILL the hell out of you. Horror elements blast in. Suddenly the rain is DANGEROUS. There are "creatures" coming for you. This is very weird, exciting and thrilling. 

The ongoing story will give you a main GOAL and many, many missions and places to get there. There are 14 chapters and even after the end you can continue playing and go back to see all the stuff you missed. Playing after the end even gives you new missions which tell you what happened to some story characters after the ending.

I recommend, DON'T RUSH THE STORY. Do the "side missions", try to max out everything that's between the story chapters and make this game last longer. Doing the side missions will give you the opportunity to upgrade new stuff.

Warning! The story is intentionally confusing. You won't understand what's going on directly from the beginning. But from chapter to chapter you will get the puzzle connected. And the story is super emotional, you will fight with tears. 
"Story" is not just text or speech. They made a BIG MOVIE out of the story. That's super cool. The game switches between the "movie story elements" and the gameplay.

One more thing about "WALKING SIMULATOR":

In the early game you have to suffer! The game makes you suffer from walking. The game will throw DIRT at you. Yes, the player gets dirty like a car from a dirt race. But this feels GOOD. Because it's like real life. You have to WORK, SUFFER AND OVERCOME before reaching a goal and the goals after a hard way are the only ones that feel good. If it was easy, it was boring.

When you connect the first waystations into the network, other players structures and warning signs appear for you. Decide if you like them or delete them. Don't worry, if you delete another players stuff, it's just in your own game. The player will keep it and it will not be deleted for others. You can even BUILD OWN STRUCTURES into the world that others can use and like.

Following the story you find an electric MOTORBIKE. Yeah, what's a movie or pc game with Norman Reedus not having a bike?

The bike lets you forget the struggle and suffer from walking and climbing.

BUT

It's an electric bike. So you have to reload it. You can build "charger structures" all around the map. Or use the structures from other players. Build it smart or the bike will run out of energy and you strand in a hostile area.

And be careful! Your first bike is unique. If you wreck it, it's lost. And you have to walk again.

In the second open world map it gets even better. YOU CAN BUILD ROADS all around the map !!!!!!!!!!!!!!

And following the storyline you can produce new bikes and use that roads. Even produce TRUCKS and load endless cargo.

Transporting cargo from place to place will stay a main part of the game, because you are an apocalyptic "porter" that carries cargo through the wasteland.

You will get many upgradeable stuff that will make your life easier like exoskelletons, new boots, weapons.

And yeah, there is not just "dead" landscape. In the wastelands you will find prepper stations, hostile human scavengers, beautiful destroyed places. And the most important things that even freak me out after 300 hours of gameplay. THE CREATURES. I call them creatures, because i don't want to spoiler.

Over all this game is a unique masterpiece.

One more thing that is supercool. In the second open world map you see a BIG, BIG mountain in the background. I thought this was just HDR decoration. No, it's not. More i won't tell :))

The most fun in the game was enjoying the story and building roads through the hostile landscape and after that, building a ZIP-LINE network what is the ultimative end game fun.

Short review: you are the last Amazon Prime deliverer left during the Kung-flu lockdown and it's jolly good fun.
I might be biased though, I have transport autism. 

Long review: you play as Norman Reedus, who rides a motorbike in the post-apocalyptic US and the dead walk the earth. I'm sure I've seen that scenario before, but I can't remember where for the life of me.
Anyway.
It took me a number of years and a decent discount to finally try the latest "Hideo Kojima Game™," mainly due to my severe disappointment toward MGSV (even more so considering how good Ground Zeroes was). I'm happy to report that this game, while having its own set of shortcomings, is far better than MGSV.

How could I describe the gameplay? Because you quite literally deliver stuff from one place to another, trying not to wreck your precious cargo while climbing up mountains or navigating around hostile entities.
This sounds a bit basic, and in a way, it is. Death Stranding is a walking simulator at heart, but it does that exceptionally well and the environment (based on Iceland and not the US) looks really good.
What makes the game different is the asymmetric multiplayer element. The game is entirely solo, but the world will get populated with other players' structures, signs, etc. Yours will also appear in the world of other players. It's not entirely different from Dark Souls' soapstone message system but more elaborate.
Interacting with other players' structures will give them "likes" that serve absolutely no purpose in the game but make you feel good about yourself, much like any social media. NPC also gives you like for successful deliveries, again to no benefit to you except for that sweet oxytocin which is one of the game's major plot points, albeit a silly one.

I want to point out that Death Stranding is the first game I've ever played where playing non-lethal made sense from a plot perspective. Not just to add achievements or to berate the players when they dare use the tools given to them (I'm looking at you, Dishonored). Simply said, in the world of Death Stranding, corpses create BT, dead who have returned from the other side. If those BTs grab a living person this causes a "void out," a matter-antimatter annihilation. 
Obviously, you might want to avoid that sort of thing. So, if you kill people, you have to destroy their bodies by throwing them in an incinerator. It is seriously time-consuming and really not worth the hassle. Better to not kill people.
Most human enemies don't even care about you anyway, the Mules use non-lethal weapons and are just interested in your cargo. The terrorists or "Demens" are more inclined to shoot you dead, but that's a minor setback since the MC just respawns (yes, there is an actual reason for that).

Despite a decent combat system, there's not a lot of action in Death Stranding. 99% of your time will be spent delivering, rebuilding roads, and reconnecting the different settlements. Some planning is recommended to avoid unnecessary trouble along your delivery routes, but the tools at your disposal make it possible to solve those problems in a variety of ways. You must also look out for your stamina, which runs out very fast when lugging around a hundred kilos of crap, knee-deep in the snow. Don't fall asleep there, you might not wake up.
It's probably not a game for everyone, but it's gorgeous and relaxing, even on very hard, which is really not that hard.

Let's move on to the story part of Death Stranding. I'm sure most of you familiar with Hideo Kojima will know that he sees himself as a movie director and it's reflected in every one of his games. Death Stranding is no different and with over eleven hours of cutscenes, it's not a short movie either. To put that into perspective, that's the runtime of all the LoTR extended movies put together!
I won't spoil the story, that would be petty. Some have called it confusing, but I disagree with that. The game goes out of its way to be as painfully self-explanatory as possible, leaving no room for the imagination or for YouTubers, desperate for views, to make an hour-long video theorizing about some random plot point based on two lines of description on a useless object.
The pacing of that story is all over the place, though. First, it begins with a cardinal sin of writing: a long and somewhat tedious infodump supposed to give you a broad understanding of the world around you but never going into any detail, making it looks like the game throws out-of-context words at you for no reason but to make it sound smart and mysterious. Very much in the same vein as Hideaki Anno did with Evangelion, "Boy, I love that old testament vibe! I have no idea what it actually speaks about or whatever meaning there is behind it, but I sure as hell love the aesthetic!"
That's about the first part of the game. Then the information trickles down more slowly when you reach the second (and main) map. So slowly in fact, that you might, at times, forget the story because you're too busy delivering tons of Prime packages to the locals.
At some point, you'll move forward with the story to the last and final map, where another hours-long explanation of all the game points occurs.

Said like that, it might sound horrendous, but the pacing of the story is really a mess. Regardless, I found the story endearing and the characters not as one-dimensional as they initially seemed. 
The story inspiration varies wildly, taking out on themes from The Postman (that's not a great start), Asimov's "Cave of Steel" and "The Naked Sun," The Walking Dead (what a surprise), or Andrei Tarkovsky "Stalker." 
The universe is coherent with its inner mechanism and while I wouldn't say that my suspension of disbelief wasn't tickled from time to time, it's well-written and convincing.
The actors do a great job; Mads Mikkelsen, in particular, is really damn good in this, and so is Norman Reedus. Troy Baker's character steals the show every time he appears on screen, and he plays a great antagonist.
My biggest beef with the writing is how heavy-handed the metaphors are. All the characters' names are their literal description, there are constant references (or puns) to the concept of connection, binding, etc. And it feels incredibly forced.
There's also a bunch of cameos I could have done without, like the Dorito Pope and Generic Funny TV Man.

I could go on, but at the end of the day, it's just Kojima doing whatever the hell he felt like it and while it may be disjointed at time, Death Stranding has a lovely eery charm to it unlike any other game.

This is a very strange game. 

STORY: the story is similar to Red Dead Redemption 2 in the sense that stuff does not pick up until chapter 4 (both in DS and RDR2) or so and really kicks into high gear nearing the end. The game immediately throws you into the worlds incredibly complex lore and background which is very confusing at first. However, as time goes on you start to understand it more and more. Once the story really kicks in, you understand why so many people adore this game. I won't spoil anything, but just trust me when I say that this game goes crazy. 

VOICE ACTING: Now, the voice acting is a bit of a mixed bag. Whilst the majority of the characters are well played. Some secondary characters and one or two main characters are missing some soul in there lines. However, the majority if the voice acting is great (My favorite is Higgs) and makes that characters that much believable

GAMEPLAY: The gameplay requires a certain player to be enjoyed. If you enjoy slow paced games where you get to appreciate and take in your surroundings (Elite Dangerous, American Truck Simulator, etc). You deliver packages over relitavely large distances (~10 minutes on average per delivery). I found this actually really enjoyable with the addition of BTs and MULEs as obstacles that you need to overcome in whatever way you please. Plus the music that randomly plays always puts a smile on my face (even if it is a sad song)

GRAPHICS: The game is pretty asf. The world is brimming with beauty, tall mountains, lushes green plains, large forest, I could go on. It's all gorgeous. However, I found that the optimisation left something to be desired. It's far from terrible but I found that the game stutters a lot when turning your camera and cutscenes make the games frames die.

CONCLUSION: There is no other game like death stranding. Whilst it isn't perfect, if you are intrigued, I highly recommend you give it a try (especially if you have played the games listed earlier). However, the game does start off with 2 hours worth of cut scenes so refund it doesn't exactly workout too well because you have yet to actually discover most of what the game has to offer. But to get back to the point, this game is great. I find it to be on par with RDR2 in terms of story and graphics and I highly recommend it.

I have now beaten this game, as of 7/24/23, and can say this is one of my all time favorite games now. I have never played a Hideo Kojima game before, so I did not know what to expect from the story that seemed so convoluted at the start.

This game definitely isn't for everyone. It's basically a way, way, way too long walking simulator with 10 minute TV episodes in-between. I really should have wrote this when I finished the story instead of waiting until I 100% it because I really don't have the patience or energy left to be long winded. 

The game-play was really at first and this game does an amazing job of never running out of upgrades to give you. The chiral bandwidth is extremely stupid. Basically you have a certain amount of "bandwidth" to be able to make structures and they cost different amounts and you get more by connecting new people to the network and leveling up your status with people but the number is complete bs. It's like when you get a new hard-drive for your pc and its 1tb and you install it and it says 935gb or when your phone is 128gb but your OS takes up like 50gb. I swear the chiral bandwidth is like 65-75% fake and you really only get 25-35%. Also I swear half way through the game all the controls completely changed how responsive they are. For the first like 40 hrs all the vehicles and sam would stop when you press S to "apply the brakes" but after that 40 hrs there just are no brakes. When you pull into a distro center on a bike and stop pressing W and hold S the bike will, I kid you not, slide at least 50-75 ft to the back of the distro center to the point where I literally, for the rest of the game (~107hrs), had to just crash the bike into the wall near the terminal in order to stop it. Also, while it is incredible that you can open the map and look at a structure and hold a button to dismantle that structure and get that bandwidth back, there should have been a button to delete all your structures because at the end of the game I only had the First Prepper and the Veteran Porter left and I couldn't scrounge up enough bandwidth to make a zip-line system to get to them nicely. 

ALSO SPEAKING OF ZIPLINES. WHY IS THERE NOT A WAY TO PLOT A COURSE ACROSS SEVERAL ZIPLINES AND THEN ENGAGE INSTED OF GOING 300 METERS TO 死亡搁浅'S ZIP-LINE BECAUSE YOU CAN ONLY SEE 1 ZIPLINE OUT FROM THE ONE YOU'RE ON AND I DON'T REMEMBER WHICH ONE GOES WHERE I WANT. OR WHY CANT YOU, WHEN BUILDING THEM, SET THEM UP AS A CONTINUAL PATH SO YOU CAN GO FROM PREPPER TO PREPPER, I PROBABLY WASTED LIKE 30 MINUTES ZIPPING TO THE WRONG LINES.

ALSO. WHY CANT YOU SKIP THE CUT-SCENE OF BB'S LITTLE ARM THINGY ALERTING TO THE BTS. THE GAME ALREADY DID THE SLO MO THING. I KNOW THERE'S F*****G BTS NEAR BY. IT'S F*****G RAINING. OF COURSE THERE'S F*****G BTS NEARBY. I PROBABLY ACTUALLY LITERALLY REALLY WASTED AT LEAST 6 HOURS JUST IN SEEING THAT CUT-SCENE OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER <that's literally how long the cut-scene is, the time to read my "over and over"'s is how long the cut-scene is.

Also they do give you a lot of upgrades and unlocks over time but some stuff is completely useless like the floating cart thing. They should have given that thing early on before vehicles because it's literally obsolete as soon as you get it. And for the directors cut the bot that walks along with you cant keep up with a vehicle so why in the world wouldn't you just take a truck. Also nothing in the entire game compares too the value of a truck long-range level 3. Like you can hold more packages than Amazon movies in a month and with the battery you can literally cross the whole map without roads with like 1 or 2 pcc lvl 2's.

The graphics are next level. The music is well done early on but I don't like a lot of the later songs.

***Story Spoilers*** ***Story Spoilers*** ***Story Spoilers*** ***Story Spoilers*** ***Story Spoilers*** 
I never like Amalie or Bridget and man I hate them, her, what-ever, by the end. I couldn't get a read on Cliff till the end but when Bridget killed him and only regretted hitting BB, Sam, what-ever, I felt more disgust than I ever have in my life. And when Cliff actually acknowledged Sam and recognized him as his son I cried which made my anger and disgust for Bridget even worse.

I really enjoyed the mystery of the war sections with Cliff and Mads Mikkelsen's performance in general. I really enjoyed the stuff with Deadman and the friendship you grow with him over the game. I also really liked the story of Cliff and Die-hardman's past together. This story was really really good but I really should have wrote this before playing like another 60 hours past beating it.

I really liked the stuff with Higgs, ESPECIALLY the boss fight against his Giganto-BT but over-all I feel like he was EXTREMELY underutilized. I love Troy Baker (I've only seen him in COD Advanced Warfare and Uncharted 4. I haven't played The Last of Us yet.) and I feel like he's got amazing potential, especially in a game like this, but I feel like when it came down too it he came and went way too fast and was not explored almost at all. I know there's like 47 million interviews from him and about him but after playing 147 hrs for 100% i am not about to read 86 interviews and read between the lines too put his story together when this game has such good cut-scenes and story telling.

Truly there is something about this game. The quiet world, the amazing acting / music, cannot forget the weird Kojima story. Seriously, if I did not hear Tom Howard say it, I truly would think the, "It just works" quote would be for this game. I know DS2 has been announced, so hopefully we will see fixes in the few a categories. What could use some work is the combat and horror / enemies. As far as the combat goes, it isn't the worst and I understand not the point of the game but that is no excuse to me. Just because the game is about connecting people doesn't mean we should negate the action. Why not both be equally good? Maybe in the second it will be. 

That being said, I endorse this game. I am one of the, 'I am glad I gave it a chance' kind of players.

The game pace itself may feel so slow but I enjoy it. I like strolling around this game just to enjoy the scenery, or delivering cargo from point A to B. One thing for sure, this game making me appreciate more of the courier or delivery crew out there, as well as around the world. (^_^)d

When I first heard Kojima was making this game, I was really let down by how different it was from his traditional series of games. However, I had picked up a copy from GameStop for a fraction of the price despite what I had heard of it "walking simulator". To my surprise, I loved the first iteration on the PS4 but I really wanted to play it on PC with the director's cut. My wishes were granted three or so months ago reading a leak that it would be released. Finally, I can say that Death Stranding Director's cut is amazing in itself but on PC is also amazing! This game is way more than a "walking simulator" and is way ahead of its time. Still need some performance patches but that is to be expected with just releasing on PC. If you've ever been interested in Death Stranding, this is the copy you should pick up. Have a nice time porters!

Update: This is now one of my top ten games of all time. I'm also very excited for DS2! All of us Porters are very appreciative of Kojima and his team!

I know why people think this game is boring and they are justified.

I've played Kojima games even since fairly young, so I'm used to the personal touch he does with his brand. He loves movies, styling an entire game like it's a cinematic masterpiece. This can especially be seen in cutscenes for how long and drawn-out they can be to fully experienced. These are some of Kojima's strongest expressions of his games and are some of the landmarks he makes while he paints in this artistic, realistic, empathetic to the player.
So why do people find this game boring? It's a Kojima game.
Well, as very experienced with his writing and style, I can say the main issue seems like the faults he made with MGS4 while new issues of misunderstanding game philosophy.

To make it simple, Kojima goes complex even when it comes to gameplay and interactivity. I can't tell you how I felt the first time playing MGS4 and had to use a back compression because I'm old and have back muscle pains from crouching too much. However, the trivial addition and the role it plays as a core gameplay loop combined with all the other trivial ideas was slightly annoying. This is kinda here in Death Stranding, but Kojima had the titanium nuts to experiment with a game where the core gameplay isn't stealth or combat, but a style of gameplay that no other game has while keeping trivial maintenance details.
And it's empty.
There's an insane amount of not explained (which is good) exposition as you start the story with extremely long, drawn out, and obviously the fantastic Kojima style of repetition in cutscenes and gameplay as we begin. Which is sad, because the gameplay is thoroughly about traversal and exploring feels awful when I have to have my hand held for... hours. I'm still in the "tutorial" area of the game as the game slowly drip-feeds me mechanics and information and being absolutely heavy handed about this.
Let me be clear.
It is absolutely unnecessary to spend what felt like a full hour OR MORE of cutscenes or monorailed cinematic gameplay to tell me what my purpose to do in the game from now on will be. Atleast in the way it was done. There's atleast three big cutscenes that tells you about this, and then I was thoroughly annoyed when a specific dream sequence furthers this. It doesn't help that, through this whole time, the most engagement I had with my controller was holding the toggle stick forward. I got it the first time and was annoyed my time was being wasted for this lengthy cinematic view of what I already know bashed over the head by narrative and tutorial boxes on the most simplistic of things very slowly. The story is amazing and all the elements it does very well to NOT explain to you easily is perfect. I wish to be treated as an adult who is paying attention rather than being reminded either of the main story concepts of "Travel to the West". Or in the game when a cutscene, the tutorial tooltip, and two narrative characters explain and tell me how to do an extremely basic task like using the shower. The shower explanation had to have been... what... fifteen minutes by itself? Some sort of unnecessary time where just a button prompt to shower would be fine enough after quickly being told it.

Older Kojima titles drop you with a variety of tools and, although the same sort of over-explaining and cutscenes there are, the concept actually feels warranted as you have a lot you can possibly use to deal with the variety of moving from Point A to Point B. This is my main argument for why I think people are justified in feeling that this game is boring. Although it grows slightly better over time, a majority of your first hours with this are Holding Forward to move and clicking two buttons to balance either to the right or the left. The enviroment itself, although beautiful, is also extremely basic and flat and can be described as rocky moss features of uneven terrain with some rivers. Interesting, but there could have been more complexity to make the feeling of traversal more engaging gameplay wise.
I was fine with it at first, but so far this fundamentally has stayed the same. Features like caves, buildings, or really anything could have added some flair to the beginning and reasons for having reasonably simple tools to make traveling more fun and less like the feeling of using your movement and balance keys to go to a place while learning not to fall and drop/break all your shit. What finally irritated me was when I came across my first invisible wall early on in the guise of a "Can't Construct Here Zone". My only real tools are grappling ropes and ladders and already I have my creativity stunted by a complex invisible rail which dreadfully reminded me that my hand must be held as I can go through the, although extremely wide area, the area I am designated to have to move through. So not ONLY am I wasting my time just walking around, but the very moment that I am given tools to make traversal more interesting is suddenly when the game design tells me it's stunted. Boo. 

I have been asked to accept an extremely hard sell of this game as it repeatedly beats me over the head in reminders of both narrative, which is more interesting the slower it is explained, and gameplay that is too basic for insisting on every aspect to tell me in ten different ways how to do something extremely simple whether that be walking forward or putting down a sci-fi mailbox. You get some mech legs and a motor bike after awhile, but the flat land is broken up just enough where the actual use of the bike feels pretty limiting as I spent more time slowly rounding rocks rather than enjoying the breeze through my hair. The mech legs is really just upgrades your carrying capacity and you have to pay attention to the battery; that's it. The fact it takes a couple hours just to get your first traveling tools like the ladders made the beginning even more of a slog and the fault of this is mostly how unnecessarily long the cutscenes are. Which, I should mention, other games of Kojima have pretty long cutscenes but they have a lot of reason, purpose, and the talking always seem to serve to something important to explain an overly-complex plot which I enjoyed but it seemed here, since the charm is the weirdness and foreign world being slowly explained, that very simple story beats took dreadfully long to spoon feed to you which feels pretty hypocritical. [spoiler] To best explain this, the story trusts you enough to barely explain why concepts like babies in jars help you with ghosts or why dead bodies explode like nukes but feels it MUST explain what Bridges is and how American it is, how you must travel West to save your sister, and constantly stating that the world sucks as if you already weren't aware of this fact and it will be sure to constantly say this for the first few hours. [/spoiler] Lengthy amounts of words with long dramatic shots doesn't make something "good" and a majority of it feels completely unwarranted as well as unwanted but it also feels too important to skip incase you miss an important detail. 

tl;dr
This is a great game narrative wise and extremely unique if you like this kind of thing. If you were looking for a hiking simulator that has you delivery packages and mail, than this is the game and the only one that does it. It's a slow, relaxing, and enjoyable build as you walk through an American wasteland lost to time and the absolutely absurd strangeness of a dystopian world metaphorically related to a world Post-COVID. What holds it back is the most Kojima he's ever Kojima'd, in both his best and worst stereotypes, is doubled-downed here on an experimental gameplay loop that severely needed compensation to make it entertaining while also trusting a player, in design and literal writing, to play the game themselves which feels dreadful when the gameplay feels dramatically less complex being mostly inventory management.

Death Stranding is, without a shadow of a doubt, one of the video games of all time.

Death Stranding is, in essence, a piece of art. I mean that in a literal sense - this project is artwork. And much like real art, whether you enjoy it or not is really subjective.

You either love or hate Death Stranding - there is no in between. Personally, I love the game. But for people who don't like the  type of gameplay it offers, they won't like the game at all.

Positives - 

-Story
-Graphics / Visuals
-Overall Quality
-Intricacy / Overall depth


Negatives - 

-BT encounters get pretty repetitive. They end up becoming more of a nuisance, a roadblock to slow down your delivery. Unlocking the ability to cut cords does make it more fun, but still, their encounters are too frequent.

-MULEs and terrorist encounters are usually boring and too frequent.

-For the last chunk of the game, you are forced to deliver and trudge through snowy mountains. It's slow, boring, and the permanent snowfall means your packages are sure to need constant repairs. This section is annoying and really disservices the game.

              Overall an excellent game with a few flaws. If you like what you've seen on it, you probably will love it.

Death Stranding is a thought-provoking and visually stunning game that pushes the boundaries of storytelling in the gaming medium. Its unique gameplay mechanics, centered around traversing a desolate world and connecting fragmented communities, offer a refreshing and immersive experience. The game's atmosphere is beautifully crafted, complemented by a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack. With its intriguing narrative, impressive performances from the cast, and the deep exploration of themes like connection and isolation, Death Stranding stands as a bold and memorable gaming experience that defies expectations.

[h1]Hideo Kojima is a GENIUS![/h1]

I remember when Death Stranding (DS) was released for the PS4. After months of seeing weird post-apocalyptic videos featuring Mads Mikkelsen, Norman Reedus, and Guillermo del Toro, the resultant product was that of a so-called “walking simulator.” For fans of the Metal Gear series, it was assumed that Mr. Kojima would pull a tactic that had been pulled before and bamboozle anxious gamers with DS being a new installment of the Metal Gear franchise. No bamboozle was to be had; DS is its own game, set within its own universe, albeit with some easter eggs that remind us that DS is connected with Mr. Kojima’s love of music, film, and (again) seemingly benign minutia as much as it is connected to his past work. Prior to reviewing DSDC, I had never played DS on the PS4, PC, or even DSDC on the PS5. I had avoided all spoilers for almost three years so I could be surprised by what Mr. Kojima had to offer; I loved being surprised in Metal Gear Solid 4 (MGSIV) and 5 (MGSV), so I needed the bamboozle once again. Please, Mr. Kojima, please continue to bamboozle us.

To simply call DSDC a “walking simulator” or a “delivery simulator” would be entirely unfair to the depth DSDC takes to immerse the player into the world of the United Cities of America (UCA). If I was to agree with the flawed notion of DSDC being a “walking simulator,” then Breath of the Wild and Horizon Forbidden West are to be classified as that, too. Sure, you are tasked with getting from point A to point B, but how you get there and when are entirely up to you. Once you break your assumptions of what you think you need to get from point A to point B, you can start to experiment with gameplay mechanics that range from svelte and efficient to downright silly. At that point, DSDC becomes just as much of a deep third-person open world game just as much as BotW and HFW. But again, you need to break yourself of specific gameplay habits that have been beaten into your consciousness by derivative gameplay installments you may have encountered in the past few years.

Death Stranding‘s storytelling follows the Hideo Kojima method of worldbuilding with minor adjustments: Expect a lot thrown at you at once at multiple points throughout your time playing. My first time playing MGSIV, I was stunned to encounter 30minute long cutscenes that went into excruciating detail for seemingly benign plot elements, only for these elements to reappear as a plot twist further down the line. I remember folding laundry during one of these cutscenes as a high school student. Prior reviewers of this game have criticized the story as being too frontloaded AND backloaded. I don’t necessarily agree with these perspectives because they don’t get at the root cause of so much plot occurring simultaneously at the beginning AND the end of Death Stranding: Death Stranding‘s “midgame” plot occurs deep within the menus of Sam Porter Bridges’ cufflinks.

DSDC presents you with an illusion of isolation as you trek across the nation with your BB (bridge baby) strapped to your chest. Norman Reedus’ Sam Porter Bridges is just as much disconnected as his world, yet his journey forces him (and you) to connect to others in ways that seem unimaginable and unpredictable. Simply adding a ladder on a hill makes it easier for you AND other players to get to your destination and find others, and you may find yourself going hours out of your way to become the world’s best road worker. In no way is this required of you to dedicate that much time to navigate the world, but…how you choose to utilize your tools to make the world easier to explore will impact others, and their worldbuilding will impact your experience, too.

Other than the cosmetic and fanservice content, DSDC offers additional elements that are mindful of players’ time and add creativity to how you make deliveries. First on the list is Cargo Catapults, which are large stationary guns that can literally shoot your cargo across the map and allow you to remote control where that cargo goes. If you want to avoid investing playtime into building roads, then catapults may be the way to go to get the larger deliveries to the more disparate regions of the UCA. Ziplines have been given additional buffs, too, in that you can now bring your floating carriers along as you zip across large vertical and horizontal stretches of land. I personally loved using ziplines in the mountainous region (you’ll know what I mean when you get there), as I was able to make deliveries and complete quests in a matter of minutes. Also unique to DSDC is a racing mode that offers a fun little diversion for those tired of rebuilding the UCA.

Combat has been upgraded and given more attention in DSDC. No longer are you confined with stiff melee combos that occasionally fail against human enemies. Now, you can equip gloves that make your punches more agile. You can dropkick enemies. And, if you’re struggling with using the guns at first (especially the Maser Gun, another DSDC addition), you have a shooting range and set of tutorials and drills to walk you through how to best use these weapons to their fullest extent. All of these additions are helpful for the player and give you an easier time with some of the learning curves of DSDC‘s combat.

DSDC offers eight additional tracks to DS‘s already phenomenal soundtrack. Kojima’s appreciation of Low Roar adds to the desolate nature of the world, and these additional tracks are no different in being perfectly fit for the DS universe. It’s very rare for a game to trigger goosebumps on my skin like DSDC‘s song selection, and DSDC features several goosebump-inducing musical moments in the story where the music ever-so-gently fades in while you travel about. One of my few gripes is that the only place you can select music to play is in a private room while Sam takes a break. Unlike MGSV that allowed you to play music freely as you explored, you’re limited to the ambient soundtrack of DS (which is pretty good, don’t worry) and the occasional Low Roar song as you complete a story-related quest. I would have loved to listen to the songs in their entirety as I drove through the game on the roads I built. I miss MGSV‘s cassette player quite a bit.

I’ve spent 120 hours playing DSDC for this review, and I can very easily say that DSDC is absolutely fantastic…for those who haven’t played DS before as well as those who have invested a hot minute into DS and want more. For the casual player, I find it slightly difficult to recommend them to pay to upgrade to the Director’s Cut. Despite the gameplay improvements, combat improvements, graphical improvements and flexibility, and so much more, I find DSDC to be more appealing for those like me who can find themselves immersing themselves into Mr. Kojima’s vision of a disconnected and near-apocalyptic America. DSDC is the DS that is meant to be played by those who are able to defy gameplay routines that we take for granted.

At its core, Death Stranding: Director’s Cut is an inventory management game. The more you play, the more freedom you have to do things with that inventory. You can help others. You can hurt others. You can save citizens. You can kill them. You can grow your world. You can destroy it. Regardless of your decision, DSDC is a game unlike others in that your assumptions about core gameplay loops and storytelling are pushed aside in favor of exploring a disconnected future. For those who have yet to play DS, DSDC is clearly the iteration of DS that is worthy of your time given its iterations that are increasingly respectful of your time and patience while also giving you additional creative outlets to muck about. For those of you who were unable to get hooked into this game, then DSDC may not be the answer you seek in a cinematic experience. Give it a shot, though; I’d love to be proven wrong.

Visually - stunningly realistic. A dystopian world with familiar construction but strangely few people. Beautiful rocky mountainous landscapes too. But a ludicrously stupid set of tasks - including delivering lost parcels for 'likes'. Lots of darkness - oil-covered corpses pulling one down, oil-covered seas and oil-covered dying marine life. A world of strange bedfellows, but what an anticlimax to be just delivering parcels for 'likes'. The banality of evil. In practical terms there are a huge set of controls which nobody but a complete anorak could remember. 

All of which adds up to a pretty disturbing game which I cannot ken the reason for playing. I dont have the patience to spend hundreds of hours fathoming the logic/backstory. 

At the back of my mind is that global warming is going to deliver death, starvation, random murder, parcel delivery, oil-coverd corpses and empty cities soon enough. All in bizzarre, Jumanji style. Lamborghinis and Ferraris of dead people at the bottom of chalk cliffs, a field full of dead and dying Flamingoes, hyeenas and Gollum-like humans searching the endless tailbacks of burned-out cars on motorways. Death Stranding is just a stylised imitation of what we are going to be facing soon enough. Only the game has a bit of tech added. Tech that didnt prevent the game's dystopian world from evolving, and which isnt going to offer a solution to a better world either. Like the stupid phone that has grown into our hands which has enslaved us. We are stranded on a dying planet - a death stranding - in actual reality. This game just reminds me of the nightmare unfolding right now before our complacent, somnolent eyes. It would have been a better game if it was able to wake up the zombies behind gaming screens to the danger that they face in the real world.
Keep on keeping on!

Death Stranding is a "walking sim", not in the sense of "you walk around and passively experience the story", but rather in the sense of a farming sim. The main mechanics of the gameplay are managing the traversal of the landscape and Sam's resources. In most games your cargo is just an abstract list that just adds up to a weight total, but in DS it's a core strategic decision where you put things.
Also Death Stranding is janky on purpose. Managing and overcoming that jank is an important part of the challenge, but it's not one I care to put up with.

Upon completing the campaign of Death Stranding, I was left feeling somewhat exasperated due to the plot's pervasive obscurity. Certain segments seemed utterly nonsensical. However, in a world steeped in such ambiguity, perhaps it's excusable. Having experienced prior Kojima games, this one feels like the most quintessential Kojima yet. I felt as though the plot was reminiscent of an art-house piece favoring style over substance, and emotions over rationality. This is not to say I didn't enjoy it; the game is sprinkled with several poignant moments that truly stand out.

The gameplay caught me off guard in a pleasant way. Initially, I was put off by the first mission but decided to revisit it later. As I continued playing, I noticed the missions' journey aspect gradually decreased in difficulty within the context of the world. This was primarily due to unlocking new equipment like bikes, enhancing the overall gameplay experience.

The game's social aspect was particularly intriguing. I found myself willingly taking extensive detours just to construct a road that would aid both myself and others. It felt like Elden Ring's note system elevated to an unprecedented level, with new structures and pathways all collaboratively built by players.

The presentation is, quite simply, stunning. Playing as Sam is a tactile treat, with each step and stumble meticulously rendered. The game mirrors your emotional highs and lows, ranging from the elation of completing a strenuous journey to the dread of trudging through muck and the frustration of a misstep causing a tumble, resulting in your cargo scattering. While the sound design and music are excellent, my only complaint is that the player is not allowed to play music at will, but only in specific rooms where the primary activities are reading emails and interviews, along with taking care of Sam.

The combat, in my opinion, isn't the strongest part of the game, but it thematically aligns with the protagonist's role as a porter rather than a soldier. Nevertheless, it felt somewhat clumsy to me.

In conclusion, Death Stranding offered a unique experience that I'm glad to have embarked upon. Its value lies in its unwavering dedication to a singular vision, despite the frustrations I encountered. Even after putting down the controller, I find myself mulling over the events of the game.

I have no words to even describe the journey I went though with this game. In fact it may even be seemingly made up, of what I am about to say. (do note, this was NOT the directors cut version but still relative to this game) 

Okay, so Hideo Kojima came up with this "all players are connected with rope/threads" and lemme tell ya, I have never experienced a more motivated and helpful community in all my 28 years... I started a type of zip-line highway from the start of the second map ALL the way to the END of the map and I kept going and going with these zip-lines using other people's zip-lines from the highest mountains to the most dangerous BT areas throughout the entire game. INCLUDING small outposts. All connected... I later found out in the midst of fabricating these zip-lines, that people are helping me, incredibly! 

We made a highway ALLLLL the way from start to finish, which made the whole "last journey" last a little over 10 minutes... IF THAT. (I did not time it). People were giving me resources to create these things, and others were creating bunkers along the lines (a majority of them) and then after a bit under 24 hours, I came back and it was ALMOST all done. I had to add the last 8'ish lines and that was it! I spent over a day IRL (I think?) making all the lines overall...

Hideo Kojima is a genius, he KNEW that we would try doing this and we did, making everyone's journey safer and fast in game. 

And you know what, I bought the directors cut just to do it again, however unsuccessfully... lol, but that just gives me more of an incentive to do it all by myself. I love this game and I cant get enough of the story, the lore, the everything.

Get the game, unless you hate walking LOL. I dont expect you to experience the game the way I did the first time, BUT there is nothing wrong with working as hard as you can making something that helps others including yourself along the road...

A Hideo Kojima Game.

It is definitely a polarising game - it is not everyone's cup of tea. But boy is it a great story - albeit convoluted in a way we have gotten to expect from Kojima by now. It's something of a slow game most of the time but the Walking Simulator 2019 memes are a caricature, the gameplay is much deeper than that. The soundtrack fits in well. There are a ton of ways to play the game that don't immediately become apparent, but discovering it is satisfying.

Only downside is that the Director's Cut is heavier on the system requirements than the original (which sadly has been taken down from the Steam Store). Framerates are lower on weaker PCs when demanding similar graphical quality (e.g. on my previous 1050 Ti, which did the original on 55-60fps, while the DC ran at 30-45fps with a really garish look), but it is well-optimised for more recent cards such as the RX 6800 XT I use, which runs it at a stable 60fps on maximum.

Other than that, solid buy. I took 128 hours to get to 100% achievements in the original version. Finishing the storyline for the first time took me something like 60 hours, so the game is a very good value for money proposition. I would suggest setting difficulty to hard on first playthrough, because 'normal' feels way too easy. It isn't like MGS2/3/4 where hard mode was insanely difficult.

when people say this is a game you will love or hate, they mean you will LOVE it or HATE it. there is no in between

the gameplay for the first dozen hours is walking back and forth from the same couple of locations, while a near incomprehensible story is revealed to you. +the world is incredibly beautiful and interesting, the gameplay is in depth, and strategizing the perfect route to your next location is incredibly fun

if that doesnt sound interesting, then this game might not be for you.

as the game goes on, you learn more about the world through lore tidbits and emails in the game. you unlock new ways of transportation (vehicles, ziplines, catapults, etc.)

now is a good time to mention theres a sort of building mechanic in the game where you can place things like bridges, vehicle charges, and so on. if youre connected to the internet when you play, you can see other player's structures and use them.

MINOR SPOILER: [spoiler]new areas will be unlocked as well, and youll eventually gain the ability to fast travel from area to area. you cant fast travel with packages[/spoiler]

theres some questionable dialogue and story beats, but overall, the game tells some very interesting and even emotional stories through a large cast of characters.

the final "act" of the game, the last couple of chapters, are INCREDIBLY story heavy and is almost like an entire movie of cutscenes. its a hideo kojima game, so.

CONCLUSION: if you like weird story games, vast open worlds, traveling, minor strategy, then this game is for you.

if you dont like weird story games, repetition, long experiences, then you should probably skip it

HIGHLIGHTS: the online feature where you can see other player's structures is incredibly useful and makes the game much more playable. the soundtrack is nothing short of perfect. playing as Norman Reedus. BB.

It's incredible something like this got made, and you owe it to yourself to experience it. Both Maximalist and minimalist in interesting ways. Some of the most beautiful terrain ever rendered, which is not that rare in big games, but making a large part of the game focused on traversing creates more attention around it. All the setting and scifi ideas explained exhaustively, but much of the story just simple human conflicts, expressed with immense care by capital A actors. 

The most fun I had playing the game was just walking and vibing, and managing cargo. I want more games to treat human objects with volume and weight and physicality. Hovering up endless amounts of resources is fraught consumer capitalism that tickles our mammalian brain for safety and material security. The things we carry around when there are limits tell a story, creates a choice, that has more narrative than a slot machine.

Positive:
-Graphics are lovely and I had no problem running the game.
-Loved the songs they had in there and the voice acting was great.

Negative:
-Game physics/movement is pretty trash. Woulda been more consistent if it had just been ragdoll at this point.
-UI is pretty trash. Looks cool and all but the fact that you can't just hit escape or something in order to save and quit the game? You have to be at a part where you can access your cuff or a terminal. Hella annoying and frustrating when I'm trying to get off the game but can't find the right time where it allows me to save and quit.
-Super interesting premise but the execution, at least as far as I got (finished the prologue and chapter 1) was mediocre. Feels like it's 80% cutscenes and only 20% actual gameplay. With the amount of time spent in cutscenes you would think that they could explain things better... And you would be wrong. Here and there they give some useful information, but I'm three hours in and I can only understand about half of what they're talking about. Maybe they chose to give less information to make it mysterious or something to look forward to, I don't know, but it was a bad decision in my opinion.

TLDR;
Even with an interesting premise, the endless cutscenes make it feel about as fun as watching paint dry. Don't recommend unless you have hella patience and even then I can't guarantee much. And that's coming from someone who got it on a pretty good sale.

Based on common discussion about Death Stranding found out there in the internet I'd like to help you figure out if you should play or not. It is important to notice that this review is a review from a player that loves the game as I am a LoLoLx540 porter:

[b] 1) Is this game a walking simulator? [/b] Stop wasting your time with this question. If it is a good game it doesn't matter. It is a good game.

[b] 2) Stop falling [/b] Some bad reviews includes people complaining about falling and I have watched many streamers falling a lot. That creates great frustration and some players start attacking the game overall out of frustration. I noticed it is common for many players to come to Death Stranding expecting the standard action experience, combat and bang bang and they just come to fall to the ground. They expect to run the map like many games and they expect the same action. Well that is a recipe for great frustration. Think of any game, if you fail the main objective you may get upset, if you keep failing you will get frustrated. Imagine playing something like Overwatch or Counter Strike and you only die. In Death Stranding [b] falling is failing [/b] and the action comes in another way. Stop falling, stop failing. Protect you precious cargo, think about how to not fall, explore the tools the game gives you to achieve that. Then you will maybe start to enjoy the work of a porter.

[b] 3) Give the game a second chance [/b] Death Stranding is not easy to digest... at first. Just search in the web "Death Stranding second chance" You will see many people glad that they gave the game a second chance. It is very interesting. So if you already have the game and quit it, give it a second chance. Death Stranding breaks the usual, give it some time and then come back, you will probably be able to enjoy it better then. 

[b] Complains that the game stalls / I am 50h in the first area [/b] I would say that Death Stranding post game content is somehow available since start. So it is possible for a player to play a lot without any progress towards the story. Relax, you can focus on main story deliveries with no worries about missing content. [b] Death Stranding post game content allows you to do everything [/b].

---------------

Maybe this really isn't for you, not everybody was born to become a porter. But since it is not a trivial game from start, I gave you some tools I think might be able to help you enjoy it like I do.

[b] Technical) [/b] The game runs really well. I have experienced no glitches and no crashes. Ultra-wide support.

Take care porters. Don't fall.

[h1]Death Stranding: A Mind-Blowing Journey of Connection and Reflection[/h1]

[b]Let me start by saying that Death Stranding blew my mind in ways I never expected.[/b] To me, this is a game that I was afraid of playing out of fear that it would disappoint. But it's precisely what it's hyped up to be, and the story is a masterpiece.

Hideo Kojima and the folks at Kojima Productions have created something truly extraordinary. This game is a refreshing departure from the usual cookie-cutter titles we see these days far too often, and it's a testament to Kojima's unrivaled creativity and the talent of the development team.

From the moment I stepped into Death Stranding's post-apocalyptic world, I was captivated by its stunning visuals. The attention to detail is mind-boggling, and each landscape feels like a work of art. It's a world that's simultaneously familiar and strange, drawing you in with its [u]haunting beauty[/u].

What sets Death Stranding apart is its unique gameplay mechanics. You're not just playing a game; you're part of an experience that explores the power of human connection. As Sam Porter Bridges, you're tasked with reconnecting isolated communities and rebuilding what has been lost. With every delivery made and every connection forged, you feel a sense of accomplishment and a reminder of the importance of collaboration.

The story of Death Stranding is an intricate tapestry of hope and despair. It's filled with complex characters and philosophical ideas that left me pondering long after I put down the controller. The performances by the cast, including Norman Reedus and Mads Mikkelsen, are outstanding, bringing these characters to life with depth and emotion.

The gameplay itself is a triumph. Traversing the terrain, managing resources, and outsmarting otherworldly threats are all part of the challenge. The weight of Sam's burden is palpable, and every decision feels meaningful. It's a game that demands your attention and rewards careful thinking.

But Death Stranding is not just about gameplay; it's an audiovisual feast. The haunting soundtrack by Ludvig Forssell perfectly complements the atmosphere, and the voice acting is top-notch. The combination of visuals, sound, and storytelling creates an immersive experience that stays with you.

In a world where games are often judged solely on their popularity or mainstream appeal, Death Stranding stands out as a work of art. It's a game that pushes the boundaries of what's possible and challenges you to think differently. It's an experience that will leave you in awe and spark conversations with fellow gamers.

I can't recommend Death Stranding enough. If you're looking for a game that offers a unique and thought-provoking journey, this is it. Hideo Kojima and the team at Kojima Productions have created something truly special—a game that redefines what video games can be and leaves a lasting impact. Don't miss out on this incredible adventure.

Death Stranding is flawed, stupid and incomprehensible sometimes, but my god does it digs its way into your very soul by the end. Its wacky elements distract you as you progressively grow immensely emotionally attached to the world and characters. I started off thinking it was a goofy sandbox and ended it in tears. Every aspect, the story, the missions, the random characters with ridiculous names, they all come together to form an experience that feels extremely human. Kojima's games all share this theme of humanity, you can feel the love put into everything from the environments to the easter-eggs. Nothing will ever come close to replicating the feeling of playing Death Stranding for the first time, but here's hoping DS2 somehow blows away that expectation too.

A lot of people like to call games like this "walking simulators".  A lot of people like to buy Call of Duty every year.

The majority of people leaving negative reviews for Death Stranding in 2023 seem to be folks who purchased a name by a guy FAMOUS for nonlinear, exposition-heavy but equally bizarre storytelling that heavily favors cutscenes and fourth-wall-breaking narrative... and then decide to publicly tell the internet they found they deeply disliked nonlinear, exposition-heavy but equally bizarre storytelling that heavily favors cutscenes and fourth-wall-breaking narrative. 

It's like strutting into an actual taqueria and throwing a hissy fit because they only do street tacos with tender slices of steak and not white people taco night ground beef tacos. 

Whinging about Death Stranding being weird and "a walking simulator" is the game equivalent of going to a movie screening for a funky auteur filmmaker and complaining John Cena isn't in them. That person is fundamentally in the wrong place, and that's entirely on them, not the movie. 

Death Stranding is a gorgeous game that very much relies on you having watched enough anime to develop that "let him cook" instinct. Everything makes very little sense. There's a lot of vocab words being thrown around, and it's clear they will be explained EVENTUALLY, but you gotta eat your vegetables an be a little confused for it to pay off. If you can handle Neon Genesis: Evangelion, you'll be fine with Death Stranding. 

For those who have their grown-up pants on and enjoy actually thinking about themes and enjoying beautiful landscapes that still impress four years later, the opening ten hours of Death Stranding are a phenomenal trip and really make you earn that transition from helpless Normal Reedus walking around trying not to die to the fully decked-out Metal Gear Solid V-esque endgame where you have more weapons than you know what you'll do with and the narrative gets INSANE. 

Hideo Kojima is the master of subtext that's so brazen it's basically just text. This is absolutely a game made by a man who has been interested in world politics since his 20s trying to come to terms with with what the Trump administration looks like from the outside looking in. 

Death Stranding is a game custom designed to piss off everyone who missed the blatant politics of Metal Gear Solid and say they dislike MGS2 "because Raiden sucks" because they dare not internalize the fact the game held up a mirror to politics and individualism in a way that stung. 

Also: the game runs butter smooth on my RTX 3050, a relatively low-grade card. The majority of people complaining about poor performance don't mention their specs, which is a huge red flag that maybe, just maybe, they're using super old unsupported chipsets and aren't considering this fact.

Masterpiece.

Death Stranding is extremely unique. Instead of your L/R click being your shoot/aim or your attack/block... you just grab the straps of your backpack with either hand. That, to me, should tell you immediately that this game is different than your typical AAA soldier/warrior fantasy, it's something all it's own. That sense of otherness permeates and characterizes Death Stranding from start to finish. 

The story and world building are beautiful, emotional, complex, lovingly thought out, unique as the mechanics are, and leave plenty of room for expansion and/or theorizing. When you first begin, you might perceive the characters as inscrutable and shallow, however as you progress in the story and read in-world lore you will see that that is not true, come to love them, and feel a connection to them.

The progression is outstanding... truly one of the most rewarding gaming experiences I've ever had in terms in terms of the the way you increase your stats and add new functionality to your character. The same goes for the completion of deliveries and various other tasks. 


As in Kojima's other games, it contains ample humor and occasionally breaks the 4th wall.

The world itself and character models are beautiful.

10/10- unique, emotional, masterfully crafted.
"Well, Kojima, you are an odd fellow, but I must say... you steam a good game".

This is an excellent game! There's so many different types of game play here.
- Easily making deliveries from point A to point B with a chill soundtrack. Very relaxing and satisfying!
- Retrieving stolen deliveries from "bandits." Can be quite tense. But here, you can sneak in or use non-lethal weapons to make your way through.
- Retrieving items in BT occupied areas. Very tense! A whole list of other weapons are at your disposal to assist you.
- Battlefield sequences. Again, very tense!
- And just when you've got the hang of walking, using a motorcycle, or driving a truck to traverse the world, things get upended! Human cargo!

There's a lot of diverse gameplay! And the story/cinematic sequences are amazing! Death Stranding is definitely an underrated game. I highly recommend giving it a try!
Takes a little while to get into it, lots to learn about the premise of the game to understand what's going, but if you get through that hurdle - - - this game is amazing!

Death Stranding is definitely not for everyone. I am 11 hours into the game and think I can give a reasonably accurate idea of it. The opening is very slow and it takes about an hour and a half to get to the meat of the experience. Once you get to the meat however the game is very open; it gives you the choice of how and when to complete certain deliveries. The world is extremely beautiful and quiet (except for when you come across MULES). The ambiance in this game is very calming; if you just want to relax, you certainly have the opportunity to. The combination of the constant rain and the gorgeous environment is unmatched. Some parts can feel tedious and annoying but the reward for completing these sections is rewarding enough to make you want to keep playing. This may not be your type of game but I recommend you give it a shot.

I absolutely love the Metal Gear series and I respect Hideo Kojima's work in the industry. With that said, most of his other work has not really clicked with me. I have played a bit of Boktai and Boktai 2. I tried Zone of the Enders and its sequel, but they just weren't for me.

With those past experiences in mind, I admit that I kind of slept on this game until this year. Now, having played through the story (59.9 Hours) I can say that Death Stranding is one of my absolute favorite games of all time. I went into the game expecting to put it down (and I nearly did), but I pushed through the lengthy tutorial section and discovered an addictive and surprisingly deep game-play loop and mesmerizing story that, while I correctly guessed some of its biggest twists, I thoroughly enjoyed. The final hours were an emotional roller coaster for me in the very best way. 

The journey this game took me on and the emotions I experienced as stakes raised into the story's final moments will stay with me for a very, very long time. Not since Solid Snake's final monologue at the end of Metal Gear Solid 2, or the debriefing of Metal Gear Solid 3 have I felt truly emotionally impacted by the conclusion of an interactive experience, and even those are given a run for their money by Death Stranding.

Virtually every game mechanic is integrated into the narrative in an interesting and compelling way. [spoiler]On top of all that, after the story wraps up, Death Stranding encourages you to keep playing in a time period AFTER the resolution of the story, and doesn't hold you in "narrative purgatory" prior to the final conflict, like so many open world games with a "post game" component do.[/spoiler]

In stark contrast to the incomplete and somewhat empty feeling Metal Gear Solid V left me with (which some might argue was the point of the game), Death Stranding feels like a truly complete and full experience. Death Stranding is one of the most immersive and satisfying experiences I have had in gaming in years.

Maybe Death Stranding isn't for you, but if you're sitting on the fence wondering if you should dip your toes in... 
Well, I am certainly glad I did.

I don't know why I love this game so much, but I just do.  It's an intriguing world shrouded in mystery that is satisfying to explore and attempt to understand more.  Don't get me wrong, it's definitely weird for most people with character names such as Diehard Man and a concept that is very unusual, but it's a fictional setting; who is to say that things like that can't be normal in another timeline? This is a great game to chill and vibe to, and I found that it became most enjoyable when I stopped trying to play it in a hurry.  I'm a busy person that is guilty of rushing through games at times, but this game shines when you take the time to look around and enjoy the world.  The directors cut addresses some of my issues with the original version (I upgraded to the Directors Cut during Chapter 3 of the game, as it happened to release when I was in the midst of my playthrough) such as the Monster Energy drink product placement, as that was a bit immersion breaking.  It's a very character driven story that relies on its presentation and atmosphere to draw the player in while staying exciting by sprinkling in moments of action.  Highly recommended, but definitely not for everyone.  I think if you can make it through the first few chapters, it really shines.

Wow, this is a strange game. The story is weird. The mechanics are weird. That will make it polarizing, but it also makes it brilliant.

[list]
[*] A lot of the game is literally about package delivery. But it is presented as a challenge of physics: how can you best balance all of this cargo on your body? How can you traverse difficult terrain and maintain that balance without falling and damaging yourself and the cargo? For the most part, the cargo itself is visible on your body and takes some appropriate amount of space. As a result, the quantity and weight of things really matter here in a realistic way.
[*] The graphics are just staggeringly beautiful. They went for a naturalistic look but with a focus on sprawling, often bleak landscapes that often are themselves worth the price of admission. In spite of this, the Director's Cut version runs pretty well on my modest system (which also runs Linux, but there are no issues there either).
[*] On par with the graphics is the audio. A big part of this whole experience is the crunch crunch crunch as your boots seek purchase on the craggy rocks, or the sound of slogging across a rushing river. Play this in headphones.
[*] On top of the relatively unique balancing and cargo transit mechanics sits a more traditional stealth one, which is used when you encounter enemies. This too is well thought out and executed. 
[*] You can make weapons out of body fluids. Yup.
[/list]

Tl;dr if you don't mind a game that let's things be slow here and there so you can take it all in, this might be the game for you.

Eu já zerei a versão base no PS4, comprei a versão de PC e fiz o upgrade para a Director's Cut.
O que eu posso dizer de Death Stranding é que não é um jogo para todo mundo.
Não digo porque é um jogo desafiador ou excludente, mas sim que a proposta dele é muito diferente.

É um jogo que pode ficar muito maçante, tanto que eu tento evitar jogar ele por longas horas seguidas se não vou acabar dropando. O que me estimula a continuar jogando a história. Mesmo já sabendo como as coisas acontecem do início ao fim, eu acho este o melhor universo que o Hideo Kojima já criou. Há aqui potencial para desenvolver uma lore mais interessante que Metal Gear. Os personagens aqui são muito legais, uma pena que alguns deles são pouco aproveitados como Heartman e Mama.

Graficamente falando, é um jogo espetacular. Não vem com tecnologias como ray-tracing, mas é muito lindo e o mais impressionante: é leve para o que oferece.
O único problema para mim é que como estou limitado a ter 8GB de RAM, a performance no Windows 11 na Director's Cut é muito afetada. Mesmo na qualidade mais baixa possível, haverão stuttering causados pelo péssimo gerenciamento de RAM do Windows + Directx12, é recomendado no mínimo 12GB de você jogar no sistema da Microsoft.
No entanto, no Linux (uso Pop OS), com o Proton-GE na última versão, a experiência é excelente. Arrisco dizer que esse é o melhor jogo que você pode jogar no Linux hoje. Se você habilitar o pre-cache do Vulkan (já que o jogo roda com base no DXVK3D), vai abrir o jogo sem qualquer problemas e vai rodar perfeito, até na qualidade máxima.

A jogabilidade é boa para o que é proposto, mas como eu disse, ela pode ficar entediante. O jogo vai te dar recursos para variar a jogabilidade ou facilitar algumas coisas, mas não adianta: o jogo é a mesma coisa por dezenas de horas, o que te motiva é avançar na história para que a narrativa ande e os momentos mais épicos apareçam. Acho o ponto mais fraco do jogo e espero que numa sequência eles arrumem.

A trilha sonora é fenomenal, não tem nem o que dizer.

Acho que Death Stranding (incluindo a Director's Cut que ainda esotu jogando) é um jogo 8,5/10. Para um primeiro jogo introduzindo uma ideia nova, é um bom começo. Se a sequência corrigir estes problemas da jogabilidade, que é basicamente o único ponto fraco, tem tudo para ser um dos melhores jogos dessa indústria.

I think this game is a masterpiece, but I can't recommend this game for everyone since this is basically a glorified walking simulator. Here are some pros and cons

This game has a similar difficulty to Dark Souls just not as hard but Kojima has a deeper meaning behind this. He made the game difficult not because he wanted to make you suffer but because he wanted you to lessen the suffering for other players.
The multiplayer really shines in this game. You won't meet other players but they can donate you items and tools for your journey. They can even leave tools (Ladders, Ropes, ect...) behind to assist the player. You can build structures (Watch Towers, Lockers, ect...)  to help other players. Other players can do the same too. Players can leave little token that act like messages that can warn the player if danger is ahead. Some can give you boosts too.

"If half of the community hates a game and the other half think it's a masterpiece then you'll know it's a Hideo Kojima game"

Rating: 10/10 "Masterpiece"

I played through the main campaign on the original version, which is no longer available.  I migrated to this edition when I went back to 100% the game.  This review is just copied from my initial review.


This game genuinely surprised me. I wasn't sure what to expect, really, but I figured it would likely be uninteresting. Turns out, it got me hooked right away and kept me all the way through. Pretty soon, I - a person who hates survival games because they all want you to build bases - was out gathering resources to build a highway through this one area because it would make travel a lot easier.

The storytelling is what you would expect from Kojima - philosophical, wordy, and confusing. I'll be honest, I've played a couple of Kojima games and don't really get the hype surrounding his storytelling. He's like that one guy at every coffee shop or college gathering who knows all these deep sounding philosophical phrases, but he's only using them to sound smart. He's as wide as an ocean, but as deep as a puddle, you might say. Not that the "message" of the story is hard to catch (human connection, in this case), but the actual story being used to deliver that message is so muddled in the philosophical word soup that it loses it's punch. In Death Stranding, I did have an overall idea of what was going on at the end of the game, but most of the way through the game I kept wondering if there was some other game I was supposed to play before this one so I could understand what it was all about. So for the story itself, I can't recommend the game. Still, I ended up really enjoying the game, and I didn't feel so lost that it damaged the experience. That was mainly thanks to the environment and gameplay.

The environment manages to feel lonely and isolating without feeling empty. You will feel like you're meant to: Like a lone wanderer roaming the wilderness on a mission. The multiplayer aspect fits with this very well, as it works a little like Dark Souls. In this case, you'll see remnants of other players as you travel - a ladder used to cross a stream, a shelter from the rain, worn down paths where many players have been, etc.. All this serves to ease that lonely feeling, and it all works together very nicely.

Ultimately, I think what loses a lot of players on this game is that they are hunting for the end. Most games are building to a specific climax, and reaching that climax is the main point of the game. With this one, however, the journey IS the game. There is absolutely an ending to the game, but it's the journey getting there that really sells this game. Without all the stuff in the middle, the end wouldn't be all that interesting. So slow down, take your time, get into the role of "courier who also has a mission", and you'll love it.
YES

I wish I could explain why this game is a masterpiece,
I wish I could explain Why I think you should experience it for yourself,
This is something I can't find a way to explain, because the nature of this game, its world, its story. It's so wonderfully weird and wacky, yet so serious and grounded. Going into this game completely blind was perfect because what started out as just a delivery/hiking simulator turned into a mission and world I truly got invested into. If I could tell you anything before playing this game it would be to take your time, complete all the side objectives and do all the extra orders to max out your rating with every NPC. There is so much to unlock in this game and there is no new game+ so make sure that first playthrough isn't rushed. I know this game won't be for everyone but it was most definitely for me.

One of the few games I ever cared to 100%, and for a good reason.
Its got elements of immersive sim, stealth and building games all built around the foundation of a transporting simulator.
