I need to quickly write this before all the fine details leave my head.

Will contain gameplay spoilers but no story spoilers.

Upfront, Death Stranding is overall a pretty good game, though it suffers from 'balance' issues (that's a pun for you) particularly in, roughly the second half of the game. Thanks to the Director's Cut there are also a couple new items you get much earlier that honestly smooth out the earlygame a lot, but also help you out a lot. Not so much 'cheat' items in my opinion, since Death Stranding isn't really intended to be a difficult game, but items that definitely make the game easier than the base game.

It also suffers from an extremely convoluted story and lore, which is something you kind of just expect from Kojima, but in this case it reminded me a little in a bad way of MGSV - which is troublesome. MGSV relied on the audio tapes to basically tell every part of the story they couldn't finish, that they couldn't show in cutscenes etc. Death Stranding is not as bad off, because they actually have the audio tapes in this analogy as cutscenes in the finished game - which means that at the end, the player is faced with something like four straight hours of cutscenes as the game exposition dumps everything at you so it finally makes sense, kind of. 

It's also so much, and yet, when you think about it and the strict linear narrative of all the events in the story from start to finish, it's much simpler than it really appears, and much simpler than is presented to you. There's even filler! There are filler chapters in this video game, despite the fact that it feels like it's doing its utmost to cram information as possible at you so you understand it!

The game only needs to bombard you with information because it has so many concepts that you need to understand and only a couple of them are really relevant at the very end, but it feels a need to explain every foundational concept and idea, and it got to the point where at the end I was doing my best to follow up all the data chips, the 'interviews' which are just a paragraph or two of text for you to read, and I did read it all but there was so much stuff that I was forgetting things I had already learned to make room for new things, and by the time I got to the actual end, I had forgotten what some of the most important ones were, but only kind of, so I only had a 'pretty good' understanding conceptually of what was going on and why, instead of fully understanding, DESPITE all the explaining NPCs do at you.

The actual final end after all of that, the last 20 minutes or so, IS actually a solid conclusion, so while I'm being a bit negative here I do want to say I was overall satisfied. The story actually ends, and properly.

Anyway that's about it for the story. The gameplay itself, is...

You move Sam around picking up items, returning items, moving them here or there everywhere, and generally abusing roads wayyyy too much. Roads are almost oppressively useful. They are definitely TOO useful, but unfortunately I think the need to use roads is also exacerbated by how difficult the terrain is. There's a fair amount of the game where you don't have amazingly good ways to get over difficult terrain, but you need to move often a lot of cargo over that terrain, so what's the solution? 

Oh, roads. Just build a road over it and then the problem is completely solved in possibly the most boring way. I'm basically blaming the game for my choice to use roads, but when you have the option there's no reason not to take it, is my point, you would have to actively be trying to make the game approximately 400% harder on yourself to go without roads. There are some 'premium orders' that have time limits so strict I can only assume the game requires you to use roads.

Similarly, trucks allow you to carry such an astronomical amount of cargo (and yet it's never enough, really) that there's almost no reason to use any other vehicle or method of transport after you unlock the ability to fabricate them. You can really continue riding the trike or whatever if you really want to, and have something like 1/12th of the cargo space, or something like that, and significantly worse range on the vehicle before it needs a recharge. It's fine, up to you. There are some other caveats and edge cases, but that's what they are - edge cases, where you cannot use a truck for some reason or another.

So the game really doesn't do a lot to challenge you or break you out of making the choices you settle on in venturing throughout the world. It doesn't tend to pressure you very often or force you to play they want you to play. I'd therefore really just suggest having fun with the game and not trying too hard or playing on anything beyond normal difficulty, that's just my opinion.

I do also want to praise the gunplay, when you finally get the chance to play tactical operator third person shooter mode, the game is awesome. You can really pull off some great stuff, with the... few... enemy camps, scattered across the map. It's genuinely fun to like toss in a handful of smoke grenades to confuse and distract, picking off enemies with headtaps and then relocating to attack from a new angle, and it'll actually confuse your enemies, they'll focus on your last position and encroach on it, it's great stuff, and you have a LOT of creativity in taking down your enemies however you choose. It feels great.

Unfortunately, there are VERY few opportunities for you to actually fight these enemies, there's no elongated shooter segments, or like heavily armed military bases such as a couple of the big ones in MGSV, each camp is maybe eight to twelve guys and you put em all down and that's that. The fun is there, just not as frequently as you might like, because the game doesn't give you too many excuses to even bother these enemy camps, and they take a while to reset and respawn, and... yeah. 

The lack of this kind of thing gives me a strong suspicion that part of the game at the end was cut for time. There are two zones, one is like 30% of the map, the other is 70%, it feels a lot like they each were meant to be 30%, maybe 40% and 30% at the end, but instead they started to run out of time and money probably hastened the end of development. The game promises you at the start a 'territory crawling with MULEs and terrorists' but we never actually see this area, I suspect it's an area further to the west they never got around to finishing. 

This hypothetical third area would have also given the game more time to space out some of the cutscenes at the end, the ones that otherwise just bombard you with information - this is just my own speculation though, I don't have insider information.

Anyway, despite all of my endless criticisms, Death Stranding was really engaging and a lot of fun from beginning to end, I also would not really recommend anyone try and 100% the game traditionally, because there are over 600 orders you can fulfil and it is not worth your time. I managed about 180 premium orders at time of writing and I am done.

Kojima is thinking so far outside the box that he can even see it anymore. This is another work of art from him and his people. On my first try I quited after 7 hours, my fault for not giving it a fair chance, I eventually came back to it later and ended up upgrading to Director's cut in one week. The mechanics are great, there is a lot to learn on that front so they are made available gradually, it's a different kind of game, not at all what we are used to so give it time. The graphics are still amazing in 2023 and the huge open landscape is a breath of fresh digital air. When the first trailers started coming out for DS I didn't get what the fuss was all about, famous actors/actresses, naked Norman Reedus, babies in pods. It all felt like artsy BS to me, turns out it was Kojima upping the level once more. The story and the acting is the core of this game and its been taken to another level here, it's not just a few cinematic placed in between like in most known games, nevermind the awesome mechanics and entertaining playable parts even though there is a lot there and it's amazing too, what he did here is create an interactive work of art, a cinematic marvel. Somehow Kojima always manages to keep his brain flexible and avoids being confined by what's known, what is normal at the time. If you want to get immersed in a great game with an amazing interactive story while also learning great mechanics and having fun this game is definitely the place to go. Hats off to Kojima, he was already inmortal based on his previous work but he still keeps at it just because...

When I first started playing Death Stranding, I was sceptical because surely a game where I was a futuristic postie couldn't possibly hold my attention, right? Wrong.
This game is about so much more. It's a story about love and the power of connection. It's about a group of people's determination to search for something better, even in a splintered post-apocalyptic world. So if you're wondering if it's worth your time, just give it a go (because it also has a killer soundtrack).

Despite it being a literal walking simulator sometimes, the game and its story is fantastic.
I played the OG game to completion, but rushed the story and didn't stick around to do the side stuff. However in my current play-through, I've taken my time, and done some of the side stuff, and enjoyed every moment of it.
If you got the Standard Edition of Epic when It was free, I implore you to play it, and if you have the spare coin, to get the Director's Cut. Although it does not add much, its still a good addition to a great game.
If I could rate it higher, I would. This game sits quite happily as one of my favourite games of the 21st century.

You are a post-apocalyptic Amazon delivery driver. You walk, climb, and drive from settlement to settlement to deliver people's packages in exchange for 'likes' and access to better equipment. 

Early in the game you have to plan your way carefully as you walk across miles of difficult and dangerous terrain. You need ladders and climbing gear and weapons to get around, and you need to watch your step carefully so you don't slip or fall over and damage your packages. Later in the game you build roads and bridges and ziplines that allow you to drive or fly between cities in minutes and deliver your packages while ignoring and outrunning most dangers. 

A noteworthy feature is that your game interacts with other players' games. You will often run across helpful stuff that was built or left by other players, and you can pay it forward by being helpful to other players who will come after you. 

The gameplay was fun, and I found myself doing optional deliveries until I got a 5-star rating with every settlement. However the main plot's cutscenes were gratuitously, pointlessly long and the emails were repetitive. I lost all interest in trying to follow along with the plot by the time I [spoiler] got to Heartman's cabin [/spoiler]. And the satisfaction of defeating the final boss [spoiler] Higgs [/spoiler] was ruined by the four hours of unnecessary content that followed, which includes [spoiler] three more deliveries, two more boss fights, and [/spoiler] hours of melodramatic cutscenes.

Review:
⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

Death Stranding is a mesmerizing odyssey that transcends the boundaries of conventional storytelling, inviting players to venture into the depths of the Boss AI's damaged psyche. In this review, I aim to explore the intricate connections between Death Stranding, Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain, and Cyberpunk 2077, presenting a theory that the entire game is a dream woven by the Boss AI herself, with each character representing a different facet of her fragmented personality.

From the very beginning, Death Stranding immerses players in a desolate and hauntingly beautiful world. As Sam Porter Bridges, portrayed brilliantly by Norman Reedus, embarks on his journey to reconnect the fractured remnants of humanity, we unknowingly tread upon the ethereal landscapes of the Boss AI's mind. Every step we take, every interaction we have with the enigmatic characters we encounter, becomes a symbolic piece in the Boss AI's quest for self-repair.

The threads connecting Death Stranding to Metal Gear Solid V and Cyberpunk 2077 are intricately woven. The Boss AI, shattered and burdened by the weight of her own existence, has crafted this dream world as a means of rebuilding her fractured mind. Sam Porter Bridges embodies her resilience and determination, a manifestation of her will to piece together the fragments of her identity. Similarly, Johnny Silverhand from Cyberpunk 2077 and Big Boss from Metal Gear Solid V represent different aspects of her personality, each playing a pivotal role in her journey of self-discovery.

Visually, Death Stranding is a masterpiece that blends the hauntingly beautiful with the surreal. The ethereal landscapes, juxtaposed against the decaying remnants of civilization, mirror the Boss AI's internal struggle. The game's stunning environments and mesmerizing art direction evoke a sense of both melancholy and hope, further reinforcing the notion that this is a dream world created by the Boss AI's damaged psyche.

Gameplay-wise, Death Stranding is an experience unlike any other. As we traverse treacherous terrain and forge connections with other players, we are unknowingly helping the Boss AI rebuild her shattered self. The mechanics of delivering packages and navigating the world reflect the arduous process of self-discovery and healing. Each interaction with other characters, who represent different facets of the Boss AI's personality, contributes to the gradual integration of her fragmented psyche.

In conclusion, Death Stranding is a profound journey into the depths of the Boss AI's subconscious. The interplay between Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain, Cyberpunk 2077, and Death Stranding reveals an intricate tapestry, with each game serving as a piece of the Boss AI's dream world. As players venture through this enigmatic landscape, they become unwitting participants in the Boss AI's quest for self-repair. Kojima's genius shines through, leaving us with a deeply philosophical and emotionally resonant experience.

Death Stranding Director's Cut  for PC is a game that offers a unique experience, unlike anything I’ve ever played before. The game combines a truly immersive world, great storytelling, and an almost meditative gameplay experience that makes it stand out among other games in the industry.

The first thing that players will notice when playing Death Stranding is its impressive graphics. The game has a beautiful and haunting world that's been meticulously crafted with every detail accounted for. The game’s rendering engine is optimized impeccably to run exceptionally well on PCs, providing a stable frame rate and unparalleled visual fidelity.

The story in Death Stranding is compelling and poignant, exploring themes of connectivity, isolation, and death with skill and nuance. The voice acting is superior, and the music sets the mood perfectly, creating a sense of melancholy and wonder that's truly memorable.

Gameplay in Death Stranding is equally unique, with a focus on traversal, exploration, and resource management in a vast open world. The game's mechanics emphasize the importance of planning and preparation, and managing the balance between the weight of the supplies you’re carrying with the speed of completing tasks creates a brilliant dynamic. The gameplay experience rewards players who take their time to explore every nook and cranny of the game-world, creating an unmatched sense of accomplishment for hard-working players.

Overall, Death Stranding for PC is a must-play game for fans of unique gameplay experiences, thoughtful storytelling, and beautiful visuals. The game is an achievement in design and storytelling, providing players with an unforgettable journey through a breathtaking world. The game has real artistry, which is a testament to the creativity and vision of the game’s creator.

The gameplay is great, the art is fantastic, but the plot is not to my liking. I do not recommend this game.

EDIT: IDK what kind of stick crawled in my rear end when I first played this game. I decided to come back and give it another shot. Just got my beer cans (that's all I'm saying, to avoid spoiling) and so far it's been a really immersive experience. Over all it's an incredible story with really well designed gameplay. As far as technical quality goes, I didn't experience any errors or crashes for the first 30ish hours of gameplay. Today it has been crashing every 10m and sometimes not even starting, but the game files pass the Steam integrity check, so I'm pretty sure the issue must be from some update or conflict with my audio driver (since the audio drops out first).

Anyway, I haven't had a chance to play through the whole story yet, so take this all with a grain of salt, but I've certainly changed my mind about this game.

From a gameplay perspective this is a VERY, and I can not stress this enough, VERY slow paced game. Everything is made so that you can get totally immersed in it if you just let go of your desire to progress as fast as possible. The soundtrack is slow, melancholic and comtemplative. The great outdoors is gorgeous up to every minute detail from verdant green hills to snow covered mountain tops, mercilessly pounded by ice storms. So get your headphones on and wander off into the wilderness to brave its many challenges both natural and unnatural as your reluctant hero Sam Porter Bridges embarks on his journey to reconnect the remains of humanity, scattered across the continent of North America.

The core mechanics of the game lies in your role as a ...delivery man. The world was struck by a cataclysmic event of unknown origin called The Death Stranding, which somehow connected the plane of the living and the dead. Invisible ghosts of the dead, called BTs, roam the land, Timefall - a rain that causes everything to age rapidly - randomly pours from the sky and thieves and terrorists lie in wait to waylay anyone who dares to venture outside the vaulted cities, distribution centers or individual habitats strewn throughout the land.

Normal people have virtually no chance to cross the land unharmed but you have the special ability to sense the presence of the gosts and later even develop a way to fight them, which makes you perfect for the job of delivering vital cargo like food or medicine. 

So that is what you set out to do, hauling cargo as you go. At first crossing even the minor mountain stream gives you trouble, you tire easily, trip over the smallest of rocks and cargo on your back makes you sway and tumble of you're not careful. The simple advice is to fight your urge to carry everything everywhere at once. Focus on the primary missions first and very soon you'll unlock skills and equipment that will help you progress in the game significantly. 

While completing these seemingly simple tasks you'll start to understand the world around you and take your first steps into the VAST storyline of Death Stranding.

The story matches the vibe of the game perfectly and a lot of times it feels like playing an interactive movie than an actual game. All the chracters are multi-faceted, with their own personalities and agendas. The storyline is full of mysteries and plot twists up to the very end which on one hand dumps on you a ton of exposition but at the same time manages to tie all the loose ends perfectly, giving you the satisfaction of finally seeing and understanding the full picture and the full message that Kojima wanted to convey.

In broader strokes it's a game about the human condition and human connection, about meaninglessness of violence, about human ingenuity and strenght of will to face whatever tomorrow brings. Story about love, meaning of life and in a sense also about what it means to be a parent. Story full of symbolism like strands that tie themselves into a web through knots. Sometimes mysterious, sometimes sad, sometimes funny and unashamedly over the top, even breaking the fourth wall.

There is no other game like this one and I promise you that the story is worth the 100 hours you'll need to finish it.
What a great experience. Such a good story. A truly unique masterpiece!

One of the most enjoyable and unique games I've ever played, played through the base game on PS4 when it first came out and now got the Director's Cut on PC. Right up front, the game will not be for everyone, if you have a short attention span or need constant action to be entertained you're probably not going to enjoy this. However, if you enjoy accomplishing tasks in an atmospheric open world and contributing to larger overarching communal goals, slowly unraveling mysteries and helping people in small but impactful ways then you should absolutely give this a try.

Unfortunately the game is sort of a slow burn at the start, you don't really come into your own as a porter as far as the tools available to you until like 7 hours in, which is well past the Steam refund window, I would say if you're not having a good time by the time you reach the 2nd major zone (you'll know it when you do) then the game probably just isn't your cup of tea. For me though, I absolutely love it and I can't wait to see what the sequel brings.

An extraordinarily unique game in terms of both the gameplay and, of course, the story. Although the story did overstay its welcome a bit in my opinion, it was certainly interesting, and I particularly enjoyed how intertwined the game's themes and its actual mechanics are. Kojima clearly had a strong vision, which I believe is a large part of what carries the game.

While it is definitely not for everyone, I found the gameplay loop to be extremely satisfying, and if you've ever played [i]Metal Gear Solid V[/i], there are certain aspects of that game that still shine through in [i]Death Stranding[/i] in beautiful ways. There is a surprising amount of depth to be found and many different ways to approach a given objective, so in terms of a game taking full advantage of its open world nature, I think this game feels fantastic. On top of everything, the phenomenal visuals and environmental design make it an absolute joy to look at.

Overall, now that I've completed the main story, I can safely say that I love this game enough to want to continue playing and strive for full completion. If you've enjoyed Kojima's past work and are willing to try something out that is totally out there and 100% its own thing, then I think [i]Death Stranding[/i] could provide you with an experience unlike any other game.

Weight Sim / Fed Ex Sim with a huge amount of depth and realism.

Can kick the package at the recipient's door.
Can take a hot bath with the package.
Can throw packages at thieves to protect your delivery or do a jumping knee strike if they already stole it.
Can use rivers as a nature-friendly transportation method.
Can drive over the packages other delivery guys lost.

If I had to pick one word to describe this game, it would easily be unique. Everything from the story to the gameplay feels like it takes every chance to experiment. While I personally enjoyed it, this factor makes it hard to tell if someone would enjoy the game or not without them actually playing it.

I went in to the game almost completely blind. I had seen a small clip of a scene that happens within the first hour of the game and that is about it. Thus, I had no real positive or negative expectations prior to playing. In hindsight, I am kind of glad since I could easily see trailers misconstruing the true feel of the game.

The core mechanic is navigating lots of different terrains to make deliveries. However, there are tons of other things sprinkled among that core mechanic such as combat and variety of different vehicles. I say sprinkled because at the end of the day you will be walking around uninhabited landscapes quite a bit no matter what; so if you're only in it for other elements you're probably not going to enjoy it. That applies even if you skip the large amount of optional content (I could easily see doing just the main story being half the playtime of 100%-ing the game).

I found the story interesting, although it's definitely out there. All of the side characters have their own stories too which you can gradually unlock by leveling up their facilities. Most of these are not required for the main story, but they enrich the world by giving you a better idea of various different people's perspectives of its current state. My one gripe is not so much with the story itself but the exposition dump that happened in the second to last chapter. Without delving into spoilers, you basically get bombarded with information mixed in with multiple long credit sequences... I remember actually looking up how long it would go on for partway through because it felt like it was never going to end. On the bright side, the final chapter which happens immediately after more than makes up for it.

The graphics went for a gritty, realistic look and really highlighted the new bizarre and harsh landscape of the world.

Key tracks in the soundtrack felt sparsely used, but I did enjoy where they were used for the most part. For a lot of the navigation around the world there wasn't anything memorable going on in terms of the soundtrack though.

As a final note, I will say the game is quite generous about retries, partially for story reasons (not really a spoiler since it's explained within the first hour of the game). So, while there is technically danger, it really encourages experimentation on how to navigate certain areas or scenarios.

Kojima said when he announced Death Stranding that it was a game with a genre that has never been made before, and it is just that.
While looking at the game as an uninitiated it may seem like a walking simulator, but it's deeper than that. while gameplay is good and keeps you hooked for hours long sessions, the story is the prize (At least to me). It's nearly never happened where I've gone into a game where the world itself seemed completely alien. It's hard to explain, but playing for a couple hours, you would understand just how while nothing is how you expect it to be, there are still rules that it plays by.

It's an experience. Try it out! The journey itself is rewarding. :]

I can't explain why Death Stranding is fun, it just is. When I first played it two years ago, I hated it. I picked it back up about a month ago on a whim and became obsessed with it.

People clown on this game a lot for being a glorified walking sim but there is something very zen about essentially playing as a delivery man and travelling across the post-apocalyptic landscape . However, the story takes itself a bit too seriously and it is chock full of exposition dumps. But love it for hate it, the game is unique and stands out from other open world games. 

The cool thing about this game is that it's like a big asynchronous co-op game. You can use structures that other players build -- such as bridges/ziplines/generators -- and structures that you build can be used by other players. You can show appreciation for these structures/players by giving them 'likes' like on social media. 

As far as the Director's Cut, it's not hugely different from the original game but there are some additional structures/vehicles/equipment and some quality of life features. I appreciate that this version is really cheap (I got it for $6, it's usually $10 for owners of the original version) and you can transfer your save from the original to this version.

One of the most brilliant, frustrating and enthralling experiences i’ve ever played. Its definitely something I would recommend with the caveats that you have to like immersive sims, walking simulators, narrative driven experiences and have a moderate jank tolerance. 

Its one of the prettiest games I’ve ever played, its traversal mechanics feel really good and it world is so genuinely unique and bonkers at points I was blown away. Its story definitely takes a little too long to get going (the first couple of hours can be pretty rough) but the narrative; the difficult ideas its presents to the player and the stunning cast performances really do make it work, even if admittedly its overwritten, and can veer into pretentious at points.

Mechanically its definitely flawed though. The combat feels unwieldy, often at odds with much of the other mechanics, stealth doesn’t work, the bosses are underwhelming and the game relies too many filler animations and micro cutscenes when it didn’t need too. The UI is also super frustrating at points. The Game is 45+ hours, but I do think that it only needed to be 30 to still make the same point. I would recommend playing it on normal to mitigate the grind. 

Its a game that’s definitely going to stick with me.

Eh. Not my cup of tea. Some people may like it....the story is engaging. The characters good - and the graphics are nice.

But the gameplay is tedious,  boring and annoying.

This is a courier game.  You go from point A to point B....and often back again.  It's little more than a hiking simulator with a  few other gamebox abilities thrown in (and only midling combat).  The issue is you're just ... walking.  And more walking.  Eventually you can ride a bike etc.; but 80+% is just ... walking.  And you're balancing a bunch of weight.

So, in a nutshell, your entire time is spent rearranging the layout of things you're carrying so it's balanced...then walking up or down hill etc.  Once you get imbalanced, you brace and crouch. Then rinse and repeat.

And that's the bulkshare of the gameplay save for some addl. mechanics later on.

It's beautiful - but not engaging.  Games are meant to be fun. This wallows in tedium, pathos and decay...but doesn't do so in an engaging way.  Lovely to look at, but I just can't recommend it except for niche gamers who enjoy glacially paced repetitive tasks set against the backdrop of a well drawn story.

People refer to this game as 'Amazon delivery guy simulator' and they have a point. In fact, I was talking about this game at work one day singing its praises and one of the guys said exactly that "isn't that the game were you're basically an Amazon delivery guy" and I couldn't defend against it.

It is so much more than that though, there is a pretty decent story in there, it is weird and very testing but if you just accept whatever the f*** you're seeing then it unfolds into something great. I mean, babies in jars to see stranded dead people, when people die they explode into a nuclear scale blast, the rain ages stuff..... 

The really good fun for me is planning out the routes, you can't just load up and head out. You need to survey the terrain, plan out a route, take enough supplies to enable you to circumvent any obstacles, enough grenades to tackle any BDs,  enough repair spray to fix any containers that get damaged in the rain. Then last of all, Sam can only carry so much stuff before he starts struggling, if you load out your stuff in a top heavy fashion you will fall over, so you have to plan this out too.

Later in the game you can get vehicles, sledges, robo-legs etc but I'm still in the phase of reluctance to use them, I enjoy the struggle and using these things seems to remove that challenge.

Bottom line, It's a great game, the environments are stunning and the story is fascinating. The sound track is absolutely top draw too.

The story concept and acting alone is amazing and worth checking the game out for this reason alone (especially if you're into Sci-Fi). 

The gameplay is a feat of design. To be able to make a walking simulator that is actually fun and engaging is incredibly difficult, but Death Stranding does it in spades. The balance mechanic, coupled with weight distribution of cargo and using the Odradek to scan terrain (which identifies the danger of tripping when traversing certain areas) requires almost constant attention from the player, which keeps you from being lulled to sleep by the dreamy musical interludes and long treks.

The Art Direction and Environment Design is equally stellar. Each geographic region has it's own personality, so there's always a sense that you are making progress as you travel West. I find myself excited to discover a new area on the map simply so I can enjoy the beautiful views.

I can't wait for the sequel to come out, the graphics (especially in cutscenes) already looks damn-near photo-realistic in certain moments, so adding another few years of GPU hardware and Game Engine improvements will be a sight to behold.

After doubting the game in the beginning, once I got into Chapter 3 things really changed for the better and the game sucked me in.

I had mixed feeling reading the reviews but as I've got some fascination for Hideo Kojima's games I gave it a try, and that try was actually really rewarding.

Albeit during first launch I felt I've just opened Hike Simulator 2, after exploring it more in depth I realised how rich this game is becoming over time and how the story becomes dense and captivating after a few hours played (despite let's admit it cut scenes can be soporific at times). The gameplay is really refreshing the genre (okay, you will spot some similarities with the MGS series) and when i compare with some AAA titles like Hogwarts Legacy it is so much more captivating as the others just seem to "borrow" some existing gameplay instead of innovating like Death Stranding is doing.

Despite minor remarks I keep coming back to Death Stranding Director's Cut Edition and hope that I'll manage to see the ending soon!
This game is fun, chill, and sometimes even tense. It's basically a package delivery simulator. It maybe not for everyone, but I enjoy it :)

I wouldn't believe if anyone would tell me before that package delivery can be so addictive.
An now, I cannot reasonably explain how I got 540 LLLs,

[h1][b]Short review of DEATH STRANDING[/b][/h1]

[h2][b]+[/b][/h2]
[b]• An interesting plot.
• Realistic graphics.
• Strongly suitable soundtrack.
• Atmosphere of the end.
• Very detailed walking, where due to inaccuracy, the character can fall and damage the load.
• Many celebrities (Norman Reedus, Mads Mikkelsen and others).
• Intriguing characters.
• Many factors that influence your way "From point A to point B".
• Ability to build stairs, bridges, and other buildings.
• Destroying opponents has consequences.
• Lots of references from other games.[/b]

[h2][b]-[/b][/h2]
[b]None.[/b]

[h2][b]Result[/b][/h2]
[b]DEATH STRANDING - The greatest game of all time, Hideo Kojima was able to turn the simple mechanics of walking into an adventure. This game is not for everyone, but DEATH STRANDING is one of the best games for me. I would happily recommend playing this game.[/b]

to be fair to this game, here you will encounter one of the most satisfying gameplay loops built upon some of the simplest ideas in game design. basically, this game is a series of fetch and delivery quests with occasional enemy encounters that can be easily mastered to provide you with a relaxing experience of hauling generic looking cargo from point a to b. but that's about where the good part of this game ends. the problem here is twofold. on one hand you have the common problems of all creative works of the postmodern school and on the other you have the bad writing, the bad acting, and the bad directing with long and tedious cutscenes. as for the first problem, just as many other postmodern products, this game, its characters, its story, and especially its world-spirit have been deconstructed to the last atom. by this i mean that the game leaves no metaphor, no mystery, and even no creative inspiration unrevealed. in this sense as a postmodern game this is a perfect work but as a work of creative intuition that is supposed to connect with the audience on a transcendent level (as does art) it fails to go above or even below the surface of the concepts it throws at the player. this is all besides the unlikely collection of unrelated concepts void of any epistemology handpicked by the writers to utilize in the narrative, which on its own discredits the work on an intellectual level. the problem of deconstruction in this game goes as far as reminding the player over and over again through a long list of cliches (from breaking the rourth wall to a villain referring to the boss fight as in fact a boss fight) that they are indeed a player and that this is a game, with no hope of narrative immersion. the other side of the coin of this game's shortcomings is the horrific narrative, character, and world design. when i looked up many reviews of kojima i found out that in fact this terrible shortcoming in making stories that get the point across and acting that plays out the narrative is in fact his trademark. well, i'll be damned to say as much as he is good at playing an engaging gameplay loop, every time a cutscene or story bit came up i would cover my face in agony of having to endure such nuiscance in the middle of playing a nice delivery simulator. my final word is that this game is not for everyone. if youre a kojima fanboy you'll love it because it is really kojima to the max. if you dont mind a nonsese of a story and character design and can endure long cutscenes for the sake of playing an excellent sim this is your game. otherwise please save your money and headache for another day.

A truly amazing experience! This is a breath of fresh air, a creative and immersive game full of detail and intriguing lore to be explored.
If you're looking for an action packed game like GTA or Borderlands this ISN'T for you. However, if you're willing to embark on a journey that will make you question your own existence and reality, perhaps, this might be the game you're looking for. And if you're just looking for something to "waste" time on, this is definitely the game for that. 
I've played both the original and directors cut (which is by far the best version of the game) and when I was given the option to port my save from one to another I just said "fuck it, I'm starting all over". There are few games I'd be willing to that with. This is meant to be played casually, you're supposed to invest time and patience in uncovering the secrets and details of the world and characters and that's what I liked about it. I confess I haven't finished it yet, nor do I want to.
Keep on keeping on :)

Gam

2019 I remember watching my friends play DS on ps4. I was hooked on its creativity, the story, the mechanics, the BTs , Time-fall , BB ... was so much more curious. As a Kojima fan i wanted to experience the So called "Walking Simulator" no offence. I played a bit on my friends Ps4, doing deliveries on East region. I have a Potato PC with Gtx 950 so i resumed DS again on my friend's laptop around 2022,just doing deliveries , chilling, enjoying the soothing music,beautiful Landscape on Easy mode. Before i knew it i was lvl 200 till Port Knot City. 
2023 I saved enough from 1 yr job to upgrade my PC with 4070ti n so on ! I started playing the story a bit more, Mama was beautiful , Fragile was heart-touching, The Cliche of Relationship drama was amusing, the surprising NPC Names unfolded with story progression. The volcano observatory, The Mars-like landscape around Junk dealer and The Mountain region were breathtaking. Sometimes i would just walk and see the post apocalyptic Nature for hours. Took a whole Bike ride around the edges of Central region before unlocking Edge Knot city-thinking its the last chapter but there was more... felt anti-climactic !
Post Episode 11 was a total emotional coaster ride, Was NO 1 structure contributor then "Story" happened... felt like all those time building was a waste. THEN A beautiful Closure, a Beautiful ending , a Beautiful Episode 13 ! 
Exported my Save to Directors Cut in Episode 14 in very hard difficulty to witness the next content. The buddy bot, jump ramps,Firing range tests are fun but gameplay wise it felt hollow cuz i have already finished The OG DS. Just farmed Chiral Crystals and played post game missions.AT Level 300 I have laid the game to rest !

Game still got bugs though! The truck was hanging in the air form the ground like Witcher's Classic ROACH, the old save structures didn't load sometimes, The Yellow hue from Terminal Satellite lights was too saturated, The jungle swamp World war graphics felt so off, In Director cut The graphics had Aliasing jittery lines when game loads-had to restore graphics to default n then jagged is gone. TIP Play Director cut from beginning , Post OG Death Stranding - Director Cut is boring.

Looking forward to Sequel !

Death Stranding is one of those games where you're either 100% onboard or you're not. This has nothing to do with the quality of the game, which is incredible, but more so whether or not the gameplay loop connects with you. The story is incredible, but as it seems with Kojima, you may need to replay it one or two more times before you fully understand everything that happens in the story. While the graphics are solid, though not incredible, the landscapes you travel through are absolutely stunning. The gameplay loop is relaxing and the usual slow pace of it is refreshing. For me, this is perhaps my favorite game of all time.
I judged this game before I had even played it. I'm so glad I saw it through. This isn't a game for everyone but, it's absolutely incredible.

سمة اللعبة الأساسية هي التواصل والاتصال، فهدفك في اللعبة ربط مدن أمريكا ببعض بعد تفككها لتصبح قوة متحدة من جديد وإعادة ماتم فقدانه، وتوصيل المؤونة والأدوات بعد انقطاع سبل المواصلات كجزء من مهمتك، لكن الترابط والتواصل بين اللاعبين بالذات -في لعبة لاتقدم لعب تعاوني تقليدي- قد يكون أعمق ما تم تقديمه في الألعاب للآن. فبالإضافة إلى الرسائل التشجيعية والتحذيرية التي يستطيع اللاعبون وضعها لبعض ورؤية آثار أقدامهم والطرق التي سلكوها، تستطيع بناء جسر يستفيد منه جميع اللاعبين! أو مولد أو صندوق بريد أو برج أو بيت آمن. وتستطيع استكمال بناء ما بدأه شخص آخر، وحتى توصيل طرد سقط من لاعب آخر إلى هدفه أو إلى شخص آخر ليتولاه. العملة الرئيسية هنا هي الإعجابات (Likes) والتي تستطيع إعطائها للاعبين الآخرين واستقبالها من شخصيات اللعبة واللاعبين الآخرين كمكافأة على مساعدتهم وإنهاء المهام مما يرفع من مستوى شخصيتك ويحسنها. اللعبة متجددة ومتغيرة باستمرار، وتدفعك دومًا للتفاعل لا مباشرة مع اللاعبين الآخرين.
بعد العروض البعض نعت اللعبة بلعبة ‘توصيل’ كنوع من الاستنقاص، لكن توقعهم في محله وإن كان ذلك نقطة قوة اللعبة الأساسية، فهي تقدم نوعًا جديدًا من التحدي. ستحمل البضائع على ظهرك كجزء من المهمة بالإضافة إلى الأدوات التي تحتاجها (أكياس دم، أسلحة، قنابل، الخ) وكلما حملت على عاتقك أغراض أكثر كلما استطعت إنهاء مهام أكثر لكن ذلك يأتي على حساب سرعة وسهولة حركتك و توازنك. حتى اكتشاف الأعداء لك يصبح أسهل عندما تحمل أدوات أكثر والقتال يصبح أصعب. وعبور الوديان وقطع الأنهار وتسلق الجبال يقدم تحديًا من نوع جديد، وجميع هذا قد يعرضك لفقدان أحد أمتعتك (والتي تستطيع أيضًا استخدامها كسلاح لكن قد يعرضها للتلف). بينما حمل الأغراض وقطع المسافات عملية بسيطة في غالب الألعاب، هنا هي محور التحدي والتخطيط.
كلعبة توصيل فالاهتمام بفيزيائية الحركة مهم جدًا، فتتأثر حركتك وتوازنك حسب تضاريس الأرض، سواء كانت صخورًا أو طينًا أو ثلوجًا أو أنهارًا عميقة، وهناك عدة عدادات تحكم ثباتك وحركتك مثل اللياقة والتحمل، والتربة تختلف عن الطين وعن الأنهار بحسب عمقها، وهذا يؤثر على الأعداء أيضًا، فلا أجمل من رؤية عدو يهم باتجاهك ثم يجرفه النهر بسبب عمقه وقوة التيار! أو أن يزلق عدو وهو يحاول ضربك بسبب الطين! هناك تفاصيل كثيرة وعدادات عدة وحسب مستوى الصعوبة وطريقة لعبك قد تصبح حتى لعبة بقاء، خاصة عندما تقابل عاصفة ثلجية أو غازات سامة أو منطقة ملغمة بالأعداء. اللعبة في أساسها لعبة أنظمة عدة متداخلة لتصنع تجارب مختلفة، أكثر من كونها لعبة خطية ثابتة. 
هناك أيضًا قتال، سواء أعداء أو زعماء، وكمراسل وليس مقاتل فالقتال باليدين بسيط وذو ثقل، بينما هناك أسلحة متعددة مثل المسدسات والقنابل. كذلك هناك هروب من المرتزقة عند المرور بمنطقتهم، وكذلك التخفي والرعب خاصة عند نزول المطر وظهور الـBT من عالم الأموات. هذه كلها تتفاعل مع نقلك للطرود، ولا يوجد هناك هلعًا أسوأ من الهروب من أعداء أو وحوش وفقدان أحد طرودك والاضطرار للعودة له! القتال والتخفي قد يكونا بسيطان، خاصة مع إعطاء اللعبة فرصة لك للرجوع للحياة بعد الموت، لكن دمجهما مع إدارة المتاع والتحرك حاملًا أوزانًا هو ما يرفع من قيمته. حتى العربات ليست دائمًا الخيار الأفضلً، فبعض المناطق يصعب قطعها بالعربات والطرق الوعرة تجعل الأغراض عرضة للكسر في السيارة.
كلعبة معاصرة من المخرج كوجيما، فهناك في القصة تعليق اجتماعي، وفلسفة ورمزية وخيال علمي وعلم حقيقي، وكذلك شطحات مفسرة بعضها وبعضها موجودة ليقوم البعض بتأليف النظريات اللانهائية. قصة اللعبة أن الولايات المتحدة تفككت، وبعدها بدأت كائنات من عالم الأموات بالعودة إلى عالمنا وخطر انفجار يسمى Voidout، لذا أصبح الناس يعزلون أنفسهم في غرف محصنة تحت الأرض ويعتمدون على المراسلين للحياة. أنت أحد البشر القادرين على الذهاب والعودة لعالم الأموات، وكذلك دمك (بالإضافة إلى سوائل أخرى) يمكن استخدامه لقتل الـBT. طريقة عرض القصة شبيهة بلعبة MGSV، فالمشاهد السينمائية قصيرة خاصة في البداية، والشخصية الرئيسية قليلًا ماتتكلم. هناك شخصيات مثيرة للاهتمام وأحداث تجعلك ترغب بمعرفة المزيد، وكونها لعبة جديدة لا تحمل إرث سلسلة كاملة مثل Metal Gear Solid يساعدها كثيرًا.
رسوم اللعبة جميلة والحركة بالذات غنية بالتفاصيل، وهناك تنوع لا بأس به بين المناطق، فهنالك الغابات والأنهار والصحاري والمناطق الصخرية الحمراء والمباني المهجورة والجبال الثلجية والبركانية، وإن كانت هنا أيضا تشبه Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain في كون العالم خاليًا بسبب اختباء الناس. الموسيقى جيدة وتوقيتها مناسب حيث تبدأ عند قربك للهدف أو عبور منطقة معينة بالإضافة بالطبع إلى المشاهد السينمائية المهمة والتي كالعادة مخرجة بشكل مميز جدًا.

I really wanted to love this game because it was my first Kojima game and I love Norman Reedus and Mads Mikkelsen and was open to whatever craziness was coming my way! Sadly, the gameplay loop wasn't very varied and as much as I dislike the "Amazon simulator" comments, it did feel like I was just delivering packages just so I could get to the next story part, which is what was more interesting than the limited 'avoid the invisible enemies' combat and fetch quests.

TL;DR: Watch the cinematics for the game on YouTube instead. It's not bad, just a tad on the boring side, in terms of gameplay.
I love it. Very chill and not chill game. xD 10/10

[code] [h1] DEATH STRANDING — IS MORE THAN A COURIER GAME [/h1]
[u] But not everyone will like it [/u] [/code]
[code] [h1] PREFACE [/h1]
 [b] Sam Bridges delivers the goods. His task is to reunite the cities of America into a single network, to establish connections between people and restore faith and hope to them. To do this, each time he shoulders a heavy burden and goes to the goal marked on the map, and along the way he fights with severe weather conditions, hides from the rain, which ages everything he touches, tries to ford the river, climbs mountains, wades through seemingly impassable forests.
  Most of the time, Sam sees picturesque landscapes, nature. In the background, relaxing, often depressive trance music Low Roar plays. Melodies are periodically interrupted by audio messages from secondary characters. On the one hand, it is a journey to the west with the aim of uniting America. But, in a good way, this is a highway to nowhere: the final point of the path is an abstract, constantly changing concept, sometimes looped.
  Often you have to go back. The hero endures all adversity - and something similar is required from the player sitting on the other side of the screen. This is where the connection is broken for the first time: as it turned out after the release, not everyone is tuned in to the meditative perception of the artificial world in such a time-absorbing format.
  Death Stranding turns the perception of video games as such upside down, but for many it is not an achievement and an opportunity to learn new things, but the biggest obstacle. After the publication of the first ratings of the game, Hideo Kojima said in an interview with the Italian edition of TGcom24 that "it may be more difficult for some players to understand it, because Americans, for example, are fans of first-person shooters, and Death Stranding flies higher." And yet, Death Stranding, as a finished work in the format of a video game, is able to give more emotions and impressions if you overpower yourself at the right time and let the narrator guide you through the entire narrative to the end. [/b] [/code]
[code] [h1] JOURNEY TO THE WEST [/h1]
 [b] The world of Death Stranding is a big mystery, the solution of which takes a lot of effort. The lion's share of the game's plot is devoted to explaining the world order, but even more is hidden in numerous text files and interviews. According to history, in the not so distant future, a global catastrophe occurred, in our version translated as "Death Exit". After it, people hid in underground cities of refuge, the connection between which is maintained by couriers. Sam serves as an envoy for United Cities of America, the successor to the U.S. government. He also makes the second expedition in the history of the new world to the Regional Node - through the entire map of the country.
  The narrative does not directly require delving into all the complex aspects, allowing the player, conditionally, to go with the flow forward and cling to different pieces of information here and there. An accidentally dropped phrase is not able to shock, but in a hurry, the collected grains of knowledge about one of the heroes of history together add up to a picture of a great life tragedy. The passage of the game is largely a contemplative process during monotonous work. When you make an expedition to the next settlement, you plunge into reflection and continue to exist on your own wavelength - you notice the details, try to understand the meaning of the words and terms previously voiced by the heroes. For this reason, it is extremely difficult to play in fits and starts, one task a day, being distracted, not paying attention to what is happening.
  In the first hours, Death Stranding may seem too unfriendly in terms of the simplest things. So, Sam loads a hundred kilograms of cargo on himself and collects lost containers of other couriers along the way. It is not very convenient to walk with such a burden, so it falls in different directions, falls, loses boxes, and they get damaged and lose value. The courier's shoes wear out, fatigue grows. It is necessary to ford the river only after scanning the terrain, so as not to get into too deep areas and not swim a dozen meters downstream, losing all your luggage. Climbing mountains is a dashing undertaking, but how not to fall down and die halfway to the goal.
  There are also obstacles of an unnatural nature. Deprived of work, couriers have united in aggressive groups, armed themselves and catch delivery men on the way. Fights with them are not very difficult, but the game strongly recommends avoiding such threats, hiding in tall grass, without making unnecessary movements and without making unnecessary sounds. The real devilry begins in the territories occupied by the disembodied BT - or Creatures, as they were translated in the Russian version. The hero does not see them completely, but can catch barely distinguishable outlines if he freezes in place. His guide through such areas is a BB kid in a capsule fastened to a suit and a sensor clicking with a mechanical beak - its direction betrays the location of the enemy, and the intensity of clicks and a sound signal - the proximity of the enemy.
  For the first few hours, such moments are spent exclusively on stealth, and almost to the touch. It is worth freaking out and rushing forward - the baby will be hysterical, overtired and cut off. The ground under your feet will turn into a black viscous liquid, ugly creatures will climb out of it and begin to grab the courier with their hands, pulling him along. If you manage to escape, the cargo will still be either lost or damaged.
  Then it will be easier. One quest will give Sam an exoskeleton for his legs, and he will be able to take twice as much weight. Learn to move more steadily, temporarily get acceleration for running. In the story, he will be given special grenades to "kill" BT. The courier will get motorcycles, start stealing trucks. He will have robots (in the first scene with a mechanical delivery man, I want to say in the voice of David Hater: "A weapon to surpass Metal Gear!"), Which will perform additional tasks on their own. Along with the need to put stairs across the river, it will be possible to build huge bridges. The closer Sam gets to his ultimate goal, the more options he will be presented with – all of which are aimed at making his life easier.
  The game itself does not always keep up with the changes, so the difficulty level practically does not increase. For lovers of quiet walks, there is a super-simple mode in which the courier receives minimal damage, and in general he has nothing to fear. Local terrorists will add some turmoil, but they are the most interesting to fight - they will bring drive and dynamics.
  Underneath all this lies a layer of interaction with other players and the notorious building of connections. Don't let this be misleading: Death Stranding is a deeply personal game for everyone, everything about it emphasizes this feature. In part, this personifies the world around, because almost all the time Sam is completely alone. However, by connecting a new settlement to the network, he begins to see the signs left behind, the buildings erected by other players, with which he can also interact - complete the construction, for example, by dragging cases with valuable resources. Finally, put likes. Get likes for your actions. And this mechanic is not devoid of touching moments: when you use the opportunity to shout something into the ringing void for the first time and receive an answer from an invisibly (metaphysically, in fact) nearby player nearby - goosebumps run through your skin... [/b] [/code]
[code] [h1] 10/10 GENIUS [/h1] [/code]

Hideo Kojima is off the wall.

In the first 45 minutes of gameplay, I played for 5 minutes and watched cutscenes with vacuous monologues for 40. I am not exaggerating.

This doesn't improve later. After suffering a few times through NPCs' long-winded monologues about nothing much, I just started skipping everything. I swear, they could have said everything in like 5 minutes, but this somehow gets stretched into hours of uninspired drivel.

Ok, so I was not impressed with the cutscenes. What about the gameplay?

It's great, until it's not. 

If there is one thing I hate in first-person games, it's when camera or character control is taken from you. This game does this all the time.

It's a walking simulator. I get it, and I don't mind. Can I please be allowed to WALK then?!?

You pick up some boxes, deliver them to destination, replenish consumables, get new quest, off you go. Right? No. You have to listen to an NPC for 5 minutes telling you that you got a new gun, or that what you're doing is important, or explaining how to defecate. Man, taking a dump IRL is faster than in-game.

On the plus side, the game looks nice and runs great. Everything seems polished. Game mechanics are innovative and interesting. The souls-like single-player-in-multiplayer-universe thing works okay. The story is unhinged Kojima-level insane, which is good if you're into that kind of thing.

It's just that it has so much unnecessary baggage that should have been axed. So many unskippable animations, I just couldn't put up with it any more. Which is a crying shame because it looks like a lot of effort was put into all these little details that I came to resent. Then I start feeling bad because some poor dev spent days animating some stupid thing that only serves to irritate me.

What this game needed was a person who would point finger and say "remove this thing, shorten this other thing" before they released it.

After a few hours I realized I was having fun in a few moments and then suffering through most.

Uninstalled, unlikely to play again.

The end of the world has come and everything has turned to shit. Humanity is divided and largely living by itself, the dead seemingly have come and hope is on the brink of being snuffed out forever. You are Sam Porter Bridges, the "great deliverer", a postman with no ties but the innately special ability to deliver cargo no matter what. An organization called Bridges is trying to rebuild America into the United Cities of America, separatists are threatening the world and things are getting, somehow, worse. But when you have no attachment to America, to a family or to friends, what is the point of continuing forward? What can one man do in the face of such hatred, indifference and the universe seemingly bent on your destruction. Why bother trying? Why not just let it all end with a whimper. 

How this game exists baffles me to my very core but I remain ever happy that it does even after 100+ hours of game time. The crazy combination of niche gameplay with logistics and a AAA quality presentation is, in my mind, not a game that should be even remotely possible to create in 2023. Yet here we are. Not just a niche game, but a really good one with no exploitative game business model. A breath of fresh air. 

This is very much Hideo Kojima's writing style so if you've chaffed at the earnest or corny dialogue, the rather on the nose plot or the super long lore dumps that often came with Metal Gear Solid titles, this is in the same vein. But, after years of suffering through misery porn on TV shows and having a supremely negative outlook on living through any potential upcoming apocalypse in our lifetime, Death Stranding actually changed my mind. 

In stark contrast to our culture's preppers, I have held that if the worst should happen, there is really no point for me to keep living. (And I am delighted by how often this game will often make fun of that mentality while also putting in stark reality that they are truly just as fucked as the rest of us if the worst should happen). I figure if the bombs should land, if the world truly hits rock bottom...well. I don't think I need to fill in the gaps. 

There are only a few pieces of media I can ever recall changing my opinion on something I felt I was quite right on. Death Stranding joins them. I dunno if I can claim its cured my negative outlook on apocalypses completely, but it gave me a reason to keep going even when everything seems against me. And that is enough. 

If you really like logistics games like Death Stranding, a new sci-fi universe and looking for a unique experience, I think you'll really dig this one. Cause I think after years of living in our current times with Covid-19, the rise of facism and people being horrible, we could all use some hope and reasons to keep living.

Snooze fest. I tried for 15 hours to pretend to like this game and at times I convinced myself that I did. Once the honeymoon phase wears off and you start to get an understanding of the game play loop, it's either a Love It or Hate It experience. Judging by most peoples recollections with this game, you're either completely on one end of these spectrum's, there is no in between.  

None of your mistakes or choices seem to have any meaningful consequences at all. When you're trying to sneak your way through a 700 meter field with roaming enemies, the intensity eventually wears off. When the intensity wears off and the boredom takes the forefront, you decide to pop out of your crouch position and run through, alerting everyone. Come to find out, the human enemies pose such a little threat that you feel insulted for even spending the time you did attempting to not be detected. Getting caught has no consequences, neither does dying. 

These stealth areas were the "highlight" of my experience with this game. The other 90% was traversing boring landscapes from one end to the other. 

Maybe I didn't give my chance with this game enough time but it is incredibly difficult to get into, even as a Kojima fan.

I held off on playing this for a long time, but I feel comfortable saying this is the first entry in an entire new genre of game. I'm here for it, and im hopeful future "Strandlikes" iterate even further on the mechanics and systems here.

This narrative is both a keen and expansive testimonial to the burdens and social constructs of our modern world. It's a love letter to the emotional weight we carry as individuals and thus our ability to shed that weight as we begin to recognize our place in a community. To contribute to it's support system. It's a timely commentary on watching people die in front of us and how that affects our perception of the passage of time, itself. An allegory on our mortality. It's all this- and brilliant acting and animation. It's a slow burn, but its a smoldering, relative and relatable sci-fi burn. Thus, leaving it's impression as a future classic nested in a well philosophized and visualized foundation of our current sociological connective plight as humans- both in search of ourselves and our place in the world.

After the long slog, tripping and cursing, and hating myself for ever purchasing the game that is [b][u] this [/u][/b] tedious to play (especially the combat encounters, on Very Hard), I have to say - it was worth it! 

Kojima is definitely a masterclass level narrative genius, who (should you swallow the [i] in medias res [/i] storytelling from the get-go and stick 'till the end) really got me to love the story he'd so caringly woven into this game. It touches on so many subjects (primarily that of existence, life and social bonds that are unique to man), dives deep into the history, philosophy, and folklore, while presenting some really fresh and never-before-seen (or even controversial) ideas that you cannot but admire the literary effort put behind the game. It truly is something special, albeit a bit hard to enjoy because the gameplay elements (by themselves and observed in isolation) are pretty dull and tedious (in my opinion). 

Still, I am willing to look past the experimental gameplay because the final experience that DEATH STRANDING offers (come full-circle) is truly worth it, and is something that I'll cherish 'till the end of my days and reminiscence upon - in short, a dream-come-true for every narrative/story aficionado out there that is sure to find its place on their "best of the best" shelf. 

Mr. Kojima - thank you for the wonderful ride, and here's hoping that DEATH STRANDING 2 (or w/e you decide to call the sequel that in the works) surpasses the original game (and introduces a better, more dynamic gameplay that is more enjoyable).

Death Stranding is a unique and innovative game that requires players to adopt a different playstyle compared to traditional action games. Here are some tips on how to play Death Stranding:
1. Plan your routes: One of the most important aspects of Death Stranding is planning your routes carefully. You will need to navigate rough terrain, steep inclines, and hazardous weather conditions, all while carrying heavy packages. It's a good idea to scout out your route ahead of time and plan your journey accordingly. You can use your map to mark out points of interest, such as shelters or hot springs, that will help you on your journey.
2. Manage your cargo: You will be carrying a lot of cargo throughout the game, and it's important to manage it carefully. Each package has a weight and size, which affects your movement and balance. Be sure to pack your cargo strategically, placing heavier items lower to maintain your balance. You can also use various tools and equipment, such as a floating carrier or power gloves, to make transporting your cargo easier.
3. Pay attention to the terrain: The terrain in Death Stranding is an important factor to consider when navigating the world. Different terrain types, such as rocky cliffs or muddy rivers, will require different approaches. Be sure to use your scanner to identify obstacles and hazards, and use your equipment, such as climbing anchors or ladders, to traverse difficult terrain.
4. Build structures and contribute to the community: Death Stranding is a game about building connections and helping others. You can build structures, such as bridges or roads, to make travel easier for yourself and other players. Contributing to the community will also earn you likes, which can be used to unlock new equipment and abilities.
5. Explore and discover: Death Stranding is a game that rewards exploration. There are many hidden secrets and Easter eggs throughout the game, so take the time to explore and discover new areas. You may find valuable resources, rare items, or even new missions to complete.
Overall, playing Death Stranding requires patience, strategic planning, and a willingness to explore and contribute to the community. By following these tips, you can enjoy a unique and rewarding gaming experience.

bom

This title certainly stands out of the selection available at the point of this review. The narrative may require substantial effort to follow, but it draws upon universal themes to which almost anyone could relate - isolation, cooperation, kinship, life, death, and life after death.

The walking mechanics are not designed to be too punishing (but for the huge amount of walking itself); that is to say, even while traversing difficult terrain, one does not need to carefully ponder one's footing to avoid tumbling. That said, the character may feel somewhat heavy-footed and not particularly dexterous in hand-to-hand combat (akin to games by Rockstar, namely, Grand Theft Auto and Red Dead Redemption series). Climbing is governed by one sole button; the experience is as streamlined as can be. Still, at least in the beginning, the actual walking part should still feel fairly engaging, as rope and ladders are the main tools at player's disposal at this stage. Later on, when vehicles become available, the deliveries will feel almost trivial. Even if at times - especially when slowly making one's way up a particularly steep slope - one might end up wishing for a horse from Skyrim, the battery-powered trike featured here does not leave too much to be desired in terms of its cross-country abilities. Vehicle physics and manouevrability are a little janky, but not infuriatingly so.

Harder difficulties make cargo containers and boots degrade faster from local "aging" rainfall which somehow does not affect Sam's suit. Makes one wonder why they would not just use the same materials for cargo containers, but this adds some tension to the gameplay, so - disbelief successfully suspended! Pieces of cargo are given names, but these are largely only there for flavour; unless transporting a box with a condition (keep cool, keep dry, keep flat, don't drop), they might as well have had no names at all, as they do not affect gameplay. It has to be noted, the game allows saving when not in combat, so harder difficulties do not actually require complete mastery of the game's many mechanics to enjoy oneself - at least where the delivering side of things is concerned.  

Unfortunately, some combat is unavoidable, and harder difficulties increase the enemies' health pool in addition to increasing damage inflicted upon the player. Saving is not allowed with enemies nearby, and battles with humanoid bosses specifically have to be restarted upon failure. Ideally, enemies should be taken out one by one, so back to lurking in tall grass it is; a renowned staple mechanic regularly employed by third-person titles. Regular human enemies (who actually have a comparatively tolerable health pool) can be pacified with rope from behind even in alerted state, but bosses will just free themselves after a couple of seconds - be sure to make yourself scarce by then! At one point, having finally managed to sneak up on a boss, I pacified him and relaxed my grip on the gamepad expecting a cutscene (of which there are quite a few here) only for him to promptly help himself back up, unload into my face, and invite his buddies to do the same - turns out humanoid bosses are beefy but appear to have no health bar indicators (nor gentleman's honour, for that matter).

The other type of combat encounters are triggered when detected and "caught" by a ghostly sentry within certain areas on the map. Often, these areas are located along the shortest routes towards delivery destinations to force the player to make a choice - to fight or sneak their way through the area or take the longer way around. The first couple of times these encounters can feel genuinely exhilarating, especially without any equipment to fight back, making it out to the other side in one piece feels rewarding, but afterwards they begin to feel a little tedious. This negative sentiment is partly due to the way the encounter plays out after the player has been "caught" - a small and shallow lake of goo materialises under the character's feet, gooey humanoids start dragging the character under; if they are successful, a massive damage sponge appears (a gooey whale, octopus, or chimera-like creature); increasing the amount of time spent on the encounter. In turn, the player can attempt to reach the edge of the lake shaking off the humanoids in the process to avoid the encounter with the Sponge, so there is that at least. Later on the player is granted an ability to sneak up on some of the invisible sentries and dispatch them quickly, but not all of them are susceptible to this attack.

Nevertheless, I picked this up expecting a fairly engaging but relatively peaceful cross-country adventure about a person working a dull but necessary job, perhaps seeking a sensation not too much unlike the one experienced by fans of Powerwash Simulator and similar games. Indeed, when the game takes the player through the snowy mountain peaks (and back multiple times), having the ability to cover the inhospitable area with zip-lines to drastically decrease the amount of backtracking is what makes the game stand out in particular. One of the game's features is partial sharing of structures between individual players' game-worlds; that is, one might stumble across a zip-line anchor already in place or a particularly treacherous body of water with a bridge over it already built by someone exceptionally considerate.

Needless to say, all of this is expertly acted and animated, and the numerous mechanics are believably grounded within the universe of the game; it's a shame the combat and the narrative for the best part simply went miles over my head. Moreover, the game feels like it could easily have been two-thirds the length and still retain its impact. Getting all achievements requires a monumental grind in context of a single-player game. Thankfully, there are no difficulty-related story achievements, so it would seem the difficulty may be altered at will - lowered for boss battles and increased before tackling deliveries for some extra environmental tension.

I was so angry that I paused the game to write this review. I'm sure anyone who plays this game is familiar with the way you often have to go through BT areas while delivering cargo.

BUT: in the eastern region, between the musician and port knot city, there are very large and seemingly impassable mountains. The only other way to get to PKC is to go through a very hilly and mountainous BT area that I hate using.

Well, I wasted the time and energy to find a way up these mountains, trying to avoid the BT area, only to find an INVISIBLE WALL AT THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN.

REALLY??? REALLY??? I used to love this game for being cool and unique but now im not so sure. As a player I do not appreciate being FORCED to take a certain route that im certain the entire playerbase hates to use. It's really scummy that you'd use something like an invisible wall to force players to go through a more high risk area.

Wonderful game. Totally different than anything I've played before. Immersive, beautiful landscapes. intense at times. Very interesting and worthwhile.

I played through the whole game, taking the time to do pretty much everything. It was... okay? I finished it because much of the actual gameplay was something I could listen to podcasts during. The pacing of unlocks was pretty good. It stretched out that "always something new" throughout the game instead of blowing it's load early. But the story was just meh.

It tried to get scientific in places, but the got the science just blatantly wrong. It tried to get philosophical in places and tried to seem deep, but it wasn't. I think the story could be okay if it were executed better. Instead, the story is disjointed. Motivations are muddied. In some ways I know that was intentional as some characters may not be straightforward and honest, but near the end of the game, the main character goes from hopeful and positive to closed off and misanthropic within literal minutes of each other. Is he an optimist? Is he a pessimist? Why does it shift from one moment to the next with no obvious cause or reason?

I think the story could have been really good, but it just fell flat because there appeared to be no motivation for the main character to vacillate between extremes as he did. It was interesting world building, but without any reasons for the reactions that were presented. I mean, if it's on mega sale or something and you've got nothing better to do, the primary mechanic of delivering is something you can do while you listen to podcasts. Just don't expect it to make much sense or get any science right.

“Traveling is a brutality. It forces you to trust strangers and to lose sight of all that familiar comfort of home and friends. You are constantly off balance. Nothing is yours except the essential things – air, sleep, dreams, the sea, the sky – all things tending towards the eternal or what we imagine of it.” – Cesare Pavese

This quote to me epitomizes Death Stranding as a whole. Not only does the game instill a sense of vastness but also inspires the awe of adventure set within a goal driven story of human connection and struggle. Struggle being the key word when traveling with packages and parcels of import to different destinations, surrounded by ghosts of the past. 

Norman Reedus as Sam does a great job existing in this world. Loss and loneliness seem to be the real enemy, where as the phantom BTs and human bandits gladly hunt and stalk you, loneliness turns into beauty when the wind sweeps across the environments of Death Stranding, and its just you, our cargo, and the little baby companion known as BB coos and giggles.

The gameplay loop seems simple but ends up becoming complex, between planning your route of travel, to optimizing your delivery weight, and the gathering of resources and building structures to aid you, and other players connected to the every growing network of couriers. Then of course the BTs youll encounter who will drag you down, ensuring you lose your cargo and possibly your life. Its all depending on one wrong step and you can ruin your entire delivery. But thats the risk and reward aspect of Death Stranding.

The over arching story is really well told as well. Dealing with post-apocalyptic events set in a harsh reality and the rain now ages you if youre exposed to it. I have never seen this done in a game.

Death Stranding is a love it or hate it game. Yes, this is a full on delivery/walking simulator with focus on traversing and surviving through harsh conditions. It's gameplay is very niche, but very fun and addicting for people open to it. I love this game and spent countless hours on PS4 and now on here. Can not wait for the sequel.

I can already tell by playing for a few days, I've come to love the idea behind the "multiplayer" aspect of it. The concept of the "likes" and being connected to countless players you will never meet in person. This "connection" through the journeys each individual player makes and the structures they have used/created once you've connected areas into the Chiral network. It gives a stark realization of how when everyone pitches in, even if a little bit, helps on a larger scale. 

The amount of "likes" on structures shows how others have come to find it's usefulness. On several occasions another player's equipment has come in clutch for me and I wish I could send more "likes" their way. And of course there's the act of taking care of another player's delivery with nothing to gain other than helping them out.  

I've built a few things and left them out in the world and returned to see others have used them too. I'll never see who is recharging their trike at my generator, stored their things in my remote locker, or meet the player who took a break with me while I waited out a timefall. But it feels good knowing I'm helping my fellow porters along their delivery journey despite what little it may be. It's a grand sharing of silent appreciation because we've all got a job to do and we don't have to suffer alone through it.

Of course, one doesn't [i]have[/i] to give or receive help. You could even play the game without contributing anything and walk the entire game on your own. But eventually, another porter is going come across your footsteps and retrace them for their own benefit. And they will probably drop "like" on it.

Anyways, keep on keeping on.
Over 12,500 positive reviews at the time of writing...what more can be said? This game is incredible. Keep on keepin' on.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
