Gorgeous. Bizarre. Pretentious. You will never play a game quite like this one. Yes, you deliver packages like a UPS or Amazon driver. But that really doesn't give you much of an idea of what it is like to play this game. 

Building structures that exist in a multiplayer shared universe is the highlight of the game. Build a bridge that helps that unseen delivery man on the lap top across the world. IF it helps out others, you get votes. By helping yourself you are helping others. 

There are features of the game that will annoy or frustrate many players. Transportation across the landscape can be tediously slow and dangerous. You don't get vehicles till later in the game, which makes the game a walking simulator for the early part of the game.  Walking everywhere in the deadly rain takes time and resources. Since everything tends to degrade in the game, you may find yourself doing a lot of repairs. 

Combat with the invisible phantom creatures is horrible. At least in the beginning. You are given grenades to throw at them. Weak grenades. Grenades that are hard to aim. So if you get in combat you will probably die. Since the online part of the game is limited to structures, you will find yourself facing a certain death a lot of the time. There are human enemies too, and they are very well equipped. You aren't. 

The story sounds a bit preachy: the unity of mankind or some such. But I don't play for story. 

If you can get past these negatives, it can be a unique and rewarding experience.

Just try it, stick around for the first two chapters and see if this could be your cup of tea. You may find yourself surprised by what you discover!

death stranding is a video game developed by kojima Productions and published by sony interactive entertainment. it was released on november 8 2019 for playstation 4 and later for microsoft windows in july 2020. the game is an active-adventure game set in in a post- apocalyptic would where the player takes on the role of Sam porter bridges, a courier tasked with delivering essential supplies to isolated settlements and reconnecting a fragmented society. 

the gameplay mechanics of Death stranding are unique and innovative, with an emphasis on exploration, survival and social interaction. the games world is vast and expansive, with players having to traverse treacherous terrain, navigate through hazardous environments, and avoid dangerous creatures known as BTs (Beached Things). the players primary objectives is to deliver packages to various settlements, which are often located in remote areas of the game world. these packages contain essential supplies such as food, medicine, and other equipment that the settlements need to survive. the player must carefully plan their route, taking into account the terrain, weather conditions, and the weight of their cargo.

the games mechanics are centered around the corrupt of connectivity, with players having to establish and maintain connections with other players in the game world. the games online features allow players to help each other by leaving helpful messages, constructing structures such as bridges and roads, and sharing equipment and resources. players can also undertake delivery missions together, which can be particularly useful when tackling difficult and dangerous areas of the game world.

One of the standout features of Death stranding is its visuals, which are nothing short of breathtaking. the games world is beautiful rendered, with stunning landscapes, intricate details, and realistic weather effects. the character models are also incredibly detailed, with realistic facial expressions and body movements that bring the games characters to life. the games audio design is also exceptional, with a haunting and atmospheric soundtrack that perfectly complements the games eerie and foreboding atmosphere.

however, the games storyline has been a point of contention among players and critics alike. the plot for Death stranding is dense and complex, with large cast of characters and a convoluted narrative that can be difficult to follow. the games story also deals with heavy themes such as life, death, and the afterlife, which may not appeal to all players, however, those who are willing to invest the time and effort to understand the story will be rewarded with a thought-provoking and emotionally resonant experience. 

the games combat mechanics have also been criticized by some players, with combat encounters feeling clunky and unpolished. however, combat is not the main focus of the game, and players are centered around exploration, survival and social interaction, with combat being a secondary aspect of the gameplay. 

overall, Death stranding is a unique and innovative game that offers truly immersive and memorable gaming experience. the games world is vast and expansive, with stunning visuals and exceptional audio design that creates an eerie and foreboding atmosphere. the games mechanics are innovative and centered around the concept of connectivity, with players having to establish and maintain connections with other players in the game world. however, the games dense and complex storyline may not appeal to all players, and the combat mechanics can feel clunky and unpolished. despite these criticisms, Death standings is a must-play for those who are looking for truly unique and unforgettable gaming experience.

Fantastic Game
I found the story extremely touching and moving, and there's nothing like getting absorbed in the process of getting Sam and his cargo around the big open world.

It's a beautiful game, but in the end, the inspiring and compelling components, and there are many, are outweighed and obscured by sometimes silly, sometimes outright painful choices.

First off, let's address the story, which is definitely a significant part of the game, and real effort has been made to stop players from skipping it, even once they have completed the game, and may just want to wander a virgin version of the landscape and just work on rebuilding america (because yes, even this mostly japanese development team has made this one of the most ameri-centric games I've ever seen.  The fate of the world is explicitly tied to the rebuilding of the USA, okay, UCA, but it really is the same thing, and it is at times nauseatingly patriotic).

But that story I mentioned, oh boy, that story. While interesting at first, is longer and more convoluted than the plot of Lost.  And makes about as much sense.  In the end, I couldn't stomach it.  Though I had played it for 60+ hours, turns out I was less than a third of the way through this beast.  Back and forth, false summit after dubious twist it goes, where it stops, Hideo only knows.  I ended up watching the remnants online and had to spam through miles of pointless dialogue to get to the (spoiler alert) hug that ends it all.  Yes, that's right, a hug, because it's all about connection.  But it's also all about connection in exactly the manner Hideo thinks best.  Connection, but without that pesky feedback loop.

This guy has a following, and I get it, he's clearly got a gift, but what he desperately needs is some friends and colleagues willing to give him honest feedback, and a box full of red pens.  Because about seven hours of the roughly eleven hours of cut scenes (really) were just pointless.

And like I said, you have to watch them.  Because the game is heavily contrived to spoon-feed you all the best stuff only after you make it through a sea of exposition.  And in the end, it all starts to feel less like a game and more like a timeshare pitch.  

This is before you get to the gameplay, which is original and inspired, and so close to great, but again, filled with needless and quickly annoying tollbooths that make each and every delivery a chore.  Every single time you make a delivery, you have to get off you bike, open the location's hub, select the delivery menu, select the 'make delivery' option, say you want to deliver requested goods, then watch a cutscene of the good's going in, then watch another cutscene of them checking the goods, each of which take loading time even if you spam the skip button, then watch an evaluation screen for each part of your delivery, each of which must be clicked through, even the "auto-skip" doesn't stay on, you have to keep manually 'auto'-skipping, then watch another animation of the results of these reviews being added to your overall score, then watch another freaking cutscene of them thanking you, and then go through almost the same to select a new mission.  That's thirty or so clicks and about three minutes between each bout of actually playing the game.

It's painful, and worse still, completely unnecessary.  Give me some skip settings in the options (and make said options accessible all the time, not only when I'm certain zones and off my bike.)  Stop forcing me to only play the way you like to play, start listening to the community (I am not the first to say these things) and be aware that not all gamers are alike, and not all want to consume the story the way you might prefer.  

Otherwise, while you may have made something that is, at it's core, almost beautiful, your egos have ended up wrapping it an exorbitant amount of self-aggrandizing junk, junk you won't let us have any choice over whether or not to watch.

Except the one choice, the one I made, and the one I suggest you do too, of not playing the game at all.

Kojima, eres un genio, gracias por todo, haz creado un videojuego con un nivel de detalle enfermizo, con unos personajes interesantes a la par que una historia increíble y una banda sonora extraordinaria. Un mundo con una ambientación mágica y fascinante. 
Me da pena haber terminado con esta montaña rusa de emociones por que se que pasarán años hasta que salga otro videojuego de este calibre.
Así que gracias Kojima, gracias por traer este juego al mundo.

Finished this game on PS4, then purchased the normal edition in Steam, and now I am replaying it one last time with the Director's Cut.

I understand this is not a game for everyone, and it may become a bit repetitive at first. But give it a chance. It gets much better and you'll learn to love it... or hate it.

There is no middle ground.

Death Stranding is one of the most unique titles I have ever played. It is such an odd mix of various genres that coalesce into a rather beautiful package. The game is simultaneously a delivery simulator with cooperative building elements, action and the occasional horror. It is a strange stew. Add to the mix the various 4th wall breaks, meta narrative, collectible product ad(?), and a beautiful  musical playlist. The music that plays during various deliveries and accentuates and enhances the tone with all background sound becoming muted and the camera zooms away. These are some of the best game play moments. The only issue is that for some reason, the game does not let you play music outside of the rest area. This is a strange choice as the music is great and would ease the tedium of constant delivery. The themes of the game can be rather blunt especially with the naming conventions. The game is about connections between people and the importance of those bonds. Dealing with the death or separation of loved ones. Various discussion on the nature of biological evolution as well as the idea of the soul. There are probably other ideas as well but they may have gone over my head a bit. The Execution of these ideas however can be hit or miss and the text logs can be chore to read. Like I said, the game is rather blunt and in your face. Quite literally at times.

Overall, the game is a unique experience that I would recommend. It brought over 70 hours out of me as of this review. It can be a bit tedious at times but I say that it was quite worth it.

One of my favourite games of all time. It's a slow burn tho, so I'd recommend it more for people who like long elaborate story lines and who are used to these types of games. It has lots of lore and amazing cut scenes. Great combination of strategy, action and skill. 15/10 !!
This game is just a Masterpiece. The worldbuilding, details, characters and story are just immaculate. It can be slow at times but if you are patient enough you will experience a story worthwhile.

One of the most unique and unforgettable AAA gaming experiences. I was immediately hooked on the gameplay, story and world. The characters were interesting, the soundtrack was excellent and the cutscenes were on a whole new level.

Flat out doesn't work. Can't get even get to main menu, some error on startup. I've tried googling/troubleshooting, and this issue also exists on the original/base game (forgot I'd bought that years ago and tried starting that up). After much reading, apparently the issue is something to do with Windows, and you need a fresh Windows install to get around it. I'm not doing a whole OS reinstall just to play one game. It's also absurd that this has apparently been an issue for years that they haven't fixed. (For clarity, every game I own other than this one runs just fine, the issue is exclusive to this game)

Edit: Coming back to mention that I ended up playing through this in its entirety on PS5, and I quite enjoyed the game (it was included in my subscription there). So while I would recommend the *game*, I can't recommend the PC version when it doesn't work on my system. Advice would be to try it, if it runs on your system that's great, enjoy. If not, refund immediately. I didn't even attempt to play this until I was well outside the 2 week refund period, so don't dawdle as far as making sure it works.

I often criticize modern AAA games for trying to be a work of high art, instead of simply being fun, but I'll make an exception for this game. 

This is the best damned game I have ever played in my life. After completing it, I'm still thinking about all of the layers and themes I encountered in this game and unpacking the narrative on a personal and human level that Kojima was telling in this story. 

Everything done here was done purposefully. Yes, the first few hours of the game are a slog, but that means when you acquire a new way to traverse this uninhabitable planet, it becomes even more rewarding. This game is very grindy, but you never actually feel like you're grinding. Again, unlocking a new way to get across this map just becomes more rewarding. 

The absolutely batshit story and themes that Kojima was exploring will keep you glued to the screen for more during these especially sluggish parts. I'd always say to myself "just one more delivery" and after this delivery there would be some other huge revelation or a new interesting character that I would have met. 

Seriously, this game is a work of art.

And so, yet another game is welcomed into my pantheon of favourites. Hideo Kojima's Death Stranding, A Game By Hideo Kojima, developed by Kojima Productions, written and conceptualized by Hideo Kojima (featuring a special appearance by Hideo Kojima) is not a game I would easily recommend. It's tedious, slow, clunky, obtuse, and often boring. But not for me. If that's what you see when you look at gameplay, then that's likely the experience you'll get, but Death Stranding is the type of game that just clicks, provided you're the right kind of crazy. I have friends who take comfort in playing games like Animal Crossing or Stardew Valley, but my therapy game is this one. There's a serenity in the package delivery simulation - a struggle between you and the truly stunning open world. Every inch is beautifully crafted and built to be as rewarding as possible. Over every pain in the ass mountain you crest is a gorgeous view of the trail to your next destination. Besides, it's not all rough terrain and endless walking. The game provides you with all the equipment you need to succeed, and if that's still not enough, there's always other players. You see, every structure you build in the game is sent to another player's game so it may help them. Need a ladder to reach the top of this cliff? Good thing another player placed one for you. The sense of community this system builds is powerful, and it helps that you can reward other players in return by responding to supply requests and helping upgrade their structures. I would also be remiss not to mention the music, which is beautiful. Largely carried by Low Roar as well as The Silent Poets, the soundtrack is rarely ever used in-game, reserved for the moments in the open world where they would carry the most impact. This works to an unprecedented degree. The story here is trademark Kojima - deep and thought-provoking, but only if you're pretentious enough to dig into each word of dialogue and codex entry. Lucky for me, I very much am. In conclusion, Death Stranding recieves no recommendation from me, because to say it's not for everyone would be the understatement of the century, but the game feels tailor-made for me. 9/10.

As a big fan of Kojima games.
And as some one who has played nearly every game hes created and loved/followed his games since i was young.
Kojima will forever be held as one of the most legendary game developers of my time, in my eyes.

However Death Stranding is a strange one to me, it added a lot of doubt over his games with him leaving Konami and all the negative reviews calling the game 'a walking sim', that eventually putting me off purchasing the game at release.

Till 'December 26 2022', when I received Death Stranding (standard edition) for free on the Epic Store.
Where i spent over 96+ hours playing the game non-stop and couldn't wait to come home from work to play more, I'm unsure if the game was different on release, however after playing the standard edition in 2023 there's a lot more options available to the player vs walking, while all having there own disadvantaged. Voiding most if not all reviews i've read. 

Dont get me wrong, though this game wont be to everyone's liking, Your either going to love it or hate it.

Personally i found the game oddly satisfying, building answers to the story. Don't get me wrong there are flaws in the game and the UI does take some getting used to, just like in MGSV, but ones your past that the game becomes enjoyable.

As such i decided the support the game and purchase it on my main platform, Steam. While upgrading to the 'Directors Cut' which includes more content.

I'll be sure to update this review when i get around to re-playing the 'Director's Cut' of Death stranding.

This game is an absolute masterpiece and one of the most unique games i have ever played.

But it is not for everyone.

The game is a slow burn with incredible mechanics that slowly unravel itself and change your perspective of the game world. The main content of the game is delivering packages, but its such a relaxing and at the same time rather intense experience that i never felt i got tired of. The asynchronous multiplayer is amazing and it works well with the story making you feel like you're a part of a bigger community. The soundtrack kicks in at just the right moments and hits just right. The dialogue can be a bit cringe at times, but the story is well told. It is a Kojima game and he adds his quirks to it. 

I can understand why some people may not like it, but i highly recommend trying the game before you decide for yourself as gameplay footage and trailers don't quite convey the experience of playing this game.

Gameplay looked promising but when your reward for a successful delivery is half an hour of the worst TV show on Earth, it's impossible to stay motivated - this was my first Kojima game and after just five hours into it I'm sure it'll also be my last, absolutely cringeworthy garbage. [h1]D grade delivery on Directors cut story content, B/ A grade delivery on other parts[/h1][b]NOTE:[/b] This review focuses on parts that were added in Directors cut, you can read my original game review here:
https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198271105938/recommended/1190460/

Let’s start from story-missions part, The Factory “chapter”. Unfortunately, this is the part where Directors Cut delivers only what feels like minimum viable product, as you can complete Factory related stuff under one hour and amount of story content given could have been fitted into one A4 paper (or save to Death Stranding 2 as a side mission would have been better solution). Heck, even the Cyberpunk 2077 collaboration missions set felt more fun than what Factory stuff did.
And that racetrack thing? Let’s just say that driving with truck in long race track is minor torture and someone at Kojima Productions should have stood up and say out loud how its not engaging gameplay. Plus vehicle controls overall in this game isn’t the best from start so yeah... hopefully we don’t see this return in DS2.

Luckily, on other parts Directors Cut brings more on the buck and expectations with few new gadgets like container firing canon, container grappling hand weapon, jet pack stabilizer that allows you to jump into air and come down without taking damage and so on. Few new side missions that bring slightly more variation to mission structure and great few new songs are also added (rest in peace Ryan Karazija, everyone from Low Roar to other people are sad for your being gone so soon).

Is Directors cut worth the 10 bucks asking price for those whom already own the base game and have beaten it long time ago? It depends, if you most cared about Death Stranding’s main story you will be disappointed. But you actually like roaming around the rocky and spacey America with containers in your back? I did and if you do, then I say it’s worth it.
Does it make game “playable” for those who dislike the original game? Absolutely not.

[h1]Verdict:[/h1]
Despite some ups and downs of directors cut, I will definitely be looking up for Death Stranding 2 and what more Hideo Kojima has to deliver to this universe. Keep on going Kojima Productions.
-3 billion/10 or 10/10, depends on my mood

Death Stranding is an impressive game. Hideo Kojima has once again delivered a unique experience. The world map and the struggle to traverse it is the main focus of the game. Kojima Productions has managed to make traversal engaging and interesting. It can be challenging and confusing at first, but don’t let that deter you from trying something new.

The graphics and art style are immersive, painting a vivid picture of a landscape that evokes the rugged beauty of Iceland. There is a wealth of information to read, including some typical Kojima “nonsense,” but it’s also compelling and adds to the story. The story itself is emotionally captivating but likes to keep you in the dark. It’s kind of crazy how the high-level concepts of the situation are so related to the events that happened in 2020 in the real world. I highly recommend taking the time to read it. The cutscenes pick up pace in the last part of the game.

The UI can be confusing at times and some controls are unconventional, but managing gear is satisfying. Take your time with the game and don’t rush it. I thoroughly enjoyed taming the map and forming connections with bases and other players. The gear upgrades represent the only form of progression and are well executed.

I highly recommend Death Stranding.

Death Stranding is a very unique game. It defies conventional game design and as a result, players tend to fall into two camps: Loved it, or hated it. Very little in between. Right off the bat, you're hit with this duality: An intriguing, yet god awful opening.

The beginning of the game is just oozing with mystery and you're given just enough to sate your appetite. However, we're talking roughly 2 HOURS of cut-scenes VS about 15 minutes of gameplay. That's right, you have to watch a movie just to play the video game. It does open up a bit more after this... but that first hurdle is rough. The end of the game gets really heavy on the movie cutscenes too.

While playing Death Stranding, it becomes incredibly apparent that Kojima really just wanted to make a movie. This game LOVES it's animations. After you're done listening to a 15 minute long movie cutscene? The characters will then repeat themselves in the actual game! As if you were [u]expected[/u] to skip it! Want to increase your stamina cap? Well Sam has to get up, walk to the table, pick up an energy drink, chug that energy drink, crumple the can, and toss it in the trash before sitting down again. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. You need to do this 3 times minimum! Thank god for the skip button!!!

The story is, in a word, [b]WILD[/b]. 

A world where the dead have become stranded in the world of the living as ghosts. Longing to form connections, however, if the living and the dead ever touch: it triggers an antimatter explosion that wipes out entire civilizations! The world is broken, jaded, and lonely, just like your character, Sam Strand. Death Stranding's story is at it's best when it's tackling the humanistic stories and the connection between people. The only real critiques to the story I have is that it drip feeds you things in this god awful bomb format. Get to South Knot City? Great! Let's just go over Fragile's entire backstory all at once in a series of cut scenes! Every character get's this treatment, even Amelie and Sam. There's a LOT of good story here! It's just not told in the best way. The entire "Secret government cover-up" plotline was entirely unnecessary as well. It's not strong, and just kind of bogs down everything else.

The gameplay is engrossing, but divided into 2 categories: Delivery and Combat. 

When you're simply delivering packages, planning routes, and optimizing your loadout for the journey, it feels a lot like an RPG. There's a sort of strategy to it all that feels pretty rewarding. The journey is pretty chill, the world is wonderful to look at, and it's pretty easy to get into the groove. For the Delivery aspect, I highly recommend the hardest difficulty. It barely makes a difference but does incentivize you to use tools you wouldn't normally think of using. 

Combat is, a little clunky. Since the game's systems focus so heavily on balance, and balance has almost no purpose in combat, it feels pretty jarring to transition. It can also be immeasurably frustrating when you're about to drop kick somebody and Sam suddenly stumbles and you're just awkwardly running around the enemy as they shoot you. At the end of the day, the combat is serviceable, but not great. It can be frustrating at times, but it can also be pretty fun. The Difficulty setting though, really just makes enemies into bullet sponges. I beat the entire game on Very Hard, and I can say with confidence, you should just turn down the difficulty for boss fights. It doesn't make the fights much harder, but it does make each encounter much [u]longer[/u]. 

The "Strand System" is actually pretty awesome. Items you create can appear in other people's worlds and vice versa. Sometimes these are really helpful and come clutch! Generators, Timefall Shelters, Zip Lines, and more! The final mission of the game relies heavily on the strand system and it feels pretty good! Other times however... it can be utterly useless. Since it's based on "Likes" and there's no dislike feature, there's no quality control. The sheer amount of random bridges in the middle of an open field I encountered during my time playing is maddening. Sure, you can remove junk from your world, but because those structures have so many likes, they'll just reappear a few minutes later. Not much you can do about it.

All in all, Death Stranding is a divisive game. Either the story, relaxed pace, and beautiful world will suck you in or the clunky combat, forced animations, and movie long cutscenes will drive you up a wall. You'll either be intrigued, or bored. All depends on you.

There's no question in my mind that this is a fantastic game, and I enjoyed my time playing it. However, as many have said and will continue to say: this game isn't for everyone.

The dense atmosphere of an dystopian America of the future is almost tangible and staged in an impressive way. In this future people live in isolated bunkers due to an event called 'Death Stranding' which deformed physics in a strange way like rain which let's you age in fast motion. I've never felt so torn on a game. I enjoyed the walking mechanics right from the beginning, and the licensed music that plays at key moments sets a really unique tone. I often play this game after a really long day, and it's nice to have an option that isn't demanding you play at your best all the time.
That being said, it is a long game, and the stealth and combat are not implemented particularly well. While I find the story interesting, cutscenes are few and far between (though they are all quite substantial), and I don't think it is engaging enough to keep you going if you don't enjoy playing the game.
I personally find the gameplay engaging enough, the cast is brilliant, but this is not a game I would recommend to anyone who doesn't know what to expect. Props for creativity, though.

I will freely admit I cannot give a unbiased review of this game, so I'll just explain how I feel about it.  Death Stranding has captured my heart and soul in a way few works of fiction have ever managed.  It's been like watching a dream or a vision I've had since I was a child come to life in shockingly vivid detail.  Something like this world was always lurking at the edges of my innermost fantasies, but never fully realized until I saw this.  It now consumes my thoughts whenever I'm not playing it like a drug addiction.  Asking me if I would recommend this game is like asking me if I recommend breathing.  If you consider yourself a true fan of the science fiction genre or just action adventure/survival horror games you are doing yourself a great disservice by missing out on this genre bending achingly beautiful work of art.  For me at least, it set the bar higher than I ever thought possible for a third person PC game.  The people who made this will probably never meet me or know I exist, and yet somehow they knew it was exactly what I always needed.  And then, just like Sam, they delivered.  This one's for you.

I had the pleasure of starting this game right before embarking on a road trip across America, where I was able to witness the beautiful landscapes of the country.

The game introduces several futuristic concepts, such as wireless power, warp-3D printing structures, exoskeletons, and assistive devices. It also touches on heavy themes of life, death, multiverses, and logistics, which add to the overall complexity of the game. Not to mention some horror elements thrown in too which get under your skin. 

The game's gameplay requires meticulous planning and consideration, and world traversal becomes a puzzle that is sometimes frustratingly challenging and sometimes delightfully relaxing. While it may not appeal to all types of players, the game's various sub-systems create an interesting loop of gameplay that can be appreciated with patience.

Managing trips and routes, as well as preparing for unknown obstacles, is crucial in the game, just as it is in real-life hikes and logistics. The game instills a sense of Zen as players manage gear and navigate through the game's landscapes, which in turn, enhances appreciation for real-world movement and the movement of delivery. 

The game has its share of frustrating moments, which is intentional, and its storytelling is on par with or better than anything Kojima has done previously. The meta conversations interspersed with moments of playful disbelief at the game's scope is presented to us in very Kojima ways. The level design and pacing are well done, and I am curious about where any potential sequel will take us.

Throw in pretty unique hybrid multiplayer elements that can improve your trips and encourages you to think about others is an interesting design choice I did not expect to influence me as much as it did. 

Overall, this is a great game for players who enjoy meticulous organization and action elements.

To quote a post on the r/patientgamers Subreddit by user u/HeyUsernameImDad: "Death Stranding is a masterpiece that I cannot recommend". This sentence perfectly encompasses my experience with the game. Don't be fooled; I'm still going to buy DS2 once it comes out, but if I am to recommend the game or the series to anyone, it would be to a very narrow slither of the population. I'll try to outline why. (Note: For the purposes of this review, I will not be distinguishing between the base game and the Director's Cut edition)

To start with, let's go over the basic premise of the game... which is easier said than done. In a post-apocalyptic USA, you play Sam Porter Bridges, himself played by actor Norman Reedus. Sam, as his aptonym would suggest, is a "porter", a deliveryman in the UCA, or United Cities of America. After the titular and apocalyptic "Death Stranding" event not long in the game’s past, the world became a hostile place, with most people disconnected and unable to contact one another, physically or otherwise. The ones who do the job of connecting people - transferring messages or goods or even people - is that of a porter; vaguely similar to a courier or deliveryperson. As a notoriously good porter, known as  "The Great Deliverer", DS sees you guiding Sam across America to reconnect it, delivering goods, facing various threats, and learning how he can himself connect with others along the way. There is far, FAR more to it, but that’s the basic story.

The game’s creator, Hideo Kojima, has notoriously described it as "the first 'strand-type' game". While quite obfuscatory, this has been interpreted as meaning, basically, "the first game of a new genre, characterised by incorporation of social connectivity". We could argue what this means, or whether multiplayer games are "strand-like", but there IS something to be said about the relatively novel aspects of the game. Specifically, DS implements asymmetric multiplayer interaction: your actions can affect the game world of other players, items you build can be sent to players with whom you otherwise have no other interaction. Every player plays Sam Porter Bridges, and you can help each other across the gap between universes, as it were.

But, if we're blunt, this says little about what the game actually is or how it plays in any pragmatic way. So, down to the brass tacks: what genre is DS, really? I would say it's a third-person exploration game with vague action and horror elements, with a mostly sci-fi storyline. A common joke is that it's a "walking simulator", but there's a lot more to it than JUST walking, and the walking you do is actually so involved it prevents the game from being an effective walking simulator most of the time... but it’s true there’s a hell of a lot of walking. In a world where most technology is destroyed, how else are you meant to deliver all those packages? You travel between cities and shelters, carrying packages on your back, avoiding ghost-like threats and humans who will try to kill you or steal your cargo, while eventually unlocking means by which to make your deliveries easier. Sometimes you have guns or grenades, sometimes you use "stealth" to avoid detection or capture or loss of deliveries, sometimes you drive vehicles to get to your destination faster. But, in essence, it's a third-person exploration game.

And the exploration is great! No matter what else, remember the quote at the start: DS IS a masterpiece. The world is gorgeous, the music is beautiful, the characters look great... it's just a shame there feels to be so little of each of these elements, all considered. The game was somehow enough to compel me to play for over 100 hours, yes, but how much of that time was spent on "unique" activities? I'd argue not much. DS is almost undeniably unique as a whole, but if you want to get all achievements? Or if you even just want to beat the main game? You'll be doing a lot of nothing; nothing much other than walking, anyway. Unique walking though it may be.

Regardless of your videogame preferences, it’s likely you’ve heard of the creator whom I mentioned earlier; Hideo Kojima. Kojima is perhaps most well-known for the Metal Gear series, of which I am a huge fan. DS is Kojima’s first game after his departure from Metal Gear publisher Konami. DS is the first and thus far only game of Kojima’s eponymous studio, Kojima Productions. Nonetheless, he has very much brought the same charm from Metal Gear to this new venture. Just as with Metal Gear, DS is a dizzying combination of highly polished gameplay and absolutely buck-wild, oddly America-centric storytelling. But, quite unlike Metal Gear Solid V for instance, I would say DS ironically feels quite disconnected, not like a cohesive whole. While this could just be the full creative prowess of Kojima unleashed, DS feels like it’s a lot of ideas packed into not a lot of product. This can be seen in various ways, including the raw foundations of the game, its story, and its broader world.

DS’s game engine, Decima, is shared with the Horizon games, among others, which I’ve also seen praised for polished gameplay and excellent visuals; DS is evidently coming from solid foundations, reflected in what is generally a very smooth gameplay experience. As I’ve mentioned, it is a beautiful game to play, seeing you traversing snowy mountains, desolate wastelands, verdant fields, and beyond. The oddly incorporated combat elements work well enough, with novel mechanics that may owe their execution to the engine. Despite the good Decima brings, the mechanics are all over the place design-wise; travel, while a core element of the game, is a complete pain, for instance. While the basic premise of this “strand game” is connection, none of it feels “active”; it’s all quite passive. You never engage with other players directly, only indirectly. Even from a story perspective, Sam is reluctant to connect with anyone[spoiler], and even after his quest to “reconnect America” is complete, he states a desire to remain unconnected[/spoiler].

This disconnect comes across in the game’s raw construction as well; a game is not an engine alone. While it was actually the first Metal Gear after Kojima’s departure, without his involvement, I said in my review of Metal Gear Survive that it did not stand up beyond its foundations in the Fox Engine. Both Survive and DS are bizarre worlds built upon good mechanical foundations. But while both games feel like they operate a lot off of some appeal to “rule of cool”, there are vastly different interpretations of what this might look like; while Survive is bizarre yet boring, DS is bizarre in a way that will, admittedly, leave you hooked and wanting more.

I’ve seen many say DS can be a calming, meditative, and almost addictive experience. I can certainly attest to that. Coming out in late 2019, the game was almost prophetic in its reflection of the real world during the Covid-19 pandemic; the game reflected that feeling of disconnection, but its relatively slow-pace, long-form gameplay made the experience feel like just the kind of mind-numbing that was needed when the world seemed to be falling apart. But would we have loved it in the same way if Covid had not happened? I’m honestly not sure.

All-in-all, Death Stranding is a wholly strange game. The story is so convoluted and so “Kojima” so as to be compelling, at least to me; the gameplay is so unique but so frustrating as to unintentionally be a challenge in frustration; and the artistic direction is so beautiful as to somehow hold this whole mess together. In its entirety, I think I would only recommend DS to those who are patient, those who want to try something new, or those who are already fans of Kojima. Otherwise - if you’re looking for something quick and easy, something predictable, or just another typical AAA experience - you’re likely to be disappointed.

Death Stranding is a stunning & compelling allegorical story about connection and love, and the game supports this hard-hitting, detailed story with stunning visuals and some of the best in-game physics I've experienced. 

I played Death Stranding when it came out on PS4, and years later, it still feels impressive and entertaining. The game stands the test of time, having pushed some graphical and engine boundaries of its time.

My advice to those playing for the first time: take your time. Go of course. Take some un-required delivery requests. Spend time soaking in the atmosphere and build up structures for a rewarding experience. For those already playing: keep building the community. Death Stranding has one of the coolest community-building methods in my opinion, especially for a single-player game.

It is boring.

[h1]What I liked[/h1]
- [b]Terrain is your enemy:[/b] Everything that had to do with overcoming the terrain was unique. I have not seen any game embrace the “simulation” part so much of a “walking simulator”. This game proves that there are still triple-A games out there trying out new stuff. There is something inherently satisfying about going from the base of a mountain to the top, especially if it is made challenging and you have many tools to help you. I could see some improvements but it's impressive what the game does.

- [b]Strong ending and subjects:[/b] I thought the very end of the main storyline was very good. It’s pretty open for interpretation but I kind of like that. In my mind it touches on some heavy themes without making it too explicit. [spoiler] Specifically I am talking about bringing Lou to the incinerator. And subjects like parenthood and miscarriage. It normalises pregnancy and childbirth in a way. The game is full of references to these subjects that unfortunately are still a taboo in society. [/spoiler]

- [b]Interesting NPCs[/b] Some of the NPC’s are very memorable and unique. I love Heartmen [spoiler] It’s such a cool character trait that he dies every 21 minutes for 3 minutes. They really used that trait to its full extend.[/spoiler], Moma & Lockne [spoiler]The twins that are actually the same person is very weirdly portrait, I love it.[/spoiler] and Cliff [spoiler]It’s such a sad story and was played very well. The only one where I was surprised by the pun in his name. With him opposing Bridges, while he is named Cliff.[/spoiler]

- [b]General weirdness:[/b] Love the general weirdness of the game. They try to explain just enough that it sort of makes sense what is happening to the world. And the inhabitants of the world are so used to this just being the state of the world.

- [b]Floating carrier:[/b] The floating carrier is a great tool to play around with. It can be used as a snowboard to go down hills and just to pile on cargo. It feels great to have it.

- [b]Music plays out of nowhere:[/b] The real magic moments happen when you are travelling and the perfect song starts playing. It makes you appreciate the world even more. Unfortunately opening a menu will cut it short. I actively tried to not open menus during these moments even though I would need to.


[h1]What I didn’t like[/h1]
- [b]Music player while travelling:[/b] Would have been nice to have it similar to changing the radio stations in GTA while in a car. Though I can understand that you would then lose the effect of the music suddenly starting to play out of nowhere.

- [b]Story surprises:[/b] The quality of the story is all over the place. Some moments are brilliant and others confusing or awkward. [spoiler] For example I was confused why “Moma” suddenly died when I delivered her to Locke. There was no build up for it. Though the moment after was a cool story point. Also the running on the beach with Amelie was kind of awkward. [/spoiler]

- [b]Vehicles:[/b] I honestly think the game would have been better without the vehicles. They drive kind of floaty and circumvent most of the interesting restrictions like rain and falling over. Especially on rough terrain you can kind of jank your way through it without taking to much damage. They are the optimal way of playing without any of the fun. I would advise to stick to walking and only use vehicles on roads. I hope for the second game that they improve this. They should implement systems like in the Dakar Rally games or SnowRunner/MudRunner where the terrain is also your enemy.

- [b]Obscure ways to progress story:[/b] Especially at the end of the main story there are some obscure ways to progress. I almost gave up and looked it up online. Only for Sam to say it outloud. This happened a couple of times. [spoiler] The way to reach Amelie in Chapter 8 deep in the tar pit for example. I was looking for a way around. But apparently you have to get caught by a BT on purpose to trigger the floating buildings. You have to do what you are trying the entire game to avoid to progress? I also had this after having to reach Higgs and Amelie on the beach. How should I know that Fragile can jump me there? And lastly the shooting of Amelie. Had to look this one up. It’s heavily implied that you have to shoot here. But what you actually have to do is put away your gun and hug here.[/spoiler]. 

- [b]Boss fights feel out of place:[/b] I didn’t like any of the boss fights. They have little to do with the main gameplay and often turn into a mediocre third person shooter. [spoiler] Didn’t really like the fighting mini game with Higgs in the end. It felt forced and was a bit too long.[/spoiler] 

- [b]Menus are slow:[/b] It takes too much time to bring up the map and switch between menus like the private stash. It might seem like a small thing but it adds up.

- [b]Too much Tell, and not Show in the last part of the story:[/b] There was a bit of a lore dump and too many reminders from the NPC’s at the end  of the main story. It got a bit annoying. I like that some parts of the game were mysterious.

- [b]Player progression feels meaningless:[/b] The reward you get for doing optional missions feels pretty meaningless. You just get “likes”, it’s kind of funny with the relation to social media, but it also caused me to not care much about the side content. It’s not entirely clear how you unlock new tools. I seemed to just randomly get them from some side-content.

[h1]Why others should try it[/h1]
It was a pretty good game. I did just focus on the main story and didn’t feel the need to do much of the side content. The building of roads was satisfying but too much of a grind to really be bothered with. I would advise new players to try the game out for 2 hours and see if they like the “walking simulator” part of the game. If you don’t, just refund. You will be doing it alot. At least you had a unique gameplay experience.

24hrs in and I cannot play this game anymore; not because it's bad, but I bought it because I was looking for something "chill with great visuals and v.little combat" - The game fits this brief perfectly, except I'm playing it while pregnant... so the sound of BB crying and having to pause and console it is driving me freakin nuts. Although, under normal circumstances I still don't think I would have finished it; I feel no empathy for the characters and really don't care enough about connecting America to keep pushing forward.

Death Stranding is an unusual and super ambitious game that breaks typical gaming norms. This game focuses on preemptive planning and problem-solving to complete your tasks. You are heavily punished for brute-forcing your way through the game. This game is not for everyone, but if you enjoy being alone with your thoughts in a beautiful atmosphere. You should give this game a try.
More than just a “walking simulator”

If you already played this game, don't unless it's on sale. At the core, you'll get at most 5-10 hrs of new content. If you haven't played it yet, go for it. The small but sensible QOL changes and new improved introduction will make it easier to get into. The new addons are fun, the VR missions are enjoyable and the new tools all have their uses in the sandbox. Given everything else is the same, I'll just copy my original review-

Death Stranding is the best game I love but find it hard to recommend to almost anyone because it feels like a game deliberately made for me.
To get my criticism out of the way- the story in much of the style of MGS4 is a combination of me laughing out loud and just being completely lost for words, you have all sorts of big cameo stars doing extraordinarily contrived dialogue and being weird all over the place, with some of them being characters I don't want to be around with, the boss fights and combat scenarios are hilariously bad and the spooky stuff are disappointingly easy to defeat.

However, as much as it paints it as hours of bizarre, stupid plot, there is one thing about this game I can’t get enough of, the entire experience of ‘porting’. 
In this bizzare post-apocalypse, it's your job to hand supplies manually from A to B, and you are left to figure it out yourself, carrying heavy cargo and dealing with the wild terrain, enemy factions, and supernatural anomalies.

It might be because I like hiking, but everything about the simple act delivery is executed with a wonderful cohesive design. You have plenty of tools to plan, scout ahead, prepare, take notes and optimize your routes, and as you improve your skills as a player you go from having a ladder placed to cross a river to knowing exactly how to move around dangerous hills with confidence.

Your backtracking allows you to leave tools and equipment behind in the field and delivery knots to rely on in the future, as well as build structures other players can help you upgrade or use as well.
This brings me to the rather exaggerated “strand” mechanics, which are an important tool of the game to carry it’s themes and also have players get a true feeling of cooperation.

Seasoned users can equally help and assist newbies with things from warning signs to a perfectly placed zip line route. It’s a really nice way to have people help each other out and motivate them to carry on.
The care for Sam carries this as well, with the tools at his disposal all having useful ways to help with your travelling. Nothing in your equipment is useless and all have their place, it's a matter of you finding your rhythm and playstyle.
And in a way, this does justify the bland combat, as to be honest, if it was more demanding it would probably be a game too stressful to handle. I am confident almost anyone can beat the game, it just requires patience and most importantly- persistence.

In the end, the best way to boil it down is whenever you are at a peak of a hill, you see for yourself the hard work you’ve put in getting there. This feeling of mastery within a zen-like relaxed and laid back gameplay creates an aura of peace and a refreshing change of pace I haven’t gotten in any game for a while now.

It’s probably not the game you expected, and I’m late to say that, but if you need something that completely shifts gears and lets you have a more soothing experience (and you can put up with Kojima creatividad at his worst) there is a chance this might also be a game you’ll enjoy.

I have read people saying how great this game it. Sorry, don't get it.

People like to call this a walking simulator (derogatory) when it is actually a walking simulator (affectionate, complimentary, enthusiastic). This started out as a very awkward and hard-to-immerse-into game for me but the extraordinarily odd story and bizarre parallels to real life (covid, quarantine, etc) kept me interested and devoted to familiarizing myself with the controls and style. Once I got familiar with the flow and controls the game really clicked for me in a way not many do and is strangely addictive. Norman Reedus and the Funky Fetus has since become my comfort game with slow paced and relaxing but fulfilling gameplay that is well paced with intense action sequences that are as visually stunning as they are daunting at times. I recommend this game but only if you go into it with a willingness to be patient in learning the unique gameplay style and enjoying relaxed pacing and build up between significant events.

I wish I could recommend this game. There is a clear vision behind it, even if its a little silly at times. The atmosphere is great and the story is interesting. 

But, playing this game feels like i'm fighting to enjoy myself. It physically feels unintuitive and I cannot get immersed for very long at all. I'm constantly having to jump back into the real world to assess what buttons I'm pushing (git gud, I guess).

I'm  sure there is an artistic reason for why each action has to be some drawn out arcane combination of button presses and cinematics, but it isn't worth it for me.

And just when I think I'm getting a groove going I mess up, slightly, and get catastrophically punished by the engine/mechanics. I feel that the cascading sequence of punishments for falling into a river is the single most upsetting thing I have ever experienced. THERE IS NO QUICK WAY TO RECOVER FROM A MISTAKE IN THIS GAME! 

But I guess it made me feel something, so I guess it wins, it certainly is art.
A game like nothing else, but still Kojima through and through.

I'm 20-some-odd hours into Death Stranding, and I can't actually decide if I like it. It definitely has all the hallmarks of a Kojima game. Take "Gruff 'Murican Special Forces Sterotype" from MGS and change it into "Gruff 'Murican Special Forces Delivery Boy" and you've basically got the lead character (why Kojima fetishizes "Gruff 'Murican stereotype" so much is beyond me). And unfortunately the enemies are largely neutered completely about half way through the game. But I will say that the story is actually super interesting. You sorta have to suspend your disbelief in that one "city" that you can reach in about five minutes of travel is half-way across the continental US, but whatevs. The story is good enough (and the graphics are spectacular) that 20 hours in I'm ignoring what I would consider as mediocre gameplay to get the next part in the story. 

In all, great graphics, great story, music is super good, interesting concept, mediocre gameplay. I probably wouldn't pay full price for this one, but I'd totally grab it on-sale.

Edit: MY GOD I'M 70 HOURS IN AND I JUST WANT IT TO BE OVER. THE LAST THREE HOURS I FEEL LIKE I'VE BEEN WATCHING HOLY GRAIL WITH EVERYONE SCREAMING "GET ON WITH IT!!!". 

Definitely worth buying, but MY GOD does the game drag on at the end.

Upgraded from the standard edition as i quite like the gameplay loop and figured i should get the whole experience (some of the stuff added should really have been patched in the old version...)

But not even 20 mins in the game crashed, tried several solutions online but nothing worked until it randomly didn't happen once (going to the southern city in area 2) thought great it might have fixed itself but nope, went to the farm for a delivery and it crashed constantly there instead so no choice but to refund and go back to the standard edition.

The standard edition lags like crazy in some parts to the point i've fallen off bridges and ran into walls several times thus needing to reload but at least it didn't crash once.

These issues have been around since launch what i could see online so they really should fix it but probably won't. if anyone reads this and is on the fence i would recommend the standard edition instead even with it's issues as it's at least playable.

hopefully if there is a sequel they take some time optimizing to avoid this happening again or change the game engine to something stable.



Note this part is for the original edition, as it isn't on Steam i couldn't write it there but for that one it's recommended for the DC edition it's still very much not so:

To begin with, it's not for everyone!

You have to not be accustomed to immediate gratification, instead take your time and enjoy the journey or you likely won't find any fun here.

Did every order on Hard, with the added requirements for LL Grade and really enjoyed my time. Once you have ziplines up you don't even have to pay much attention and can be a little proud of the planing that went into a well setup fast travel system but it wasen't all great.

The gameplay itself i have no real problems with, it is what it said it would be, but the stability of some areas are terrible.

Mainly anywhere there are a lots of rocks or BT spawn zones, the location near one of the Delivery points are worst as it always lags horrible when you go on the road there. (for those that have played, it's near the Cosplayer)

The game isn't demanding with the settings i have though my CPU is a bit old but it didn't have a high load most of the time but at a few locations the game lags so badly any input is done multiple times and if you are turning, say on a swerving road, it will very often just cause you to drive off and ruin any cargo you had.

This happens for example at, Road near Mountain Knot City, Road near Cosplayer, Near Mountain to southern part of first map to name a few.

It might be caused by the added spawns of BTs in those areas with the already cluttered landscape or maybe the texture for wet and dry of the same areas aren't separated enough = load double the assets. Hard to say for sure but no settings helped noticeable for these.

(Have: RTX 2070, Intel I5 7500, 16gb ram so should run decent at medium settings but alas)

Also tried midway to upgrade to DC edition but that was an unstable mess that kept crashing so was refunded in the end, nothing i tried helped meanwhile this one only crashed once but now and again was missing textures both in cutscenes and during gameplay.

There are several QoL i would like to see if they make another ex: 
-No bikes/trucks allowed to spawn on roads, kept driving into them during timelimited missions.
-Zipline paths should be kept clear when the game spawns in other porters structures, it kept breaking forcing you to destroy stuff, mostly bridges.
-Don't boot you out of terminals all the time, if i deliver something let me pick more orders up right away. If i want to leave i can easily do so after myself.
-Improve the driving up slopes, i swear it seems to be ice physics on some slopes so you have to reload multiple times for some timed missions as i constantly slip off slopes, it frankly is just annoying.
-Improve stability, I'd rather be able to play smoothly than having the nicest graphics. The lag issue has been around since launch so either they didn't find a solution (Maybe engine limitation) or didn't care enough to fix, it is also in the DC edition so leaning to engine problems.

The downsides are fairly minor so if you are on the fence about getting it then either wait for a sale or watch some gameplay first as again it really isn't for everyone but those that it works for while enjoy the journey :)

I was pleasantly surprised by Death Stranding, it exceeded my initial expectations. Despite my initial assumption that it would be a mundane walking simulator, I was proven wrong. The story is compelling and the way it's told is exceptional. The gameplay is intricate and offers depth that caught me off guard. The meticulous attention to detail is impressive, and it adds to the overall experience. Additionally, the multiplayer components are groundbreaking, setting a new standard for gaming.

Yes it is a good game I have enjoyed this and the prior game, my review remains the same as the previous one though this has has some added bits and a I assume some of the new deliveries were swapped in to allow some of the end game deliveries to be swapped out from the old game.

They have added a race track and made doing the Roadster courses a requirement for 100% achievements (fortunately you do not have to do the bike courses as the bikes have an annoying 'feature', where they turn in the opposite direction you a pressing when not boosting before hard turning in the direction you want to go in - makes for a really bad experience for no reason and my only real complaint about this version of the game).

The other obvious change is the BT's now re-spawn after a while, I understand they wanted it to be harder however, it does remove some of the peaceful wondering effect the first game has once you are nearing completion and I do think that was something worth keeping. However, that is likely just a me thing.

Last thing I want to mention is they seem to have fixed 'things' disappearing (At least for my computer setup), which was a bug in the last game that caused the terrain and almost everything else to start disappearing at random, the longer you played the less there was left. You could still interact with them they just were not visible. This bug has resulted in some unusual pictures relating to when Sam showers etc. Anyway good remake and enjoyed my play through.

Below is my review of Death Stranding, which should provide the details on what the game is like to play.

Have fun :)

--------Review from the original Death Stranding--------

The first Hideo Kojima game I have played (to my knowledge) and I was not disappointed. I liked the plot and the game play.

I actually played it with the sharing turned down to its lowest setting (I wanted to try it out raw for a first play through) and I liked that experience. Once I finished all 500 orders, I turned the sharing on to full and that works well to but at 274 hours I am not sure there would be another play through. Knowing what the sharing is like if they make a second game, I would like there to be more sharing options since I would have liked to have peoples signs up all the time and only a select few buildings (randomly selected) within areas that I picked.

I liked that the game transitions play styles as you 'get better' via the equipment you collect/can use and build. The objectives you have to figure out are a nice touch too (You can make wrong choices until you make the correct choice) and I particularly liked the birthday message you can receive on your birthday :) .

I like the like system (I managed to almost receive 1.5 Million likes in the game by the time I'd finished all achievements), though I had to remove some things I built due to limitations in the network and if they make a second game it would be nice to have a way to generate ever grater network to avoid this (Balanced by grind so game completion does not become too easy).

The only negatives I have are:
- The walking, when Sam falls over because the ground is an 'unsuitable surface' yet the normal surfaces make that ground inconsequential (I am thinking cliff material but its only half a foot high and I just need him to step up onto it).
- A similar thing with the trucks and going uphill on any surface even in perfect dry conditions being unable to stay straight or turn (not the most believable aspect since I drive a 1 Litre car and have no issues like this). Having made this point, you can 'boost' your way up most places in the trucks.
- The out of bounds areas are invisible walls in areas (I have a thing for uncovering all the map in games so I tend to find these in games where the map is larger than can be explored). 

I know some people described it as an Amazon simulator and it is true there are a lot of deliveries however, you do not need to do them all only the ones for the quest/story. Also, later in the game you can turn it into more of a hunting game killing of BTs and taking out Mules to get their loot. I would also argue that a lot of games are just delivery yourself to various points on a map anyway and this one makes it more about caring for something else, getting to where you going in the state it needs to be kept. Though again if you do not fancy moving things from A to B a lot of the time this game might not be for you.

This is certainly a game I enjoyed and I think a game worth playing.

Have fun :)

Hideo Kojima is a gamer filmmaker. He came to prominence during the 2000s for his adaptations of video game franchises. Released theatrically, the games were critical and commercial failures; his 2005 Alone in the Dark adaptation is considered one of the worst games ever made. Kojimas's games during the 2010s, comprising mostly original projects and independent games, received home media releases to better, although still mostly negative reviews. After retiring in 2016 to become a restaurateur, Kojima announced his return to gaming in 2020. His games are financed through his production companies Boll KG and Event Film Productions.

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

After the end of the game, I was negative about the Death Stranding. But when writing a review, I weighed all the pros and cons, and was surprised that despite so many positive qualities, I was dissatisfied with this project. Need to mention that before buying this game I haven’t seen any gameplay videos, but have seen articles where was only said - Kojima is genius. Despite the fact that I didn’t enjoy the game, Death Stranding has much advantages.

[h1] Main Plot [/h1]

The plot in general is very interesting. From the very beginning in first hour I heard so much time words ‘Chiralium’ and ‘America’, that each next time I heard this words - just was laughing from scenario. Later on plot shows why Chiralium is integrated in each word. But why each character continue to repeat ‘Save America’, I don’t know; I understood from the the first time that our main mission is to recover America.
From the side of the plot - World rules or lore built very properly. All things are connected and it has logical explanation, each new information doesn’t contradicts earlier information, but rather reinforces it and connects things that at first glance cannot be connected in any way.

From the side of scenario dialogues may be done better. During all gameplay - all characters have been only sources of information, and one scene was allocated for the disclosure of each character. For the most part, the plot was concentrated only at the beginning and end of the game. In the middle characters have been repeating their own words and mostly we had no new information, of course in the middle was some story advancement, but compared to all the game time, this story expansion was very small. To understand - we have 2,5 hour movie in the beginning and 4 hours movie at the end, but in the middle each 2-4 hours of gameplay we have 10-20 minutes of cutscenes.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

[b] Main Gameplay [/b]

Gameplay pissed me off. First 10 hours I didn’t understand what’s going on, how to plan the journey and what should I take, that’s why I was traveling with all things collected before. After 15 hours of gameplay I finally understood what should I look at, how to plan the journey and where should I turn to avoid stealth or fighting.
During the journey may be seen two types of enemies: BTs and MULEs. With BTs better to use stealth and with MULEs you need to have shooter. But in reality I had no confrontations with them, because I just run, and when I ran away from their zones - both BTs and MULEs stop to run after me.

In the game I had only 6 direct confrontations with enemies: 3 with BTs and 3 with soldiers. All of them have been due to scenario. So all my gameplay was concentrated on running, walking and riding a bike or car.

[b] Multiplayer [/b]

Multiplayer in this game is realized in a way - your cars and buildings may be seen by other players and they may like it. So such type of multiplayer makes gaming experience of other players much easier. And it’s realized very good, this type of Multiplayer gave me the desire to help other players with my buildings. But in reality I had no sharp need to make buildings on my way, because most of them have been done before me. So I just was using other players ropes and if necessary added some my ropes to connect them.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Death Stranding is a game made very properly, here I had only one crash for 35 hours. The plot is really good, world lore is built wonderful. The only thing I couldn’t enjoy is gameplay. With all cutscenes we have around ≈10 hours of movie all other 25 hours I had a courier simulator. That’s why I can’t recommend this game, because gameplay is most part of the game. I wouldn’t recommend to play Death Stranding for plot without enjoying the gameplay, because there is big gameplay parts between plot advancement. The game has many positive moments, and it would be definitely a lie if I tell that I didn’t enjoy the game at all. I deeply believe that the game has an invaluable contribution to the development of the gaming industry, despite the fact that I did not fully enjoy the Death Stranding.

Death stranding is a half cinematic storytelling and half casual gaming. If you've played any of the Metal Gear series, you'll know that Kojima rarely tells a straight forward story. Wrapped up in allegory, internal references and sweeping story plots, with a sprinkle of cheese in there. It can feel a little lopsided, as there's a lot of wind up in the beginning introducing you to the world, a steady serving of exposition as you get into the core gameplay, then an ending that's almost about 90 minutes. 

The game is best played at a relaxing pace, rather than hurried to get to the story points. I enjoyed it much more that way, as this was my second start after putting around 20+ hours on a PS4. While this game is definitely not everyone's jam, this was a very redeemable play after being let down with the wrap up on MSG5.

Yes, I would recommend this game to others.
- Great story, amazing voice acting, fantastic graphics not requiring a beefy GPU and last but not least 2 memorable characters that many know and love from the Hollywood movies are present In this game.

Many strongly just consider this game to be walking sim and nothing more, but that is simply no all that's to It. That claim would be same If me saying that the only thing you do In GTA Is drive cars. We all know that Is not true, but It's a very big aspect of the game, just like walking Is In DEATH STRANDING.
 
Yes, you are going to be walking a lot. However the walking aspect of the game Is challenging, and that makes It Immersive and also rather challenging depending on the game difficulty one choose. Furthermore, the later on In the game you typically would be spending the most transport time on structures build by you PCC's like the really convenient zip-line or the jumpingpads and If you prefer other transport methods, crafting bikes Is also possible (by episode 3). 

To conclude, of course any game Isn't perfect and this game certainly also have It's flaws.
- The Inventory mechanics feels a little clunky
- The PCC lvl 2 Is too overpowered 
- The ending Is too long of a segment In the game In my oppinion

Visuals are awesome, HDR visuals are amazing. The exploration is very rewarding. Some of the set pieces are epic. Gameplay is original, varied and mostly fun, if at times slightly boring (you can only deliver so many packages). Sound and music is great. acting is good. Main story is strange but cool. The explanation of the plot is confusing. The character names are so silly that that it is immersion-breaking. Writing is VERY BAD, like a mexican soap opera. Dialogue is so bad as to be immersion breaking. VERY annoyingly other "online" players can put these stupid holograms and signs all over an otherwise beautiful landscape. Cut-scenes are WAY too long, I found myself starting to skip through them around chapter 8. The two-hour long ending is a joke, the first 90 minutes could have been done in 5 minutes. Characters are mixed, some are 2-dimensional cut-outs (the terrorist bad guy, oh my, that guy makes no sense - what the hell is his motivation again? He met Amelie and just changed his mind, huh?) and others feel like properly developed real people interacting with each other. Again, parts of the main story are excellent, yet other smaller parts are a confused mess that feels like the explanation is "space magic" instead of a logical comprehensive story - although I think this is due to the fact that you spend 95% of the game not really knowing what the hell is going on. The gameplay is so original that this could have been one of the best games of all time, and it is almost annoying how the game can shift from being great to being dull so quickly. Because of that and the bad writing, dialogue, overly-complicated and at times nonsensical story, it remains just a very good original game with some boring bits. So yea, play, set aside a solid week of your life to finish it or play it over the course of a year on some weekends like I did, but either way, it is a game worth playing.

A dark and bizarre package delivery RPG. Great game but it can be tedious at times, gets better as you progress the story line; has a lot of side content to do & explore. Its single player but you occasionally come across your friends landmarks or lost packages which is fun.

Turns out, having a plot that both beats you over the head with it's themes and is obtuse as all hell dosen't matter when it has some of the richest, most rewarding meeting of mechanics to theme's I have seen in ANY title. Death Stranding is at it's best when it shuts the fuck up and lets you live in its world. There are some truly jaw dropping and emotionally resent sections during the core story, but the real beauty comes as it most often does, in the simple, quiet moments.

I tried liking this game. And the beginning was very intriguing in terms of the story, at least it felt that way when I tried a pirated version. A few first minutes were enough to tell me: I need to buy this, it promises to be good. So I did buy it. And then I tried playing more.
I knew there will be lots of walking, and I thought I could live with that for the story. Firstly, the walking is not just long, but annoying, because of mechanics attached to them. And I can understand the reasoning for the mechanics, but when there is so much barren land to cover while suffering from them... That was already sucking the life out of me.
Secondly, the story... No. It has a really good hook, but than it starts falling apart right away with myriad of little things, that just show that whoever wrote this, has no idea how people behave in real life and has no talent to imagine how they could behave in these extraordinary circumstances. And even outside of human behavior lots of practical things in the world simply do not make sense.
Every single interaction after was painful for me. I would not call my self a literature critic or something, but I just could not bare it. And definitely am not going to bare it through boring yet somehow overwhelming gameplay.

This is a very difficult game to review. At its core, it really is a walking simulator. But this game is the embodiment of "The journey is what matters, not the destination". it's a game about the bonds that tie us all together, whether fleeting or permanent. it's a game about picking yourself up from the lowest lows, dusting yourself off and getting on with it. It's a game that shows you no matter how alone you feel, or how distant you try to make yourself, there's always someone out there who can help. And that there's always someone you can help too, if you try hard enough. Some things are inevitable, but the indomitability of the human spirit will always shine through.

Excentuando-se a parte de combates com terroristas, bandidos e espiritos do outro mundo, a gente se sente em um verdadeiro Camel Trophy ou Paris Dakar. Quando chegamos ao objetivo é um alivio enorme e vem com uma snesação de conquista, de realização. Os graficos são excelentes. Os modelos dos personagens são ultra realistas e não pesa muito no sistema. Enfim, para quem curte este tipo de jogo é um prato cheio. Recomendo 100%.

Death Stranding is an exceptional game that stands out for its complexity and deep meaning. While the first few chapters serve as a tutorial and introduction to the complex world, the game is much more than just a game. It offers a profound truth that becomes evident as you progress through the game. The story is a perfect juxtaposition of the game's central theme,  and this theme is intricately knotted into the game's structure. In my experience, Death Stranding is the only game that manages to intertwine the essence of humanity with its structure. This game is a testament to Kojima's genius.

This game is my new obsession, i don't think I'll ever stop talking about it. 

I don't even know how to formulate a coherent and well structured review for this game because my emotions are all over the place lol, but to cut to the chase this shit is wayyyy more than just a walking simulator. This is a beautiful game and I HIGHLY suggest people to play this if you value story rich games. Of course, the first two to three chapters are bit of an annoyance to get through if you have low patience and low tolerance, but once you get past the first two chapters and really start to understand the flow and mechanics of the game, you'll get addicted, just as I did. I was NOT expecting to pour 70+ hours into this game. 

Kojima and everyone who worked on this game created a true work of art, this is one of the greatest entries in gaming and 100% in my top 10 video games of all time. This is not your average video game, this is an emotional experience that will move you in so many ways. I've felt every emotion while playing this game, anger, sadness, happiness, melancholy, you name it. I haven't felt this much emotion from a video game since Silent Hill 2. The story within this game is so fucking beautiful words cant even summarize how good it is, there is just so much heart and soul put into the story and its lore. You can tell everyone who played their role in this game put their all into it. Norman as Sam, Mads as Cliff, Troy as Higgs, and everyone else did wonderfully. I was not expecting Cliff and Higgs to be such incredible "antagonists". And Sam has such perfect development throughout the game, his conclusion is PERFECT. 

The music in this game is so fucking good, the way Kojima implemented Low Roars music is so damn good. I wanna thank Kojima for introducing me to Low Roar because their music is incredible. Ludvig Forssel made an OST that fits this game perfectly, it captures the vibe of Death Stranding so well. I must add that bb's theme is spectacular, definitely my favorite track in this game. The graphics are awesome, not the greatest but they're great. I have like 100+ screenshots for this game because of how cool the stuff in this game looked. There are some dope ass moments in this game that wow you. I am a sucker for weird and breathtaking imagery and Death Stranding has it. The acting in this game is also very good, Tommie Jenkins as Die Hardman surprisingly stole the show, theres a specific part of the game where his acting got me super emotional. Norman Reedus towards the end of the game also did fucking great, he made me get teary and any actor that makes me tear up is great in my books. 

I could ramble on for hours writing a review for this game, but it'd just turn into a 10 page essay. Needless to say, this is an incredibly well made game and I am SO excited for Death Stranding 2, and the fact that it will most likely top this game excites me even more. I am for sure preordering the shit out of DS2 when it releases. Kojima is truly a genius. I want him to make a movie so bad, but you could argue that Death Stranding is a film, just a really long one lol.

Also, I love bb. I would sacrifice my life for him.
