[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Death Stranding is such an awesome game and I enjoy it so much, yet it is safe to say it is not for everyone because there is no exciting gunplay or swordplay - it is a slow-paced walking simulator. Normally for walking simulator, walking is merely a mean to move the story forward, in here walking is the game, as all you do is to walk from point to point delivering cargos. But it is not just simple walking - you will have to manage stamina, balance, battery, weight, delivery time, cargo stability and integrity as well as challenges from different terrains and weather while facing threats from bandits, terrorists and ghosts (BT). It can actually go pretty in-depth, involving some real-life logistics questions such as how to arrange delivery order (as in a particular sequence) from point to point to make the most out of each run, or how to position each transfer point (zipline station) to maximize the coverage with minimal numbers of stations. There is no other game like Death Stranding and as such a unique game, the gameplay and mechanics are surprisingly refined and polished. It manages to be reasonably realistic to be challenging, but does not overdo it to avoid being too much of a grind.

I find the gameplay strangely addictive. There were a few times that I fired up the game at night, the next thing I know is the sun came out. There is always stuff to do and cargo to deliver and I feel oddly satisfied doing them, but it greatly varies from person to person. I read online comments saying this game is stupid, tedious, or meaningless, and from what I have read and seen, it seems Asian people tend to more appreciate the game than people in the west (particularly North America). I don’t know if it is the culture or the game simply appeals more to certain demographics or something, it is hard to tell whether you will like it or not. But I like it anyway, as I find the game not only offers a good sense of exploration as an open-world game, but also offers a great sense of expedition because each delivery is not easy. After going through all the steep terrains and hardship, the sense of completion and achievement is immense, sweet and satisfying.

It is not always hardship though. As you progress through the game, you are rewarded with gears like vehicle and zipline which not only make your life so much easier but also offer a good sense of progression. However, you will have to earn it by doing quests or other things, per se, finding a good zipline spot, which is not simple as I spent tens of hours doing it (and maintenance). But it is the thing you have to earn that is precious, and it is the hardship and challenges that make you appreciate other people, as the game implements this Social Strand System allowing players’ constructions to be shared and used across the community. It is a very creative and genius design that aligns with the main idea of the game – connection - as a profound reminder that we humans as a society are not to conflict but to help each other with shared efforts.

[h1]Flaws[/h1]
Some imperfections are hard to avoid, and combat is arguably the weakest part of the game. I don’t mind that it doesn’t have many combats since it is primarily a delivery game, but I don’t like the combat not having much momentum. By design, you need to switch weapons a lot in combat and might even have to go into the inventory, which kills the momentum. To make matters worse, all weapons are clustered with other non-combat tools in one scroll wheel, so you have to pick the desired weapons among other items during hectic combats. Since the game leaves D-Pad down button unused (unless in sub-menu), it is simple to use down button as dedicated weapon button, and when it is pressed, use other D-Pad buttons for lethal, non-lethal arms and grenades (controller control is uncustomizable). It is such an easy fix and could make combat so much better, and I really don’t understand why it uses a bad design instead.

As for others, because the game doesn’t have a good enough mechanic for measuring and planning, picking proper zipline spots is cumbersome; there are an excessive amount of cutscenes in regular actions and have to be manually skipped each time and after hours in, they are going to be a hassle; the menu design is not good enough for the amount inventory management you need to do in this game, and it has a weird control logic you need to get used to. Additionally, community construction is not shared between the original and Director’s Cut, so returned players may have to rebuild a lot of things.

[h1]Story[/h1]
I reviewed Phantom Pain a few years ago and stated Hideo Kojima is not a very good storyteller, it still stands in this game. This game has a fascinating and unique post-apocalypse setting, and the main ideas of the story are “connection” and “life and death”. The former is well demonstrated through gameplay yet doesn’t translate into the story because all side characters just talk about connection but don’t do anything to make players feel relatable or “connect” with them. For the latter, each episode is centered around one character and their view of “life and death”, packed with metaphors, symbolism, philosophical thoughts and an uncomfortable amount of male nudity (just kidding). I don’t have an opinion about this one. I enjoy the narrative tone and pacing and how Kojima packed in some wacky stuff, however, most of the story is just explaining things and there are some cringe dialogues like “I am Fragile, but not that fragile”. In terms of the plot, it kind of falls apart from episode 9 with an unnatural and convoluted twist with seemingly inconsistent characters, but the epilogue (ep14) is so good and touching that I am willing to cut it a slack.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]
In previous review, I also stated Hideo Kojima is a director like Michael Bay (who is not a good storyteller) that can put out some stunning visual and presentation, and Death Stranding proves my point once again. Despite some low-res textures on the edge of the map, this game is photo-realistically beautiful overall. Cutscenes are meticulously crafted with shadows, lighting, contrast, object layout and proportion, along with beautiful, beautiful music and the amazing acting that can be viewed as the pinnacle of video game acting by the actors. And a few parts of the game are very emotionally contagious. On the flip side, primarily as a console game, it doesn’t offer enough graphical options despite it coming with excellent optimization, and music is usually so brief that it ends before going past the chorus. I wish I could turn on the music manually when delivering.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
In conclusion, Death Stranding is a well-crafted, one of its kind experiences like no others. Fans said it is not just a game, but an art piece, and I can totally get behind this opinion. With that said, it is not a mainstream game and is not for everyone. But if it clicks with you, it clicks hard.

This game is heavily inspired by the hit Flash-based videogame "QWOP." You play as the protagonist, a pregnant Norman Reedus, who has taken the job of an errand boy and road construction worker in present-day Detroit.

The game features many challenging enemies, such as "MULEs," a group of disgruntled ex-UPS employees fed up with being constantly attacked in rough neighborhoods; as well as "BTs," a gangstalking squadon of ghosts who are infatuated with Norman Reedus.  Ashamed of this fact, they immediately present an "upside down rainbow" whenever they encounter Reedus, in a vain attempt to let him know that they are not gay.

Overall, I believe this game is a worthy successor to QWOP, and I am especially impressed by the giant leap in graphics quality in comparison.


I have received financial compensation for this review.

This game is an absolute masterpiece. While you may be able to dispute the gameplay, it is actually quite addicting. You actually feel like you're accomplishing something, and your well rewarded for your efforts, between likes and special equipment each prepper will reward you with to make your job easier and more fun. The visuals are very much the peak of what you'll find today. But if all else fails, the story will stick with you. It will make you laugh, and make you cry. Even if you're hardly an emotional person, this game WILL make you feel feelings, and is worth playing through for that reason alone. Get this game, and play through it at least once. Trust me, it is worth the ride.

Death Stranding might be one of the worst games I've ever played.

Now, I've never played the metal gear games. I have no attachment to Kojima or his supposed genius. I went in expecting wacky ass-pull writing but oh boy did I get it in far greater spades than I ever expected. But that's not why I hate the game, no. If you beware spoilers, probably stop reading, since with the nature of the plotline I'm really not sure where to start considering things spoilers so I'm just not going to. Let's see:

Things I liked in Death Stranding, in whatever order I think of them:
- Sam
- Sam saying "bullsh*t" to stupid plot twists at the same time I did
- Deadman (grew on me)
- Exploring the map to make number go up
- The part of the game where you build highways and unlock trucks and deliveries become American Truck Simulator
- Wiping out Mule camps with a truck to fund those highways
- Mads Mikkelsen
- Realizing how much of a non-threat BTs actually are once you have weapons, and how much further trivialized they are by the melee takedown you get for them later, making Chiral Crystals a total non-concern for the rest of the game

Things I didn't like in Death Stranding:
- The things Sam said were bullsh*t happening anyway
- Melee combat
- Ranged combat
- The part of the game where enemies suddenly become able to die so running over them with vehicles to avoid the garbage combat is no longer an option
- Realizing how comically long it takes for bodies to go necro, and how many fit in a truck to trivialize delivering them, so killing people isn't actually a concern at all, despite what a big deal they make of it
- The introduction of lethal firearms to the player also introducing them to every single enemy for the rest of the game including in areas you'd been to before
- The game's abject hostility to the transportation shortcuts it itself gave you, trying to force you to walk around in the sticks that vehicles can't or won't take whenever it can
- Snow, when every vehicle offered to you has slick tires, compounding the above, and making walking even worse
- That time I had to carry a specific cargo through the snowy mountains that was so fragile the random physics interactions the bike causes destroyed it, giving me one of my 2 game overs in the entire playthrough, forcing me to walk through the waist-high snow for what must have been multiple hours, about half of which being through BT territory
- That time I had to carry a specific cargo through simple, familiar territory, except every BT area in the path was scripted to immediately start a boss BT encounter, forcing me out of my vehicle and throwing my cargo, and to evacuate until it despawned from distance, which combined with the scripted unending rain caused a delivery of 100% container damage 99% cargo damage
- The inescapable boss fight at the end of the above run, which is the one thing I wouldn't dare spoil, but took like 20 minutes of standing around shooting it until its health ran out (you still have the cargo during this btw)
- Heartman
- Heartman's university lectures on theories of humanity that I could not care less about
- Fragile
- Every subsequent time after the first that Fragile said "I'm Fragile, but I'm not that fragile"
- Every other goofy reveal of why these characters have these "symbolic" names (you'll love finding out why they call him Die-Hardman)
- Kojima rewriting the entire history of not only mankind but the entire universe to fit into his plotline but still referencing contemporary real-world events, like this could still happen but we just don't know about it yet
- Codex entries being locked behind specific arbitrary orders that appear entirely at random
- Fighting Mads Mikkelsen (ever seen that movie clip where two guys in an apartment fire fully loaded automatic rifles at each other and neither of them fall down? It's like that)
- The guy who constantly makes video game jokes about himself and calls himself the final boss and isn't the final boss
- The 1 for 1 replica of the snake vs liquid fistfight from MGS4 but worse and with none of the stakes or attachment
- Being given "a choice" where taking either of the two options causes a game over and you actually have to take a third option not presented or explained to continue
- Unskippable "playable" credits that the game loredumps at you during, forcing you to take action between each piece of dialogue for them to continue even though nothing is happening and you can't do anything
- A post-credits cutscene where you watch the actual events play out that were loredumped at you anyway, begging the question of why they bothered
- The ending itself being like 6 hours; my game actually crashed in the middle of it and I was almost very upset, but for a mercy an autosave was created at the end of the playable credits so I could just cutscene skip back to where I was

And finally
- Spending 100 hours of my life seeing through this shitshow to make number go up and because I just had to know how it ended and receiving the worst ending of my life since Mass Effect 3, and THEN finding out even if I finished 100%ing the game it would still be incomplete because there is an additional "Legends of Legends" delivery rank for Hard mode AND a "Legend of Legends of Legends" rank for Very Hard, what a joke

I did think that [spoiler]the reveal that the BB in the Mads Mikkelsen flashbacks was actually Sam, not your BB, and both of their reactions to finding that out[/spoiler] was pretty cool though. Only part of the ending I liked.

I will not be playing Death Stranding 2, and I will never finish a game I'm not enjoying for the sake of the story again. Hideo Kojima is a hack and a clown.

Played 80 hours Death Stranding and now 10 in Death Stranding Director's Cut. Absolutely amazing. One tip: start from the beginning in the director's cut and don't upgrade half game. It works, but you loose quite some structures. One of the best games I've ever played. Incredibly immersive.

Hideo Kojima really knows how to tell amazing stories through metaphors that often go ignored. Not only are these metaphors present throughout the entire game, they are also elements of the main plot. The overall theme of the game is surrounded by "connection." Bridges, ladders, the chiral network, the beaches, your relationship, America, your cufflink, terrorism, etc. It's talking about the division of modern society but without it actually being spelled out for you. This is a common theme with Hideo Kojima's games. His concern for society is often depicted in metaphors and other hidden messages. The man is really concerned for society, America at most for this game, and it shows. 

As for the game and its main plot, it's absolutely brilliant. The lore is interesting, the characters are well developed, and plot comes with many twists and turns that I couldn't predict. It's a sci-fi world that uses actual scientific theories and ideas such as Higgs Field, matter and antimatter, and turns them into something creative and new, which helps give the universe an almost real feeling. Even one of the villains is named after this. Higgs refers to himself as the God Particle, which is what we also call the Higgs particle. 

The gameplay isn't perfect but it is very fun. Much of the mechanics seen in the Metal Gear Solid series, especially the 5th one, is brought back. There is a lot of micromanagement and stylistic choices that feel very Metal Gear-y. You can build roads, print items that help you on your journey, you can ride vehicles, use weapons against enemies and BTs. There is a lot of things you can do to make your mundane Amazon run feel less boring. It's not for everyone and I would not recommend it for everyone but I do recommend to give a try. Many of these game mechanics aren't shown until the second part of the map, which can be about 10 hours in.

I could write you a meme review: "Norman Reedus and the Amazing Feetus Reconnect America's Internet One UPS Package At A Time."  I won't.  Not after the last two days.  I want to tell you a story about a motorcycle and the Waystation at the End of the World.     (spoiler free)


I had just moved on to the second map chunk of the game and as I steeled myself to set out into new territory I stopped to check communal equipment locker.  A motorcyle had been left behind by another player, Logick: Logick's long-range reverse trike.  With 15 or fewer hours on my save file, I pulled it from the shared garage, thinking about my good fortune.  A ready-available bike with a double-size battery.  Surely it would serve me well for a few runs before I swapped it out with something else.
I would go on to put a total 90 hours on my save file, and cross the largest, most varied map of the game over and over and over on Logick's trike, secure in the knowledge that it would get me to where I was going and back home every time.  You can give "Likes" to other players' equipment and structures to show your appreciation, and Logick earned over 3000 likes from me through the trike alone.  It would become the single vehicle I used the most, by an enormous margin.

The moment I lost Logick's trike was heart-wrenching.  I was attempting a risky river crossing, sure as I had been every time before that Logick's trike would see me through.  I failed.  I lost Logick's trike and my cargo to the river's current, and as I scrambled to recover my load from the current, Logick's trike was gone without a trace.  This piece of essential equipment I had borrowed from a stranger I would never know, that had carried me through hours of gameplay, was gone in an instant.  I pressed on.  There wasn't anything else I could do.
About ten minutes later, a notification appeared on my screen: "A reverse trike has been recovered from a river".  I opened my map to the discovery that Logick's trike had found it's way to the shore, and while it was in very bad shape, it still had a mostly full battery.  I couldn't spare the time to turn around, so I would have to trust that it would be there when I returned.  The better part of an hour later as I tore across the landscape on foot, no cargo to weigh me down, Logick's trike came into view, smoking, on the riverbank where I had attempted the crossing.  Nearly broken, but with a full battery.  I coasted into the nearby distro center on single-digit durability, and finally let out a sigh of relief.  Logick's trike was back in the garage, safe and repaired, ready to go on the next delivery with me.

That one trike, in theory entirely replaceable, was my second most valuable piece of equipment.  On the final trek back across the whole of the map, I rode Logick's trike in a reverse-tracing of the path I had first taken while riding west.  With it's unfailing reliability, it brought me the whole way back.  I crossed the map perhaps dozens of times, hurtling through some of the worst hostile territories in the game, over mountain foothills and rivers, on that one trike.  I couldn't take it any further than the mountains, but it would be waiting for me for the return trip.


As I approached the end of the game, beyond the reach of Logick's trusty trike, after hiking through the worst terrain the game had to offer with the singular largest load I had ever moved as part of one of the story-line related deliveries, sneaking through an enemy camp and even being shot at, I finally reached my objective.  Sitting there, listening to the game's soundtrack, I looked around the area.  Scattered over the immediate vicinity was a safe house, a charging station, and a shelter, each built by a different player, with materials contributed by who knows how many others to help upgrade and repair them.  We, as a community, had put together a waystation, here at the end of the world.  One last stopping point before the final push, a chance to breathe easy and ready up.  Every single one of those structures had been brought here, through hostile territory, by players spending their own precious materials, knowing full well they would likely only benefit from this effort for a few minutes at most.  They did it anyway, because they knew it would be there for the others who came after them.

We were all just ships passing in the night, unable to interact beyond simple expressions of thanks, notifications reading "Player _______ has used your structure and sends their appreciation.  __ Likes received" in the bottom left of your screen, and yet we had provided for each other nearly everything you could have needed, then and throughout, be it a trike, a charging station, shelter from the rain, or something as important as a place to rest and repair your vehicle.  It's all just zeros and ones, code and pixels, and maybe it's silly, but knowing that there were people who went out of their way to help those who would come later, and being able to be part of it, contributing materials to that waystation, to roads, and building a zipline network that would become a highway, it reminded me of the good there is is the world.  This game, and its community, will help rebuild your faith in humanity if you let them.

I cannot recommend this game enough.


And Logick, if you find this, thank you.  Your trike carried me through so much of this game.  It took its lumps traveling with me, but I made sure it always came back, same as it did for me, and I made sure to store it in the garage after that last ride.

[h1] Director's Cut NEW FEATURES[/h1]

*DualSense feedback support!

*Strand Contracts with Friends!

*Graphic enhancements (e.g., DLSS Quality & Performance, sharpness, fluids reflections).

*New story missions and standard orders.

*New game modes (e.g., extra stealth missions, ranked orders, firing range, drills, boss replays, racing, leaderboards).

[b] MINOR SPOILERS: [/b]
[spoiler]* New map locations (i.e., Ruined Factory in the Eastern Region).
* New roads (i.e., connecting Distribution Centre South of Lake Knot to Mountain Knot, race track behind Timefall Farm).
* New abilities (i.e., riding zip-lines with carriers, running attacks, rest on the bike, grab cargo from the bike).
* New vehicles (i.e., Roadster, Trike Transporter).
* New structures  (i.e., cargo catapult, jump ramp, chiral bridge).
* New equipment (i.e., buddy bot, stabiliser, jetpack, solar powered support skeleton!)
* New weapons (i.e., maser gun, turret).
* New customisations (i.e., pod and backpack patches, new colours for accessories and equipment, new holograms, new music tracks, new signs). [/spoiler]

[h1] PROS & CONS:[/h1]
[b]PROS:[/b]
+ Jaw-dropping details!
+ Excellent optimisation.
+ Kojima's genius and humour! XD
+ Induces an urge to explore its immense beauty!
+ Genre-defying gameplay mechanics and meta-games.
+ TRUE sandbox on every level!
+ The asynchronous multiplayer feels organic.
+ Significantly improved combat system.
+ Photo mode is infinitely fun!
+ Strategical planning.
+ Mesmerising direction and fantastic acting performances!
+ Touching and mind-bending philosophy.
+ Memorable soundtrack.
+ Even more equipment and features for different scouting situations.
+ Rich with Easter eggs and secrets to discover!
+ GREAT replayability value.

[b]NEUTRAL:[/b]
~ Probably the worst game to Twitch. Needs to be experienced first-hand.
~ A real-time co-op extension could increase its players base.

[b]CONS:[/b]
- Why wasn't it a DLC instead of a separate title?
- Still no music player during deliveries.
- Many of the online structures from the original game will disappear in the Director's Cut.
- The structures built before connecting the chiral network won't be shared.
- No day and night cycles!
- Should be cross-platform!
- Still unable to change the colour of the writing "Tomorrow is in your hands" in photo mode.
- The story ends, unfortunately!

[b]SCORE: 10 / 10.[/b]

I'm 97.8 hours in.

There are a number of interesting ideas here. I've spent the majority of my playtime trying to make things easier for other players by putting down devices like ladders and bridges, in addition to helping a number of imaginary people with their lives via delivery, so I've barely moved the storyline.

When I'm playing I'm usually too busy with one project or another, too bent on going just a little further to tame the proverbial wilderness and make sense of the world with roads and bridges. It's definitely an engaging game, as there's always something to do.

 When I'm not caught up playing, though, I wonder if I'm having "fun" or if i'm just appeasing the part of me that's seeking some sort of "work/structure/routine" in my life through a video game. On the other hand, after Days Gone and Ghostwire I might be burned out a little on sci-fi/urban fantasy and that may be affecting my feelings.

Ultimately, I love the presentation and I can't find anything wrong with the gameplay, though it's a little frustrating that it has a strange a strange (timed?) auto-save that can make you miss hours of work, but i'm not sure if the game is right or healthy for compulsive people like me personally. This might be also one that I personally have to stop for awhile and try again with fresher eyes (maybe after an FPS or two) so take this review with a grain of salt.

TLDR: Awesome storytelling and aesthetics, but excruciatingly boring gameplay

-----
-Plot (Pro)
The story is magnificent: well crafted fantasy with very original world filled with mystery and revelations.

-Visual (Neutral)
The environment is very soothing and conveys the perfect ambience for the narrative, but its all the same everywhere. I got bored and googled all the environments I had not yet visited, and it confirmed my suspicion. No variety.

-Gameplay (Con)
If you love just slouching barely awake with a controller on the edge of your fingers slowly leaving your grasp due to your gradually growing comatose state, this is for you.
Otherwise, there is nothing to this title when it comes to gameplay. They slapped a good plot and storytelling on a 'walking-simulator'. Basically, you need to balance stuff on your arms and legs, try not to trip on rocks, and move mail around - that's literally it for god knows how many hours. Seriously, just go on Youtube and watch all the cut-scenes and cinematics (some people just mashed them into 1 video) - save yourself the boredom and enjoy the plot for free.

-Performance
I don't care about 'Frames Per Second' and '8K Graphics' - My appreciation of a game revolves around gameplay, story and art.

Immersion. Music. Visuals. Anticipation. Intrigue. Just a few words to describe this title from Kojima. As someone who doesn't have any experience with prior Kojima games, except a few hours of Metal Gear Revengeance, I am dumbfounded how he can make an Amazon delivery simulator so fun to play. At first I thought it would be so much of a chore to lug things across the map, I'd just run through the story missions as fast as possibe to experience the story. However as I have played more, I have become obsessed with the sandbox aspect of the game. From building roads to placing terminals and generators at key locations to assist not only myself, but other players. Can't forget the joy of exploring the vast world and navigating the challenging terrain with a mix of finesse and outright ballsy maneuvers to make up time. At first glance, this may seem like a walking simulator, but trust me, it will grow on you and have you hooked, if only to find out what happened to our beautiful earth to force humanity into such a way of living.

I simply did not enjoy Death stranding.  

I thought the narrative was interesting and the game did hold my interest for a few hours but it quickly became tedious.  The presentation and performance was stellar as were some of the design choices.  This is a very interesting title that has its own identity not only in terms of narrative and design, but also gameplay and mechanics.

That being said, however, the atmosphere is bleak and the gameplay stressful. It feels and plays like a Kojima game and I can definitely see the appeal.  It's just not for me.

Glad I got this one on deep sale.  It was worth the ten or so hours I put into it.  I probably will never go back in, though.
It gets better as soon as you get to build roads and ziplines - funnily enough skipping the core mechanics of the game - but that takes about 10 hours or so.

I started this game with a predisposition, that there would not be nearly as much action as was possible in Kojima's previous Metal Gear Solid series; that this game would essentially be a walking simulator.

I was sorely wrong.

If you have enough patience and curiosity to get through the prologue and first couple episodes, you will be rewarded with a sandbox experience that is totally unique. If you've played a mainline Metal Gear Solid game, you've come to expect that every aspect of those games are excellent - style, narrative, themes, direction, character modeling, voice acting, gameplay, world building, the list goes on - and that all remains true for Death Stranding. Combat and gun-play do exist in this game, but not in the traditional sense that you may be thinking; lethal violence can also breed certain consequences, which adds an extra layer of consideration in choosing how to handle certain engagements.

What Tarantino is to film, Kojima is to gaming.
Death Stranding oozes style and substance, being totally abstract, quirky, visceral, haunting, charming, and thought-provoking all throughout the journey. You can easily feel Kojima's inspirations and appreciations, ranging from the game's cast selection, to the plethora of easter eggs nodding to other games, pop-culture, music, and works of art.

I've thoroughly enjoyed my playthrough of this game, and I can't wait to spend more time with it.

This game is absolutely amazing. The story (and there is a lot of it) is great. The landscape and atmosphere of the game fits perfectly and it is great to go through. It's another wacky Kojima story filled with absurdity. You're walking through fields collapsing from exhaustion, getting assaulted by box obsessed bandits, and then to top it off there are weird ghost things that are trying to turn you into a nuclear bomb. It's pretty cool, whatever's going on slowly gets revealed overtime but doesn't really make sense until the end, and even then some people are still confused. Characters acting awkward and cheesy dialogue doesn't help much.

The world is fantastic and it's one of the best looking games I've seen, It can be a relaxing experience or a frustrating one depending how you tackle it. 
Exploration is the best I've seen in a game, because similar to games like Splintares and Mudrunner, you have to be considerate of the terrain before go down a path that ruins everything. Your scanner tells you what paths are safer than others, but it also helps to have a basic understanding of the outdoors and physics. You're not going to pull a Skyrim and drive a bike with 400kg of cargo weighing it down up a steep mountain covered in rocks. 

Combat is something I find isn't done very well. The movement and overall "handling" of Sam is clearly focused on the travel and world exploration. Later on in the game melee is almost useless as almost every Mule has a gun. Stealth is only really useful against BT's if you want to sneak attack them, but before you even unlock the ability to do that the game's already handing you grenades and guns that are silent, so why even bother sneaking up on them when you can punt a BT in the head with a blood grenade. Sure you save resources, but honestly they're so abundant that you could print tons of weapons and armors without feeling the resource drain.

The music is what really ties it all together. Even if you don't like Kojima's storytelling, I'd say his music selection was handled perfectly in this game, from the original score by Ludvig Forssell, to the soundtrack featuring groups like Low Roar (RIP, Ryan Karazija), Woodkid, and CHVRCHES . The game wouldn't be the same without it.

So what's the gameplay? Is it a walking simulator? Nope, you press way more more than wasd. Is it a delivery man simulator? Kind of, but the story implies you're not just delivering people's packages, but more so helping them to help yourself.This game has combat, bosses, all the usual stuff you'd find in other Kojima games. It's just not constant this time.
You start noticing a few things as time goes on. MULE's get more and more armed to stop you, more and more buildings from other players appear everywhere, BT's stop being threatening and you end up mowing down groups of them to build more postboxes with giant duck holograms next to them.
Then it hits. Underneath the Kojima storyline there's the truth of what you're playing. 
AMERICA SIMULATOR.
BROTHER WE'RE HAULIN 500kg OF STUFF ACROSS THE UCA TO REBUILD AMERICA. IF A MULE TRIES TO STOP YOUR TRUCK, HIT EM WITH YOUR TRUCK. BT'S IN YOUR PATH? SHOOT THEM WITH BULLETS AND EXPLOSIVE ORDINANCE COVERED IN YOUR OWN BLOOD. TIMEFALL CAUSING NATURE TO RECLAIM THE ENVIRONMENT? THEN GET POLLUTING WITH OTHER PLAYERS ONLINE BY SPAMMING RANDOM BRIDGES AND LADDERS IN THE MIDDLE OF NOWHERE. TAKE BACK AMERICA. 
[b]KEEP ON TRUCKIN ON.[/b]

If you plan on suspending the game instead of closing, I recommend turning on the TDP limit setting in the battery tab (the ... button on the right). This will cut the FPS down significantly but after a good 5-10 seconds the fan will slow down and you'll spare the hardware. I hate shutting it down immediately when it's been running at 80C for a while. Cheers!

if you don't like it within the first 4-12 hours, that's to be expected. it's work, and it's more fulfilling the more help you give and receive. director's cut specifically adds things that might help new players through the opening act a bit more, so the experience may be more approachable now.

Hi everyone
Time to review this game after 70 hours of play time invested into it.
I have come across many games some good and some bad but this game i rate as 10/10 it is one of the best games i have ever played.

This game has so many things to do as you progress into this game you manage to unlock many more features of the game so many to mention.

The idea of the game is too build bridges from one end of a city to the other end and to rescue your sister, You play the part of Sam Bridges and your missions is to bring all the cities back on line and you build bridges to make this task much more easy sounds easy but it is not as you will encounter Mules this are human just like you but they are rogues and will try to destroy you then you have the dreaded BTs these are very deadly they are like monsters and very hard to kill you will come across these as you progress into the game.

To help you to level up and unlock more items you must collect lost packages dropped by others and take these packages back to a city and discharge the packages into the terminal you must also take on missions to deliver packages to other cities this is how you progress up levels.

There is a great story line in the game which unfolds as you progress and the game has good instructions within the game to help you understand and play it better.

In the 70 hours i played this game i have had no issues with it as it has never crashed on me and i have seen no bugs in fact the game appears perfect to me and i am running this game on a very top end desktop computer with all the latest hardware and of course the latest drivers too.

The game has fantastic graphics and sound the graphics is sharp and crisp on the highest settings with no lag on 60 fps

The game is well created and developed by what seems very talented game developers they thought it out very good and brought it all together like skilled developers to create one of the best games ever created.

this game is a good investment and you will enjoy it for many years to come and it is a (AAA) title and worthy to own and have in your game collection.

and at the moment it is well under £35 to purchase cheaper at some third party sites for a steam version. 

Have fun playing and good luck.

A summary of Death Stranding. Spoilers ahead.

A man accompanies an unborn fetus along treacherous journeys both on-foot and aboard vehicles as he attempts to deliver important packages to the fragmented settlements of the United States of America, after a disaster hit that made rainwater age anything it touches. In this thrilling adventure, the man must use his delivery skills to impress the leaders of the settlements, and convince them to connect to the big network, allowing the man to see random ladders, climbing ropes, and abandoned vehicles more frequently.

The man then goes back in time to each of the big World Wars and shoots at Mads Mikkelsen for a little while.

This eventually all boils down to a confrontation with another man and his ability to control a bunch of sludge monsters from the ground, inevitably leading to the delivery man having to fight these monsters with his own blood and urine.

After many conflicts, including cutting many umbilical cords with handcuffs, the man confronts the other man in hand to hand combat, after successfully using a Playstation System® as a throwable weapon.

The man then cooks the unborn fetus.

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
Death Stranding - Director's Cut is an open world package delivery game.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The United States is no more. A mysterious even known as the Death Stranding has opened a doorway between the living and the dead. When a person dies, if their body is not cremated in time it goes necrotic and causes an event where their body explodes creating a crater like a bomb going off, called a void out. Void outs have taken out a large number of cities. Rain has now become deadly, it is called time fall and anything it touches ages rapidly. The president wants you to reconnect the remaining cities on a network so they can become a civilization again.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The most interesting thing about Death Stranding is that it is a solo multiplayer game. While you play solo, items that other people build will appear in your game. However, you won't have to compete with other players and they will not be in your world.

You start off on foot with no weapons. As you make deliveries and connect more people to the network they are able to share their knowledge, which allows you to fabricate vehicles and weapons. Each person you deliver to has five different levels represented by stars. At one star they will allow you to add them to the network. This will allow you to see items created by other players and increase the number of structures that you can build. At two stars they will join the UAC, this will allow you to fabricate items at their shelter. The remaining three stars will give you access to more building materials from that person.

All packages have a tag on them that you can see when you scan the terrain. When you scan a package you will see who had it originally, what is in the package, and where the package needs to be delivered. Some packages will contain building materials, these materials may be used or delivered. You don't have to deliver the package to its final destination, you can drop it at a city or shelter and someone else can move it closer to its destination.

There are renegade porters, called Mules, that steal packages. You can go into their camps and liberate these good. However, you must remember that you cannot kill anyone or you will cause a void out. Later in the game they don't care and will use bullets against you.  If you incapacitate all of the Mules in a camp other porters (NPCs) will now be able to use the route for a bit of time.

There is rain, called time fall.  Items that get wet, age at an accelerated rate.  This causes damage to your vehicles and equipment.  Also the rain attracts BTs (Beached Things).  The BTs will try to drag you to the world of the dead.  Good thing your blood hurts them.  Bad thing is you have a limited blood supply.  Good thing you can carry blood bags to transfuse yourself if you lose blood.

The main bug I experienced was that I would get disconnected from the server and it would continually try to reconnect, but would not succeed until I shut the game down and restarted.

One of the most annoying things about the game is the cut scenes. There is a cut scene for everything: delivering packages, putting a shelter on the network, getting into the vehicle, getting up when you have picked up your items to deliver. One massive improvement would be allowing you to automatically skip cutscenes that you have already seen. When you deliver a package there is a cut scene where you put it on the delivery system, then the person receiving the package has a cut scene, then you get to the actual delivery score.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
I found this game cathartic, lots of time roaming the world by yourself. The world is a beautiful place. The only real stressor is the BTs. Early in the game would let them catch me, then I'd "escape" and I wouldn't have to deal with them.

[h1]System Specs[/h1]
Intel i7-8086K Coffee Lake 6-Core 4.00GHz CPU
Crucial Ballistix Sport AT 2666 MHz DDR4 RAM (16GB x 2)
ASUS GeForce RTX 2080 Overclocked 8G GDDR6

Production quality is what I have come to expect from a Kojima game, the best. Slow to get going, but really enjoyed the rhythm in after the second chapter.

The story and cut scenes seem like a combination of lost in translation and writing by someone on mushrooms. The controls are convoluted. The optimization for PC sucks. I have no idea how equipment sharing and likes really work.

All that being said, I'm 65 hours in. It's just fun to deliver packages and the environment is nice. Not sure if I'll actually finish the game, but probably worth it on sale.

Looking forward to see what DS2 ends up like.

At first, I didn't understand it. 
Now? ... I adore it.

Plenty has been said about this game already. It's good. It has a vast world to traverse. At times it can feel dreary and lonesome, but that's kind of the point. This game wants to make you feel things about life and  existence, humanity, technology... and it will mostly succeed at this if you let it. 

It's the kind of game that if you decide to play it, you should do your best to see it through to the end. Not only to get closure or a better-ish understanding of the characters and narrative (which are gradually unearthed from under many layers of exposition and backstory... obscure and sometimes confusing, but still intriguing and compelling to uncover) but also to experience the twists and turns in the plot and gameplay mechanics, and the progression of unlocking all the different tools at your disposal.

The game teaches you the importance of planning ahead, having situational awareness, and being deliberate in your movements. It forces you to be patient and cautious. It requires commitment to see each delivery through. And the more you deliver, the more the game opens up with all sorts of new items and gadgets and tech that makes your job easier and quicker. 

It's a game driven by pure creative vision that *just so happens* to have the budget and graphical fidelity of a AAA studio. It's not often we get to enjoy a truly unique and different premise backed up with sheer talent and production value. It's a game that fully commits to that vision, and mostly succeeds in what it sets out to do. 

As far as criticisms... there can be occasional frustrating moments when it comes to how vehicles handle. Overall they work well enough, but the physics are a bit clunky when it comes to momentum and acceleration, which (in the wrong place at the wrong time) can prove to be disastrous if you happen to be close to any big drop-offs. I learned my lesson *real good* at one point and took more care from then on.

The gun play and shooter elements of the game become more prominent in the second half. I was able to roll with it and only had a handful of moments that were frustrating, but I could see some people getting turned off by it if they were expecting the game to be purely about picking up and delivering packages and building structures. The mechanics of being under fire, running out of ammo and frantically trying to swap weapons while trying to run away aren't as smooth and responsive as your average modern third person shooter. If you're caught out of cover by several enemies with rifles, you won't last long unless you can manage to scramble to safety. Regardless, it's mostly limited to certain areas and a few chapters in the story, and I didn't find anything overly difficult to complete on normal difficulty. 

The core of the game is about having what people need, and figuring out how to get it to them. It's a puzzle you get to solve over and over again as you figure out which path you want to set out on, where you'll stop along the way, and what you'll take with you to make it past all the obstacles lying in wait.

Without getting into spoilers, It's worth mentioning that the game does reward you quite a bit for getting to the end of the story. It takes a while to get there... but if you've got the time, a bit of patience and an open mind, the game *will* take you to a place you've never been before and leave you with a lasting impression.

I really want to recommend this game, but I just can’t do it.  There were parts of the game where I kind of felt that I was getting into the groove of things, just taking my time and enjoying the slow pace, but those times disappeared and now the game is just overly monotonous un-fun aggravation.  Now that I am in the snowy area of the middle map the game is literally sucking the fun out of my life.  I can’t take it, and no matter how much I am enjoying the story I can’t play a game that feels worse than working a crappy job that I don’t get paid for.

Everything about the game feels geared towards making the game as un-fun as possible.  The driving mechanics are not good at all, even the big trucks often feel like they are on ice skates, slipping and sliding all over the place.  The reverse trikes are constantly banging into even the smallest piece of terrain, creating a jarring experience.  No matter the vehicle you’re constantly going to need to repair it, which requires that it be empty of cargo.  You can’t just drive it and then drive it out.  None of it is realistic, so there’s no argument to be made for it being realistic, it’s just fun-fun and aggravating.

The shooting mechanics just suck, combined with weapons sharing the same radial menu as all your other gear and the click-to-the-next-page aspect makes changing weapons a real slog.  The shooting itself is some of the worst I’ve experienced in any game that I’ve played and I say that having played through Mafia: The Definitive Edition and Mafia 3.  All the weapons feel like water guns, aren’t fun to shoot, and have the worse aiming mechanics I’ve ever used.  It’s just not fun.  It’s something you do when you have to, but it’s not something to look forward to.

The building mechanics are the worst aspect of the game.  You are given these incredible tools that work on paper but kind of suck in the game.  A good example of this is the zip lines.  Once you have a network set up it’s pretty cool, but setting up a network is tedious and un-fun.  Maintaining the network once it’s up is tedious and un-fun.  Farming and transporting the resources required to maintain the network is tedious and un-fun.  All so you can do that one order in less than 4 minutes.  There’s no payoff for the work required.

The story is amazing, 10/10 so far.  It’s really weird and I can’t say that I fully understand everything, but I can keep up and I really like some of the characters.  It’s all hidden in between hours and hours of tedious un-fun work though.  I spend too much time in between the great cut scenes wondering why I’m even playing the game at all.  Booting up the game is starting to feel like I imagine it feels watching your abusive alcoholic father take the last beer from the fridge knowing that when he goes for another and discovers there aren’t and you’re going to get the crap beat out of you for it.  I actively feel like I’m being punished for trying to play the game.

Bewildering cinematography, a lovable main cast and actors, as well as unique worldbuilding, gameplay, aesthetics, and a whole lot of enjoyable extra content (Like the Valve crossover). Definitely try this one for a spin, it's a Hideo Kojima game, so what's not to like?

After completing Death Stranding, I realize that the game is this huge metaphor for life - right down to the ending. You spend the vast majority of the game alone, just struggling to make it from point A to point B. It is those moments where you meet someone, actually connect with them, that feel the most important. I wish I could say that those moments were done prepper to prepper, and the game DOES try to get you to feel something for them and see this diverse array of personalities at play even during this strange apocalypse. The key to all of them being alive is that they all enjoy one simple thing, be it music, collectibles, cosplaying, or upholding the patriotic vision of America. This is the thing that has kept them going on in a terrible horrible situation. It is a pretty good message, really. However, you never get enough time to really know these people and entirely too much information is exchanged through e-mails. It was a problem with Kojima's past game too, where a lot of the information was hidden in the background and whatnot (that game being MGSV) so you just don't feel like you are experiencing a whole story at times.

The main story doesn't suffer so much from a lack of information and is, for the most part, immensely fleshed out. My favorite part is just the vague nature of the Death Stranding itself. The event is seem as an absolute inevitable thing that just happened because it was going to one way or another. Death, though it leaks over to the world of the living, is still this unknown feared experience. And, really, the BTs here are pretty much just lost souls caught in limbo. The game was smart doing this, as it still leaves the whole 'afterlife' as a mystery - like real life. We still don't know what happens, or why. Everyone is tied to the Death Stranding in very intimate ways, but not even Sam, who can't actually die, understands the breadth of it. That being said, I will admit that most characters act sort of strange and childish at times. I don't know what it is, but every seems oddly 'innocent'. Perhaps its to cement the idea that without coming together everyone is lost in some way, but I don't know - I don't get that part of it. I will say that it does make interactions between Deadman and Sam some of my favorite moments of the game, its just endearing to hear these grown men doing some of the weirdest interactions ever and trying to deal with existential conspiracies with little knowledge of what exactly any of it means. What I mean to say is - if you like the funny and weirder interactions of the Metal Gear series, this game is like 90 percent those.

Gameplay is really where the 'player division' comes in. There is combat here, but for the most part you are punished heavily for partaking in lethal action of any sort. Its okay, since there are plenty of non-lethal alternatives - but why even make the lethal options a thing when it goes against the story and Sam's character as a whole? I don't get why they'd be there just to punish the player. In the end, the only real valuable weapons are those that use hermetic rounds to fight off BTs and the numerous boss incarnations. And bosses are just really interesting bullet sponges made of black goop from the afterlife. Its okay. Besides that, you'll just be trying to make your way across an extremely hospitable landscape and using some resources to build a quicker way from one place to another. Its all about weight management and traversing routes. Sometimes it can be rewarding, and other times it can be so boring you fall asleep. I'd say that 75% of the game is manageable and its rewarding to construct all the roads available and go across the entire map! Yet, that mountain area and the couple of hidden preppers are some of the worse most sluggish parts of the whole experience. Yeah, the mountain area certainly almost breaks the entire game for me. There were more then a few times I thought of throwing in the towel and uninstalling, but I wanted to connect everyone and finish the story.

Directors account sort of just adds some fun stuff and a few generally useless means of getting back and forth. I don't see the point in the catapult, and the race-track is completely hidden unless you happen upon it or someone mentions it exists at all. The differences are essentially useless, really - the only real cool addition being the few backpack additions to help out, but there isn't enough space on your backpack to really take full advantage of any of them.

Honestly, you'll have to play the game to really know if you'll like it. However, if you read this, I hope it helps you know what to expect going in!

The lore is fascinating. The landscape is lifelike. The ambience is quietly epic, contrasted against quirky cheek.

I like plotting my routes, balancing my burdens, and thoughtfully plodding and detouring across a reclaimed-by-nature wilderness. I like rock-a-bying my BB. I like whipping out my PP and draining the lake mid stride.

Unfortunately, all these stream-of-consciousness pleasantries are frequently jarred by (1) the voice of the writer and (2) the abominably cruel menu interface. The juxtaposition is stunning - the play experience is quite playful and open-ended. But outside of traversal, the game just KEEPS. CUTTING. TO CUTSCENES. And for things that would work perfectly well as animations!

I'm talking 3-8 second silent cutscenes of my guy: putting things down; standing up; zooming in on an object; detecting a nearby BT. These are things that happen very often, and they feel like rude interruptions on the flow state the game is so good at getting me into.

And then the eye-crossingly excessive cargo menus contain more information than like, a Civ game diplomacy screen, and yet none of it seems to matter that much. The core game loop is collecting and delivering packages, but for some reason this is the least streamlined process in the game. I have to click "accept" like 6 times for every single collection and delivery. & in spite of this information overload, sometimes it's hard to tell what's what, or what I'm confirming. I'm barraged with another 6-8 confirmations just to click through the XP/leveling-up screen. Just due to these menus, starting and ending deliveries is a bigger chore than the actual gameplay.

This "chore" feeling is further exacerbated by the codec calls or whatever they are called in this. The NPCs NEVER. SHUT. UP. What could be explained in a sentence or 2 is dragged out into 8, 10, 15 sound bytes, most of which restates the obvious, or just STATES YOUR CHARACTER'S NAME, MULTIPLE TIMES. 

I've never wanted to a game to shut the hell up and get the hell out of my way this badly and this frequently. I was really interested in the story and characters, but within 8 hours of playtime, I realized I was pressing the "skip nonsense button" about as often as I was pressing buttons to actually play the game.

If there was a mod to simplify the interfaces and streamline the chirping monologues, allowing me to engage more directly with the game systems, I'd probably recommend it. But the raw & uncut pedantry of the overall UX puts the game in its own way far too often to be worth my attention.

Some main points:

Story - 10/10

plot twist - 8/10

Long review:

This is prolly the most atmospheric game I ever played. The whole idea of Death Stranding is absolutely brilliant and I love it. My favorite part of the game are the BTs, it is a enemy you will encounter quite often, but there is catch. You can't see them, and the fear of something that's invisible to you is horrifying more then if there was a deformed soul of.. something, hunting you. The theme of Tar and the BTs is also very disturbing. 
When it comes to story, it is reaaaaaaly slow at the beginning, but more you play the more interesting it will become and honestly, for me, the biggest plot twist is actually AFTER credits when the game ends. Now the whole Stranding and how it happened is a repeating mystery and isn't 100% clearly explained, rather left for player's imagination or rather, interpretation. 
Game-play, your biggest and most difficult enemy, is player itself. The hardest challenge is the environment, and balancing your cargo, tripping over uneven terrain and there is a huge difference when you stock up your cargo to max weight and when you go in light, but when you go light, you might be missing that one ladder or that one climbing rope, but when you go heavy, you might trip over a rock and spill your cargo into the river and don't let me start on sneaking with full cargo through BT infested area. Planning is important in this game.
Overall, it is unique experience in a very unique world that I will be very happy to return to every now and then.

I heard this game is a walking simulator, this game is bad, and I believed thus decided not to play this game for the past 3 years. Then in 2023, out of curiosity, I finally bought this game. After spending 83 hours unlocking all achievements,  I would say this game is both a masterpiece and mediocre. My rating is 8/10. 

The setting, the story, the characters, and the concept are genuine, it’s so unique, there is almost no game that can compete. I spent 38 hours beating the game, well, main missions, I enjoy every second of it, I was amazed by the mystery, It kept me playing to see what would happen next, its story is so catchy,it’s absolutely awesome.

On the way to the end of the story, you are building highways and ziplines to connect every facility. At the end of the game, every isolated facility is connected, you are just go anywhere by driving on the road or ziplining, contrary to the beginning of the game where you can only run by foot. It feels good after connected everywhere.

But after beating the game, I started playing side missions, then I understand why some people hate this game. The side contents are basically delivering packages over and over again, non-stop, hundreds of times. It’s repetitive, and some of people are living on top of he mountain, and you are not allowed to build ziplines to reach them until you successfully delivery couple times later. So you have to carry heavy loadout and climb the mountain slowly to the top, then go back, and do it again. This is painful, not enjoyable. And there are many side missions are just like that, you doing something slowly and painfully, over and over again. That’s why many people hate this game. I understand.
Good luck, we are playing on PC, so you can use a trainer and cheat table,to teleportation, to run faster, or even fly. Cheat makes this game much faster and more enjoyable. And I highly recommend you use mod to make gameplay faster and your life easier.

So, in conclusion, I recommend this game. It’s not a bad game like many people said, not at all. Yes, it has some gameplay problems, but if you only want to beat the game, not to unlock all achievements, I don’t think those problems will bother you. Whether you like this game or not, there is one thing I am pretty sure of: you will find this game different, unique.

To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Death Stranding. The gameplay is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of theoretical physics most of the gameplay will go over a typical gamer's head. There's also Kojima's nihilistic outlook, which is deftly woven into his characterizations - his personal philosophy draws heavily from Narodnaya Volya literature, for instance. The true gamers understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of the gameplay, to realize that they're not just fun- they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike Death Stranding truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the gameplay in Kojimas's existential product placement "monster energy" which itself is a cryptic reference to Turgenev's Russian epic Fathers and Sons I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Kojima's genius unfolds itself on their screens. What fools... how I pity them. And yes by the way, I DO have a Death Stranding tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the ladies' eyes only- And even they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand.
good

Death Stranding is Hideo Kojima's 'The Menu' Meal...   That's not a good thing.  The game is essentially a series of fetch-quests dressed up in deep lore and unique mechanics.  

Your character in the game is that of a barely-psychic courier who also happens to be a nepobaby in the most mid-90's Saturday-afternoon action flick way possible.  Your job is to avoid invisible ghosts and deliver stuff between cities of agoraphobic people who have access to both flawless holographic technlogoy and super glitchy 3D projectors...  Your biggest challenge isn't avoiding invisible dead things though... it's keeping your balance as you carry your stuff around, while trying to keep the boxes containing your deliveries dry so they don't rust.  Oh, and you get a SONY-sponsored lofi chillwave indiepop soundtrack advertised to you as you explore a post-apocolyptic nature-reclaimed America, where travelling by for ten minutes and bike for three minutes is the equivalent of 300 real-world miles (Fallout sense-of-scope-and-scale be damned)... Think DC to Knoxville.

And all of that could STILL sound fun...but it's soulless. 

Look, I Remember my first Hideo game.  I think of Far Cry, American McGee's Alice, Remember Me, Alan Wake, Life Is Strange...I play a lot of different games with a lot of different styles, and it's the blend of soul-in-the-story, fun mechanics, and the love the artist put into it that keep me captivated. 

With Death Stranding...It feels like Hideo got in a room with a bunch of money people and was like "Alright, How Cool Can We Make This By Being Original...Let's Do All The Ideas You Never Got To In Other Games And Make People Fight Space Whales"

It's just...novel-mechanics heavy with an obtuse story that I guess reveals itself somewhere around hour 14 (I'm in hour six), and it's... it's cool for the sake of cool, but not a good game.  I've looked at reviews and people expressing how the game gets popular in waves...but six hours in and this whole thing feels like a chore.  

The character names are annoying even AFTER you recognize the structure, the menus make no sense, there's some kind of social credit system that's obtuse and you're just supposed to 'get it' I suppose... I love hoighty toighty high-minded stuff, but this just... it gets back to that word 'chore'.  This game feels like a soulless, loveless, chore where a director couldn't see the forest through the trees.

Maybe I'm wrong.  Maybe it'll pay off in hour 12.  I'll get my $30 or whatever's worth out of it and play it through, but I'm definitely taking a break for a few weeks to pop into something fun and story driven. I'm really bummed because in a small way, this ruins the joy my memories of MGS bring me.

Is Death Stranding flawed? Yes. Is it still my favorite game in a long time? Also yes. The game grows on you in a way I don't think I've ever had happen with any other game. I'm on my third play-through at the moment and while I'm a little sad there's not more of it, what is there is really great. The sound design is immaculate, making this fake world really come to life, and the DualSense features work absurdly well with Death Stranding considering it was originally a PS4 game. Being able to feel the timefall on my palms, as dumb as it sounds, actually came in handy a few times while trying to find a covered spot to wait out the rain and rest a bit, and the Adaptive Triggers just lend themselves perfectly to the cargo balancing. This was my first Kojima game, and the use of motifs, either auditory or visual, really ties the story together when you know where it's going. 

Sadly, while the Director's Cut was a lot better at guiding players to use the features of the Cufflinks, a lot of gameplay mechanics can go unnoticed depending on how you play the game. On my first play through I never really used the floating cargo carriers for example, mostly because I didn't know you could tie your cargo down and I liked doing it by hand, but during my second play-though I remember sliding down from the Geologist to the Veteran Porter on the floating carrier, tearing the slopes, which was a ton of fun. That's kind of how most of the game is really: not as wide as it is deep. I also struggled during key story segments that didn't seem to have a clear goal, either requiring you to sleep in a specific place to trigger a cut scene or for you to just guess the solution, unless you read your mail which usually just lays it out a little too plainly for it to be considered a puzzle anymore. The gameplay and mechanics are surprisingly deep, while the story is a lot more focused on serving the world you inhabit, explaining the character's motivations and stories, rather than being some grand adventure. Don't get me wrong, the game has amazing story moments, but some of the dubbing as well as some of the acting is a little stiff, especially for how little we see and hear from certain characters (the Chiral Artist really stands out here, as well as any prepper with dialog reused for every delivery). I've also often encountered strangely low resolution textures and more rarely flying geometry, but it never really impacted gameplay at all. That's sort of my main issue with the game, the more you poke and probe at it the more you start to see the limits of it, physically speaking. (For example the 21:9 support being a non standard resolution, leaving you with black bars unless you're willing to do HEX edit, or the horrendous performance in some Director's Cut specific areas)

But all of that is really only nitpicking and rarely really affected how I play the game, most of the time I had a blast immersing myself in this dystopia and delivering packages. Might be slightly biased as my tag is literally bb_lou but I remember being interested in the game as soon as I saw the first trailer, even considered buying the special edition that came with the baby in the jar when the game launched (ironic I know). The story is really captivating and most of the key points are acted well. It really lends itself to replays as a lot of the story is teased early on, and the information is given to you really randomly, making things come together a lot better on subsequent play throughs. It also has that Twin Peaks quality where, by not taking itself too seriously and having quite a healthy amount of goofiness, it allows me to suspend disbelief a lot easier and enjoy the product as a whole, flaws and all. I remember having to put the game down at first because of how much BT's scared me when I played at night, while now I'll just run past them without a second thought. Progression in this game is really rewarding, not only with items but also just skill wise. I always fell around or would get caught by BT's at first, but now I really do not have that issue anymore at all, just have to know how to do things in a sense. 

While not spoiling the story I want to say the ending is satisfying on it's own, and I really did not think it would get a sequel, but I still am incredibly excited to see where that goes. In conclusion, Death Stranding is really a game like no other. If you look at gameplay and trailers and don't think it's for you, by all means it's probably not, but if you're even slightly interested in the premise, the game grows on everyone I know who's given it a fair shot. It's not perfect, far from it, but it's damn good at what it sets out to do, and that's really all I can ask of it.

This version offers new content and features making an overall good experience even better. The more you play, the more freedom you have to do things with that inventory. You can help others. You can hurt others. You can save citizens. You can kill them. You can grow your world. You can destroy it. Regardless of your decision, DSDC is a game unlike others in that your assumptions about core gameplay loops and storytelling are pushed aside in favor of exploring a disconnected future. For those who have yet to play DS, DSDC is clearly the iteration of DS that is worthy of your time given its iterations that are increasingly respectful of your time and patience while also giving you additional creative outlets to muck about.

From the mastermind Hideo Kojima comes his first game with his new studio, Kojima Productions.

You play as a 'Porter' named Sam Bridges, who is played by Norman Reedus. This game has many other cameo appearances from famous actors and producers as well, such as Guillermo Del Toro, Mads Mikkelsen, Troy Baker, Nicolas Winding Refn, Conan O'Brien, and even Junji Ito.

Death Stranding is a very beautiful and atmospheric open world game. The main purpose of the game is to travel across America, branching all the communities together to the 'chiral network', delivering cargo and packages to these people along the way.

Social interactions play a huge role in Death Stranding. Linking more people to the chiral network creates more bandwidth, thus allowing you to build more structures to help you make your journey easier. Some of these structures include generators, to recharge vehicles. Zip-lines, to help traverse some of the more treacherous terrain later in the game. Bridges, placed over bodies of water, or rocky terrain to make passage on foot or in a vehicle a breeze. Other people playing the game can see other players structures and upgrade them to make their lives easier too, helping others along the course of the game.

As amazing and beautiful Death Stranding is, it certainly isn't for everyone. It's very repetitive, and it's what people would call a "walking simulator". The opening prologue and early game might turn off a lot of people. Even I can admit that the first couple hours are a little boring. However, after breaking through the initial opening of the game, it really starts to open up, and the way you execute deliveries can really start to get creative. You unlock different upgrades and structures as you progress through the game, making your journey a bit easier and a lot more fun as you travel across America.

I can't recommend this game enough, it is one of the most unique gaming experiences in years. I'm sure Death Stranding 2 will be an improvement in every way when it releases. One of my only complaints about this game is the fact the Directors Cut removed the Monster Energy drink branding, and replaced it with their own 'Bridges Energy' drink.

The best Mail man simulator ever made (no sarcasm). Very unique game in the market we are in now and I think it succeeds. Combat is so fun punching the guys trying to steal your packages. Trying your best to avoid the BTs (invisible monsters) is some of the most intense horror I've played period. The BTs practically come at you at any time, and YOU MUST STAY AWAY FROM THEM.   

If you don't like 20 minute cut-scenes and gameplay where you pretty much just walk for hours... don't buy it. Death Stranding is an interesting new approaching to a game I never knew I'd like. In my opinion, it's simply fun as hell looking at this dead world yet graphically looks astounding. This is a game where I feel I can just relax for a bit and become the best courier all time. 

Fantastic story
It is one of the most unique games I have played in recent years but Kojima needs to learn to stop repeating himself.
The game play is not for everyone but the story is in fact a masterpiece.

Just went straight for the story, lots of great moments there and I'll probably buy the sequel for how much I liked the characters. Music slaps and Kojima is yet to miss with that. The actors are all amazing, the characters are all so memorable. Gameplay, especially in the mountain areas is an absolute ball ache at times, passing BTs involves crouching for a few minutes while walking in straight lines and gets old quick. Game is a complete slog but when you get a cut scene, your eyes are glued to the screen. Boss battles are mostly sponges.  Make sure this game is for you before committing to keep it, I played the original version for around 8 hours and gave up at Chapter 3, had to buy the Director's Cut two years later to emotionally justify keeping with the game to the end. It does thankfully get better but this is certainly a divisive game and might not click straight away. Thank you for all the generators and timefall shelters, faith in humanity restored, you're the unsung heroes :)
