[H1]So what's it about?[/H1]
"Living is no different from being dead if you're all alone." You are Sam Porter, but he likes to be called Sam. You are the anti-hero that will connect people in-game (and players). 

Delivering packages is how the game starts - but you will progress quickly from foot to vehicle, from prepper to city. You will learn how to construct new items, vehicles, parts and buildings to build up a delivery network. While goals are important, part of the experience is the journey as well as a larger story arc that slowly unveils itself with surprising and sometimes creepy twists. 

[H1]The good[/H1]
The visuals, sound effects and music are some of the best you can experience on PC today. I didn't know many of the artists and group playing the sound track: they fit the game so well. The terrain can be deformed by certain events. The attention to details is insane.

I love the hiking and exploring - it's doesn't get better than that at the moment simulating it on a computer. It's amazing to see all the details: how to navigate using your map and taking into consideration your load, the terrain and other [SPOILER] dangerous [/SPOILER] elements. It's also great that the terrain can be a puzzle: will you use your bike to drive around, will you abseil or bring materials to build a bridge?

Interacting with the community in-game is indirect: you will find items and objects that other players constructed spread throughout your world. As the game is a scale of real life it allows to invest in the cast of characters and through your journeys you will learn more about them: some you may like and others you will despise: the character building is in general good.

Soon after I started, I thought why does everyone think I'm a hero crossing a stream and a hill? Or defeating three enemies (and why non-lethal [SPOILER]later you have the option to use lethal weapons but there will be consequences[/SPOILER])? I realized that instead of literal thinking that the map represents the USA and the distances and dwellings are meant to represent 1:1 to real life, I considered them more symbolic. The game mechanics the game would become boring if it was to any real-world scale and it is not really the point of the experience anyone. Actually even at the current scale it can take 40 minutes or more to move from one location to another - the map is large but becomes smaller when you gain access to more infrastructure upgrades. 

I like the rewards that you receive for performing well. In a sense it's a little RPG lite as you will get slightly better abilities but it feels nice to achieve them anyway. But you are not forced to five star the settlement you can focus on the story if you want and that is the great thing also: they want you to have an engaging experience on your own pace. It's the same for the equipment: the options are there and they are slowly expanded to the point that it sometimes feels overwhelming. This however does change in the latter chapter where the game put you on a track that you cannot deviate from. Even when it says you have a choice: there is none really.

You can definitely see that DS is an evolution of systems and details developed in previous games like Metal Gear Solid. And it goes to the next level: the costume, prop and location design are amazing. You can even specify that the sound from certain items [SPOILER](is it really an item?): BB [/SPOILER] comes from a different speaker set than where the music and normal sound effects come from. In your room you will see the "green plastic American soldier" action figure style that is used to tell your story, dreams and nightmares that you experience throughout the game.

The photo mode is one of the best I have ever seen - it's like you bring your own DSLR into the game as most settings are there. It's user friendly though so even if photography is not your thing it will be easy to use. 

You can manufacturer vehicles, equipment and other items and then share it with other players. There is a firing range with competitions added where you can try out weapons and tactics against various enemies and compare your results with other players. The further you progress the more options it gives you and you can decide what works best for you. 

[H1]The not so good[/H1]
I've had consistent crashes throughout the game: in particular [SPOILER] at the Incinerator, playing the harmonica and during some missions in chapter 3, 5 and 15 [/SPOILER] (so I had to replay the last 20 minutes several times :-(). DLSS was sometimes the cause of the issue and to resolve it I had to turn off DLSS in the video menu. Other times it was just a hard crash – frustrating to the point that I gave up going for 100% as I was tired replaying the same areas over and over again as I couldn’t save. 

The interface could probably be better: there are so many menus and hidden features that you have to get used to. The number of systems is overwhelming and while it's great that they can suit your play style it would be better if you had like filters in place where you only see your favourite items instead of seeing everything all the time. 

The minor NPCs have just a couple of lines at each location. If you made enough deliveries they start to repeat - even Sam falls in repeating his lines quickly during travel. I also would have liked more music during traveling or that you could build a music player and just listen to the great music. This is only possible when you rest in your room. 

The game is not difficult at hard: it feels it just gives you more rewards. Just make sure they don't overwhelm you. The game does like to throw curveballs to you: that last piece of the road that cost 5x more than normal, terrain with sudden storms and increased durability loss, locations that are tedious to unlock and even harder to increase or enemies that can’t be defeated.

The vehicle physics can get weird - it may have to do that the terrain is deformable but it's like they are on a track and not completely connected to the ground as you would expect. 

Playing connected (online) means that you will get sometimes helpful constructions from other players to your world. Often they don't help and as the amount of buildings is limited in each area, constructions that you will never use will still eat up your 'bandwidth' limiting what you can build. 

There are hard boundaries installed on how you progress: certain NPC will not be able to progress until you move further in the story. With constructions it's the same: some things are better left until later usually you realize this when you don’t get any or little reward for tasks compared to other locations. 

The last chapters of the game feel unbalanced. Looking back, I feel the game started small and then expanded: the best experience I had was chapters 1 – 7. It would have been great if the game ended soon after but it drags on and becomes small again in later chapter: putting you on tracks that you cannot skip. 

[H1]Summary[/H1]
It's strange you start walking around and think why is it so special but the game has this tendency to suck you into the story slowly unwrapping locations, people, gifts, achievements and a story. It's one of those games that you say: "OK 10 more minutes, then the next time you look at the clock two hours have passed and you realize you should have been in bed a long time ago, but then just five more minutes". 

I do see that it would be hard to put the game down and continue a month later - you probably want to do a solid playthrough as otherwise too much won't make sense anymore especially as you progress and the amount of things you can do is overwhelming. 

For the first chapters it sets new high standards on performance, visuals and acting. It would have been a master piece if it stopped in time but sadly it doesn't and keeps on going whereby the experience gets worse as you progress.

Is this the first Strand type game? Or just the first one we accepted?

Death Stranding feels like a joke. A particularily mean spirited one aimed directly at the people playing it.

Your first act in the game will be an agonizing crawl up a miserable mountain. The second one is an equally miserable slog through a marsh carrying way too much equipment. It's the game all but daring you to keep going. 

I kept going, for what it's worth, to the point where the game mutates from a pain simulator into a strange mix of Eurotruck Simulator and an Ubisoft Open World Game, which sounds like more of a backhanded complement than it is. There's a strange pleasure to building roads, moving materials, and rebuilding a doomed world coated in acid raid. The game literalizes it's themes about connectivity by punishing you severely, almost to the point of unplayability, if you don't play online. A lot of the development and open world convenience is centered around following in the footsteps of those before you. Go alone at your own risk. 

The game pushes your controller to the absolute limits, and it starts to break down when the game wants to stop being a 3rd Person Delivery sim and start being a 3rd person shooter. The absolute worst parts of the game depend on a very clunky inventory system to be used very rapidly (Natch, a recurring boss needs to be garroted with one item, grenaded with another, and then shot with a third to do reliable killing damage), which is frustrating but not run ending. 

But how did it make me feel? If Kojima games are about their batshit stories and commentaries, what did I walk away feeling more than anything?

That the loss of Silent Hills was the greatest tragedy the medium ever faced. Death Stranding, just beneath it's surface of Post Apocolyptic Delivery Boy-ing has aspects of the single greatest horror game ever made. Kojima has a taste for nightmare imagery and cinematography that are wasted by a game largely about walking. 

We'll keep waiting. We've made it this long.
Director cut is a must get and replay. Wish this happened on day 1 release. Excellent work!!!

This is not Metal Gear Solid, but it is not a walking simulator, either. The game does take you through hostile territories, facing enemies both human and supernatural. The enemy AI allows you to employ stealth tactics when engaging hostiles, and the enemy AI allows for undetected movement to be useful. But stealth and combat are not the core gameplay.
Most of the game has you path finding point A to point B, convincing communities to connect to the network you are building, and subsequently reaping the benefits of tools other players left behind, while doing the same for other players.  For most of the game, the biggest threat you will face is your own recklessness or failure to plan ahead. If you had fun getting the horses in Skyrim to climb mountains, you'll probably enjoy this aspect quite a bit.
The storyline is where the game really shines. The writing is exceptional and the delivery is amazing. The characters all feel like real people, have their own very human flaws, and everyone has their own brand of Kojima Weirdness. 
As you progress, you'll unlock new and exciting tools, gear, vehicles, and weaponry, that you can largely use at your own discretion. The game does have a very linear story path, but doesn't force you to stick to the main quest until you're basically at the very end.

The base traversal mechanics of balance, cargo placement, cargo weight, the ladder, and rope are all very solid but need balance tweaks to provide greater feedback and possibly allow time for players to let go of the mouse for a while (i.e., taking a quick drink caused me to damage cargo several times). Later in the game, the zip lines and roads can severely ruin the core mechanics of the game, essentially bypassing them throughout the final third of the game's runtime. I found the combat enjoyable, but too easy. The only two difficult fights were final Higgs and Vietnam fights, in my opinion, and I don't consider myself particularly good at video games. The BTs are a letdown mechanically, and therefore created some severe ludonarrative dissonance with the terror they should have inspired and the sheer annoyance that they actually gave me. The game is gorgeous throughout and is strangely enough a great game to listen to music or podcasts to. Finally, the story is mostly nonsense. It reminds me of a lot of mainstream arthouse films: incredibly focused on the theme and neat ideas, without utilizing the narrative mechanics necessary to make them work logically. Overall, I give this game a positive review simply because of its complex traversal mechanics. More games need to integrate something deeper than "press forward" when traveling through the game world.

I highly encourage watching Matthewmatosis' video for a much deeper breakdown that I fully agreed with after playing the game.

*Story Spoiler-Free Review*

When I was reading reviews and deliberating whether or not to buy Death Stranding Director's Cut, I repeatedly read comments such as, "I was bored and miserable the whole time. It was a life-changing experience. 10/10." After almost 55 hours, I have beaten the main story, and I have to say that, yes, the game was life-changing, and yes, I highly recommend it. But I was never bored or miserable. Though you spend most of your time walking around the map traversing increasingly inconvenient terrain, the game is about more than that. It's a lesson in community, in doing small acts of good for the benefit of strangers, and in turn being lent assistance by strangers in your own time of need. Though the core gameplay is very solitary, you and unseen others make small contributions to the world that make the collective experience more enjoyable. In between story missions, I set my own goals and sometimes spent entire sessions on these unofficial side objectives.

In terms of the plot, Death Stranding is a Kojima game. This means long, back-to-back, self-indulgent cutscenes; over-abundant, mind-bending lore; and gross over-use of symbolism and metaphor. It's a story of ropes and sticks, knots and strands, grasping hands and tangled webs. It would be fun to figure out what Kojima was trying to say, but instead the characters explain it all to you, repeatedly, throughout the game. There's a fair amount of fourth-wall breaking and references to other games. This is the only game I have played where a character let me know when I was half way through the story.

Play Death Stranding. Become a contributing member of society. I will be playing the sequel at launch.

I bought this game when it came out for PS4 back in 2019.

At the time; I was intrigued by this game as it was a huge AAA production attempting something different from the norm and after playing it for a bit I was convinced I simply had to stop playing it and go back and play everything made by Hideo Kojima that came before it. It was thanks to this game I finally got the push to go and play through the Metal Gear games and it has since become my favorite video game series. I finished Death Stranding, the Director's Cut on PC, for the first time in late 2022.

The game starts off very *slow* and it almost appears to be hostile to the player. If you are going to play Death Stranding you must be patient and willing to re-learn how to navigate a 3D world. The beauty of the game lies in taking your time and planning ahead. The controls and mechanics feel completely alien at first but that's because they serve as a ludo-narrative metaphor for forming connections with the people that inhabit the world; and by the end you'll have learned how to blaze through the maps just as you will have learned how to love all the quirks of the game’s cast of characters and how to speak the game's language.

From a purely technological standpoint, Kojima's games never fail to deliver. His games are always first class when it comes to optimization and performance so there's no need to worry about it with this game (although I do highly recommend playing on an SSD as the fast loading times do absolutely make a difference). 

One thing that caught me off-guard was how successful Death Stranding was at portraying naturalistic human models in a way no other game manages to be. It completely shatters the Uncanny Valley-ness one tends to expect of “realistic” video game 3D models with how large the range of emotions through facial expressions that the models can deliver is. That results in the actors delivering some top-notch performances in-engine, and what better fit for a game that cares so deeply and sincerely about humanity and connecting with others.

Death Stranding is simply put, an incredible game. It’s not a game for everybody, but neither was Metal Gear or any of Kojima’s previous work.

I stayed away from playing this for over a year and I am kinda glad. Got this as a birthday gift from my friend and I finally started playing it.
First few hours of the game, everyone told me is going to be a little boring but I did not find it boring at all. I enjoyed doing those little deliveries and cut scenes. 
Fast forward to 10 hours into it, I got engaged with the game and the surroundings. 

Now a little story from my walk-through, so I was doing a delivery and after a long walk through many obstacles, I could finally see the facility. As I was walking towards it, music started playing and I absolutely loved it. Small thing but it made me hopeful. 

Another thing that I realized during my play-through is that there are people all over the place but there was little to no in-person interaction with them and this particular thing reminded me of a certain period of time.
I started to relate to it on a very personal level and to some extent that it made me feel a little uncomfortable. 

Anyway, as a person who loves shooting and destruction, in games obviously, Death Stranding did not seem to be my type until I started playing it. 20 hours into the game, I was balls deep in it. 

The story, the characters, the stories behind them, how they were, and why they were like that, everything is absolutely perfect about Death Stranding. And this is as perfect as it gets. 

During the last cut-scene with Cliff, I could not hold my tears back, I was left speechless, and I cried.
And during my last delivery to the incinerator, BBs Theme started playing and on God, I lost it, I burst out crying and my heart could not take it but then right after the cremation(technically) my heart was so full and I was crying still.

Now, do I recommend this game? ABSOLUTELY YES I DO.
I know not everyone's going to enjoy the mechanism and gameplay of Death Stranding but I think it applies to all the other games.

If you want an amazing, beautifully made story, Death Stranding is the absolute best.
Lastly, as almost everyone knows already, it does not contain a lot of fighting or anything like that because combat is not the main focus of this game, but there is a good amount of fighting.

Thank you for reading, I will be waiting for you on the beach.

This game is, to me, a wild and emotionally moving adventure. One of the best games I've ever played, and one of the best original stories I've ever heard of. The gameplay in itself is, curiously enough, calming and satisfying. It rewards patience and planning with a sort of meditative introspection. The story is original and well-told through the use of not only cutscenes and flashbacks, but through messages (in-game mail), interviews (data/lore dumps), environmental storytelling and context clues. It is to me like reading a good book that you can't put down, and once you're done you just want more.

I highly recommend this game if you want a laid-back experience, as odd as that sounds. Be patient. Enjoy the sights and soundtracks as you go on hikes and explore what it means to you.

50 hours in and I have things to do. Yes it's a walking simulator.  A fair amount of the game is about making your walking, and later driving, easier.  The game introduces you to it's world and the controls slowly.  Good. I'm the kind of player who can miss the "this is how you do that" because I was busy trying to survive when the tip popped up. Then I can't get it back.  The backstory sets up the strange world you are in, but...I still don't fully understand it.  Just the impacts.  By the end I probably will.  The Directors Cut add quality of life improvements well worth having.

Visuals? Good. Plus fairly well optimized.  I played on a High End PC i9/3800TI Then switched to a 6 year old laptop good for 1080p.   Visually it looked the same.  

Game Play.  There is always something to do. It's well paced as you level up the world around you.  Your work lets the UCA give you more and better tools to deal with your environment and enemies, as well as make your job as a porter easier.

Multiplayer.   This is well done. You can see the impact of other porters in the world around you.  They will often have build a bridge or road you will need.  Here and there you will do the same and make their world better.  Shared equipment and cargo add an element that make your play more rewarding without adding extra grind.

Leveling is indirect. You work for likes, stars, and your rating.  Start and cargo leads to better equipment and tools.  Likes and rating leads to more connection in multiplayer and more "skill". Skill lessons the starting difficulties so you can better focus on the later challenges that the game brings up as it progresses.

I can see some elements of Phantom Pain in this game.  They work well. Better here than there actually.  I'd love to attach a balloon to the MULES and "Recruit" them for the UCA. But different game universe.

At the time of this review I'm probably 1/3 of the way through the game.

I had been looking forward to playing Death Stranding for a few years, knowing little about it other than that it was Kojima production and Norman Reedus was the lead character.   I bought the director's cut on sale and started my playthrough.

The game was a joy for me to play from start to finish.  I love a game that values exploration.  While there are clear points of origin and destination with the missions in this game, the player is free to roam the beautiful landscapes and erect their own ladders/bridges/zip lines.  

The online system feels like it does in the Dark Souls games.  There are players out there for you leaving bridges, ladders, climbing ropes, and messages that you experience while never seeing them in person.  

The graphics are great and the vistas are really beautiful.  

This game has a true soundtrack which plays often while you traverse the wilds which is a nice touch.

The acting is top notch and it's a lot of fun to run around as Norman Reedus.  His likeness and mannerisms are captured really well.  

The story is a sci-fi story that grabs you from the very start, at least it did me.  The ending is a little long and a tad bit convoluted, but this is nothing new for a Kojima game and the twists and turns aren't as bad as the MSG games.

If you want a mostly open world adventure with a sci-fi story and lots of exploration and travel, then this game is for you.  If you need a lot of action and shooting this game has it but not as the primary focus, so this game would not be for you.

I hope these narrative story driven games continue, I really enjoyed it.

I don't need to mention already what other's have posted. Yes, at the core you are making deliveries between different points either on foot or a truck/motorcycle. You can either plow through the story and complete the game in 30ish hours or take your time and not even be halfway done while spending 145 hours in it.  I finished the original game in a little over 250 hours.

It comes down to this: You need an imagination. You need an imagination to appreciate the story and the off-world/spiritual occurrences in it. You need an imagination to appreciate the level of insanity placed into the beauty of the abnormal in the game.

You are Sam. Your job is to connect the inhabitants of a continent together through the game's "internet." And most of them give you perks the more deliveries you make. It is what happens between these deliveries. You have mildly annoying humans who want to steal your cargo and you have the supernatural trying to take your soul.

Why have I spent 145 hours in the OG and am not even halfway done? I enjoy the scouting. I would look at a mission and its route, not accept it, go towards where I need to make this trip and scout for the best route. Sounds simple enough, but you are dealing with areas vehicles do not always fit through, streams/rivers, avoiding the supernatural, making sure your electric vehicle doesn't run out of charge, etc. It is a real threat to have driven and not have reached your destination, your vehicle's charge is half gone, and you are unable to carry all the cargo on your back. Do you turn back or do continue forward to your destination?

The grinding in the game is fully optional. Will you build your highway systems to make your future orders far easier to deal with? Or will you just deal with off roading it the entire game?  I suggest not building the highways if you prefer battling the game's biggest enemy: the terrain.

Playing the game with DLSS makes it pure eye candy. Even 145 hours in I still find myself looking at the scenery and marveling at how amazing it all looks. I eventually spent over 278 hours in the OG. I ended up playing the DC to play without the highways. Want a real challenge in your journeys? Don't build the highways or ziplines!

If you like plowing through games and not even putting any thought into the wildly imaginative story and think the supernatural is something silly, then the game is probably not for you. But if you love building, connecting NPCs, seeing insanely looking beings, are a big sci-fi nut, and have an affinity for appreciating landscape, then you just might enjoy the game.

Let me just clarify that this game is not for everyone. Death Stranding is a game that was never meant for mass appeal, but considering its creator, that should come as no surprise. Hideo Kojima games have always been on the fringe of sanity.

Death Stranding is a game unlike any other. Some have called it a walking simulator, while others called it a boring mess. These statements are going to depend on each individual playing, because I would be describe Death Stranding as an experience. It's a game on the surface about delivering packages, but its soul is an experience. It's an experience that will touch everyone differently and provoke different thoughts.

The game does have a slow start, there is no denying that, but once you get past that slowness and start to see pieces of the puzzle, the game takes on a new life. Death Stranding is an absolute breath of fresh air, that will make you experience varying degrees of emotion. While I would love to go into details on how that is, it's best you simply experience it for yourself. There is nothing like Death Stranding; it's an anomaly in gaming, with having such a simple premise, yet somehow executing that premise with flying colors. There's something special about getting a like in the game, and that satisfaction of delivering cargo without any damage that just keeps you playing.

Is it a perfect game? No, certainly not. The story can slow down at times, there are repetitive sections, and there will be some frustration. But that is all part of the experience, and it is an experience. If you stick with it and engross yourself in the loop and its story, you'll be stuck thinking about this game long after you put it down.

I don't think any of us expected a game about delivering packages to be fun or engrossing, but Kojima Productions pulled it off. Strap on your backpack, because you have many trails to forge.

Death Stranding subverted all of my expectations, masterfully - but in all of the wrong ways. At first glance, my reaction to Death Stranding was "This gameplay of delivering packages looks rather dull, but the story and world seem pretty interesting". After having played through the game, my verdict is now "Delivering packages is surprisingly fun, but the story is an absolute chore to sit through". Death Stranding is, at best, a game that manifests neat themes in its gameplay before proceeding to mash the game's themes through your skull through dialogue that comes across as practically pretentious to me.

The gameplay of Death Stranding is surprisingly gripping! The asynchronous gameplay of DS is actually completely novel and unique and for that, I can really commend it. The graphics are generally pretty great too. Out of the gameplay elements, the only major issues I have are:

- The combat is very mediocre, especially the boss fights
- Reuse of buildings (there's one large and one small bunker that the game uses for almost every single major location)
- Occasionally wonky physics
- Late game, you almost always want to use trucks except in specific missions

Despite that, I enjoyed the gameplay.

However, what I cannot recommend are the hours upon hours of god-awful cutscenes, cringy dialogue, lore that make no fucking sense, and characters that are as shallow as a puddle. I would legitimately give this game a better rating if all of the cutscenes and dialogue were excluded from the game. Kojima cannot leave anything up to the imagination, and every single fucking detail of the game is exposition dumped to you again and again and again.

Death Stranding is really hard to recommend for this reason, especially since many don't seem to click with the gameplay of delivering packages. Even though I enjoyed it, even I often found it incredibly frustrating at times. Because of these reasons, I'm just short of being able to recommend this game. I hope the sequel will be better about its awful storyline, but based on Kojima's progression from MGS4 to MGS5 to this, I don't have much hope.

Death Stranding isn't for everyone, the game's main loop is delivery and could be described as a walking simulator. I just completed main storyline yesterday and personally I would definitely recommend this game. It's an artwork. Kojima used a new and unique way of showing the main idea of connecting people. During the game, the concept of bonds, bridges and connecting people are constantly mentioned. You play as Sam the delivery person and by delivering to others you connect people together and you will also feel connected by using other players constructions. When the road was bad and the task was rough, a ladder or a road sign from others somehow magically inspired me. Plus the BGM is really really good! And I'd like to leave signs and constructions on the road in the hope that it may help another Sam.
Also, this is a game that needs patience especially for the first two episodes (roughly first ten hours for me). It may seem a little boring at first since all you do is going from one place to another in order to deliver goods. Repeat the cycle of “take order-deliver-complete order” over and over again. But once I got used to it and made it through to the episode 3, with more elements added and the story expanded, I gradually began to love it. I just took my time and started to appreciate the beautiful view on the road. As the story goes to its end, the ending is splendid and touching. I actually cried in episode 14. So no rush and be patient, just dive into the story and embrace the spectacular feelings it gives you.

Amazing Story, This is one game that sucked me in and has not let me go after almost 31 hours. Kojima has done it again and I can not wait for DS2

What I Liked:
The Graphics/Environment- Quite simply beautiful. The mountains, the streams, and pretty much everything else looks very realistic and the characters are no exception either. 

The Premise/Concepts- This is definitely one of the game’s biggest strengths to me. Kojima has certainly come up with some creative and unique ideas here. And though it is another game with an apocalyptic setting, it’s the type of apocalypse that shows how unique it is..

The Voice Acting- While nobody did a bad job in this section, the quality does tend to rollercoaster from passable to pretty good, the latter of which is primarily displayed during Chapter 14. Those that I felt did the best were Troy Baker and Mads Mikkelsen.

The Character Design- This was done pretty well. If you were to place the main character and the side characters in a room next to each other, not one would look similar to another. 



What I Wasn’t a Fan of:
The Story- I had heard that one of the things Kojima was known for, aside from wacky character names and long cutscenes, was his cryptic story narratives and after playing the game, I can see why. However, I’ll just say that it simply wasn’t my cup of tea. So many things felt unexplained that by the time I reached the end, I still didn’t understand 75% of what had happened.

Gameplay Progression- Some games may start out slow and simple and get more intense/engaging as it goes, but this game remains the same exact way throughout its entire runtime with pretty much no gameplay progression. 

The Side Missions- To put it simply, the side missions are exactly the same as the main missions. Which means that if you don’t enjoy the mains missions, you more than likely won’t enjoy the side missions either..

The Excessive Mechanics- For a game that doesn’t look to be too complex in how it’s meant to be played, the mechanics section in the menu would beg to differ. However, instead of adding complexity, it comes across as over bloated, due to the fact that there are dozens upon dozens upon dozens of mechanics, which increase as the game goes along.

The Cutscenes- Don’t get me wrong, the cutscenes are well done and I personally think the first two are my favorite from the entire game. The rub is that they have a tendency to be longer than necessary, leading to them feeling dragged out at points. The reason for this is the lack of engaging material being displayed. r.

The Dialogue- This commonly ranges from ‘meh’ to ‘comes straight out of a scientific essay’, neither of which are rather interesting to listen to for extended periods of time. This also isn’t helped by the previous point regarding the cutscenes, which is where the majority of the dialogue is. Other times, it’s the constant calls from side characters right after a cutscene is finished, which can get annoying.

The Pacing- Pacing helps player engagement and when a game becomes either too slowly paced or paced too fast, it creates the possibility for the player to lose that sense of engagement and perhaps enjoyability. Unfortunately, this falls into the slow pacing category with long treks that start to feel tedious and the, once again, long cutscenes that feel longer than needed.

The Characters- Like the story concepts, the characters didn’t feel as fleshed out as they could’ve been. Granted, they do have some depth and uniqueness to them, but it doesn’t feel like enough to cause me to feel connected to them/care about them. r.

The Driving Mechanic- The trikes bump into nearly every rock on a bumpy landscape and while you might try to find a smoother area to use it on, they’re few and far apart. A couple other unappealing aspects are the vehicle shutting down temporarily when getting close to a BT area, the jerky turning, and it pausing when you go to drive forward after reversing.
This game can be very relaxing. The atmosphere catches you and doesn't let you go. The visuals are stunnig, the in-game music is great, Highly recommend. 10/10

I truly, really truly wanted to love this game... But by the end of this thing... and I call it a thing cause its really trying to be art but the art doesnt work. Let me explain, The whole point is for people to come together, real players, to build strands and help one another, but 20 hours in, you realize noone really cares about anyone else and they stop maintaining each others fast travel routes etc, etc. And in some cases, some of the structures like ziplines seem to be placed in joke areas, that are completely unusable. the point failed. Its actually quite profound in what the game is showing instead of what it wants from people. SOme people build bridges and highways, whilst the majority of people dont want to help maintain them, only use them. By the end of the game when you need all of this stuff, its not available cause noone thought to maintain anything nor did they care to help others.

Now that, thats out of the way, lets talk controls, they are THE WORST CONTROLS I have ever seen in a video game. We are talking playstation 2 Brank games, like the ones made for movies, like Charlies Angels. The mechanics never work correctly. A cliff or a path you have had no issue using before, makes you fall on your ass another round and break all your gear and lose all your cargo.

The game does everything a great game should do, like teach you the mechanics and build you up as you go, but near the end, it just starts to punish you, not only in difficulty, but in respect, the game does not repect the player at all. 

By the end, you are just shouting at sam, and the BB, because its just an endless slew of him falling, the bb crying and the gear just falling apart as ghosts just multiply and multiply. Im sorry, but its true what everyone was saying about this game, it freaking sucks ass. The 1 saving grace in this game is from another game from a completly different developer, Cyberpunk 2077. There are easter eggs that give you V's quick-hacks... and those come in handy to a point that you are using those more than quite a few other deterrence. Its really sad that the game was so bad they needed to ask CDProjekt Red's for permission to use an attack...

On the last point, it says it runs on steam deck but mine is crashing, dropping frames, and completely shutting off. Im sorry, director's cut is not worth the price, wait till its free on Epic if you truly want to play it.

The game even has to have other players whomst have beated then game help you in boss battles because the dev's seem to have realized they messed up on weapon loadouts. You get to a fight with nothing and then need a dozen grenades and other things to beat a giant hulking monster and you have 2, so other avatars come out of the muck and throw you gear they had.... its ridiculous. 

You know what this game is, its a tech demo, thats what it is, its a giant advertisement for Kojima's studio and his ability to produce/ make revenue for investors. Thats it.

This game is a masterpiece YES, but it's not for everyone, thats why I won't recommend it. The story is really good, but the gameplay subverts expectations in ways lots of players won't like it. If I could give stars on steam it would be 4/5, 80 out of 100 (85 out of 100 in fact, in my case). Of course Hideo Kojima is amazing, it's just a fact.  If you can play a game with a really different gameplay of most AAA and appreciate the story, play Death Stranding and get blown away. If the gameplay is annoying for you, that's ok, the game is just not for you, reason why I won't recommend it for everyone.

Look, I'm not going to lie. I only bought the game to support Kojima after his battle with Konami. That, and the graphics. Because initial reviews made me think the game play loop was tedious. And it is. But somehow it's amazing. Watching the world come alive with objects left behind by other players that help you navigate is exciting. Remember to turn off all the cinematic setting like motion blur. Can't comment on the story thus far, but the cheesy nature of some of the characters and the seriousness of the world will be a familiar feel to any Kojima fans. BT encounters are some top notch heart stoppers. Sometimes i find myself holding my own breath while Sam's about to pass out. I really thought I wouldn't like this game. But the rush of trying to keep packages from being damaged, to weight and item management, and trying not to get robbed just make for a good few hours of chilled yet exciting fun. Also after just having a spat with UPS I now strive to be the best damned delivery man

[h1]Society: The Game[/h1]

Death Stranding isn't a video game in a traditional sense, it is more. 
What I think what Hideo Kojima wanted to accomplish is, that he wanted to create a movie inside a game. 
This game/movie tackles topics such as our problems of our day and age. Social isolation, overreliance on social media, dopamine rushes induce by likes on said social media and a general dehumanisation of our overall society and not caring for each other. Also, since you transport sperms and eggs, it tackles the problem mainly Japan has but also Europe and generally the whole western world, where the young generation is slowly dying out, since nobody has children, and the countryside is dying out because it is dominated by old people that are simply dying out. 

I think this game does a well job at this. As it shows that we are on a full collision course with our downfall, until we somehow manage to reverse course. Thank you Kojima for redpilling me.

Директед бай КОДЗИМА.
ВРИТТЕН БАЙ КОДЗИМА.
КОДЗИМА КОДЗИМА КОДЗИМА.

Мем "кодзима гений" похоже настолько завирусился, что Кодзима сам в это поверил чего делать никак нельзя было. Игра изо всех щелей будет напоминать, что её сделал САМ Кодзима, и титры покажет раза три.

Я опасался, что базовый геймплей будет унылым симулятором хотьбы, но вышло вполне не дурно, симулятор хотьбы не унылый. Примерно через два часа игры появляется машина и мотоцикл, мотоцикл может проехать где угодно, на любой горный пик можно забраться на мотоцикле, что я и делал. На этом магия пешего курьера из яндекса развалилась. Благо карта маленькая и хождение особо не успевает утомить. Чтобы это подпереть геймдизайнеры (КОДЗИМА) добавили несколько заданий  когда надо провести коробку, которую нельзя трясти, тут приходится не на моцике по горам скакать, а просто бегать. Можно построить дороги, но тогда проще сразу евротрак симулятор купить, там доставка сделана интереснее и сложные миссии на доставку всякого негабаритного там тоже органичнее и интереснее.

Повествование выглядит прикольно, нагоняют всякой загадочности, актёры стараются, Михельсон вообще молодец, но в этот мир очень быстро становится трудно поверить. А напыщенная серьёзность только хуже делает.
Вообще когда знакомишься с местным лором создаётся впечатление, что разговариваешь с 12летним чуваком, который посмотрел дискавери и битву экстрасенсов: всего по верхам, и всё вперемешку. Тут тебе и антиматерия, квантовая физика, геология, астрология, египетская мифология и всё всё всё, нехватает только Таро и древа Сефирот, ну или я не заметил. Всё это с претенциозной серьёзностью тебе рассказывают, при этом персонаж типа местного завсклада в жопе мира спокойно про египетскую мифологию может порассуждать. 
И в целом то сюжет ну такой, сойдёт, но по итогу ничего особенного. Нагоняли пафоса зазря.
Гораздо больше проблем в том, что этот сюжет рассказвают супер криво и растянуто. Тут не будет такого, что равномерно поглощаешь какую то историю и просто с каждым разом она обрастает нюансами, чтобы потом дойти до точки разрешения и ты такой "офигеть как это разрешили". 
Нет, тут всё через задницу.
Ну то есть вначале дают инфы. Потом долгое время основным источником сюжета служат по сути текстовые файлы, которые тут типа база данных или там письма которые тебе другие персонажи пишут. Халтура кароче. Потом ещё чутка сюжета расскажут. Потом титры. Через 30 минут титров оказывается что это ещё не конец, после титров продолжается одна за другой катсцена где и рассказывается примерно 85% сюжета, который до этого был особо и не представлен. 

Ещё касательно противников, тут есть болванчики люди, с ними всё понятно.
А есть ВТ, это типа адские приведения которые наводят ужас и вообще страшно страшно. Вот примерно в самом начале игры разбираешься как их убивать и они вообще перестают быть проблемой как противники, а остаются ислючительно как заноза в жопе. Всё дело в том, что эти чуваки спавнятся в определённых областях и когда ты мимо них проходишь, они хватают тебя за ноги, пытаясь опрокинуть, из тебя валится груз вызывая приступы жопной боли, надо отбегать подбирать груз и дальше ковылять, кароче просто пустая трата времени. Но вот если им удалось тебя уронить или если на моцике неудачно влетел прямо в БТ этого, то начинается фаза боя с этой штукой, которая представляет из себя скучный тир, когда просто стреляешь и знаешь что проиграть тут невозможно, это не опасные монстры. Что, конечно, создаёт диссонанс. Вообще тут нету интересных боёв, единственное что было прикольно это мордобой в грязи, ну там ближе к концу. А так уныло.

В игре есть онлайновое взаимодействие, можно построить мост, по нему будут ходить другие игроки. Прикольно. Ну и всё.

Можно ещё порассуждать на тему этой игры. Она не безоговорочно плохая, даже наверное стоит своих денег не будь настолько бездарно растянута и откровенно хуёво срежессирована.

Гений ли Кодзима? Возможно.
Так вот, пошёл ты нахуй Кодзима-гений, больше в твою дрисню играть не буду.
Пошёл нахуй.

Death Stranding (DS) is an odd experience. So odd that I can't really decide if I regard it as a game or a movie or something else completely considering its special story telling. All I know that if you have an ear for what and how it says it will be one of the most immersive things you have ever touched in the world of games. 

About the Director's Cut edition I can't decide if the numerous new little things that I could find compared to the vanilla release are the products of updates or this "maxi" version but they are definitely there. Some are subtle and some come with a massive kick, especially if you play and know some other distinctive game worlds as well.

Apart from gamers with other-than-the-typical taste, I'd absolutely recommend it for people recovering from a mental disorder. When I played DS first around 2019 I was neck-deep into it. Without details it was something that temporarily blocked short-term "memory recording" in a random fashion and the world fell apart around me as hours vanished from the events of a single day. I became disconnected. During DS playthrough my conditions slowly started to improve. I started to re-connect. So the process what happened in the core of this somewhat meditative game, happened in the real life as well in parallel. All symbolic. Because of the meditative flow of the game you can dive inside. You have time to think about deep questions while you're carving your way from A to B through the unbelievable scenery of the game. I believe playing DS improved my recovery.

Nearly 60 hours in, I have no idea what I'm even doing. I focused on building some roads, not knowing where those might go. But the game keeps telling me other players use them regularly, so I guess they go somewhere.
When I'm out exploring on my own, I stumble across a ladder, a rope or maybe some helpful machinery placed there by other players and I wonder, weather their travels were as aimless as my own.
There is no real quest hub, a place from where to start a mission. There is no fast travel that takes you to the next thing to do. 
I constantly feel like I have found the center of the game world, when I am arriving somewhere, but not here. There is no hub of the wheel around which everything revolves. No hero, no protagonist. It's only the connections between the things and people in this world that matter. And that is kind of beautiful to see in a video game.
ye

This is a review from someone who has played this game since it's initial PS4 release. 

Firstly, DIRECTOR'S CUT is the version to buy over the base game. If you didn't know that, well now you do. The quality of life improvements are great worth the extra dubloons alone and the additional content such as missions are fun and inticing.

This game is very good when you come into it and allow yourself to be immersed in the world and lore. The characters are played by people you'll likely recognize and the story itself invites you to look deeper and investigate and discover for yourself what this world is, who lives in it and why things are the way they are. 

The game play and mechanics are simple and may seem even a little challenging to an outsiders pov but there are enough intricacies laid out and layered on top of the game play's fundamentals. If you've played a Hideo Kojima game you'll be familiar with this style of game play; you'll be taught the basics but the fun is in experimenting and discovering how these different game play elements interact and elevate the experience and raise your prowess. 

This game will take you for a ride if you let it, just give it a try and see for yourself. Only major complaint and problem you might face is one having to do with 'Access Violation' Crashes: to my understanding it's mainly a DX12 issue with varied solutions. Should you run into it yourself just browse the games' community tab or look up a YT video.

As a side note this is actually my first serious review on Steam; had to show support to this game; it's incredibly unique and I believe more people should play and experience it for themselves.

Hello Sam, I'm Kojimaman.  I have had a rare case of impostrintrius decaneous from birth, which could only be cured by reinforcing my cells with the genetic material of Hideo Kojima.  For as long as I can remember, I have felt an intrinsic compulsion to look, talk, and act just like Kojima, and it has led to my Ka being entwined with Kojima's Ka.  Did you know that the first game he worked on was as an assistant director for Penguin Adventure in 1986, the sequel to Antarctic Adventure?  It revolutionized the old world by being the first game with a talking penguin, inspiring scientists to genetically develop a penguin with the capacity for speech.  I have become the world's leading expert on all of Kojima's artistic works, and it is because of this understanding of his cultural contributions and our interconnected Ka that I have developed unforseen insight into the nature of the Beaches.  I now must perpetually wear an eyepatch that projects Kojima games directly onto my cerebral cortex, or my Ka will leave my Ha to recombine with Kojima, leaving nothing but an empty husk.

That has nothing to do with why you're here, though.  I need you to deliver this extra-strength underwear to my friend on the other side of the mountain.

Ever since the game's reveal years ago, I kept myself in the dark with this game until I could play it myself...

It ended up becoming one of my favourite games and I thoroughly enjoyed myself. However I can agree with the sentiment that it "isn't for everyone". Its certainly a different game from what most are used to and some may need to provide the commitment to fully get to grips with it.

So is DS a 'walking simulator'?

I would say its not as simple as that. Its a game about planning your journey A -> B, you are tasked with building roads, ziplines and other structure that will aid you in getting to your destination. The player will also need to either fight or sneak their way through terrorists/bandits or ghosts. There IS combat, there IS Stealth, there ARE vehicles/driving and there IS a vast amount of weaponry and tactical equipment. 

I would say it feels like a heavily modded MGS 5 or atleast the core DNA of MGS 5 is being used as a foundation. Like MGS5 the player has an open world sandbox to explore and 'missions'... Now in the form of 'orders' make use of segments of this open world and the player is tasked with planning and utilising his inventory.

The formula is thus:

The player is in a large open world with rest points dotted throughout the world. These rest points offer 'Orders' that task you with taking a delivery order to the destination, another rest point or way-point. The player must think about the weight of his cargo, how to alleviate it, how to make the journey smooth, any structures that can be built and used, etc. If it is a 'walking simulator' it may also be described as a 'path builder'. The player also has access to other player's structures that he can use.

A given journey may have different obstacles including enemies such as terrorists/bandits. The 'BT' ghosts are always fun to get through, the player will need to sneak through the ghosts (using blood weaponry to eliminate any ghosts in your path) but if caught the player risks a fight with a 'boss' there and then.

The story is driven by completing the main mission orders (the main journey takes the player from the East coast to the West coast of the former United States - Although definitely NOT to scale!) and is dynamically woven into the gameplay. The cut scenes are a joy to watch as always with Kojima games.

Now despite an aura of mystery surrounding this story and world since the game's reveal I would say both the world and story become very understandable as the story progresses both through lore items and cutscenes. The central story of the characters actually turned out to be incredibly satisfying and the ending wrapped things up nicely, there were many moments when it was pretty emotional and impactful. The acting from Norman Reedus, Madds Mikkelsen, Lea Seydoux and others were really stellar.

The soundtrack too was great as to be expected.

Aside from the main story, there are more than 500 side orders (with premium difficulty option for each) that the player can complete in their own leisure, as a result the end game world provides the player with a plethora of things to do, including weekly challenges, providing assistance to other players by up keeping and maintaining their structures and common infrastructure. Arguably the main game starts once the story is over and the veteran player embraces the freedom of the open world.

There certainly exists skill gaps that the new player will progress through the more they play and become acquainted with the more advanced mechanics. For instance the player will be able to complete a time sensitive order in the snowy mountains by exploiting the use of a cargo carrier as a snow board.

If the intrigued player gives the game a chance they will eventually discover that Death Stranding is a surprisingly fun experience, the formula (if given a proper chance) can be therapeutic and rewarding, especially if the player relaxes with music/podcasts. This game is BUILT for casual sessions.

Overall, I would say its a fantastic game, for the story, for the 'Kojima-isms', for the soundtrack, for the graphics, for the stealth, for the atmosphere and for the high replay-ability value. 

Give it a go!

Simultaneously a chill, relaxing, rewarding, terrifying, thrilling, and engrossing experience. There's just nothing that compares to it. You could meme the hell out of this game calling it boring, a walking simulator, etc. But the truth is, in a world of exhausting gaming tropes, over-used concepts, and predictable systems, this game stands out as unique, thoughtful, and tense. If you have any love for Kojima, please do yourself a favor and play this game. From gorgeous landscapes, provoking storytelling, to downright masterful music choices, this game will keep you hooked. If you are wanting something different, something that will subvert your expectations and suspend your disbelief, this is for you. Kojima builds a terrifying and incredibly human world that demands to be experienced.

If you are a fan of story-rich games, or cinematic games for that matter, I cannot recommend this enough. It has the best story of any game. As for the gameplay, it may take a while to grow on you, but it's ability to tie itself in with the story is second to none. You quite literally become Norman, and the performances of all characters are the best any game has to offer. To give this game the best chance for (in my opinion) the experience of a lifetime, play until chapter four and you'll be hooked if you weren't already. The soundtrack is breathtaking, and the visuals are extremely unique and captivating. Buy this game.

Forgot I didn't ever review this. 

I first played the base version on gamepass, not long ago at all. I hadn't ever tried it, because like a fool I listened to the general public about it not being good and 'being a walking simulator'. What a mistake. I should have just ignored them from the start - and that's why I'm writing this... in hopes you'll do the same. 

Is it perfect? Nah. But you know what - it's a Kojima game. So every incredibly weird thing our basic minds can't even imagine, as well as all the things we can, are all there. They've all been thought of. Then there's the "how could walking back and forth be fun' question. The answer is that it might not be, at first. But as you progress, it gets more challenging but also gives you more tools to ease the pain. 

Plotting out the route you're going to take, using well placed community objects and your own, using a truck, car, bike, floating carrier, zip-line, cargo catapult, jumping off the top of a mountain, are you warm enough, need to pee, is that a memory chip, what was I doing... 

And Director's Cut makes an already fantastic game, 1000% better with the inclusion of new tools and reasons to get those places to 5-stars. It's literally a masterpiece. I beg any of you reading this, who haven't tried it, to give it a go. An honest try. At least make it to the central region, where there are roads and ample room to stretch your legs. You won't regret it.

The short answer is both yes and no. Whether or not this game is for you depends both on what you want from a game and how you choose to play it. The core gameplay of Death Stranding is right up my alley - but certain gameplay design choices made me absolutely miserable and ultimately led me to stop playing 150 hours and less than halfway in.

If you are the kind of player who:
- Enjoys monotonous grinding
- Genuinely cares for NPCs and wants to actually help them
- Goes full RP-mode in how they interact with the game world
Then this review might be relevant to you.

If not - you will probably find my complaints silly and you should ignore it.

The gameplay is pretty straightforward: walk around an empty post-apocalyptic world with a variety of beautiful, mostly mountainous, landscapes and deliver packages sent between survivor strongholds. Gradually discover technology that makes the job easier, from an electric motorbike to an exoskeleton that lets you jump over rivers. Occasionally encounter threats that are quite easy to deal with: your biggest enemy is the weather corroding your cargo cases, but even that stops being much of a problem once you unlock covered trucks.

What I liked about these parcels is that people don't just send each other food and fuel: they send wine, old photographs, books. The game assigns equal value to technical craftsmanship and the art of cosplay, celebrating human society, the things that make us human, and those that help us connect, from an e-mail you get in-game from a farmer talking about how the shift to agriculture allowed human society to grow into what it is today, to a collectible chip talking about the magic of glasswork.

But this core mechanic is also what caused me misery. You don't just deliver cargo from location to location - you can also find cargo dropped by NPC porters (and other players) on the ground as you travel. And NPC cargo respawns constantly - and always in the exact same place. Once I noticed it was happening, it made what I was doing feel futile. Then I noticed that the missions are also repeated. Sure, it makes sense when the mission is to deliver consumable goods (they finished all the beer - and now they need more), but if the mission is "hey, the bad guys stole my collectible dinosaur figurines - can you go get them back for me?", then that just begets so many questions: my brother in Christ, how many collectible dinosaur figurines do you HAVE? How many do you NEED? Is it the same collectibles that were stolen last time? How do they keep getting stolen, anyway? Still I soldiered on, because grandpa needs his meds and the farmers made fresh bread for everyone. I'd pick up cargo that hadn't been delivered from locations I passed in order to deliver it to the final recipient - and this ended up being the straw that broke the camel's back, as the game, without warning, told me that I've reached the limits for entrusted cargo, and destroyed it, instead of just not allowing me to pick up more. I reloaded an older save in an attempt to save that cargo by quickly dropping off everything that was in my truck - but the game still destroyed something that I had stored somewhere and was going to come back to. Once that happened, I just didn't want to play anymore. The game decided to destroy the NPCs' meds, fertilizers and games because it couldn't be bothered to tell me in advance that I should deal with the cargo I had accumulated before taking on more.

The game is supposed to be open world, but is not designed accordingly. You'd think a game that's all about forging new paths would take care not to have invisible walls - but yet here we are. At some point you're told that you need to go to a certain location to update the software on your device, otherwise everything could fall apart, "but you need to stop at two other locations first, because it's a very difficult journey". Which is fine, except I had already hiked to that location while I was exploring the map. I hiked to what I'm assuming is an endgame location and found out it is easily accessible by... simply walking around. An open world game means you will have players who don't play it in a linear fashion. At least block the path off with a landslide, the equipment for which needs to be activated from a previous location.

The story felt pretty sloppy to me so far - but I don't think that's what matters in this game. It is just a framing device. What matters are the stories told through the world itself, the NPCs and their cargo, as I mentioned earlier. There are collectibles in the form of basically USB sticks with information from the old world from them, basically showcasing things Kojima likes and was inspired by in his creative vision. I feel like this bit could have been improved with some outside perspective. Do we really need 5+ motorbike models and several different mechas as collectibles, instead of, say, the works of Homer? I feel like some of the things in this showcase undermine the main message the game is trying to convey by limiting the scope of "valuable connections".

"Hi, I'm Sam BRIDGES, I CONNECT people )))". Waiting for Nomi Malone to show up with naming like this.

So I'm done. Not because this is a bad game - but because I was subjectively unhappy with certain elements of the gameplay. Just gonna go back in and give away all my stuff.

The reason I'm still recommending it is because I know my experience isn't universal and objective. If you're looking for a zen game with occasional action that celebrates humanity and human connections - Death Stranding is for you. If you're the sort of player who has to pick up every bit of cargo and help every NPC - it might make you miserable.

I have a hard time explaining this game and I have a hard time explaining how it makes me feel. The world, the soundtrack, the graphics, and the overall gameplay loops are astounding. I really enjoyed setting expanding into each area and improving it as I went. The feeling of improvement as your gear, stats, and world changed was 10/10.

The game's weakness is it's story and dialogue. The story is is full of amazing moments but it gets bogged down by endless exposition, where every single motive, thing, event, and person needs to be thoroughly explained multiple times. The dialogue, in general, is almost entirely pointless aside from 4 major characters. All of the info dumps and over explanation makes this game feel tedious, at times.

Overall, this game is really good but suffers from some of the worst writing/editing I've seen in a game.

This game I have more than 80 hours in (including my playtime for the original before I played Director's Cut).

The entire premise of this game is that humanity finally "found" the afterlife and it changed the Earth for good and created an Apocalypse. This game deals with the post apocalypse and how to survive now that the "afterlife" has invaded the real world.

What this game is: A plot-driven get from Point A to Point B adventure game. Now when I say "adventure" I say this loosely because you can literally do anything in this game; it's as open-world as you can get.

What this game also is: Besides choosing your Pt A-Pt B and deciding the best way to get there, this game has a mechanic worse than death, which is called a voidout. Without getting too into the jargon, a voidout is something that happens when the enemy catches you and it erases part of the map you can progress through.

What this game is not and never will be: A walking simulator. If you want an actual walking simulator, there are plenty of those on Itch.Io.

Quite possibly the most divisive game of the decade, and for good reason. If you're going in to this blind, know that a significant chunk of the game is trekking across a (very pretty) landscape delivering packages to places. Yes there is combat, and yes there are vehicles that make certain deliveries simpler. But for a good amount of the game, you're hoofing it. Whether you find this frustrating or relaxing is entirely up to you, but just a fair warning that if you aren't interested in this for the story, and / or aren't a fan of the "walking simulator" type games, this is likely not the game for you. Even if you're in to story-rich games, Kojima is a very special kind of writer who may not be for everyone.

As for recommendations, I really like this game. Enough to play it a second time for the Director's Cut version. The gameplay is relaxing for the most part, and the combat when you do have to do it is satisfying. The online features are implemented well in a gameplay sense and are pretty thematically appropriate, letting you help your fellow porter (delivery person) with anything from a generator to refill your batteries, to a word of encouragement for you and your baby.

The story does a fantastic job of putting a carrot on a stick for you: just enough to get you invested at first, but always leaving you with another mystery to solve, or a theory to consider. All of the voice actors did incredible work in their roles, and it really shows what a difference it makes to have high quality actors in video games. It's full of your standard Kojima "what in the world" in terms of throwing certain words / concepts at you, but given the length of the game it's all fed to you at a rather digestible rate. The world building is done well, and I couldn't get enough of the stories being told about how the world got the way it is, and where it's going from there.

The art style is...well, just plain cool. From the enemy design, armors, and just staring at the scenic vistas, there is a lot of eye candy in this game. The included art book is also really fun to look at, but of course full of spoilers if you haven't finished the game yet. Low Roar, Ludvig Forssell, and all of the others involved in this game's soundtrack + score really made something special, but it's a shame Sam didn't get a portable MP3 player to enjoy it while making his deliveries.

Overall, I'd highly recommend anyone on the fence to go watch some actual gameplay first. This is not a short game, like most walking simulators (HowLongToBeat has the average playthrough at around 40h), and there are occasionally some gaps between cutscenes / story beats that your interest may wane if you're dreading the gameplay. If you can get in to the zone of it all, or if you're already a fan of Kojima, you'll get to have a truly unique experience in gaming.

As someone who followed the hype of [i]Death Strandings[/i] release but hasn't actually played the game until now, the most surprising thing to me after years of waiting was that the gameplay is actually the best part. Death Stranding's hype was always built off it's CGI cutscenes and creator, the gameplay, on the hand hand, I've heard described as a "triple A walking simulator". However, despite being hard to explain, there is a unique enjoyment with Death Stranding. It's the same type of enjoyment you get from playing [i]Euro Truck Simulator[/i], strategizing and performing deliveries is fun when the world is this well created.

However, while the gameplay is strong, the story and pacing is where the game fumbles. Kojima is very clearly a strong ideas man, but his writing is not very refined. This is at it's most detrimental during the games awful final stretch where clearly Kojima didn't know which ending to choose so he just did all of them. Don't get me wrong, it's still a good game overall. But I'm hoping that Kojima lowers his ego a little with the second game and cuts some of the unnecessary fat.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
It’s not just a walking simulator.

[h1]Review and Commentary[/h1]
[i]([b][u]Thoughts on the Director’s Cut[/u][/b]: If you already own Death Stranding and are wondering if it’s worth the $10 to upgrade, that’s a hard question to answer, because while the new features are nice to have, they are not essential to the experience. I personally appreciate being able to use ziplines with floating carriers, but your mileage will vary.)[/i]

Here is something completely different, not just for Hideo Kojima but for any other developer, and that’s refreshing when so many games depend on tried-and-true cliches. Death Stranding at its most basic level is a game about getting cargo from point A to point B, but as the popular saying informs us, the destination is not nearly as interesting as the journey. The protagonist, Sam Bridges, is a “porter” in post apocalyptic America whose task – perhaps addiction – is to trudge across desolate wastelands to deliver parcels to a variety of far flung outposts. Playing as Sam, the player must pick his way carefully across inhospitable landscapes seeking the safest and most convenient route to his goal. Rather than “walking simulator”, I would describe Death Stranding as an exploration game unencumbered by the monotony of an enemy behind every bush. The terrain, weather, and Sam’s own physical limitations are your primary opposition. That's not to say you never face more traditional foes, but while Sam is a capable enough fighter, the game encourages you to avoid combat. Perhaps the most distressing opposition you will regularly encounter is what is known as “Timefall”, which is a mysterious rain that causes anything it comes in contact with to age rapidly. While Sam’s clothes are made to protect his body from its effects, the parcels he carries are not so lucky, and enough time spent in the elements will eventually destroy Sam’s precious cargo. It's this constant tug of war with the environment that gives the game its compelling hook.

I assume Kojima was inspired in part by the question, "What if we depicted video game inventories more realistically?" Every item Sam equips has dimensions and weight and must be physically attached to him in some fashion. No "infinite bag of holding" for our protagonist, or items that disappear inside a pocket. If he wants to carry it, it has to actually fit on his person or on one of several transports he gets access to later in the game. And when he's weighed down by an especially heavy load, you feel it. His movement becomes more sluggish, his footing less sure, requiring the player to maintain Sam's balance lest he topple over and damage his cargo. Even walking downhill can be a treacherous exercise, with momentum causing Sam to take additional steps after you want him to stop, which can end badly if you happen to be near a dropoff. Unlike most games, your character doesn’t charge forward at a constant speed, floating over obstacles and effortlessly crossing waterways. Instead, every step feels earned. It adds a human element to the experience that many games lack.

To aid him in his travails, Sam has access to a variety of tools like ladders, climbing ropes, cargo sleds, several vehicles, and a number of lethal and non-lethal weapons. In addition, he can create more permanent structures like bridges, safe houses, and zip lines. Death Stranding features a form of asynchronous multiplayer. Structures and signs you create in your game can appear in other players’ games, and vice versa, creating a sense of community with others. However, so as not to spoil the experience, Sam must find his own way initially without the convenience of preplaced ladders and bridges. It’s only after you guide Sam to  his destination and connect the area to the “Chiral Network” that you can see and use structures left by others.

"Likes", the ubiquitous thumbs up icon that is a kind of unofficial mascot of social media, is essentially your currency in Death Stranding, although it's hard to tell if Kojima intended it to be sincere or a parody. Sam isn't ever actually paid for a job well done. Instead, the customer rewards him with “likes” which function more or less as experience points for your character, but it's funny to think of Sam trudging for miles across dangerous territory, risking life and limb to make deliveries, all for the pleasure of someone giving him a thumbs up. But when you think about it, is it really so different from people who post videos of themselves performing death defying stunts to the internet, hoping that someone they have never met will click that little icon? 

Indeed, one of the major themes of Death Stranding is forming connections, not just within the game itself, but outside of it, too, as you exchange likes with other players whenever you use one of their constructs, or to show your appreciation for a sign that warns of dangers ahead. The term “strand” is multi-faceted.  It can mean to leave something isolated, but a strand is also something that is used to join things together. It's interesting that the communication device used by the characters in the game to maintain contact with each other resembles a pair of handcuffs. Sam understandably mistakes them for a sign that he's a prisoner but is quickly reassured that it’s for his own protection. Is Kojima suggesting that something like our smartphones that serve as strands to connect us, can also bind us like prisoners?

The world building of Death Stranding is exceptional. The main narrative is about rebuilding America by reconnecting the scattered remnants of humanity, but as you would expect from Kojima, it’s not quite as simple as that. I don’t typically care for video game stories as they are often shallow and silly, but Death Stranding is an exception. Kojima takes the time to explain the fantastic elements in a way that makes them seem plausible within the context of the world he has created. Even something as simple as the bandits you occasionally encounter are not treated as villains but as broken men to be pitied, former porters like Sam who grew so distraught over the thought of being displaced by automation that they created their own culture where they steal cargo just to carry it for its own sake. Then there are the ethereal BT’s, spectral after images of those who have died and desperately want to reconnect with the living. They are drawn to the recently deceased, and if they interact with a live person, it causes a “void out”, an explosion so powerful it leaves behind a massive crater. Strangest of all, perhaps, are the Bridge Babies, which are live babies carried in bottles who can sense the presence of BTs. As horrifying as it sounds, Kojima somehow managed to make the BB rather adorable. And really, that’s just the tip of the iceberg. It’s a narratively dense game, full of compellingly strange and esoteric ideas. Of course it wouldn’t be a Hideo Kojima game without fully realized characters and topnotch motion captured cutscenes featuring the likenesses of actors such as Norman Reedus (as Sam), Lindsay Wagner, Mads Mikkelsen, Guillermo Del Toro, and many others.

Graphically, this is arguably one of the most beautifully detailed post apocalyptic worlds ever presented in a video game with a wonderful variety of landscapes and a tremendous sense of scale (climbing a mountain in Death Stranding [i]really[/i] feels like climbing a mountain!). The starting area gives you a lot of ground to cover, but it's the second act where the game dramatically opens up. I have also found performance to be excellent in Linux running with Steam’s Proton.

I do have some criticisms such as the enemy AI being one step above brain dead and the wonky vehicle physics, but these are mere annoyances at worst considering everything else Death Stranding gets right.

It’s rare for an established game designer to try something so different. It’s even rarer when he spectacularly succeeds.

So, the Director's Cut adds quite a few small things in it that add up to being a nice package altogether. While I've played DS "normal cut" I've found that the new things added does make the experience a little nicer and a little more cohesive as a whole. The new areas are not that exciting but the new weapon and legs are super cool to use. Nothing wrong with a another side story as well. While the "normal" PC version was spectacular to play in the graphics and sound department the DC adds some worthy upgrades and even more music to the mix. 

Listen, at this point you either hated DS or loved it. I'm in the latter category. This game is like nothing else out there and offers an experience that is just leaps and bounds above anything else available. A LOT of people say it's a Fedex sim. Others say it is boring. I couldn't debate more. Sure, it's kind of like a Fedex sim but at the same time it isn't. There's a whole slew of enemies, objectives and stories that all come together in your travels to tie the nation back together. Getting to and accomplishing your objectives can be a hugely daunting task even with the tools you are given. I highly recommend NOT using a walk-through on your first playthrough as it will kill the experience for you totally. 

All in all, a different and fantastic game that isn't for everyone. It's a Fedex sim, a fps, and a whallop of a story for those that can and do piece it all together. I'm VERY much looking forward to DS2 and can't wait to see how Kojima further advances this story. I do hope he's listened to the masses and got rid of so much menu hopping but other than that, adding anything else to this already fantastic game isn't anything but a plus in my book. Also, Metal Gears are returning? They might be. We'll see......
