A masterpiece

This game.
This goddamn game.
It's remarkable. The graphics, the physics (mostly), the story (although 99% of it goes over my head), and most of all, the fact that other players can assist you on your travels. Oh, and pretty much all of its contents. But what's the point of me stating what this game has? How about we go through it?
The graphics. It's realistic, and although that isn't really sought after by everyone anymore, it still blows me away and I enjoy looking around me at the landscape while I'm running through it.
The physics. It's pretty much what you'd expect in real life (with a few exceptions, as in Sam grabbing hold of a rock, when actually his hands aren't even on it, they're just kind of floating in midair), like climbing mountains, steep hills, running down a steep hill, trying to regain your footing so you don't essentially roll down it, and climbing over rocks, it's amazing.
The story. Although it's pretty much spoon-fed to the player (which doesn't help with retaining information, at least for me), it's still quite fleshed out, despite how confusing it is.
And finally, the multiplayer aspect. The fact that other people can help you. I often find myself smiling when I load up the game the next day and seeing that some people have given my structures likes - it tells me firsthand (or... secondhand?) that people have used my structures and found lots of, some, or any use out of it.
However. There is one major downside, which does explain why there's a massive split in the overall reception of the game - positive or negative. I don't really see any in-between.
And that's because there's pretty much nothing to do when you're running around from destination to destination. The only thing that this game does to flesh out gameplay is just to press a button from time to time to balance yourself or shift your weight to the left or the right. And while it did keep me distracted at first, it did get quite tedious, quite quickly, which is why I always look for a generator to recharge my bike or my skeleton. I haven't finished this game yet - I've gotten up to Episode 12 - but it has been a wild ride up to this point.
Well, I may as well get back to it.
And here's some advice:
Careful, the contents are fragile.

Death Stranding is one of the most artistic triple-A games I have ever seen. The cinematography, the acting, and the atmosphere are all above and beyond what you'd expect from a video game.

Is this a game for everyone? No.
Many players may not enjoy the long walks and treks needed to complete missions, these require patience and focus; however, I find them quite calming and engaging. The game is centered around philosophical themes and has many levels of detail to the world it inhabits.

This is all down to personal taste but if you enjoy games that provide a reflective experience I would highly recommend buying them.

Well, what do I say about this, I installed this on my PC (good one, not the one I let my kids use!) and dusted off my old xbox controller (because I have the keyboard co-ordination of a drunk cat), found my favourite blanket and put my office chair in the 'recline' position. 

I am in love with this game, the open world concept where you can familiarise yourself with the safest routes, know when it is going to rain and know where you can find shelter. I'm quite proud that I have only died twice in my initial 11 hours playtime however, as an Assassins Creed fan (and completionist) I kind of knew this game was for me. Although Steam didn't recommend because I normally find comfort in Stawdew!

If you are unsure if you should try this game, I would just urge you to give it a go, it eases you into the game play, nothing hard came up in at least the first 8 hours which is plenty of time to familiarise yourself with the fighting style, the characters and the landscape. 

Overall, I can see myself trying to complete all missions, side missions and tidy the world of all of those lost packages for many more hours to come. Wonderful game that pulls you in and is hard to put down.

死亡搁浅也许会是我这辈子玩过的最遗憾的游戏，遗憾到对小岛秀夫由爱生恨的地步。俗话说万事开头难，但死亡搁浅却在开了个十足的好头后，又把一副好牌打得稀烂。

游戏中有数不胜数的优秀的点子和创意：堪称预言般的故事设定，新奇的游戏玩法，不落俗套的角色设计等等。这一切给我一种感觉，小岛秀夫想让人们承认，他真的很酷。但对细节的偏执带来的是叙事上的失衡。设定繁多但缺少逻辑，于是变成了世界观的描述的堆砌。找到艾米莉后，故事的节奏便彻底崩坏了。剧情被一股脑地灌给玩家，复杂却难称得上深奥，而且漏洞百出。再加上反派的塑造太过单薄，以及缺少对故事主旨的讨论，让游戏中的一切显得更像在耍小聪明，而缺少了更为重要的，宏大和深刻的叙事能力。另一方面小岛秀夫在游戏中无时不刻不在向观众展示的他的的幽默和品味，让游戏成为了一锅他个人风格的大杂烩。但人格特色若不能锦上添花，便是喧宾夺主，甚至变成不伦不类的恶趣味了。于是我突然明白一个“杨笠式”的道理：一个男人觉得自己最富有魅力的时候，在他人看来，也许就是最油腻的时候。所以归根到底，没有把故事讲好，便早已犯下了原罪。

我不会说我比小岛秀夫更懂死亡搁浅，但死亡搁浅本可以像异域镇魂曲一样探讨生命与死亡，可以像EVA一样探讨社会的群体性孤独，而这些议题都只在游戏中浅尝辄止。也许游戏仅属于制作者，玩家只能欣赏，而没有僭越的权利。它就像你小时候最想要的玩具，却属于其他人。你可以一起玩，却要以别人的方式来玩。死亡搁浅就是这个属于小岛秀夫的私人玩具。只能说成也小岛秀夫，败也小岛秀夫。也许他知道不能满足所有人的口味，所以在离开科乐美后便选择不再迎合任何人了。

I can't possibly begin to unpack this game in a review, so I'm gonna make it short.

This is one of the coolest sci-fi universes I've ever seen, and I think it's on par with Half Life and Portal in terms of lore and world-building. I love how the story is revealed to the player, and how it rewards you for paying careful attention to details.

Gameplay is gonna either be take it or leave it for most players. You'll either enjoy it or you'll need something more. I think if this is the kind of game you'd enjoy you're probably already aware of it.

Note: This review is for those who haven't played the game(although that should be pretty obvious as all reviews typically are). Death Stranding is not an action-packed shooter as most the game is a walking simulator with carrying things from point A to point B. But what carries this game to be a masterpiece in my view and probably many others is its story-line that was carefully crafted and executed magnificently. The only issue with the story is its mainly at the very beginning of the game and the very end but that allows plenty of time to familiarize yourself with each of the characters and learn of their identity and have a sense of purpose to finish through with the game. Also the visuals are gorgeous like in the range of Detroit: Become Human and because of its many realistic graphics and longer cut scene's it took 5ish hours to download(I have a decent computer setup too).

With that in mind, Death Stranding can be split into 3 distinctive parts - the past, present, and future.

The Past: Unravel the mysteries of who the people are around you to make friends as well as enemies and become more aware of your own past. Through the aid of others you'll also find out who the woman in red is, why you're carrying a baby the whole game, what the man donning a golden skull mask is doing, and much more. Death Stranding does an excellent job showing the past of the characters to be able to have them coincide together in a revised edition of a singular event.

The Present: Return America to its former unified state through the chiral network and link all the knots that were stranded back to link them all together. This obviously requires a lot of long distance walking as well as fulfilling orders for various equipment or otherwise that people might need as you play as a porter. But on these trips you'll find yourself trapped in BT areas, rough terrain, or in MULE territory all of which makes the journey tougher but provides for a more rewarding experience when you uncover more of the plot. 

The Future: As you connect the United States back together the future of civilization lies within you, as Hideo Kojima puts it: "Tomorrow is in your hands." This furthers the importance of your aid in the whole ordeal. So, can you piece together America again? Or will the future of civilization be in the hands of those who want it to end?

The characterization in this game is very, very good. If you stick to the main story, this could probably be a 25-30 hour experience. With exhaustive sidequesting, 50-65 hours. The storytelling is dynamic, unique and interesting. Making it through the first 5-10 hours is essential - they are the hardest to deal with due to slow pacing and the walking simulator mantra. Once you get more tools of your trade leveled up, the process of the game starts to make sense, and it transforms from a chore to enjoyable. It's not without it's BS, believe me. The vehicle control is horrid, and I've had multiple undeserving falls where I felt in control when I actually wasn't. This version of the game/ director's cut keeps crashing as well! At least once every play session this happens, where a lot of the rocky areas in the game shreds my PC performance. Overall, if you enjoy a longer narrative experience that is unique and has surprises, you'll find yourself immersed.

You are encouraged to get playful and treat the game like a sandbox and it works very well in the late game.

Very memorable story telling, performances and probably one of the best soundtracks. Kojima does it again! Very excited for DS2.

I don't think I've ever asked Steam for a refund, ever. This was a first for me. I hate having my time wasted. The gameplay is not fun and people saying it gets better after 10 hours in, no thanks! I tried after 3-4 hours in, 2 1/2 of those hours was straight cutscenes. I can see myself getting into the story and the characters but this frustrating micro managing type of gameplay got to me. I didn't think the gameplay was boring, but it definitely was frustrating imo. The game assumes I know what MULE pings are. I found out the hard way. Here's how that went. I'm on my way to deliver some rare metals. Oh look a metal pole in the ground, I wonder if I can interact with it. Gets up close, it's opening up. PING! I alert all the mules nearby not knowing what the f is going on and get attacked. I run away then tripped on some rocks near a river, damaged the rare metal packages I was carrying. It starts to rain. Some of the rare metals I was delivering gets washed and destroyed in the process. I close the game, uninstalled. Asked for my refund. I tried to like this game but I felt like I was being punished for playing Death Stranding Director's Cut.

This game is not for everyone, but I'm glad it's for me. Kojima's game is detailed and polished as always, the game is 10/10 for me, also for a person loves walking dead and cannibal, it's the best fan service they got, anyway you won't be disappointed if you are looking for smt deep and slow burn.

Played original, Director's Cut adds in-game features and new content; if you like the original you can appreciate new adds such as the Reverse Trike with carrier trailer which makes it more useful than Mule and Bridges trucks yet maintains bike versatility.  New road pavers seem included giving more flexibility to reach certain UCA/Bridges nodes, can also venture inside buildings on specific missions.  Multiplayer integration is a mixed bag; the benefit is some structures are shared like roads, others aren't until you unlock the chiral network in an area; net players also make useless structures and leave abandoned equipment all over the place however delivering net player packages to Bridges nodes speeds up game progression.

You either love this game or you are wrong. This game is excellent. I've never played anything by Kojima before Death Stranding but now having since finished this masterpiece, I am on the Kojima-hype-train. Most of the time when I finish a game I will let the credits roll and reflect on my time spent, and most of the time I will say, "Well that was fun. Time for the next game." When I finished Death Stranding I put my controller on my desk, watched the credits, and thought about how much of a wonderful time I had. I kept thinking about this game, I kept mulling over its details, and I kept wondering if I should immediately start a second playthrough. I love this game, and just as I was inspired to play it by reading the revelations someone else had, I hope someone else can see the spell I'm under and join along for the ride.

Death Stranding is a masterpiece, While the gameplay might not be for everybody, I implore you to please give the game a chance - just try to reach Chapter 3 before you make up your mind on the game. The characters and story are compelling, the landscapes are spectacular, and the soundtrack is hauntingly beautiful. It's one of my favorite games of all time for those reasons -- on top of that, I first played the game during the COVID lockdown in 2020, and it was just the perfect time for such a game to be played, a game about bringing people (and the world) together, even when you couldn't directly see each other face-to-face; a game about connections, about helping each other out, during trying times, and about doing our best.

11/10 wonderful game that brought me to tears more than once. It starts slow, but once it picks up, you'll be hooked, with question after question -- and the answers are worth your time. It might not be perfect to everybody, but it sure was perfect to me. Keep on keeping on!
One of the best games I've ever played.

This is an absolute masterpiece! Graphics are absolutely gorgeous, gameplay is addictive and the music blends in perfectly and makes it very therapeutic. I was very skeptical at first, and thought it looked boring, but I was completely wrong this game is truly a work of art!

Play this game if you enjoy being punished. As far as I can tell that's what this game is about.
It's long, boring, and repetitive. The UI is clunky and so are the keyboard controls. The story keeps you mostly in the dark until the last excruciating hours (and hours). 
The only sense of accomplishment I feel after finishing is that I somehow got all the way to the end without ragequitting. It did a great job of making me feel as exhausted as Sam Porter Bridges. It's never felt so good to uninstall a game so it's got that going for it I guess.

Okay, Death Stranding. I always dodging every opportunity I had to play this game in the past. Because I always thought that this game was not meant for someone like me. This game will only works to Kojima die hard fans that willing to lie to themselves, saying that they really like the game but in reality they hate it. They said that just because they love Hideo Kojima.

That was the greatest mistake I made in my gaming live. This game is the game that can make people love it even when the gameplay should be boring and repetitive. You go there get here to deliver. That's the main mission of the entire game. That's it! but somehow I love this game even more when I gone further deeper trough the map of future America. 

Every package was meaningful, every leftover package left by the other players I want to take it and deliver it. My first encounter with BTs is so intense, make me want to try it again and again. And this game give more option to face them further in the story. Of course MULEs was not really threatening at least so far, I don't know in the next episode maybe will be harder to face them. I also like how game make me face consequence in every mistake that I made and giving rewards in every good thing that I did.

I can't tell much about the story. I currently stuck in episode 2, because I really want to spend more and more time in this game. I want to deliver as many as the game can provide me. I want to make every connection become 5 stars. I want to expand my bandwith to cover the entire map. 

Death Stranding is one game that rarely produce. Maybe there will be no game like this at least in 50 years in the future. I mean, every developers sure can make game like Death Stranding. But I doubt they can make players fell like what I feel when playing it, if it's not Hideo Kojima the person who responsible behind the wheel.

If you're a gamer, you should play this game at least once in your life before you die. You don't have to finish it, just play it. Because this game is one of a kind!

I am so glad I gave this game a shot. It is one of those games that you can flip on a podcast to as you're trekking across the land, but it's so much more than euro truck simulator. It has multiplayer aspects like dark souls but taken to a whole different level that drew me in way more than I expected. I found myself spending so much time creating better pathways, upgrading structures and delivering other players cargo because it is so rewarding to see the equipment you laid down being used by others. The story is incredible even if it does get a bit shaky at times, but it is a very powerful analogy to the world today. I really am glad to have Kojima in video games because he really does stuff AAA games wouldn't touch.

I love this game. I already played it once on the PS4, and HAD to get the Director's Cut for the PC since I loved it just THAT much.

Death Stranding can be a highly rewarding and addictive experience, but it's definitely not for everyone. There's something everyone can enjoy (hiking sim? Obviously! Stealth infiltration? Gotcha! Just straight up beating and shooting people and monsters? You bet! The ability to hoard huge amounts of materials for no other reason than "it's satisfying"? It's in there! Virtual photography? Yes indeed!), but the gameplay loop is built, specifically, to be what I would describe as "harrowing". Nothing goes unearned. You're going to be stressed, irritated, and sometimes straight-up pissed off, but are rewarded in kind. Breathing a big sigh of relief as you crest a final hill or get past a BT area become their own rewards. It's... something special.

Being a Hideo Kojima game, the story is certainly strange and nebulous, with bits of his trademark corny humor sprinkled in. But it's definitely largely a "mood piece" rather than a typical narrative, a slow, contemplative experience where you will easily find yourself swearing at rocks, falling into a ravine (you WILL fall into a ravine), and punching tons of people in the face because you want their stuff.

If you're looking for a strange new experience, go ahead and give it a shot! Not sure but still a little curious? Wait 'til it's on sale! (You won't have to wait long, it's on sale A LOT.)

Because when you get into the game's rhythm, it sucks you in and doesn't let go.

Hate to say it, but this is indeed a good game. I keep coming back to it, doing optional side activities, reading every mail I get. I want to keep playing. Ever since MGS V, Kojima has made games that are actually fun to play, purely as video games. If a game can make you enjoy fetch quests, it's a good one. This is a good one.

Is it a great one, though? That depends on your tolerance of Hideo Kojima. His pretentious, on-the-nose style is woven into every fibre of this game. Woven, get it? With a strand! There's no subtelty to be found here. The game's themes will be forced down your throat, repeatedly. All the questions and contemplations are great, however. And I wish the game wasn't silly all of the time, so I could take it seriously more often. 

It's unhinged, artistically. As a game it's focused and engaging. Focused on its world, its message and a tight gameplay loop.

Kojima is a b1tch. But he's also a genius. 
Stupid, sexy Kojima.

It takes a while to get going, but once it does I can easily recommend Death Stranding.

Deliveryman simulator with online aspects in which structures players built may appear in your game and help you out in completing orders. More fun then I expected it to be and I'd say the game has some thick padding if not for the rewards you get for maxing a facility's connection level where some facilities just offer additional color options and holograms as more a consolation reward for going out of your way for this obscure facility which helps keep you motivated.

  There's a pretty long and rewarding progression system that at the start of the game you only have your clothes and the backpack on your back to aid you, but by the end of the game you'll be using vehicles, roads, exoskeletons, and lethal/nonlethal firearms with interchangeable ammo that simplifies your loadout letting you handle humans, BTs, and stronger BTs whenever wherever. Stealth vs mules/human is kinda situational and more of a taking them down from a distance without the rest seeing the body whereas stealth vs BTs is great and 100% fullproof as long you're patient and realize that you only see the BTs when your scanner starts flickering faster in a direction and you come to a standstill and look around which is when you'll be able to see them. You only need to hold your breath when you start getting within a meter of a BT which is when your scanner turns orange and starts spinning rapidly while your BB starts crying like a baby.

  What keeps you doing the next delivery and the delivery after are the rewards in the form of new tech or the next lvl version which improves on it making your subsequent deliveries a breeze or more satisfying as there's nothing like loading up cargo on your back and two floating carriers or in the back of your truck and delivering it. With each facility you max connection with you'll get a star that goes on your suit with about three total rows of stars to adorn yourself with.

  The only thing I had an issue with is how Kojima kept most of the the cut-scenes and explanations till the very end of the game for example there's at least 15 episodes, but the 9-15 episodes are the final stretch where you sorta locked in and have to complete the rest of the game and sit through cut-scene after cut-scene and about 30min long credit scene while they pepper in short cut-scenes while you run around trying to stave off boredom waiting for the next one. From episode 1-9 your mostly out and about completing orders unlocking new items with occasional short cut-scenes progressing the story. Your reward for sitting through all those cut-scenes at the final stretch is that you finally get to find out the truth of the Death Stranding and who Cliff is.

DEATH STRANDING is an excellent game that offers a unique and immersive gaming experience. The story is well-written and thought-provoking, with compelling characters and a unique setting. The gameplay is innovative and enjoyable, with a focus on delivering packages and surviving in a post-apocalyptic world. The graphics are stunning and the overall atmosphere of the game is immersive and captivating. The replay value is high due to the ability to play through the game with different playstyles and the inclusion of a multiplayer mode. The multiplayer aspect is a major highlight, as it adds an extra layer of depth to the game and allows you to connect with other players. Overall, DEATH STRANDING is an excellent game that I highly recommend to fans of the genre or anyone looking for a unique and memorable gaming experience.

I played the original on PS4 and got a few chapters into it before I put it to the side mostly because of other games coming out and not because I didn't like it; I loved the game and I'm a super big fan of Kojima's games. So when the director's cut dropped on PC I wanted to try the game out once more and have been enjoying the game so far. It would be nice if I could delete saves on the game since they do pile up a bit but that's a minor gripe and this game's main gameplay loop won't be for everyone as it's a glorified walking sim with delivering packages so if that isn't your cup of tea at least watch the cutscenes to experience the wonderful story.

Edit: I've since beaten the game and my earlier statement still holds true; it really is a great game that makes you feel so immersed in the world with every thing you do. From picking what tools you'll need for your journey to the beautiful music that plays at specific parts to accompany you on your trek to the amazing acting from all the main cast (Amelie, Die-Hardman, Higgs, and Mads' characters being particular stand outs). It makes you think about the connections you foster in the world with others and what your impact means to them and their impact on you as well. Big recommend!

What an amazingly beautiful game 
This has to be easily in the top 5 games I've ever played 
I was completely gripped by the story, and just found it so interesting how they slowly flowered the story, and kept adding little hints, and mixing in more and more crazy cool concepts and ideas that made it so great to dig at, delivery by delivery 

The best moment I had, Was pulling a hover cart across a snow mountain and a blizzard just blowing around you, pushing through past all the BT's and then finally pushing past it all, to see the the vast green hills beyond, and i had a perfectly timed music drop, that I've had on repeat for the last few days. it finally all just hit me at once, how damn peaceful this game could be after doing something crazy hard.

Even after all this time, seeing some of my friends on steam's buildings they placed down recently and using their markers felt so cool.

I've seen some of the reviews for this game, talk about how bad the driving in this game is.
If you're only driving in this game, you've completely missed the point of it.
Life before death. Strength before weakness. Journey before destination.
Use your damn legs, you got all these upgrades for a reason, you have all these cool building tools, and items like Zip lines, Catapults, Ladders, Climbing ropes, Buddy Bots AND so much more. and you're just going to skip out on all of that by using a truck?
The trucks and bikes are meant for quick straights, but trying to drive it up a mountain and getting upset your truck is handling badly in the snow is honestly just such a joke it's insane.

I'm 100% picking up the 2nd game when it comes out, and feel like such a fool i didn't pick this up on first release, seeing everyone discover and build new and cool things, before routes we're mapped out perfectly for zip lines and catapults.

Do yourself a favour, pick this game up.

Кодзима отметил, что развлечения не должны вмешиваться в политику и быть оружием войны, но при этом творческие проекты способны менять мир.
 
Кодзіма зазначив, що розваги не повинні втручатися в політику і бути зброєю війни, але при цьому творчі проекти здатні змінювати світ.

Kojima noted that entertainment should not interfere in politics and be a weapon of war, but at the same time creative projects can change the world.

Tr;dl Not recommended - not enough walking.

Ok. So, everybody was afraid about the 'walking simulator' part of DS. It's great: route planning, choosing equipment, the whole walking mechanic - I really wished for bigger maps with more complicated terrain, and for more... you know... walking...
So as proof of concept of 'walking game' - yes.

BUT:

1. The Kojima guys projected one of the most boring and unresponsive driving physics systems. It’s like driving in GTA III, but GTA III was released in 2001. From some point using vehiclesis is a must. It is faster + you can't just grab 2000kg cargo on your back, so unless you want to make multiple trips back and forth, a truck is the must. 

2. Plot is just a big mess. With a great start and I really enjoyed the concept on paper... but it's bundled with the most cringey dialogues ever. I heard "I’m Fragile but not that fragile '' just too many times...

3...And then It's becoming an Evangelion pastiche. I think that it's trying to be like Evangelion, but without understanding why Eva was fun (Maybe well written characters?!). So it is just surreal and overcomplicated. In the end The Message is like "killing bad".

4. Boss Fights - This game has the worst boss fights I have ever seen. Lategame fights are not hard. They are LONG. Those guys can take like 16 rockets so take your time. They are slow, undangerous but with a billion HP, so not too much fun.

5. The straw that broke the camel's back for me was the moment when at some point the game gives you THE CHOICE. And gives you CONTROL OVER hero. And THE GUN. But there is no choice: Character I tried to kill... had no collision for bullets. You have to be a Good Guy Who Never Chooses Violence. And you know, power of love/friendship etc. And in the dialogue a second later I heard: "I would never hurt you". Really?! I just emptied a pistol magazine into your face!
Like, I know how storytelling works. And if it would be in cutscene - I'm fine. I get it - it's the character's choice. But if you're giving me control and you’re saying that it's such a crucial decision... THEN LET ME MAKE THE DECISION.
[spoiler] I mean killing Amelie, could save the world for the cost of my and her lives. Fair price. After emptying the clip I tried to kill her in melee combat, but hitting her triggered an emotional hugging cutscene. BIG LOL [/spoiler]


Verdict:

You want a good post-apo transport centered game, with nice views and ruined infrastructure? Buy Snowrunner.
Want a weird japanese game with strange ideas and a twisted plot (and where the plot is well executed)? Play Nier.
Want a psychedelic story, which is full of metaphors? Watch Evangelion.
lots of new stuff!!! Very sad story I love it!

I was kind of off about buying the game since it came out.  People always released clips of the vehicle traversal of land and falling over with packages.  Didn't seem fun.  I was wrong.

This game has captivated me more than any at the moment.  The package management and delivery system based gameplay is insanely fun...  Imagine why other simulator type games are fun - and Kojima put that into a genuine third person, shooter, adventure climber, existential, open world environment.  It's honestly the most fun I've had.

Then there's the like system.  Getting likes while single-handedly rebuilding America, knot by knot.  I got addicted to rebuilding infrastructure - and then the quasi-"multiplayer" system really makes the game much more fun.

The storyline is unlike any other and keeps you thinking while you can't sleep in your bed, staring into the ceiling.

Honestly the game might not be for everyone - but for those who enjoy beautiful landscapes, dark and captivating storylines, familiar faces, and a whole new style of walking game play - do buy this game.  Well worth it - especially if it's on sale!

Hideo Kojima was someone who is pretty famous (and infamous), mostly for Metal Gear and some other Konami, and being one of the people who can easily recall the Metal Gear timeline in one go, and since DS2 got announced, I thought i give my thoughts on Death Stranding, which I happen to love a lot, I'll split this into sections: you've got Gameplay, Music, Story and closing thoughts, with that settled let's start with music, as that's a vital part of Death Stranding

Music: I love it, mostly because it's experimental in a way, I like how it can go from the horror movie style soundtrack from Ludvig Forrsell to the smoothest and relaxing sounds from Low Roar, as a Writer that is doing stuff for VRC Roleplays, i've found music like Low Roar to be more of where I get some of my ideas to pop out, overall 10/10

Gameplay: I'll be honest, I like the gameplay but even I know there's a bit of a problem with the driving, lemme explain, Imagine this: you've riding a motorcycle to say, Die Hardman's office in Central Knot City, you've managed to avoid BTs and MULEs trying to kill you or take your packages, you're getting closer and then a small pebble from nowhere stops your motorcycle right on it's tracks, Tl;dr: loved the walking gameplay, shooting could be better, Vehicles could be done a lot more better. 7/10

Story: Loved it as well, remember when I gave Music a 10/10? the story is also why, certain scenes along with the music fits so well, as for the dialogue, I liked it, along with the characters, Fragile and Higgs being both my favorite characters, now normally, I could try making a non-spoiler synopsis for this game to get you interested, but I've seen that it's a little tough in a sense, so if I were you, give this a try, it may not be for everyone, but it could be for you 10/10

Closing Thoughts: I've become a fan of Hideo mostly because of MGSV, I know, sounds interesting, initially, i thought it was just a cool story, but when I checked the whole thing for Metal Gear, I got Invested, so truth be told, I also became interested in Death Stranding because of it, now I'm here writing this review to say, give this a try, if you don't like it, that's fine, at least you gave it a try and gave a opinion.

[h1] Kojima did another masterpiece <3[/h1]

This game is truly fantastic, I don't know what did kojima smoke to imagine all this stuff to end up with a product with such cohesion and such a beautiful message, but hey I want that too XD

[b] Walking as the center of the game [/b]

In all seriousness this game is mechanically amazing, yes is a walking simulator, but it literally is a walking simulator like no other, usually that term is used pejoratively against a game which revolves across exploring, but in case of this one, the entire game is about walking, the way you interact with the terrain is something no other game has done before, the way Sam interacts with rocks, how balance and weight matters is something that grounds the experience a lot, is insane how they made the game tedious and fun at the same time, and that is made through the amazing cohesion of gameplay and narrative.

[b] It's story: a slow burn that hooks you slowly [/b]

[i] The world and humanity is near extinction and you (Sam Porter) need to save the world by delivering packages to help others. [/i] Yeah, is a simple premise but the execution is amazing, yeah the cinematics are long, yeah the game has [b] horrible menus specially [/b], but once you enter on that loop on delivering, on thinking how is the most effective way to reach your destination, creating structures and receiving likes by the people you've helped after finishing a mission, is what makes the game an extremely rewarding experience. 

The game is essentially a world divided by a catastrophe and the point of the game is connecting with others via the  chiral network, but the amazing thing is that it happens in the "real world" too, the players that also are playing or that played death stranding will leave structures and tools on the map as if all of us were in the same journey together, everyone that puts a bridge, a ladder, a rope, or a bike on the map will appear on other players's worlds, creating this beautiful scenery were it shows that we as humans leave a mark on this world in one way or another, and even if those marks disappear at the end we made that journey easier for someone else after us, and honestly is such an amazing feeling to put a great generator or a great bridge on a river and receiving likes from other people knowing they needed it too, and at some point you will put stuff just for the sake of helping others, is a genius piece of art. 

The story is full of  double meanings, of ways to show you that we are not alone, that life is easier if we try to get through it together, and that's done completely via gameplay, is simply beautiful. This is an absolute modern classic.

Thank you Kojima for making this game and RIP to Ryan Karazija, the lead singer and composer of Low Roar, thanks for sharing such an amazing music to the rest of the world, you will be missed </3

I hold Death Stranding DC very dear to my heart.
I may have ""only"" played it for a little over 100 hours (the base game for around 70 to add to that), but i would still count it towards being one of my favourite games of all time.
The gameplay is so engaging that you can't ever look away from the screen for even a couple seconds unless you're standing perfectly still. And standing still costs you precious time. Finish that delivery and go to bed instead.
There is always something going on and if there is a more calm moment happening the game will remind you of how gorgeous it looks and how well it feels to play.

Death Stranding feels like you know whether you like it or not within the first couple hours of the game. After about 3 hours of cutscenes and worldbuilding you are basically set free to do what you like. That is delivering packages sometimes as seemingly unimportant as someone's old newspaper collection. But even though it should feel like those things are trivial and unimportant the game makes everything have a purpose. So you chug along. All by yourself. It gets lonely out there and no other game i've played makes you feel truly alone like Death Stranding does. You start taking in the nature more, you appreciate the detailed and well-crafted terrain and you start remembering the optimal routes if not for the paths you leave behind.

The controls will feel weird at first but you'll get used to them very quickly. The gameplay and how you approach deliveries changes dramatically with progress made and the tools you unlock along the way. The combat can be clunky and hectic but that's all on purpose. You aren't military, you are a guy who didn't even want to do this job in the first place. But it's you or no one. The game can be silly at times but it'll always be at the right moment. Sometimes it gets awkward but that makes it feel real if the actors being real wasn't enough for you. The score is gorgeous as well even if it's not my kind of music at all, it just fits. 

Never have i been more immersed into a game world and i don't think anything will ever top this. In my eyes it's an absolute masterpiece and everyone should at least try the first 5 hours. No other triple AAA game of the last 5+ years gets even close to this amount of polish and love put into a game.

Oh, and bring a controller. Please.

[h3]Handle with care[/h3]
It should go without saying, but [u]this review will contain spoilers[/u]. However, all said spoilers will only be what is revealed within the first two hours of the game. It's impossible to speak about the premise and mechanics of a game without letting a little slip out. You've been warned, if you want to go in blind, read no further.

——————————

[h3]“I'm Fragile, but I'm not that fragile”[/h3]
So what the heck is Death Stranding anyways? Is it [i]really[/i] a walking simulator? To me, Walking Simulators are games wherein the only interaction you have with the world is just that, walking. In Death Stranding, it's anything but.

Primarily, you'll be taking orders from facilities, choosing a route, managing stress, stamina and conditions of gear as you traverse the environment. But let's not to get too far ahead of ourselves; the game throws a lot of terms and phrases at you right out of the proverbial gate. Terms like Chiralium, Timefall, Voidout, Cryptobiote, DOOMS, Bridge Babies, BT's (Beached Things), “Beach” as a location otherwise not presumed by its name, Repatriate, even the phrase Death Stranding itself.

All of these things matter — so here's the gist of the premise:

You'll play as Sam “Porter” Bridges, you deliver packages to and from distribution centers and shelters around what used to be America, now called the UCA or United Cities of America. While trucks and motorcycles are in the game, they are not always a feasible means of travel due to the Death Stranding, a nearly apocalyptic event that brought the dead back to life. Well, sort of — it brought Beached Things into the real world and the surface is effectively uninhabitable because of them. Did I mention the rain also ages you and anything it touches? That's the Timefall, any precipitation actually. 

More to the point, Sam is a Repatriate and he can die, go to a beach, and come back to life. Trust me, that makes sense in the lore. Without telling the reason, a reluctant Sam Bridges is convinced to re-connect the UCA and expand the Chiral Network, that's the Chiralium, a metallic substance left behind by Beach Things in the real world. Used to essentially explain all the high-tech, nearly magical things in the game. And that's as much as you need to understand going in.

Between the environment itself, the beached things and gear management, there's also people out in the wild that live off of stealing cargo from porters, some orders will have you entering their camps to steal it back.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2904510746

[h3]”Everything is true, except for the lies.”[/h3]
The game features a number of aspects from other games, it's always online, the gear you leave behind gets shared with other porters, lost cargo can be picked up, delivered or entrusted to another porter. You can even leave signs on the ground like Dark Souls. That said, due to the timefall, structures also degrade over from exposure.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2904510754

You're also able to share resources to build larger structures, watchtowers, timefall shelters, generators and bridges.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2904510738

Fun Fact: Death Stranding uses an evolved version of the same engine that Horizon: Zero Dawn uses — it is not the FOX engine from MGSV.

[h3]"My body may be present but my soul is on the Beach, I'm already dead."[/h3]
Death Stranding is, as expected, a highly narrative title. But it's MUCH, [i]much[/i] more than a simple walking sim. A term likely adopted as a endearing term, once used as a pejorative. 

I would actually liken this game to Spintires or Mudrunner/Snowrunner but with a story. A [i]very[/i] big, epic story.

[quote]If you've found this review helpful, consider following my curation — [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28295405/]Station Argus[/url][/quote]
It's good to watch the landscape while you relax on the cliff.

This is a fantastic game that is a bit hard to classify. It is part time a intriguing detective/mystery story about what caused the apocalyptic event known as Death Stranding with some stealth and infiltration action every know and then. The BT enemies are creepy and almost gives you a Lovecraftian vibe, while the mules and terrorists is more like the standard bad guys. The other part is essentially a hiking simulator where you mostly trek through rough terrain (reminded me a bit of Iceland) to deliver things. The driving is also pretty fun and should not be underestimated for casual fun. 

It is a slow paced game but very atmospheric and especially the music is splendid. Some songs really hit like a hammer to the emotional core when you unlock them as you descent to a new location or do some other special thing. The actors are good and delivers really good performances, especially Fragile and Heartman in their backstories, but the best performance is probably Clifford Unger and Die-Hardman. The entire mystery and backstory of the BB is very fascinating and captivating and kept me playing on just to know how it all came together. The final mission where you unlock BBs theme is probably the hardest cargo to carry in the entire game, but such a crowning achievement for the long journey of Sam and BB. 

To wrap up, fantastic game that I can strongly recommend!

Story is weird at all times but insanely immersive! oh before i forget this the music is 11/10! spend 30+ hours on the Directors cut with an already 30+ hour imported safe game. Give the game a chance! Ignore the DHL sim memes and bring the UCA back together!

Even though I knew so much about the game and what I was going into, I still wanted to give death stranding a chance... to see if all the dogshit mechanics and unbearable gameplay would eventually translate into an enjoyable experience. The answer is NO. It will never be an enjoyable experience (Unless you find a zipline and skip the entire game).

I was being optimistic at the start. I was telling myself I could handle all that crap if the story would be worth it, and I was preparing myself for a good review. But believe me when I say this, death stranding will crush your soul and test the limits of your patience.

The gameplay of death stranding -as you may probably have heard- is complete bullshit. So I really don't want to delve into that. Although I ought to mention there is a satisfying and addictive feeling of building roads and bridges for your fellow gamers to help them escape this game as quickly as possible.

The story, on the other hand, is Kojima on drugs. The game punishes you for playing the game with an insane amount of exposition dumps, explaining things you heard million times and yet somehow managing to be completely meaningless. The story-telling formula of this game is, explaining every single teeny tiny detail through millions of cutscenes and expecting the player to understand them all. I still have a headache just talking about this. I finally understood why people called this game a movie, as it had at least 10 hours of cutscenes.

Talking about movies... I feel like the actors/actresses should've won multiple academy awards for coming up with incredible performances. Considering that their dialogue is one of the worst scripts I've ever witnessed, they deliver a shockingly perfect performance. I can already imagine your confusion from reading this. However, when you see actors/actresses deliver horribly written comedic joke lines as if they are the most emotional things they say, you will eventually understand what I'm saying.

In the end, astonishing actor/actress performances are all that death stranding has. Their great attempt is the only thing that holds the story together, and I assume that's the sole reason why some people actually enjoyed the story. Other than that, the whole experience is just tedious. 

I love Kojima and his creative vision, but I hope he learns his lesson from this game and makes a less infuriating death stranding 2.

I went in hoping for an interesting game and story, but Death Stranding fails on both fronts.   

On the gameplay side, I couldn't help but compare DS with Ancestors: Humankind.  In the latter game, you control a lineage of apes and try to evolve them into mankind.  That involves lots of terrain challenges, and using your senses to find the things that help your tribe exist for another million years.  Ancestors is very involved in learning how to control your ape, and how to balance your risks, rewards, and understanding the environment you explore.  To put it shortly, Ancestors is simply better at challenging your judgement.

Where story is concerned, it is pretentious in a way that is boring and hamfisted.  Again, my mind wanders off to a game that handles vague delivery far better - Lobotomy Corporation.   The narrative is focused upon suffering and redemption, managing to harmonize the narration and gameplay together to help impress an atmosphere upon the player.  Your failures are brutal, with employees dying in numerous ways, all the while you curse your inability or misfortune.   The music ramps up in despair as you lose control, and the cries of man and beast alike will echo - until there is no more man.  That silence is pain, as it marks yet another defeat.

Death Stranding, on the other paw...well, it just doesn't feel interesting.  I cannot emotionally nor intellectually connect to the situation, as it feels incredibly artificial and forced.  Kojima wants me to feel things, but there just isn't anything to bridge the gap.   I normally enjoy slower-paced games and the idea of building a community - but it feels so very hollow in this game.

Combat and stealth both feel very...blunt?  Unlike the excellent Thief or Styx games, the stealth doesn't challenge my eyes nor ears.  Beached Things are essentially landmines that you may or may not be able to see, each one having differing levels of visibility, durability, and reaction.   The way the camera and bottled baby work can sometimes make it hard to pinpoint the BTs, so they can suddenly pop up.  Worse, emptying a clip into one might not work.  STALKER did a better job with their paranormal hazards, as you can't defeat them - and more importantly, things were more based on your experience rather than luck.    

When it comes to combat, I often find that grenades can trivialize human foes.  Blood grenades blind them, shock simply knocks them flat.  The danger of the enemy comes most from the camera being too close, preventing me from seeing them approach from my side or rear.  Provided I can see them, victory is pretty likely.

It is unfortunate, but Death Stranding's greatest merit is that it will allow you to kill time by going through the motions.  While I hope the sequel can improve things, my recommendation is to spend your time and money on something better.

Conclusion. Great to play, extremely addictive, but all put together it is an immense waste of time.

I recently finished playing DEATH STRANDING DIRECTOR'S CUT, and I was taken aback by how amazing the game is. From the captivating story to the stunning visuals, this game is a one-of-a-kind experience. The atmosphere is incredibly immersive, with a haunting soundtrack and stunningly detailed environments. The cast of characters is incredibly strong and engaging, and the many complex themes explored make for an unforgettable journey. 

The gameplay is also incredibly well done, with a unique sense of freedom and exploration that allows you to play in your own way. The various missions and tasks you complete along the way give you a great sense of progression and accomplishment. It's easy to get lost in this game and its vast world. 

Overall, DEATH STRANDING DIRECTOR'S CUT is a phenomenal game and one of the best titles I've ever played. I can't recommend it enough. After finishing it, I was left with a profound sense of sadness and emptiness. Despite being incredibly satisfied with my experience, I found myself struggling with post-game depression. The game had left me with a feeling of loss, as if I had lost a part of myself in the process. It's a testament to how powerful and moving the game is.

Oh yea, delivering packets through slippery mountains, for a like, is actually fun. A big part of this game is similar to the Dark Soul's messages, but fully fleshed out and made a core feature. Through the lense of that co-op gameplay; this explanation really captured why I think I got hooked: "Kojima doesn't want us to suffer, he wants us to help others suffer less" - Unknown.
What an experience, what a visual orgasm, play it!

I should start by saying, Death Stranding is not for everybody.

I played the Original for well over 200 hours on PS4, obtaining all Death Stranding achievements. Making it one of my all time favorite games. Now, with the release of the Director's Cut and the announcement of Death Stranding 2, I thought I'd give it another go, this time on PC.

Death Stranding will let you play as Sam Bridges, portrayed by actor Norman Reedus. Who you might know, from AMCs The Walking Dead. Sam is a delivery man who works for the Bridges Cooperation. A company formed after the collapse of the United States of America.
He is asked by the UCA, short for United Cities of America, to reconnect the fractured society America has become.

In this post-apocalyptic world, strange creatures known as "BTs", somehow appeared on earth and are now looking to devour anyone in their path. Along with other adversaries, they act as obstacles for Sam to overcome, in trying to deliver packages and complete his mission.

Death Stranding is a surreal, interesting, very deep game, one of the most developed games I have ever played. The story, the characters, the visuals, the voice acting, music and landscape are all 10 out of 10.
this really is one of the games of all time

Amazing, I've never spent so much time on just one game. Death Stranding may not be everyone's cup of tea because it does require a lot of patience. But there is so much more you can do aside from just fallow the story. I like to help build roads and steal mule's cargo for more material. Throwing a number 2 poo poo grenade at your enemy is quite the laugh as well. The story is confusing at first but comes together by the end with a couple twists. The like system is a welcome mechanic as well. Building roads really boosts your likes. As you can see I've played for nearly 150 hours and I'm not stopping anytime soon. This is probably my favorite game.

Way better than the internet memed me into thinking this would be when this first came out.

Don't get me wrong. At heart, this is LITERALLY fetch quest: the game. 

I think there's this weird underlying ASMR kind of element to it too. I never considered myself the type (I don't really get into those yt videos), but I find myself vibing out to this game more than I thought would.

There's a lot of exposition and forced cutscenes in the first 10 hours, and it comes across as somewhat self indulgent. But after that, the game opens up, you're able to skip all the repeated content, cut scenes become fine again because story progression cools off (especially if you go for a completionist approach before checking off new story beats), and you're given more tools and freedom to approach the game as you see fit.

One aspect that definitely surprised me, even after seeing it mentioned in various reviews, is the sense of camaraderie and reward you get dropping traversal tools probably mainly for your own benefit, but you get to see if other players use them and that's pretty nice, as well as using traversal tools that others place that happened to be just where you needed them. 

Deep diving into that, it's because if you were to play the entire game grinding your own mats for your own tools, it would SUCK. It would be slow and plodding. I couldn't imagine playing this game entirely offline. Holy crap. You have no idea how many player-created generators, umbrellas, bridges, ramps, ladders, etc I've used so far. More than I'd like to admit, I lost my vehicle due to being impatient or straight up not careful and was happy to find another vehicle someone left out in the open as a backup option. If I had to build and place those all myself? AEUGH.  

So the game is clearly designed to leverage the contributions of entire servers of players to make fetch quest: the game a seamless experience. For me, it works.

In my case, I got addicted to the underlying online route-building aspects. If you find yourself getting into building and maintaining the super highway that you'll find a bit after getting into the second map zone, it takes a lot of mat grinding and ferrying, but you get to see how often other players end up using it (super often). Combined with the pit stops, generators, cargo-maintaining super umbrellas, and all the other knicks and knacks others leave along the way and among the many side destinations, it all just somehow comes together.

In terms of story, I don't have much to say, mostly because I barely understand what's happening on even a basic level. Um there's a yoshi's story mechanic where if you're too careless, mario cries his ass off. That's about all I've got. There's FFT where you need a phd to understand and articulate the various machinations and motivations of all the characters involved and how that influences the histories, written and untold, of Ivalice, and then there's Death Stranding, which is, being perhaps too generous here, comparably incomprehensible but for entirely different reasons.

I dunno, in the ~55hrs I've played so far, maybe I've sat through ~4-7hrs of cutscenes, so I can't imagine getting too mad about it. The last time I was over invested in a story was when I was 14 and thought Halo: Combat Evolved had some life-changing revelation waiting for me at the other end of the game. It's not worth it to get that invested. I'm here to just vibe and chill.

So overall, yeah, definitely a recommend from me. A hard recommend?.... nah. A very cautious recommend, but if for you it clicks, damn it clicks.

[h1]Do you like games where the narrative carries the experience?[/h1]

If the answer to that question is "Yes", Death Stranding is going to be a good fit for you.

Immersive, almost movie-like, cutscenes with a rich world and story being built up by a great supporting cast. Animations, voice acting, and VFX are solid through the entire experience. The gameplay on the other hand leaves something to be desired, unless you have a strong sense of accomplishment, love of exploration, and "going it alone" (kinda).

The game is single-player with an online aspect that is rather unique. Each player has their own world, and through online play people's structures, like bridges, generators, shelters and more can become populated into your world. By interacting with, liking, and repairing others structures you become more closely linked to that other player, making more of their structures and your own structures show up in each-others worlds. It's a relatively simple solution to a pretty large map.

Yes, let's get the awkward part out of the way too, the game's main focus is delivery of packages and thus creating and connecting each new way-point into a massive network. Your goal is essentially to bring America back to full communications, as the game's events will show you how they were devastated. The game's main danger are BTs, super natural entities that will seek you or any other living person out, and create a massive explosion, killing everyone and everything in their vicinity. --- Sometimes these encounters are thrilling and eventful, sometimes they can be a huge annoyance, but it really depends how you approach and tackle the problem. 

Overall, I think this was a wonderful product. I am glad I waited for the Director's Cut because they added a lot of Quality of Life things to the game, and in my opinion these things really help with the experience.

As a side note be aware that there are a lot of short cutscenes for just about every action, so if skipping repeated cutscenes over and over annoys you beyond belief, this game may be a little taxing on you.

Definitely not for everyone, Death Stranding is one of those games that's extremely memorable for all of the right and wrong reasons. Engaging story and game play, with a middle act that stumbles before taking off again. There are missteps in the games writing at times and the driving is bugged beyond belief; for whatever reason though it manages to chug along as this sort of semi-relaxing, semi-intellectual work of art. If you like experimental projects with a AAA budget then Death Stranding is probably up your alley. If you want something more traditional then this is definitely not going to be the game for you. Death Stranding manages to be a 3rd person shooting, stealth, horror, action-adventure hybrid and it does a pretty good job of combining these genres together into something wholly unique. 

I wouldn't call this a walking simulator either. The planning and traversal is the game play. It's actually pretty involved and every time you get a understanding of how it works - Death Stranding throws another set of both tools and obstacles in your way to re-contextualize how you engage in that traversal. You're not just wandering aimlessly from point of interest to point of interest like in a traditional open world game trying to find the interesting content. The traversal is the interesting content. It really does make you look at other open world games differently and realize just how wrong they've been doing it this whole time when it comes to travel, traversal, etc.

Despite the very bad tonal dissonance between gameplay and story (that makes Death Stranding feel like a pretty good game that comes preinstalled with a bonus movie you can watch in between playing sessions) I actually really enjoyed this game.
While it's basically two completely different elements that often struggle to play off of each other, I found the gameplay fun and the writing (despite being somewhat tropey and awkward at times) was written well enough to keep me interested.
It's also worth mentioning how good the soundtrack and acting in this game are, they're two elements that often go overlooked in game development but it's very clear that a lot of effort and thought went into both here.
If anything, Death Stranding at the very least deserves praise for trying to do something different in today's overly standardized AAA industry.

I've tried to write a huge review on this game three times now, I've spent nearly two hours on this and I think I'll just write a short little thing here.
I mean, there's so much to discuss and talk about, the world Hideo created is so vast and massive in its lore, story, setting and everything gameplay-wise, this could be a 2-hour long video, but won't be.

The style and design - top notch. Not a single qualm with any of the equipment, buildings, structures, vehicles (except the shitty race car). Enjoyable to look at.
Equipment management and traversing the lands is great. I love route-planning and trying to pack up as less stuff with myself as possible, keeping in mind the weather, terrain and everything else that might cross my path.
If I forget something or run out of something, there's just a means of going the longer path, but there's always a way.
Love the setting - unique and harrowing. Instead of going for simple over-used enemy types, I'm learning the best ways to deal with those weird-ass BTs.
I don't know what happened, but when I got the BB at first, I was like 'Uhh, why is this weird baby thing attached to me...' and half-way through I'm like 'Aww, Lou loved that jump I performed with the Trike, sweet'.
The story itself didn't really take turns that I completely didn't foresee, but it was good and a generally alright wrap up at the end. It made me love some characters and really hate some others.
Cliff - easily my favorite character.

[i]'You can be my Mario and I'll be your Pricess "Beach"'[/i] -  when I heard that, I swelled up inside of myself, physically and mentally. I hate to use the word, but that was [b]cringe[/b]. The scene that followed didn't help either, it was weird and off-putting.
Character names. Really? Guy with heart thing - Heartman. Guy who doesn't die easily - Die-Hardman. Guy who is a Porter and makes bridges (both literally and figuratively) - Sam PORTER BRIDGES. Come on.
These are placeholder names.
Sometimes I felt I was stuck in bad pun and dad joke land.
For some reason I just couldn't connect with Amelie. Maybe it was the acting or something, but even when she was saying all these sincere things, It still felt like she's gonna stab me in the back, never trusted her for a second, since the start.

Anyway.
Hideo presented me with a great, enjoyable game that made me feel a sense of accomplishment and also some emotion, weather is sad, dreadful or joyful at times.

Will come back to gain more stars on the thigh through he infinite two weeks before inauguration

I've heard some people say the game only gets good a few hours in, but I don't think that's the case at all; if you don't like the game at the start, you likely won't like it any more later. That being said, I do believe Death Stranding to be one of the greatest games I've ever played: I found the gameplay to be incredibly fun (which is weird considering it's a walking simulator), which combined with the beautiful environments makes for a really really good "vibe".

This may be a boomer take (even though I'm 20 lol), but I think the people who don't like the game are just way too impatient. Simply walking from one place to another is one of the most zen, relaxing things I've ever experienced.

Furthermore, the gameplay manages to stay really fresh throughout the whole game, it actually gets quite complex. New gameplay elements are constantly being introduced, even though the game is about 40 hours long, which means (for me anyway) that you never really get bored. The fighting system, while I do think isn't as fun as the walking, is actually very complex, sometimes maybe a little too much. It heavily ties into the cargo/inventory aspect of the game, which means you have to keep yourself from falling over while fighting off multiple enemies. It can get quite overwhelming, so if you struggle with multitasking you might have a bad time there.

One of the things I love most about the game (apart from the whole game itself) is the multiplayer and permanent upgrades you can apply to the world. I found the roads, though quite tedious to complete, to be especially rewarding. There's just something really satisfying about "upgrading" your world, in order to make it more easily traversable. While I do not recommend fully completing the roads, as it probably isn't needed, it's very fun to zoom from one end of the map to another in record time with a truck.

Speaking of which, the vehicles in this game are awesome. One might think having trucks and bikes in a game where walking on harsh terrain is the core gameplay would make the experience too easy, however using them (trucks especially) can prove to be almost as challenging as walking, as they can easily get stuck, or fall down holes. This means you have to carefully consider whether or not you should use a vehicle, and which one. The map also greatly helps in that regard, as its 3D aspect shows you the kind of terrain to expect on your journey.

Finally, I want to quickly talk about the story. I never truly loved any of the characters/voice actors behind them, and when I started playing I didn't care at all for the story. However after a few hours they started really growing on me, and the whole story became really engaging, though very bizarre. That being said I did think it became almost too weird toward the end, and maybe a little too pretentious. I liked that each chapter focused on a specific character, it made you appreciate characters that were previously just kind of "there".

I could probably talk about this game for hours, but this review is plenty long already lol. Overall I would probably give this game a 9.5 or above. Though it's been a while since I played it I can't really think of any problems I had with it (expect maybe like I mentioned earlier some aspects of the combat, and the later parts of the story).

TL;DR
This game is amazing, it's relaxing at times but can be complex/difficult. However don't play it if you are an impatient gamer, it is quite a slow game (which should be obvious as it is, at the end of the day, a walking simulator).

[i]Review based on the original release with 131 hours of playtime.[/i]


[h1]DEATH STRANDING... a game that I spent way too much time in it![/h1]

[h1]A little warning... this game is quite bleak and depressing at times. Be in a proper mindset before playing this?[/h1]

[h1]LOW ROAR... just wow this band!!![/h1]

[b]This is not your usual gaming experience that you get out of the many games out there. There are some action at times but don't expect a METAL GEAR SOLID gameplay. DEATH STRANDING is mostly about carrying packages from Point A to B... to C... back to A... all over the world map. The overall feeling I've got with this game is pretty mixed but more on the good than the bad.

This is a game that you can't just play an hour or two and have the overall impression of Death Stranding. The unfortunate part is DS momentum picks up around the 10 hour -ish timeframe and the story unfolds better. Which in that case, you can't rush this game. You can skip rebuilding the roads and the many expeditions/deliveries to have the maximum star level at each settler and just focus on the story... that way, I'm pretty sure you could finish the game under 30 hours. In my case, I wanted to reach the maximum amount of stars for every settlements but the last one called THE LAST PREPPER p!$$ed me off way too much since he's located in such a b!tchy area, on a mountain peak... and it is very slippery. Rare is a game that really frustrates me but oh boy the snow mountain area is VERY annoying.

Without dragging on too long (like what this game truly does), here comes the PROS and CONS.[/b]


[h1]PROS:[/h1]
[b]+ADDED CONTENT FOR THE DIRECTOR'S CUT VERSION.
+OUTSTANDING GRAPHICS, VISUALS (character models, the game world... this game LOOKS truly good).
+Voice acting is on a master level.
+Many funny moments with the characters. (quite needed in this overall depressing game).
+AMAZING SOUNDTRACK (both the music score and the tracks from bands).
+Soothing gameplay at times. (rebuilding the roads was kinda fun... so was creating building to help you and other players out in the overworld). 
+Frantic gameplay when fighting/avoiding BT's (ghost-like beings) and MULES (human terrorists).
+The game story has a a good message about connecting yourself with others and not just technology.
+CYBERPUNK 2077 extra mission/dlc are pretty fun to do and nets you some cool CP2077 gear (Johnny Silverhand aviator red glasses & cybernetic arm, V's cosmetic facial cyberware and the "Akira motorcycle". There's holograms that are added from CP2077 as well.)
+Good UltraWide 21:9 monitor support. It is not perfect since it is not the true 3440x1440p resolution but 3360x1440p.[/b]


[h1]CONS:[/h1]
[b]-PAID UPGRADE for the Director's Cut. If only the Director's Cut was the original PC release since Steam removed the original version, hence removing my review from that version.
-Playing as a UPS/FEDEX guy can get tiresome.
-Too many cinematics! Usually, I love sitting around and just enjoying the story while taking a little break after a long gaming streak but dang at times, it does feel that Hideo Kojima seems overrated. Death Stranding pretty much feel like a movie. I'm sure he'd do well in the movie industry but yeah... the cinematics in this game are often and very long.
-Story is convoluted and doesn't make much sense most of the time. It is a bit hard to follow and unfortunately, it opens up only around Chapter 5.
-The story drags on way too long. Too many cutscenes and when you think the game is over... it ISN'T! It just drags on and on...
-Game controls are very ABYSMAL at times. Especially whether on foot or on vehicle on the snow mountains.
-The game is mostly stable but I did experienced a nasty game breaking bug that is still not fixed to this day. I've got that crash to desktop near the TIMEFALL FARM settlement. The only workaround that I read somewhere (and it worked for the whole game afterwards) was to reduce the amount of MEMORY FOR STREAMING. Put it on DEFAULT and that should fix your game.
-The BT's are quite annoying at times. When you can't avoid them, you get dragged on and "forced" to fight a boss. The big irritant is when that happens, all cargo are unloaded from your vehicle... AND damaged. Gah! More irritating is the frickin' "bosses" respawns all the time.
-TIMEFALL (rain that degrades objects and some lifeforms over a short period of time) is a neat concept but the degradation is annoying and quite illogical. It doesn't affect the grass nor main settlements buildings but it does for all built structures, roads and humans? WEIRD!
-Can't listen to the soundtrack while driving or while simply walking around. It only plays at Level 2 buildings or in your safe house. It do plays at specific fixed time in the story also. I would've loved to have somekind of "walkman" and listen to any song you like at any chosen time.[/b]


[h1]OVERALL:[/h1]
[b]One of a kind for a game. Honestly, I do think I spent too much time in this. At least 30 hours more than needed and that burnt me. The overall experience of this game is relaxing, fun, humorous dialogues with main characters, depressing and very sad at other moments... fighting MULES and BT'S while listening to a great soundtrack.[/b]


[h1]RECOMMENDATION:[/h1]
[b]I wish I played this Director's Cut right away but Steam removed the original version from the store. In order to keep my review visible, I had to upgrade the OG to DC.

With that said, I recommend you give it a shot while in a big discount, like 50% off! The main gameplay is pretty much the same from start to end and storywise, it unfolds more at around Chapter 5. The game has 14 official chapters (with a "hidden 15" for continuing the missed deliveries, maximizing the star level for all settlers and whatnot). This is entirely optional and can be skipped.

Will I replay DEATH STRANDING? Highly unlikely. I played all that I wanted to play. 

I do plan to play the just announced sequel from The Game Awards 2022!
Hopefully, it'll explore more the world and fix some irritants from this game![/b]
The game is for story telling gamers.  I would not expect someone to enjoy the game if they prefer FPS or puzzle games.

One of the best games I have ever played. Anyone who is a big fan of Kojima needs this game. I have spend hours doing the standard orders (side quests) until I had to force myself to continue the story-line. You could totally just spend all day running back and forth to each delivery spot. 

The soundtrack is brilliant, Kojima did a fabulous job getting the artists to provide their songs for the game. The artwork is great, beautiful scenery even in an apocalyptic era. I just love this game. Lol, not really helpful I guess without giving away spoilers.

Dislikes: Not so much a dislike as a tedious job within the game, you may get bored of this part of the game easily. It takes a lot of time to make structures like roads and bridges plus the amount of materials required to do so. Some don't need much at all, some need a huge amount. I guess due to their location and timefall area. 
HOWEVER, if everyone contributes as much as possible as often as they can, it will be completed a lot faster. And it does make getting around quickly easier. Still 100% recommend this game.

[h1]"Joe this is just a walking/UPS simulator"[/h1]

Well... [b][i]yeah[/i][/b]. That's the story. [b][i]But there's just so much more[/i][/b] in between that makes this an amazing game. You'll likely spend over half the game confused, trying to figure out how it all fits together and the last half everything starts making sense and understanding your role in all of it. There are tons of bits and pieces of lore you find around the world and in emails/interviews but none of it is necessary to understand the story, it just adds more to it!

The multiplayer aspect is incredibly clever [i](I'm a simple man)[/i] and I think it encourages a positive team working aspect that I haven't seen in any other game. Someone uses and likes the bridge you built, your score goes up. It encourages experimenting with streamlining the process of delivery. If the things you build  are useful for you, it will be for other players and I love that. I really would have liked to see a Mario Maker style system where you could create unique challenges and missions for other players to attempt.  

I wish they made deliveries a bit more unique though. There are several deliveries with special conditions such as [i]avoiding submerging a package[/i] or a package that needs to lay flat. However it felt like they just forgot about it. You never really see any of them. 

The only other criticism I have is the lack of some sort of "MP3 player". The game has such a unique soundtrack, but the only time you hear it is at key moments in the story, or if you're resting in your room. I was convinced it was just an oversight and would be added to the Directors Cut, however that did not happen. Sure, you can just play the soundtrack over the game, but I'd rather it be in the game. 


[h1]Absolutely worth your dollar. If money's tight or you're still on the fence about the purchase, I believe the game is available on Xbox Game Pass [i](however it is not the Directors Cut)[/i].[/h1]

I always heard about the famous Hideo Kojima, but never actually played any of this game, and by "played" I mean really engage with any of them, I did play a bit of MGS V but that was kinda of it. 

Death Stranding is another story, I was already really intriugued when the trailer came out,  and even more when it was revealed that it would be a package delivery game, it sounded so ... boring... But I sensed it was more than that, and I was not proven wrong. 

There is no secret by now this game main gameplay loop is delivering packages under some conditions, either quantity, condition, time limit toward the end you have temperature sensitive cargos. On your way you will meet various obstacle BTs (some kind of ghosts), MULES and DEMENS (humans), and of course, the environement : hills, rivers, mountains, ruins, cliffs, it's your job to circovent those obstacles or just go around them. And during all of that you often have to combat timefall a rain that wears down your equipment and cargo. 

It's so interesting the number of systems that Kojima productions and its team has managed to put to make going to point A to point B an interesting activity. 

Beautiful and really well optimised graphics, you can play on the lowest setting and it will still look very good. 

The story is really interesting, but it's very complex if you look too much into it, if you just decide to accept what the story says, it will make much more sense believe me.

A truly unique and amazing gaming experience. Genre-defying and skepticism-worthy, Death Stranding takes a player through one of the most beautiful and complex stories along with a refined gameplay which makes the game totally worth enjoying more than once and taking it 100%/full completionist.
Hideo Kojima has shown the world what he can do and he wants to give us, truly a genius, endeavoring and fearless master of his trade.
Although it can and will be frustrating for even the most hardcore gamer, it quickly falls into place becoming an enjoyable experience for any casual player through a slow paced learning curve, while putting the player leading a plot transcending time and space; life and death.
Finally a game that can be considered and accepted as Metal Gear Solid V: Phantom Pain's spiritual successor, either in gameplay, story-wise, or as an entire new legacy to unfold as years go by. The easter eggs and soundtracks perfectly combine.
Visually it's perfect, a stunning game, either in massive landscapes, gear and weaponry, or the characters' design. Soundtrack is perfectly chosen and orchestrated as well as voice acting, all the actors are to be congratulated for what could have been a movie industry blockbuster - who knows, maybe it will someday. Core game mechanics truly make Death Stranding an enjoyable, repeatable and lasting journey.
Falls short one just one aspect: player customization.and vehicles. Weaponry, accessories and tools are more than enough, but there could have been more suits and clothing, as well as more vehicles, maybe a 500 LoL mission bonus aircraft - as the PC version's cross-over content of Half-Life and Cyberpunk kind of fill this gap perfectly, along with the Horizon perks; though it's always the same suit, truck and bike, we get used to loving the simple color/cross-content offerings.
Worth playing, replaying, fully completing the preset achievements/trophies, finishing everything there is to finish, and even the goals we choose to fulfill as our own objectives. It is meant to be a solitary experience and totally manages to play out this goal while giving birth to the Strand system where we feel connected to other fellow players while we explore the Bridge Link part of the game.
A perfect, flawless, unique gaming-cinematic experience that calls out for continuity - Hideo Kojima has hinted a sequel through a concept-teaser, it will be well received, at this point, a full fledged standalone expansion would also be welcomed.
Nothing else would have been expected from Kojima Productions, not to be seen as the end of a rich and masterfully loved legacy, but as the establishment of a decade-long dynasty in video game industry.
A must have for all kinds of players, give it 40 hours or 400 hours, as you please.
