Death Stranding is a game about exploration, discovery, planification and efficiency.
The feeling of accepting a new order where you have to deliver an extremely delicate package to someone who is 5 kilometers away in the top of mountain who needs the content to save his life is insanely attractive, immersive and exciting. 

This is how making orders work in DS, first you accept the order in a terminal then if you don’t want to encounter many inconveniences you will open your 3D map and check the terrain you are going to walk through for the first time and know nothing about. This terrain is going to be challenging for how wild and untouched by humans it is, then you check the route you THINK will be the best to take in order to deliver the package successfully and start thinking in what you will need for this trip. Maybe a couple ladders and a climbing anchor will do, you never know, what you know is that you cannot carry everything you want because you are not experienced enough at least for now to carry more weight and you lose stability pretty easily which could ruin the package completely. In this game there are not infinitely large pockets like in the rest of the games out there, in DS everything you decide to carry will occupy a physical place in your bag and suit affecting your stamina and balance. Once you have decided what to take and what to leave your trip starts and be prepared to experience what to me is the most beautiful terrain I have ever seen in any video game and be also prepared to change the route you though you would take for reasons I don’t want to spoil.

Yes this game is slow, don´t expect one more mass produced shooter when playing DS but if you take your time and adapt to the pace it is designed to be played this game might be in your top 10 by the time you finish it.

No spoilers but in case it feels slow just go through the main missions until chapter 3 avoiding secondary missions. In chapter 3 the game opens up and you can go back and do everything you left behind in a much more entertaining way, I don’t want to get into details but the progression in terms of tools and player upgrades are insane.

If I had to say something negative about DS is that the bosses are easy (I haven't tried the new very hard mode yet) and the story at times feels too complex and there are too many dialogues (which you can always skip). Also the ending of the game is a bloated mess, when you are ready to finish playing and the game keeps implying the game is going to end it will keep throwing boring cutscens at you like there is no tomorrow for 4 hours plus a couple of extra mission that you will probably not enjoy anymore.

Even with its downsides DS is in my top 5 video games of all time for its creativity, how beautifully crafted it is and the original approach that makes going from point A to point B a wholesome and challenging experience.

edit: I am so happy to see the reception that this game is getting over time, this is one of those titles that will age like fine wine in peoples minds making them appreciate it more and more.

About 20 years ago this'd be called an "expansion pack" because that's what it is: it doesn't add anything crucial to the base game but what it does add tend to make the investment worth it, depending on your preferences.

As for the base game itself, I wish there were more games like this with constructive, indirect co-op, it changes how the game feels fundamentally. While superficially it remains a singleplayer game, I can't tell you how many times another player's generosity helped me out, which is the kind of gift you can thank by passing it on to others by being generous yourself. In an industry driven by parasitic greed, it is a breath of fresh air to play something driven by symbiotic generosity.

The term "walking simulator" despite being considered somewhat of its own genre on par with "souls-like" and other such terms, is often seen as derogatory, denoting a game where there isn't much to do besides walking around. And yet, strictly speaking, most games we call walking simulators are not correct to be labeled such - they do not simulate walking any more than any other game, you're still just pressing one button to move.
It is the wacky adventures of Norman Reedus and his funky foetus, however, that really opened my eyes to this. Death Stranding is, by its nature, a walking simulator, but unlike the rest it does actually simulate walking (in the sense of general on-foot traversal) with unprecedented nuance and depth and I cannot help but applaud Kojima for taking the most boring type of quest and activity a game can have, making the whole game out of just that and yet making it fun.

Can science fiction be mixed with the paranormal? Probably. But only the genius of Kojima's imagination can do it so seamlessly and coherently. Death Stranding is one of the most underrated games in recent years. Wrongly considered by some as a “walking simulator”, it’s an original masterpiece, which has created a new genre. Hideo Kojima, one of the greatest game developers of all time, could have easily made a fanservice game to satisfy the fans of his iconic games. Instead, he risked to create something completely original, which has never been done before. A game in which you cooperate with other players without ever physically seeing them in your playthrough.

You are trying to unite the people of an isolated part of the world. You embark on a journey where you traverse eerie, but wildly beautiful landscapes. Make no mistake though; Death Stranding is a game which includes equal amounts of action and meditation. Yes, you walk back and forth, carrying cargo. A lot. Sometimes you are left in your own thoughts while taking in the scenery around you, atmospheric music playing in the background. But this is a very welcome break. Because the game gets so intense, you will be on edge all the time. During your playthrough, you will fight armies of terrifying ghostly entities as well as hostile humans, with a diverse arsenal of weapons and vehicles. The controls are responsive and everything is done seamlessly as soon as you learn how everything works. Thankfully, the Director’s Cut adds a number of quality of life updates to gameplay, with the most important being an automatic distribution of cargo on your body, for optimal balance.

The story, lore and characters are very well-written. The plot revolves around the worst dystopia imaginable, brought forth by a cataclysmic event that keeps happening and has brought humanity on the very brink of extinction. Death Stranding makes the player think and introspect. It does so with symbolism, but mainly through contrast. In fact, the game is truly a dance of opposites. The landscapes are immensely beautiful, however the mood is severely depressing. You feel a deafening loneliness in your journey, yet you are helped by equipment and messages that other players have placed in the world. Your journey progresses slowly, yet there’s rain which makes time pass rapidly for everything it touches. As the plot goes on, the player is transformed along with the protagonist - from a cynic into a humanist. The game ends in the most beautiful way possible.

The soundtrack is captivating. It’s a perfect fit for the game’s atmosphere. It appears at the perfect moments, adding not only ambience, but a feeling of catharsis. Included are brilliant artists, such as Low Roar, the Silent Poets and Ludvig Forssell. Visually, the game is as stunning as it gets, with no graphical issues of any kind. Optimization is surprisingly good for lower-end machines. On medium and high-end machines, it runs smoothly on Ultra settings with a steady frame rate.

Death Stranding is undoubtedly one of the greatest and most original games ever made. Made by one of the most brilliant minds in the industry. A bright example that videogames are art. I hope anyone can experience it and have as much fun as I had.

15.4 hours in at time of these comments. Purchased on sale during the November Holidays of 2022

Overall, nice looking game. It's a Kojima game, so I expected a mostly cinematic experience with lengthy cutscenes, but there are even more cutscenes than I imagined. At 15.4 hours in I think around 3 solid hours of that has been getting interrupted and nagged by tips, voice messages, cutscenes ,and tips which are answers to questions that I didn't ask. And question and explanations I did want answers to were left to me to try and solve alone.

There's no way to reduce the volume of the music, or other common kinds of gameplay options permitted in probably more than 90% of extant games in today's market. Maybe this is okay if you like the music, but mostly I found it to be distracting and disruptive to the immersion of the game.

Part of the game play is establishing a network connection to unify various geographic regions. Doing this allows placed objects like bridges, ropes and other structures placed by other players to be visible and accessible by anyone playing the game. The trouble with this is all the traversing work has been done by other players so I really did not find myself needing to do much of anything on my own to progress through the game.

The UI for depositing and obtaining cargo at destinations, as well as the UI through most of the game is clumsy, time consuming, and non-intuitive. I am wondering if the director stressed that things in this game be new and unprecedented over stressing that they be usable or fun.

I'm the sort of person that enjoys Car Mechanic Sim, Farming Sim, Viscera Cleanup Detail, and other unconventional and non-standard or mainstream games. I thought this might be an interesting game, and it definitely seems like it's outside-of-the-box concept could be for some people, but for me, this game plays like a nagging time-sink full of interruptions, long uneventful grinds, and without any meaningful or amusing actual game-play or necessity to solve any problems on my own.

It seems there is a somewhat interesting game here that some people seem to like, but I don't think it's for me, and I don't know anyone that I can imagine enjoying this. Your mileage may vary.

Death Stranding is a package delivery focused action/exploration game with a narrative about reconnecting a fractured and isolated community following an apocalypse in the near future. 

The gameplay is very physical, you don't just hold forwards to move to new areas but instead have to constantly think about how to move through the very detailed environments with your heavy loads. The gameplay loop of taking on new deliveries to connect new places is very compelling, as is the crazy story. 

The Directors Cut includes a couple of small additions, if you've played the original, this version is almost the same.

Great recommend, one of my favourite games of the past few years.
Keep on keeping on. P.S. Controller recommended for the open world stuff.

In the first 2.5 hours of games I counted more than 1 hour of cut-scenes. If they were interesting I would not mind though, but it's mostly "the world has become dark and mysterious and strange", and overall they hardly make any sense. It feels just like Mulholland Drive, which some people like but I hate. If you are patient enough you eventually get to a phase of interactivity. It doesn't last very long, and it's mostly a glorified follow-the-beacon boring chore, which nobody fathom when most AAA studios do it, but when it's Kojima it's "an entire new genre, an experience you can't even begin to explain". And then you're back to a 20 minutes "cut-scene". Also the user interface is downright infuriating. It alternates between not enough information and too much information, it's a real joke. The graphics are very good. I'd refund it but my brother wants to try it.

Death stranding review (Spoiler free)

Coming from someone who likes everything Sci-fi and weird shit, Death stranding was perfect for me, and while yes the game play of just walking can turn a lot of people off this game, I'd say if this game looks interesting to you or you have Xbox game pass, you should try it as the connected world system and story/lore were some of the most unique things I have ever seen in gaming.

 I really liked the fact that Death stranding did not put an emphasis on combat (though it is a flaw I will mention later) as it allowed for a more focus on the game play loop, walking, and to add on to that I do not think this game is just a "walking sim" as there are many elements to manage while walking (terrain, durability, just to name a few) as well as there being elements of stealth and combat that I wont spoil. 

The walking itself can feel very cinematic during story missions when your sneaking past enemies or you can see the destination in sight and then suddenly a licensed song starts to play, The soundtrack for Death Stranding is one of the best soundtracks I have ether heard, and I have never remembered a game that kept me listening to the soundtrack for long time and time again.

That said there are some flaws with this game that I will warn you about, while yes the walking can feel cinematic during story missions, beyond that your further enjoyment of it will depend on how many or little upgrades you have, what the terrain is like, or how much time you spend on side activities. another flaw I mentioned previously was combat, on PC at least, the gun play does not quit feel right, melee controls are placed in a confusing position, personally I'm conflicted on it, at best combat is enjoyable at-least when the environment is integrated into it, but I do feel like Kojima productions should improve the combat in a sequel because even though combat is not a priority in this game, that doesn't mean it should be bad. Finally I do have to mention that this game does take some time to really get going, but this should not really be a problem unless you only play First person shooters.

In conclusion, despite combat being flawed I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a unique gaming experience or thinks this game looks interesting to them,

Death Stranding is a walking simulator with action. Sure, there's fights against BTs, there's missions to infiltrate the camps of MULES and terrorists, there's the big boss fights where you use rocket launchers... But the vast, vast, VAST majority of the game is about finding a way to get from point A to point B across rocky terrain and rivers and snowy cliffs. But at the same time, that is also the challenge - literally balancing Sam's cargo, trudging along a river to find a shallow spot to cross, taking cat naps in assorted small caves while you wait for the rain to stop... 

And, of course, that entire aspect only lasts as long as you've not hooked up local shelters and cities to the Chiral Network, as once you do that, hoo boy does that Social Strand system come into play, and the landscape becomes littered with bridges, ziplines, signs, vehicles, and all sorts of other useful things constructed by other players.

It's a slow game. The cutscenes are many and long. It can take upwards of 10-15 minutes to get from the bottom of a small cliff to the top of it (and less than 2 seconds down when you fall off it). And it is gorgeous for it.

The weird, surreal tone of Dying Light 2 Stay Human combines very serious end-of-days themes with silly characters and minigames that have you smacking zombies off a skyscraper with a cricket bat is bizarre, but somehow it works extremely well. This zombie-smashing action game is a strong post-apocalyptic adventure with top-tier parkour movement, an expansive open world in which to put them to good use, and lots of great characters. What doesn’t work so well is how it combines a near-lethal case of bugs with a story centered around a protagonist so uninteresting that he’s all but (un)dead on arrival. I’m sure that when the developers at Techland set out to make this sequel they had no idea that they’d end up releasing a game about a global pandemic two years into a global pandemic, but it’s clear that trying to finish such an ambitious game under these conditions didn’t do it any favors.

Sticking largely to the plan laid out by its surprise-hit predecessor in 2015, Dying Light 2 takes place in an excellent, highly explorable city where the rooftops are home to eccentric survivors who have become masters of parkour, scavenging, and chopping zombie heads off with assorted sporting equipment. By day the zombies swarms crowd into buildings to hide from the sun, and by night they pour into the streets in daunting masses, but the real tension comes from managing the terrifying meter that counts down to you transforming into a brainless shambler. Like nearly everyone else you’re infected with the zombie virus, and staying in near-constant contact with UV rays is the only thing delaying the inevitable. The ever-present need to recharge that meter – which will deplete in a matter of minutes if you’re inside a building away from the light – is an excellent addition to Dying Light’s moment-to-moment gameplay that keeps up the pressure on every step of your journey.

It's with sadness that I say "Don't buy Director's Cut". Play the basegame and you won't miss anything.

1. Missed the great opportunity to make a portable music player, for example as an endgame mission.
2. One of the biggest content is the race track, and driving is still quite junky.
3. Achievements, one of the only drive that helps to play the endgame, are bugged since at least 9 months.
4. I wish the interviews and emails were voiced. Maybe voiced only in your room, by a "AI voice".
5. Sometimes I get casual bugs, such as vehicles on top of zip-lines... 
6. This might just be me, but among all the things added in the DLC, there's nothing that really stick or it's "game changing". In short, there's nothing like the zip-line to travel.

If you like slow-paced, full of cut-scenes with brief moments of action games, please play this (base) game. It's a masterpiece. But don't buy the Director's Cut, it's a missed opportunity.

This is definitely not a game everyone will enjoy, but if you like a slow burn sorta mundane experience with a world that grows with you, this may be a game for you. The story is pretty bananas, but it is interesting seeing how twisted it up and how warped the world is and seeing how the people who live in it have adapted to it. The main gameplay loop is really just running from point A to point B and potentially dealing with obstacles in between, whether it's bandits wanting to steal your cargo or ghost like entities that can drag you into a boss fight. Things get easier for you if you take the time to build structures such as bridges or zip lines to traverse the landscape, allowing you to bypass struggles that you may have dealt with in the past. Your structures may also show up in another players world, or vice versa, so receiving "Likes" gives you a nice sense of helping someone out on their journey.

After 133 hours, I've 100% Death Stranding and completed ≈400/500 Premium Standard Orders.

There's no other game like Death Stranding. I consider it a masterpiece. You are a "Porter" whose mission is to reunify the world by connecting unique preppers, cities, and distribution centers. The online component comes alive once you complete deliveries to gain the trust of these areas. Immediately the once deserted, destroyed, and dangerous area you traveled is full of online equipment and vehicles to assist you in the future.

Death Stranding completely captures the idea of teamwork and friendship, though I believe it can only be truly enjoyed online. Being able to help other players by building a generator in a remote area is something you can't do in offline.

My only negative feedback is about the vehicles. For a game with unmatched technical gameplay around carrying packages and navigating/climbing rough terrain (show, mountains, rivers, etc), the vehicles are horrible. If you bump a tiny rock your vehicle comes to a complete stop. You can tell they intended for vehicles to only be used for the highway roads you can construct, and not for off road use.

As much as I love this game, I freely admit that it is probably not for everyone. You may see other reviews telling you that this game is a "Walking Simulator". This is not a lie. The vast majority of the game experience is exactly that. Taking package(s) from one place, to another, often on foot, often on uneven terrain. In mid-game you get access to roads and vehicles. But many of the late game destinations, are in mountainous terrain requiring you to once again fall back to good old foot travel to get the job done. You will be doing a LOT of walking in this game. 

This is an experience you are likely to love, or hate. 

Then there is the story. The story is . . . WEIRD. It is a strange horrific dystopian future which you find yourself in. The story is told well, with good acting, and is quite enjoyable, if you don't find it too strange. This again, is an experience you are likely to love or hate.

Death Stranding is not for everyone. If you're looking for an action adventure game, you'll be sorely disappointed.
This is more akin to a puzzle game for how I see it: they tell you where you need to go, and you need to figure out a way to get there safely, without falling, while managing your stamina and items. Your reward for making it, is that you'll have the solutions found by other people show up in your game, so you'll be able to skip a ravine by crossing a collectively made and maintained bridge, for example.
Death Stranding is hauntingly beautiful in its deserted landscapes occasionally crossed by other delivery men, and peppered by the traces of other players passing through the same experiences you did, suggesting shortcuts, safe places to rest, and peeing everywhere.
I love this game. My only problem with it is that by the time I've unlocked the whole map, my OCD makes me fixate on completing all the deliveries and rebuilding all the infrastructures, so I get focussed on optimization and grind, and I forget to just relax and play the game and have fun with it.

Some people might call this a "walking simulator" or similar, but they mean it in the most complimentary way possible. The gameplay really does (mostly) consist of going from point A to point B, it makes this your primary challenge. Figuring how much you can carry in cargo and how much in tools, if you can keep it balanced easily or not, what routes you can actually travel along safely or if you want to risk one that's harder to traverse if it gets you there quicker. Makes for a central gameplay loop that that really stays interesting a lot longer than it might sound like at first.

Remember when your parents used to say: "Don't look directly at the sun, you'll go blind"? You can change that to: "Don't try to play this game, you'll go autistic". Why would you call someone Diehard Man? I dont know, im not on the spectrum.

"This isn't a game for everyone."

And we see why there should be more games like that.

Because when you get "niche" games or very unique games, if you like them then you're really going to like them. Make less games that try to appeal to everyone but fail to be outstanding, more games like this.

The core gameplay loop of Death Stranding is deceptively simple. You go to a location, you get an order, and you deliver it to another location across the map. Along the way, you will navigate increasingly hazardous terrain, feral delivery men, nihilistic genocidal terrorists, and the tormented souls of the undead who wish to eat you and then explode.

Oh, and rain and snow rapidly deteriorates everything.

There will be a number of tools to accomplish this, and gaining better tools will feel extremely satisfying as your deliveries get easier. If you like this gameplay loop like I do, you will find it weirdly addicting in how much fun it is to navigate hazardous terrain in that Kojima way of dozens of systems and weird interactions all meshing together so that you have numerous ways to accomplish any given task. Sneaking around, avoiding and or subduing enemies and ghosts is satisfying and rewarding from the man who put stealth games on the map. 

The game world is beautiful and detailed.

The story? This is the part of the review where you might be expecting me to say that the story is the weak link.

It isn't. The story is one of the more hopeful-in-the-face-of-something-horrible stories I have ever seen. In an extremely bleak world, you'll see the capacity for human good. Tears will be shed, hope will be gained, and you'll see every aspect of this game being top tier.

No, this game isn't for everyone. There is the possibility that you just won't like the core gameplay loop. That's fine. 

But if you're like me? You'll love it and this will be one of those games that really meant something to you, and that you'll remember forever more in your list of "damn, that game was incredible".

As a lifelong Metal Gear fan, this is the greatest game made by Hideo Kojima. Innovative gameplay with a twist on asynchronous multiplayer, combining the polish, detail, and subtle humor you can expect from Kojima. While the story is complex, it can occasionally be a little predictable, at least if you're paying attention. Like Metal Gear Solid, stealth here is also optional. Despite the route you take to solve the problems the game throws at you, every choice is rewarding; however, don't confuse this with the game having story choices, the ending is the same no matter what order or how you choose to complete quests. There are some long cutscenes, but nothing not to the point of being obnoxiously unbearable such as Metal Gear Solid 4.

The best analogy that can be made of this game is it's a road-trip simulator with a focus on planning and preparing for the journey. I don't know how many people have that itch which needs scratched, but this game scratches it. It is so much more than a "walking simulator", which simply does the game a disservice. A lot of the game's mechanics revolve around delivering packages, but preparing for and reacting to the obstacles of that journey is what makes this game both heavily rewarding and potentially niche.

I would go so far as to rank it a masterpiece, with the caveat that you're a fan of Kojima's work. This game refines Kojima's formula, and I am very much looking forward to what Hideo Kojima's new studio produces next.

So let's start this with the obvious: Death Stranding (DS) will not appeal to may people, even if they like Kojima's rather odd stories (which is in abundance here!). That's fine though, as long as you know what you're going in for before purchasing, which I did and I really enjoyed my time in this game (both original and the Director's Cut). 

In DS you play as a postman named Sam Bridges. However in a world where most people are isolated in protected settlements, the humble postman is a cherished profession known as a Porter. The game plays somewhere between Metal Gear Solid V (MGSV) and Euro Truck Simulator (ETS), with you ferrying around cargo across a variety of landscapes in 3rd person using tools such as ladders and ropes to help you get past lakes and mountains. Sometimes the controls can feel a little janky though, as the smoothness of MGSV controls aren't quite there. Most missions will see you laden with your cargo, after which you must balance it on your body (or vehicle, later in the game) and then plot out a suitable route to the destination to hopefully deliver the goods without damaging them from the tricky terrain. Occasionally you will encounter MULEs (thieves) and BTs (semi-visible ghostly enemies) that you must stealth past, or take on using combat methods that you unlock a little later in the game. The combat is easily the weakest part of this game though.

There is something very cathartic about delivering packages to settlements in need, but the game also focuses heavily on the themes of connection. This is seen through players being able to construct buildings such as bridges over rivers, which appear in another online players game's. You can also entrust your cargo to these other Porters, share vital equipment & resources with each other, and even helpful leave signs pointing out hidden paths or dangerous areas (similar to Dark Souls messaging). The story also focuses quite a lot on trying to reconnect one-another, which is eerily relevant given the state of our current world.

So basically, if you ike Kojima's eclectic ideas and find the idea stomping over some grasslands, rivers and mountains to take someone some scrap metal, then this is probably worth the price of admission. If you only want an interesting delivery game like ETS, maybe pick this up on sale.

Is Death Stranding a game about walking? Or is it a game about exploring the social and personal ramifications of an increasingly distant world where people can only interact through remote communication, and the means by which we may forge new bonds without throwing away the realities of the modern world?

It's the former, it's about walking. And it's REALLY good at it. Death Stranding has the best walking simulation in any game and it makes the simple act of delivering a package from one location to another incredibly engaging. It's the best postman simulator since Fallout New Vegas.

As someone with limited time to play I'd probably not recommend to someone in a similar situation.  Its a bit of a time sink. Story is weird but OK, not a must play IMO.  Gameplay is actually not that bad.  Lots of silly wordplay names for no particular reason. Not a bad game just not the best.
Amazing game!!!

Underneath the kooky Kojima wackiness that we all know and love is a satisfying gameplay loop, a surprisingly moving story, and some powerful acting. The nude scenes with Mads Mikkelsen and Norman Reedus are iceing on the cake.

Small pro and con list :

Pro:
+ Ingenious atmosphere
+ Incredible freedom
+ Interesting world and characters
+ Very good graphics
+ Good control in which you can show a lot of sensitivity
+ Hideo Kojima!?
+ Well-known actors ideally chosen for their roles
+ Novel online concept in which you can benefit from all the players and they from you.

Con:
- Very long ways
- Very cryptic story that can only be understood by reading deeply.
- High frustration factor especially in combination with Con 1.
- MULE's partly annoyingly penetrating
- If battery empty, then battery empty.

Conclusion:
Ingenious game for people who like the somewhat different kind of Kojima's storytelling. For me one of the best games I have ever played, I can only recommend it to everyone.

The gameplay itself is amazing. Before buying, I was worried that it would be boring, but the mechanics of travel is so fun that I left the story to do side orders a lot of the time. The gunplay could be improved but honestly, it's not bad and there's not a lot of fights anyway.

The story at first seemed a bit too convoluted, but in True Hideo Kojima fashion, he manages to make it make sense at the end. 10/10
I love my walking simulator.

Death Stranding... what can I say about this one?

It's a beautiful game, visually stunning.
Player models during cutscenes are superb. Seeing Die-Hardman near the end of the game gave me actual chills and hope the actor was nominated for all the awards.
The story will leave you curious, yearning for more, keeping you playing until you learn and get closure. It's a mystery, drama, sci-fi, psychological thriller.

Gameplay-wise it is definitely more than just a Amazon/Walking simulator. The goal of the game is to connect everyone together on this network to bring humanity back to some form of normalcy and work together to keep going, keep on living, keep on keeping on.

It's fun, fair, and sometimes brutal. The feature of having other players buildings being in the world can be both a boon and a burden. Example being bridges made in the middle of nowhere to generators being there to power up vehicles or timefall shelters in areas of heavy timefall.

I highly recommend this game and I can't wait for Hideo Kojima's next one.

Death Stranding is, at its core, a walking simulator. Theres no getting around that. But Kojima managed to find a way to make walking a fun, challenging, and dare I say even deep, gameplay mechanic. Theres nothing else quite like it, and the world and story surrounding all that walking will keep you making trek after trek from one end of the earth to the other. Not to mention just how much their is to do besides walking. In the middle of these long walking sessions, the game can turn into something else entirely at a moment's notice. Rain starts to fall? Its a horror game now. See a camp in the distance? If you choose to go there, or have to go there for an order, you're basically playing Metal Gear Solid 5 for a little while. Not to mention stuff like the racing mini game that the Director's Cut adds, which is surprisingly awesome despite the driving mechanics in the base game being somewhat basic. 

Of special note is the soundtrack, even more so now with the untimely death of Ryan Karazija (Low Roar). Ludvig Forssell's score is incredible, and I've never heard a soundtrack that has been able to convey a sense of something being "otherworldly" (in the paranormal sense) in such a perfect way. But Death Stranding would be far less than it is without Low Roar's contributions. Karazija's songs perfectly accent moments in the game, managing to turn what was once a mundane walk into an emotional and reflective moment. And not only are the songs fantastic in their own right, but their tonal and  thematic relevance to the rest of the story cannot be understated and is absolute perfection.

Death Stranding is one of the most unique games out there, and its 100% worth the asking price (especially if its on sale). Its not for everyone, but even if the term "walking simulator" turns you off (like it does me) I'd implore you to give it a try. You'll be surprised.

Being a Kojima game, it has a lot in common with the Metal Gear games. If you liked Metal Gear, you will like Death Stranding.
- The mechanics/movement feel very real and are extremely well made.
- You have your base(s) for which you have to gather materials and you develop your own gear and upgrades.
- The loadout menu basically works the same just with different gear.
- It focuses a lot on stealth, but you can also engage in combat if you want. (Contrary to Metal Gear, you rely on non-lethal combat).
- ...

Instead of listing more similarities, I just wanna say this: The game is exceptionally well made. It takes all the good things from another of Kojima's gems, adds a bunch of cool new mechanics and makes it an exciting experience. The characters, as always, are a labour of love. You will love or hate them, feel for them and engage with the story as you follow Sam on his journey to connect the people (don't worry I will not spoiler). The story itself and all of its mysteries really draw you in and the atmosphere (soundtrack, visual art & graphics, pace, dialogues and bits of info you can find scattered around the world, and and and) make it an immersive experience. 

It's a solid 9/10 and I wholeheartedly recommend it!
Overall just a wonderful game :3

Well, first of all, please don't look with distrust at this review, based on 6 hours of gameplay. I have watched complete gameplay on Tube 2 times, so I know what it is about. Also I played 60 hours of not much legal copy, then I felt I must buy it, it really deserves it. Actually I wanted to play with other people, even they are invisible hahaha...
   It is a second Kojima move at me after MGSV TPP. And both times I see he keeps his style - phantasmagoric, horror, surrealism elements, which I do not like; I prefer something more real or Sci-Fi instead. But we have what we have.
   A delivery simulator as it is called sometimes, an Eurotruck 2 but without trucks. Hmmm, yeah, it has something you know? Here are my tools and my goal, how do I reach it - my problem. There are few ways how to solve problems - deliver the goods: you can first dispatch enemies (if there are any in way), then collect the goods and deliver; or you may get the fast bike and rush through enemy territory; or you can go around it on foot, dragging levitating carriages with goods and so on... it all depends on your imagination.
   Second thing of Kojima is his game engines. Can't say I got ultra PC, but it is neither a rusty bucket. But as MGSV, and Death stranding are those of few most visually pleasing games, also it runs without freezes, lags or other stutterings.
Kojima for me now is becoming a sign of quality.
   Asynchronous multiplayer or what it is called. While someone says, play it offline, and feel the grind yourself, I disagree. You do not meet other players, but you see the signs of their presence - ladder here, bridge there, sometimes placed very well, you are ready to give tonn of likes for it.
   40 euro for this is undervalue. Compared with 60 euro tag of Cyberpunk, which hardly can reach 30 FPS on my machine, this feels unfair. Should be vice versa at least.

So, yeah... game's well done, graphics nice, sound nice, physics nice (there are physics, weight of load, elements of terrain, which impacts your traveling, etc), story not my kinda cuppa, but I'm trying, after 2 times of watching, 3rd time playing myself, I think (!) I start to understand it a little. :D

Thanks for reading..

Death Stranding is something strange, but very beautiful. In many ways. When I first bought the game, my PC didn't have decent specs to run it smoothly, but when I got some new parts, I was very eager to try again and fully immerse myself in it.
This game is amazing. I love games that have a ton of progression elements, and this game has it. No microtransactions, no PTW, nothing. Just you… and your deliveries.

I spent around 80 hours on the standard game and now it's time to immerse myself again on the Director's Cut

The game starts relatively slow. You don’t really know what to do, where to go, how to avoid/kill BTs and Mules/Terrorists, how to repair cargo, what do the structures do, where to build them, etc. But once you start getting the hang of things, you feel like you belong in that world, you are Sam. You know what you must do and the best way to do it. I rarely feel this in games. I get some sort of high playing this. I want to get all the achievements, I want to help all the NPCs out there, I want to help other players too! I’ve basically made all the roads on the second map, made a very nice Zip Line path going through all the most difficult places: Mountaineer, Spiritualist, Evo-devo, Geologist and all the others around the mountains. Made Timefall shelters, generators… I simply loved the idea that by helping myself in the game, I was helping other people too!
Another plus is that I am a person that usually doesn’t like to grind. I love Elite Dangerous, but I stop playing from time to time because the grind starts to get a bit boring. But the grinding in Death Stranding was the opposite. I was always very curious to see what item or color I would unlock by reaching a new star level with that settlement. It’s amazing!

But there are some things that I don’t like in it:
The vehicles are awesome and the game changes a lot once you get them. But the truck is basically the only one that I use. And sometimes it can be VERY irritating. Sometimes it feels like it’s made of styrofoam and gravity means nothing to it and the 1 ton of cargo on the back.
Minor spoiler ahead, but it was something that I didn’t enjoy so much:
[spoiler]I didn’t like the 3 segments with Cliff. the shooter ones. I understand the meaning of them to the story and the development of the characters, both Sam and Cliff. But those parts broke a bit of the immersion for me. I like shooter games, but inside a game like Death Stranding was a bit off, IMHO.[/spoiler]

The voice acting and motion capture is amazing in this game. But when the character Mama, played by Margaret Qualley, explains some story about her, her facial expressions were very dumb and funny. It almost felt like something out of Mass Effect Andromeda. But it was tolerable considering the rest of the animations.

The Director's Cut is amazing so far. Many new items, vehicles, missions, activities... And the graphical boost is very noticeable. Plus, vehicle handling is much better now!! Basically everything that was already good on the standard version got WAY better now. it's a must buy!

TL;DR

Death Stranding is different, starts slow and can get very confusing with a lot of information and controls (after all, it is a Hideo Kojima game), but if you like the feeling of progression and unlocking items and benefits in game, nice story, a LOT of well made cut-scenes, try it out.

I didn’t say everything I wanted here. I have a lot of feelings for this game, and this review would be bigger than it already is.

[quote] I've heard Death Stranding being called a lot of things: A walking sim, an Amazon delivery man sim, etc. And it is exactly those, but also so much more. Death Stranding is a fun game but not fun in a conventional way. The community aspect of the game is what makes it so fun. Getting helped by a random player's ladder or rope, seeing someone using a road I rebuilt; such things are what makes this seemingly boring game fun. The gameplay emphasises the story's moral; a community coming together to overcome hardship. It's definitely not a game for everyone but it's also not just a "walking sim".

It does have its downsides too. The redundant menus are one. Navigating the menus just to get a mission or complete one really kills the flow of the game. And the dialogue is very exposition heavy and is dragged out a bit too much.

Overall, this game isn't a masterpiece by any means but still is a great game and I thoroughly enjoyed it.[/quote]

This is what I wrote for the old Death Stranding edition and it holds true for the director's cut as well. And the director's cut comes with a bunch of new tools that are very helpful. But on the other hand, they removed the Monster Energy drinks. So it's hard to say whether this is a net positive upgrade lol.

TL;DR - A fun open-world game about delivering cargo, memories, life, and about understanding (Starring Norman Reedus). 10/10 Game changed my life.

There is something about Death Stranding that always has me coming back to it. Calling it a walking simulator (while not wrong) wouldn't be doing it justice. Death Stranding has a certain atmosphere that just can't be seen in any other game. The environment as you traverse the country grows more diverse and provides new challenges for you to overcome as you deliver these packages. tortuous mountain terrains, winding rivers, steep forests hills, knee-deep snow tops, and even the ruins of a destroyed city. Death Stranding has plenty of large and expansive locations for you to travel through while you carry pounds and pounds of cargo. 

The packages themselves are interesting as they range from medication, food, weapons, metal or ceramic, to expensive figurines, a loved one's last message, a human person, or even just a plain old pizza. I once found myself delivering a woman to her husband after believing he was dead, only for her to go back home after a lover's quarrel, and then go back again after they had made up. Another time I was entrusted with delivering a machine that would allow a doctor to remotely help a pregnant woman deliver her baby, the procedure was a success and the husband and wife decided to name the baby after Sam (the main protagonist).

The story isn't too complicated and is relatively straightforward from beginning to end. I'm the type of person to love complex stories but screw myself over with my horrible attention span and lack of brains in general. Luckily I didn't have to worry about that in Death Stranding since when something is explained, they explain it once more in simpler terms for Sam since he is usually just as confused as I am. Some might see the story as bland, boring, or just downright bad, but I see the story as one that is up to interpretation. Even if you choose to see the story as it is, it's perfectly and beautifully simple but gripping. Throughout the entire story keeps you wondering "What's going to happen next?" or "What does this mean?". The entire game will have you in tears of both sadness and happiness.

The gameplay is simple but challenging regardless. In the beginning, you have to deal with not dying/ruining cargo through slopes, drops, rivers, bandits, BTs, and rain. As you progress through the game, each obstacle changes so that the tactics and precautions you made before, while still somewhat valid, will have to be revised. A good example would be bandits. Sure you can just avoid their routes or sneak through them, but later in the game, the bandits gain vehicles, more sensors, and eventually try to kill you instead of stealing your cargo. The same goes with everything else, you become less prone to slips and falls but more difficult terrain is introduced, you learn more about BTs only to find more types of BTs. Though I must say your experience might vary from mine, as I played on Hard difficulty, mama didn't raise no chicken.

Finally, my favorite part of the game: the Music. The entirety of Death Stranding is filled to the brim with unique, colorful, and moving music that plays during many deliveries. I can say with full certainty that the game would be nowhere as good without its soundtrack. Most of its soundtrack comes from albums by Low Roar, which Kojima expertly used to further express the emotions seen and felt during the story. Whether I was delivering the body of a loved one, resources to help grow food for a city, or helping out another player by picking up their lost cargo, I had Low Roar accompanying me as I traveled to my destination. I loved the soundtrack so much that I found myself making a playlist and playing it whenever I was delivering packages. Without the Low Roar, the game would have felt a lot emptier. (Rest In Peace Ryan Karazija).

While I know there are many things in this review I've missed, I think it would be better if you found out yourself. Like good music? Play Death Stranding. Like a beautiful story? Play Death Stranding. Like a gorgeous environment filled with mystery? Play Death Stranding. Love Norman Reedus? Play Death Stranding. Like walking? Play Death Stranding. And if you don't like any of these things, what are you doing with yourself? (lol) 

The only complaint I have is that the music shouldn't end as soon as you enter the delivery point.

I HATE BABIES. im the kind of guy who likes games that focus on realism in visuals while removing the pains of realism in the actual gameplay. Think: GTA, COD, Forza, etc. Realistic but by no means real at all. Im also not the kind of gamer who can ever really finish a game to 100% without getting bored. It take alot to keep me involved. To me, the Fallout series is the perfect mix of everything. Ive played a few Kojima games, but only really finished the first couple metal gear games on earlier gen consoles. That being said; WHAT THE HECK IS THIS? AM I CRYING? HOW LONG CAN I MAKE NORMAN REEDUS GO WITHOUT A SHOWER? AM I PEEING ON THE SCARIEST THINGS IVE EVER SEEN? WHAT DOES THIS BUTTON DO?

Play the game offline first. Get as far as you can with no help. Play the game on the hardest setting or else its much too easy. Dont spend too much time in the first map, Move on to central area as soon as you can, come back later to dominate. Learn to whistle or play the harmonica. Dont focus too much on any of the deliveries beyond heartman. Go for it. Finish the game by yourself offline. THEN GO BACK AND START OVER ONLINE. Have fun. This game will change who you are inside. If you are depressed, It will undepress you. This game will leave you begging for more.

It's easy to hop on the bandwagon for this game and proceeding to call it a walking simulator. However, I am not going to say it isn't, because that statement is correct. The thing that makes Death Stranding different though, is that it is the best walking simulator there has ever been.

Of course, the game is much more than that as well but I'll get to that shortly. This game's focus is walking from place to place to deliver packages, and reconnect the fractured society that the world has become. Now while this sounds boring when described this way, the game has many mechanics in between this that make it interesting. When I say that walking is the FOCUS, I mean it. It is the focus in how an FPS is focused on gunplay, or how a fighting game is focused on pulling off combos and blocking, the walking in this game is developed with a lot of care and nuance. 

All the cargo you carry is more weight added to you, so the more you carry the harder it is to walk. This is understandable, and as you play you will become stronger you can carry more. But, you can also place your cargo where you want on Sam (the player character, AKA Norman Reedus), which changes your center of gravity. Poorly placed cargo can be detrimental to your efforts as you may be leaning heavily to one side if stacked incorrectly. Additionally, you have to choose everything you take with you that is extra like weapons to protect yourself, materials to build additional structures, etc. So while it is a walking simulator, it is an involved walking simulator where you actually have a consequence for your poor planning. I also recommend playing with a controller so that you have finer movement of Sam as you will sometimes have to make fine adjustments to complete hard climbs.

I love this part of the game. Trying to see what may be up ahead and trying your best to plan out your journey. Of course it's not just the traversal that is difficult. Sometimes you may need to go through sections of MULEs, which are enemies out to steal your cargo and knock you out. Or optionally through BTs, which are (at their core), a powerful ghost-like entity that can kill you if you get detected by them. These two hazards introduce both gunplay and stealth sections to Death Stranding and keep it exciting and fresh enough to keep going... and the story of course.

Combat in this game for me is mixed. The difficulty of combat is much higher than that of the traversal part of the game at the same difficulty, making for weird jumps in how hard the game is in main-story sequences. While I recommend to play this game with a controller, I do recommend that when it comes to the combat you should swap to keyboard and mouse to gain that extra precision. Luckily the game switches instantly between the input devices which is a very welcome feature. 

The story of this game is long, and for some may not be engaging or interesting. I quite like the story myself, but I also think that a lot of value is gained through reading journal entries and mail you receive throughout. Be aware of that going in, since that is where a lot of the actual explanations are. 

I played this game on release on the PS4. I committed most of my free time to it, and got platinum after a little over a month. I decided to purchase it again on PC, and eventually get the Director's Cut upgrade resulting in this review. 

The Director's Cut adds a lot of new things to the game, such as races, a gun range (useful for weapon practice), additional main missions, and a lot of little quality of life improvements. For starters, two new items were added (won't spoil) that help out the start of the game allowing the pace to be a bit faster so that you can get to the main game quicker. It also makes it a little less painful for new players. There's also some new side missions that gain you some extra goodies for completing them. As a player replaying this game, I felt I was gaining value out of it by getting a new side order to take on every once and awhile. They're simple but interesting nonetheless. New structures also keep the game feeling fresh while also providing some new ways of dealing with orders that help expand the game into more types of playstyles.

Now some cons of this version. The main missions that are used to sell this version of the game are nothing spectacular. While they are cool to see and open up some new types of environments to interact with, the whole area is rather small and lacking for what I was hoping for. It may be due to starting a 2nd playthrough that caused this, but I was disappointed to find that out of the three missions that this new side area has, two are available right at the start of the game... while the other requires the game to be beaten before accessing it. It was still interesting and a nice addition, but it was not worth the amount of time between missions. As a returning player you can transfer your save file, so if that applies to you I would recommend doing that if you are not interested in a 2nd run.

MULE areas in the launch version of DS were dangerous but not that dangerous. Mainly they were there to make it harder to traverse through areas and make it hard to deliver ALL of you cargo. As the game goes on things do eventually change to make them different, but I won't delve much into that. However in DS:DC, the MULE camps gain a few machine gun turrets after your first visit to them to make it harder to steal their materials. While I understand this decision, these turrets are very annoying. They can shoot you from a very long distance, damages you significantly and are very difficult to take out. Due to this I ended up despising going into any MULE areas when not required. Stealth is an option still, but if you get spotted you now have way more fire power against you, and MULEs instantly gravitate to them. To add on top of that, they also get a nice shield to protect them as well making it even HARDER to deal with. 

Anyways, there is a LOT to talk about with this game. If you haven't played it before, definitely give it a try. ESPECIALLY this version as even with it's cons, it adds a lot of new additions to the game that help it become a bigger and better game. Just remember that it isn't your typical game. It is a game where you take your time, and focus on getting the job done... not slaughtering all your enemies. Let it run it's course and let every moment sink in. It is a unique experience and it should be treated as such. It's not for everyone, but you'll never know if it's for you unless you give it a chance. 

This is one of my favourite games and I hope it can be yours too.

It is just incredible how much effort Kojima put into this game, even knowing that it wouldn't please all the tastes. The narrative, graphics, soundtrack, each aspect completes the other. The Melancholic songs matches perfectly with the story, that is all the time surrounded by this theme about death and extinction of humanity. 

The game also has this super cool feature where a person can place tools throughout the map, that not only helps him with certain problems but also can help other players out with this same problem. You can also send these tools, supplies, cargos to other players so they can make use of it or deliver for you, in case you have failed on delivering it. This system basically creates a large bond within the community.

This game has a lot of content. In the beginning it feels like a slow climb but once you get halfway there, you become one with the journey and your options are limitless. I never would've thought I'd enjoy being a mail man so much, such a calming yet action based game.

Let's be honest, we all know why I am writing this review - The Steam Awards, but I have to say that never before in my 40 years of gaming have I had so much fun sprinting from one side of America to the other while attempting to keep pizza and champagne undamaged knowing that the person I was delivering them to would have some excuse for not being there when I arrive...

While DEATH STRANDING has been a very controversial game, I personally really enjoyed the experienced. Don't let my hours fool you, I have 110 hours on the base game, and a further 17 on the Directors cut (as of writing this review).

This game creates an atmosphere unlike any other, with the environment design, ambience, and general feel. The sound design is magnificent, and you really do become immersed in this foreign world.

The thing I most love about this game is the storytelling, you're thrown into this 'uncanny' world, where it looks, and feels, like ours, but is not really anything like ours. We have the people, and the nature to keep us grounded in reality, but so many things that are so foreign to us are just a part of daily life in this world. 

While it is easy to say 'oh, walking sim, why would I want to play that', I would have to disagree. 
Yes, the gameplay is monotonous, but it has enough variety to keep you in the world. Seeing the sights, coming across other players' constructions, shouting into the void and hearing a response, all evokes an emotion of 'I'm alone, but I'm not alone'. At the very least, the gameplay does keep you entertained while you think, either about the story, or just something completely off-topic, and I think that is kind of the point. 

I've seen a lot of criticism of the storytelling, and how confusing or disorganised it is. While yes, it is confusing at first, you do slowly become more and more aware of the world surrounding you, and are able to actually understand what is going on. I think the best way to experience it is not to look anything up, but just keep playing. A lot of things are left ambiguous early on, on purpose.

Overall, if you want to really enjoy this game be prepared to sink some time in, and enjoy the stunning visuals, and this foreign world.

Death Stranding is perhaps one of the past decade's most unique and innovative yet divisive games.
Some people will love this game, some will despise it. Kojima has no doubt created an unforgettable experience.

Death Stranding is literally a walking simulator, the main gameplay loop is travelling from point A to B in the most efficient manner while sidestepping human enemies and the ghostly BTs. Coupled with the innovative only features that let the actions of other players affect the game's world, Death Stranding has made the simple act of walking and delivering packages an enjoyable and engaging experience.

Not to mention the grand narrative that goes along with the game (which I won't spoil) as well as the beautiful and serene visuals and amazing soundtrack from various artists around the world. Death Stranding is an unforgettable experience IF it is for you.

It's been long enough since I played Death Stranding that I forgot what the differences are between this and the normal version. It's a great game, maybe a little less amazing on the second playthrough. It's got all the long winded cutscenes and bizarre characters you'd expect from a Kojima game but with stellar acting. It's hard to break it down into pieces as the whole thing sort of comes together and works.

Don't know what to say about this game, the optimization is awful in Director's Cut, and the story is something you need to get used to, but the overall experience was worth it for me. I enjoyed it a lot, and maybe sometime later I'll give it more of my time to get all the achievements left.

When Konami got rid of Kojima and tanked the Metal Gear franchise, it seemed like a great loss for videogames. However, having now played the first KojiPro game, I feel like it was worth it. Kojima is now fully unchained to make whatever weird nonsense he wants and I love it. No more focus testing, business suits telling him to tick boxes off the "AAA Videogame checklist" and Kojima choosing to give zero fornications about what anybody else thinks a videogame is supposed to be. Looking forward to Overdose, whatever that ends up being.

Death Stranding is a game that I was quite hesitant about. However, after finally trying it out, I can gladly say that Kojima made another excellent game. From the complex and interesting story to the addicting gameplay, Death Stranding always managed to keep my attention, even if slightly overstayed its welcome. Moreover, the pure creativity and unique elements of the story and gameplay make Death Stranding unlike any other game on the market. Now, even though I had an amazing time with this game, it's definitely not for everyone. After all, this is Hideo Kojima's vision without anyone to tell him no. Due to this, you can expect plenty of cutscenes, bizarre ideas, and a confusing story. Personally, while I love these features and think they're some of the best aspects of the game, I can completely see why some people might not like this game. Overall, though, if you enjoyed Kojima's previous works, then I highly recommend giving Death Stranding a chance.

A Hideo Kojima game
Another Masterpiece of the Master of Video Games Hideo Kojima.

[h1]Game-Review: Death Stranding: A great and unique experience, but not for everyone![/h1]

This review is divided into two sections:
[olist]
[*] A Review of the game
[*] An Upgrade-Guide: Should you upgrade if you already own the original game?
[/olist][/i]
[h1]1. Game Review[/h1]
[i][If you are too lazy to read all of my thoughts: TLDR at the bottom][/i]

[b][u]The world, story and characters[/u][/b]

The beautiful post-apocalyptic world of Death Stranding, based on photogrammetry-assets captured in Iceland, invites you to explore. The theme of “Connecting and feeling connected” is at the center of Death Strandings story about loneliness, family, loss and hope. The game manages to hold a healthy balance between “serious”, “deeply philosophical”, “funny” and “emotional”, that worked out for me very well! If you can’t stand overexposure, some cheesy puns here and there and lengthy cutscenes (basically the Kojima-way of storytelling), then you might feel turned off by the game’s narrative at first.  The well written characters, with their deeply emotional backstories have grown to my heart after a while and I always wanted to know what’s next! Also, the cast (full of Kojimas friends and people you might know) does a great job at delivering the story through their motioncapture performances and dialogue deliveries! The cinematography of the cutscenes is also one of the best in the industry!

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2647400508

The story is one I still think about long after having finished the game and that’s quite a rare thing! The soundtrack and licensed music selection is also amazing and fit the atmosphere at any given moment! Seriously, there are quite some bangers in here! 

[b][u]The gameplay: Can traversal as a core gameplay mechanic be fun? (Yes!!)[/u][/b]
Death Stranding is a unique game. You might have watched some gameplay on “YouTube” and thought “Well that’s just a walking mailman! Boring!”. These thoughts are based on your mental model on how this “walking” feels in other games where you just press “W” / “LS forward” to traverse any terrain with ease. Death Stranding takes the element of traversal and makes that the one of the core elements of the game: Being aware of how terrain around you, planning smart routes and using the right equipment to traverse the roughest areas of the game get quite addicting after a while. You got to keep your balance, use the tools that you can craft, like ladders, climbing ropes and more. Getting over every hill, mountain and river feels like an achievement!

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2640126860

Delivering is what you do in Death Stranding (and the only thing you for for 99% of the time)! If you expect a fast-paced action game, this is not the right game for you! There is some combat against the mules and the B.T.s, which is quite fun. Especially the Bola gun is enjoyable to use! You can also avoid most encounters with B.T.s (the black slime-thingies) by using the radar that is powered by your B.B. (that baby in the orange-juice glass).

The game takes its time to suck you into its world. Playing Death Stranding is more like an experience, than playing just a game: It feels therapeutic, meditative… Finishing each delivery is satisfying! That’s only the case, if you know that this is a [u]slow-paced[/u] game, that many people might classify as “tedious” for focusing on the traversal aspect! 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2787422892

[b][u]Feeling connected with other players[/u][/b]

The asynchronous multiplayer-elements are what makes the game very special in my eyes: While working on your deliveries and exploring the world, you gain the trust of certain people, which unlocks the ability to build structures in the area around the properties of these people to make your routes through the landscape easier. Basically, you connect knot after knot. Connecting the different knots, unlocks the ability to see the structures of other players like Ziplines, bridges or shelters and use them to your advantage and help others by upgrading them.

You can also see some of the routes others took, use the vehicles someone left, upgrade and repair structures or place signs that inform other players about upcoming dangers, restore stamina or mark enemy territories. You can also upvote all the things other people build, which gives them a notification. Kojima described the goal of the game as followed: [quote=Hideo Kojima]"After spending dozens of hours in the game you will come back to reality in the end. When you do, I want you to use what you learned in the game. Connecting is one of those things." ([url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kjUpYlKs0nM] Death Stranding: Inside Kojima Productions | Newsbeat Documentaries - YouTube [/url]) [/quote]The theme of “connection” plays a major role during gameplay and it feels so rewarding receiving all the positive feedback from all the players, so Kojima definitely hit the tooth with the drill there and made me feel less lonely for the time while playing the game!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2650966924

All in all, I played Death Stranding for over 100h and completed all the achievements and do not regret it at all. The unique and deep story, the beautiful world and the innovative gameplay made it really special in my eyes! Death Stranding was a great escape from reality and sucked me into its world with ease!
Keep on Keeping on!

[b][u]Summary (TLDR)[/u][/b]

[quote=TLDR]
[list]
[*]A must-buy, if you are into slow-paced games! 
[*] If you expect a combat focused, fast-paced game, do not buy the game! This is not for you!
[*]Beautiful world  & soundtrack
[*] Playing the game is a therapeutic, meditative experience
[*]Well directed and deeply philosophical story with a great cast of characters
[*]Death Stranding reinvents the traversal gameplay 
[*]Asynchronous multiplayer-elements help to convey theme of “connection”
[/list]
[/quote]


[h1]2. Upgrade Guide[/h1]

[quote]
The driectors cut adds some new helpful tools, vehicles and customization options, a few missions and other QoL-improvements giving you more ways to complete orders.
There is also a quite frustrating car-race-mode which seems a bit out of place, but it adds some nice new music-pieces!

Recommendations:
[olist]
[*][b]"I am half way through the original game."[/b] → Be cautious! The save transfer will mess up your existing Zipline-Network´: The structures from other players in your world do not transfer and some of your structures don't transfer aswell, 
when the geometry of the landscape changed. It could be quite frustrating to rebuild some parts of your network!
[*][b]"I own the original game, but didn't start or play a lot yet (not over Chapter 7 yet)"[/b] → The upgrade would enhance your existing experience. That's the case where the upgrade adds the most value!
[*][b]"I already finished the original game once and plan to replay it"[/b] → Same case as the one above!
[*][b]"I already finished the original game once and don't plan to replay it" [/b]→ Only worth it if you are an achievement hunter! All achievements transfer, just not the ones that require to craft the new stuff!
[/olist]
[/quote]

I may update the review as I get further into the game, but so far these are my feelings about it.

Overall, Death Stranding is a very solid game, it has a few flaws here and there but it holds up fairly well in my experience so far. It certainly isn't a game for everyone, and I wouldn't recommend it to everyone just like I wouldn't recommend an FPS to someone who only plays MMOs and JRPGs. Realistically, this probably isn't the game for you if you want fast-paced or exciting action. It has its moments, but for the most part that's just not what Death Stranding is about. However if you're the kind of person who can enjoy a game by getting immersed in its story, lore/world-building, and interpersonal interactions, then Death Stranding may very well be something you'll enjoy as I believe Kojima really knocked it out of the park on all fronts there. The game also does a really good job at building up the idea that we help each other, as things that you leave behind can be used by other players to help them, and vice-versa. It fits the world and narrative very well, and really contributes to my enjoyment of the game.

As for shortcomings, I just have a couple really. For one, the map could be a bit more expansive, roads can quickly become the quickest and easiest way to get from point A to point B, and driving a vehicle on a road takes away from the charm of the game and its primary gameplay aspects, being charting new paths through rough terrain or finding paths others have taken and using the gear they left behind. This ties into my second complaint, being that there are too many road pavers. At one point there are *four* within 500m of each other and it's a bit ridiculous. There should have been fewer pavers that just costed more to make it a bit less tedious. Finally, the threats in the game like MULEs and BTs being a bit more dynamic rather than staying in their relatively static areas would've been nice. This only further contributes to the issues with the roads as they quickly become the safest way to get from A to B as well. None of these issues are really that problematic for me, but I do think doing things a bit differently would've made the game more enjoyable.

All the reviews I read about this game said that when I get to the end my mind will be blown.  That may very well be true!  But it's such a mediocre game that I probably won't get to the game.  

First let's start with the minor annoyances.  SO MANY wasted seconds!  Every time I deposit something there's a 3 second cut scene "Thank you for bla bla".  Every time the protagonist showers there are 4 (FOUR) cutscenes of him showering.  In a row.  I just have to hit "skip" 4 times.  Most times the protagonist interacts with a terminal he does 1 thing then the terminal kicks him out.  Then there's ANOTHER 3 second scene where he logs in again.  Any time the protagonist interacts with a terminal he has to do like 6 things, so we have to watch this cutscene 6 times.  Why not just keep us in the terminal to do all the things?  

These minor annoyances add up, but they're all in service to something greater right?  That's usually the plot, though in some games it can be character development or exploring the world or other things.  In this game it's all for nothing.  The plot is basically nonexistent: "Get package from here, deliver to there."  

The highest praise that can be lavished on this game is "beautiful walking simulator."  It's true, it is beautiful.  Unfortunately the landscape is all the same so we've seen pretty much all the beauty in the first 20 minutes.  

I strongly recommend everyone play this game for about 20 minutes, then return it.  That's it.  You've seen the whole game.  It's beautiful to look at for 20 minutes, then you're done.  I've put over 40 hours into this game and I assure you, you won't miss anything by doing it that way.

Death Stranding Review

My heart has been aching for a game like this for a long time; in a way, it's like a return to the 1997 PlayStation One game Metal Gear Solid, another Hideo Kojima masterpiece. There's a lot of lore in the form of in-game interviews to absorb as well as social and psychological concepts to wrap your mind around during gameplay. Hideo Kojima is an absolute master at making a story that just draws the player in and makes them really think and explore concepts they may have never even considered. like, for example, trading and its importance. Trade is what really makes the world go around (as everyone learned during the pandemic), and without it, the country would come to a complete standstill.

The concept trading might seem like something that is obvious to any normal person, but it's not something most people even think about during their normal everyday lives. The regular person just takes it for granted and keeps on moving unless, of course, something goes wrong. So when the player is forced to play as the truck driver and get packages to places on time and in good condition, it makes them really consider the challenges those people face during the course of their daily work routines. Hideo Kojima accomplishes this by increasing the player's investment in their role by making them the truck driver within the larger overall story arc and in the story as a whole. 

Consider another gaming concept or type: the looter shooter. Most of these games now allow players to kill NPCs and other players with little to no repercussions, even rewarding them with kill streaks and bonus skills or points. That's not this game at all and killing people in this game is frowned upon and is not something the player is rewarded for, like in most of Hideo Kojima's games. He doesn't reward you for taking the easy route and just killing people. It should always be the last option, and if the player does kill someone, I don't want to spoil too much, so let's just say that killing enemies will cause more problems than it will ever solve. I, personally, love games that make the player think outside the box like this, and it makes the experience so much more fulfilling than just trying to get a high kill streak. Don't get me wrong, those games are fun too, but they can't hold a candle to a game that really makes the player engage in the game play and story.

The main complaint I've seen on internet forums and in Steam reviews about this game is that it's just a walking simulator. Gamers these days are just too used to instant gratification, which is the concept of receiving an immediate reward for a specific task that is supposed to take some time. If you are the kind of person who cannot wait 10–30 minutes or even "3 minutes," as you are required to do once in the game, then this just isn't for you. However, if you enjoy figuring out complex, deep-lore-based stories while also taking breaks between them to deliver packages and unite the fractured people of America, there are also interesting boss fights that will be thrown into the mix too. Then this game is for you. 

The package delivery part of the game is not boring either; it's really a challenge to deliver the packages across the various landscapes that are filled with BTs (beached things), mules, terrorists, and pockets of time-fall storms. These can tax the player greatly, and just when you think you've got it figured out, WHAM! Hideo Kojima layers another roadblock or concept to add to the game play to make it more challenging.

I'll put it another way: if you played Metal Gear Solid, like I did in the late 90s and early 2000s, and enjoyed the chats with the NPCs over the codec as much as the game play itself, you'll love this game.

This game is an exceptional experience like no other, but it's certainly not for everyone. This "walking simulator" controversy about the game mechanics is understandable but it is also a way to transmit the solitude and beauty the game wants you to feel. While the story can be quite confusing if you don't spend enough time reading the emails, interviews, and exploring the world, I find it to be, along with the OST, the best part of the game.

Things that are improvable: the combat and vehicle physics. Even if the game is not focused on fighting, they can become quite tedious and irritating.

For those looking for a moving, emotional experience, with exceptional music, story and character development, I recommend this game.

Death Stranding is a video game where the gameplay is stripped down to it purest, most basic form. The entire game is about going from point A to point B while unlocking more and more equipment & methods to either make your life easier, or more fun.

Kojima literally looked at every single open world game and decided to parody it. Seriously, take a good hard look at the core gameplay loop of Death Stranding and compare it to any other game on the market.

Anyway, You start off as a delivery boy carrying an ethernet cable to an friendly outpost. A few deliveries later and, you're a maniac on a Bike/Truck filled to the brim with weapons, blood, human excreta & a lot of random packages that you've developed an unhealthy obsession with. 

I really did enjoy it. I don't know why, and I definitely got frustrated at times, but I look back and don't regret attempting to drop kick an entire terrorist cell into submission.

I succeeded, btw, and relieved myself on their bed. They deserved it.

As someone who played the original quite extensively on the PS4, this is without a doubt the definitive edition to get.
It may not be everyone's cup of tea as it generally involves a lot of walking around large open areas for a fair amount of time, at least in the beginning before you start to unlock vehicles, but there's just something so immensely satisfying about fulfilling several deliveries at once to a prepper or a distro center as well as being able to in-directly help other players with various structures and objects you can place out in the world.
I really love the world building too, especially with how many of the characters Sam meets manage to retain a hopeful spirit despite the world having gone through a massive apocalyptic event and how they, along with other players leaving signs, cheer you on to not give up in your journey to reconnect the world.
Seriously, give the game a go if you want to experience something different and have enjoyed Kojima's previous projects.

Goods:
-Online structure/cargo/gear sharing is a cool feature
-Various ways to handle each delivery mission
-Dynamic world encounters/weathers
-The supernatural stuffs are great 
-Various easter eggs
-Solid combat but nothing special

Bads:
-Slow paced story. The game being open world kinda messes up the narrative flow.
-Characters aren't as memorable as MGS characters. I honestly feel only [spoiler]Unger's[/spoiler] character is the most fleshed out in the entire game 
-Vehicle controls feels kinda weird in certain situations
-Lack of enemy and boss variety 
-UI is kinda messy, especially in inventory/cargo page

Overall a great game, but it certainly lacks the charm that MGS had. I think having the characters mimicking real life actors kinda limits the interaction creativity that previous Kojima games had.
