Ignore anyone who calls this "walking simulator." There is a lot more than that to this game if you give it a chance. You start without much, but eventually build up to roads and vehicles and all sorts of tools. The landscapes are gorgeous and the graphics are really a sight to stop for a second and behold, or just take it all in as you cruise around in a vehicle. Combat is not far removed from Metal Gear's and the number of weapons and tools available for combat makes for fun and creative knockouts. I felt a real sense of accomplishment when I completed my first road loop that covers the map.

Director's Cut: I enjoy the new unarmed combat like the tackle and dropkick. Couple that with the rope and unarmed combat has become more versatile. 

My only real gripe is the driving mechanic for the truck is awful.  I preferred to depend on the truck because of the cargo capacity, so I just had to deal with it. Oh well.

This game was working beautifully until the recent update wrecked the proformance and compatability of this game, with no indication that it'll ever be fixed.
Even after I completed the story, it is still confusing me. Good.

This is the most Kojima game that has ever Kojima'd. It's bizarre in so many ways, contrary to the way most AAA titles operate, deeply weird, and wildly engrossing all at once. 

The heart of most open-world games is the going from one point to another delivering various things, sometimes picking them up from other enemies, sometimes getting them from quest givers, and Kojima has stripped away all pretense by just making the character a literal Instacart driver. The challenge of the game sometimes is just staying upright while walking with a million pounds on your back, but as you find more things and upgrade your kit you get to feel the joy of freer movement and bypassing things that you once had to struggle through. 

The story is buckwild. I won't spoil anything as it should be experienced. Buckle up for some anime af set pieces.

I will say this is probably not a game for everyone. It appeals to my ADHD riddled brain in many ways and as a fan of Kojima's other works, but I can see a lot of people not liking it.
best of the stranding type games

The game is 10/10 for me, there are some flaws like side missions, possibly UI design,
but i can get over all that. The issue that lies is that this version of the game runs noticeably worse than the original version for whatever reason.

I'm running an R5 3600, 16GB @3600 & a 3060.
Pulling out ladders randomly locks the framerate at 45,
and scanning with the Odradek drops the framerate to 50.
Apparently this is specifically an issue with Nvidia cards, but I'm not sure how accurate that is.
I tested this on my friend's rig as well, same exact issue on a 1660,
we both even lowered the graphics to minimum.
Per the recommended specs, we're both above them.

On top of all that, this port has VERY poor anisotropic filtering,
despite what Digital Foundry have said. This can be alleviated by forcing it
via GPU control panel. It looks a lot better better.
This game also exhibits lots of shimmering, and i wasn't very impressed with DLSS.
Intel however? GREAT job with the new XESS technology, it alleviates a lot of issues
i previously had with the PC visuals as far as aliasing & shimmering goes.

Despite all this, i can absolutely get over it & enjoy the game & additional content from the PS5 version at a locked 30, no problem, but that doesn't mean i should have to put up with it.
If you have a PS5, don't bother with the purchase.

Narratively and visually striking. Glad I made the purchase on this. The only thing I would warn people about is that some of the in game mechanics are pretty bad. Specifically the driving. 

Often you'll find that the truck, once you get it, will decide to turn on its own in a random direction when going uphill, will get stuck on terrain, or will sometimes just drive in a direction of its own accord. I literally had points where I'd remove my hands from the keyboard to discover exactly where the truck was trying to go but sadly it seemed focused on walls or large rocks rather than anything of interest. 

This, however, doesn't ruin the game by any means - simply adds minor frustration to the process of getting from A to B. 

The music is fantastic. All the tracks fit the game perfectly. Again, a minor issue with this is that the tracks get interrupted by the game world which is a little disappointing. Many times a song from Low Roar will kick in only to be stopped less than a minute later by BT's.

Everyone knows it as 'The first Strand-Type game,' or 'just a walking simulator,' but it is so much more. Even as someone who doesn't read into lore too much and gets easily confused by complicated plot, I was compelled by the characters and sympathized with Mads Mikkelson's character as his story developed. Sure the cutscenes are lengthy and sometimes a little sluggish, they are rewarding after hours of playtime. And that's one of my favorite things, its the play style of the game that fits me perfectly. When I play a game, I don't always want a sweaty, swamp-ass-chair-staining experience that takes mental endurance and practice to be good at, this is a game to put some music too and let your mind go. That is one of the biggest turn offs to most people, but trust the process and stick with it, especially as the more tedious things like balance get replaced with cooler and more exciting gameplay mechanics. At the end of the day, I have played through this game 3 times and intend to come back for more play throughs since the world of Death Stranding is so wide and has expanded each time I come back to it, whether it was free DLC or just reading a lore log for fun while in a safe room.
At the end of the day, Death Stranding is not for everyone, but it does provide both relaxing and intense gameplay depending on what you the player wants. Each time I played I can the choice to take different paths than I had before to different equally satisfying results. I recommend this game to anyone that loves story driven games with compelling gameplay, or to anyone that loves The Last of Us and similar games.

Yes, it's a walking simulator, but that's not all it is. Death Stranding has so many amazing and unique gameplay mechanics. This game has trapped me in hours of endless gameplay. It is, most definitely, almost undeniably, one of the games, ever. 

You walk, you climb, you treat your packages like FedEx - throwing them at people, catapulting them over long distances, tripping on a tiny rock and making them tumble down a mountain.
If you ever wanted be on the other side of the package delivery industry and mistreat the cargo like a champion you are - this is the game for you.

I suppose the game also looks gorgeous and has a pretty good story. But yeah, buy it. Chug that 40kg box of concrete at whatever poor bastard decides to rob you.
Like nothing you've ever played before.
